The region was studied as part of the Inchiesta parlamentare sulle condizioni dei contadini nelle province meridionali e nella Sicilia initiated in 1906, and discussed in publications reaching a literate public. It was represented to the nation and the world at the International Exhibition mounted in Milan in 1906, and the Exhibition of Italian Ethnography organised in Rome in 1911 as part of the International Exposition celebrating the nation’s fiftieth anniversary. An important element of this attention was the portrayal of the region as being in dialogue with ‘l’immagine complessiva del paese’. 
Basilicata made a forceful entry into national politics in December 1901 when its problems were brought into sharp relief due to the calls to Rome for help.  Speaking to Parliament, Zanardelli emphasised that in Basilicata ‘there was an absolute absence of flourishing urban centers, of any manufacturing industry, of strong agricultural production, all of the things which created and maintain public and private prosperity’.  His tour was chronicled in the Italian and foreign press and was photographed.  These images include depictions of several communities along with posed and candid shots of their peasant inhabitants.  Some were published in the popular media including La Tribuna illustrata.  A few were reproduced on postcards by firms including Alterocca, and Fototipia Danesi in Rome and featured the Prime Minister in an ox cart. By emphasising the difficulties faced by Zanardelli in traversing the region, they highlighted its backward nature.
The Special Law of 1904 failed to produce many hoped-for results, and its implementation has often been negatively assessed. Yet it had positive effects in terms of infrastructure projects, financial incentives to development, and the renewal of Basilicata’s capital, Potenza.  For a brief period before the First World War, it also increased the region’s national visibility as prominent public figures – especially Francesco Saverio Nitti in his role as Minister of Agriculture, Industry, and Trade – turned their attention to Basilicata with ideas for solving its problems.
In the context of promised state-intervention, members of the local governing classes promoted their region and articulated a modernising vision of its productive capacity. Initiatives explored utilising oil reserves in the Agri Valley, employing the river to generate electric power, and improving agriculture.  This image of a region rich in natural resources and economic potential was presented to a national and international audience at the International Exhibition in Milan in 1906 as municipalities and entrepreneurs organised to highlight its agricultural and industrial achievements.  There are also examples of ‘un radicale rovesciamento di prospettiva’ among meridionalisti concerning Basilicata’s economic potential.  Describing it as a ‘scrigno di autentici tesori’ offering enormous opportunities, Francesco Perrone engaged in a ‘capovolgimento semantico’, challenging established images.  Luigi Fiorini advanced the idea of transforming Basilicata through a ‘rivoluzione agraria’ driven by science and new technologies.  Mario Buffa envisioned the modernisation of the territories through which the Agri River flowed and harnessing its waters for electricity serving agriculture, industry, and civil society. 
This vision reached a wider audience through the pages, for example, of Nuova Antologia in which Cesare Cagli, a civil servant in the Ministry of Public Works, published three articles in 1910.  Cagli provided a circumspect portrait acknowledging Basilicata’s problems but envisioning more productive farming and industry facilitated by better communication networks. The thirty-six photographs illustrating his text offer a favourable image. Panoramas of Potenza, Lagonegro, Melfi, and Rionero in Vulture could be of small cities anywhere in Italy. Posed photographs of peasants accompany candid images that are ethnographic in nature and picture peasant existence as similar to that in all regions. Photographs of construction undertaken to consolidate Acerenza, and of modern farmhouses, suggest a region productively engaged with modernising forces. A positive image of Basilicata was also presented by Giuseppe De Lorenzo in Venosa e la Regione di Vulture (La Terra D’Orazio) published in 1906. Its 121 photographs picture the landscape, Roman ruins, medieval castles, and cathedrals. Those of Venosa and Melfi depict them as developed urban centres. The images present a region rich in history, culture, art, and architecture which emphasised that Basilicata’s geography and history were particularly ‘compless[e] e interessant[i]’ in comparison to other areas of southern Italy. 
Photographs of Basilicata were also published by the Inchiesta parlamentare sulle condizioni dei contadini. A technical report treating Calabria and Basilicata, published in 1909, includes 282 images with 19 picturing the latter.  While recording the backward state of agriculture, they do not indulge in a clichéd emphasis on peasant misery nor a romanticisation of pastoral life. Instead, the photographs contributed to ethnological knowledge fostering a more accurate understanding of the socio-cultural dynamics of Basilicata.62 The report prepared the work of the parliamentary committee which published its findings in 1910.  This includes 143 photographs of Basilicata and Calabria, with 52 picturing the former. Most present the region as untouched by modernity but serve to ‘capovolgere una rappresentazione fortemente stereotipata – quella della povertà del Mezzogiorno – e a modellare una nuova – quella dell’ingente presenza di risorse naturali’.  
What appears an iconography of archaism is transmuted into one of economic potential. 
Contemporaneous with these modifications of Basilicata’s image, Calculli’s postcards depict its largest city as developed, well-appointed, and historically important. This portrayal had several precedents. Following its elevation to capital of Basilicata in 1663, Matera was ‘recorded in histories and chronicles as being a prosperous city with fine food and resources’.  In 1703, Giovanni Battista Pacichelli offered an admiring description in Il Regno di Napoli in prospettiva stating that the city boasted many palazzi and magnificent churches.  In the middle of the century, Giuseppe Antonini described it as home to many ‘distinguished’ and prosperous citizens.  Accounts from the nineteenth century often describe the ancient origin and eventful history of Matera.  This emphasis, and a focus on its notable families, is found especially in the work of local chroniclers. In his Note Storiche sulla Città di Matera e sulle sue Famiglie Nobili, Giuseppe Gattini described it as a centre of substantial commerce boasting good hotels; cafes; pharmacies; and shops selling books, maps, photographs, clothing, and foodstuffs. 
Calculli’s postcards were also preceded by pictorial representations. A schematised etching of Matera by Francesco Cassiano De Silva was included by Pacichelli in his work.  A copper engraving, influenced by De Silva’s image, was published about 1762 by Thomas Salmon.  Both offer panoramas that flatten the cityscape and employ formulas for the representation of its major structures. The intention, if not to accurately illustrate their subject, is to present an image befitting a provincial capital.
Calculli’s portraits present a city with historic and noteworthy architecture. Yet it was not only local chroniclers who wrote about and depicted Matera’s medieval churches.  The French art historian Émile Bertaux described and illustrated the cathedral and the church of San Giovanni in his study of the art of the Mezzogiorno of 1904.  Commentary in the popular Italian media, including La Domenica del Corriere and La Tribuna illustrata, also emphasised the historical and architectural significance of Matera.  In 1915, the Touring Club Italiano described it as ‘una interessantisima città di costruzione medioevale’.  Matera also attracted national and international attention because of the prehistoric finds made by Domenico Ridola whose work emphasised the archaeological importance of the area around the city.
Yet there were also many negative depictions of Matera in circulation. Living conditions in the Sassi were denounced by national deputies from Basilicata at the end of the nineteenth century and, following peasant protests in 1902, the Neapolitan newspaper, Il Pungolo, published a damning description. Upon reaching Matera, the author encountered a ‘quadro straziante e desolante’. In a city ‘bizzarramente costruita sui fianchi di una collina, senza quasi alcun contatto con la civiltà’, he found a population that he defined as ‘analfabeta e superstiziosa’ living in ‘case fetide, senza aria e senza luce, dove esseri umani, asini e maiali dormono in promiscuità orribile’. 
It was especially following Zanardelli’s visit to Matera that politicians ‘fixated’ on its ‘troglodyte lifestyle’.  Speaking in Potenza in September 1902, the Prime Minister described the city as follows: ‘5/6 della populazione abitano in tuguri scavati della roccia [. . .] in cui i contadini non vivono ma, a mo’ di vermi brulicano [. . .] nella promiscuità innominabile di uomini e bestie, respirando aure pestilenziali.’  In the report of the Inchiesta parlamentare sulle condizioni dei contadini, Francesco Saverio Nitti stated: ‘non abbiamo durante il nostro viaggio veduto spettacolo più orribile delle abitazioni dei contadini di Matera’. He described these as ‘veri covi trogloditici’ resembling the ‘abitazioni selvaggi di antichi progenitori’ and was surprised that ‘spetaccoli così orribili possano durare’.80
Saluti da Matera: Postcard Portraits
Of the postcards Calculli issued before 1920, some offer panoramas of the city that pictured, and occasionally foregrounded, Matera’s natural setting. One presents a view from the south photographed by V. Marsilio (Figure 1). Printed in black and white, it bears the caption Matera – Panorama da Mezzogiorno on the verso. The photograph pictures the Sasso Caveoso with the cathedral and Cività – the historical nucleus of the city constructed on the promontory rising between the valleys – visible in the background. This is a striking image of Matera perched on the precipice of La Gravina and emphasising the intimate relation between natural and built environment. A considerable amount of its composition is devoted to topography such that Matera seems the uppermost geological feature of the landscape. This reinforces the perception of a city and region characterised by little separation between nature and culture, its habitations uniquely adapted to its geography.
In keeping with panoramas of other communities in Basilicata, Calculli’s postcards do not simply document their subject. Their photographs are shot from scenic viewpoints to capture 
 
Figure 1. Matera – Panorama da Mezzogiorno. Giacinto Calculli. Author’s collection.
attractive vistas. Distance was required to achieve this. By this time, the Sassi had become a peasant ghetto and Matera appears on this card as a jumble of mostly vernacular, unsophisticated structures set into the tufa with no concern for rational planning. Yet given the photograph’s expansive field of vision, shot from an elevated viewpoint at a considerable distance from its subject, it does not provide sufficient detail to strike the viewer primarily with an impression of urban and social degradation. There is no indication of subterranean dwellings, and any sense of unhygienic congestion is negated by the expansive sky which contributes to a dramatic, picturesque vista composed of an intricate interplay of form, light, and shadow.
Implicitly and explicitly describing Matera as picturesque was not unusual at this time and can be traced at least to Pacichelli in the early eighteenth century. Writing in the Archivio per lo studio delle tradizioni popolari in 1898, Gaetano Amalfi described Matera as both ‘pittoresco e curioso’.  It was occasionally presented as picturesque in early-twentieth-century travel guides and, following its elevation to provincial capital in 1927, the city was regularly described in these terms. 
Another postcard bears the caption Panorama dal Castello (Figure 2). The never-completed castle was begun in 1501, on the bluffs at the western edge of Matera’s historic centre, by Count Giovanni Carlo Tramontano, who was granted the city as a feudal holding by King Ferdinand II of Naples. The photograph does not picture the castle but looks to the south-east and offers a partial view of the quarters constructed on the Piano. The Sassi are not evident and the city, at a distance from the viewer, is only partially visible in the expansive landscape that frames the background. Two men dressed in middle-class attire occupy either side of the foreground. One is holding a piece of paper or notebook and may be engaged in studying and even sketching the vista. His presence informs the viewer’s response to the image, the composition and subject of which imply a contemplative mode of looking for the sake of topographical knowledge and/or aesthetic pleasure.
Although the natural setting is pronounced, Matera appears not unlike other small urban centres in Italy: a rural municipality composed of regular, if unsophisticated, architectural structures 
 
Figure 2. Panorama dal Castello. Giacinto Calculli. Author’s collection.
arranged in an ordered urban plan. The exclusion of the Sassi and a focus on the Piano and Cività was a common way of picturing Matera on panoramic postcards before and after 1920. These commonly offer vistas from the south-west and, although not the case in this example, include a view of the cathedral rising above the skyline.
Calculli also offered particular views of the quarters of the city constructed on the Piano. These were home to Matera’s civic institutions; its most important ecclesiastical foundations; much of its commercial infrastructure; and the residential quarters of its upper and middle classes. One of these postcards bears the caption Matera – Largo Plebiscito and pictures the city’s largest public square (Figure 3). Created in the late nineteenth century by filling upper levels of the Sasso Barisano, it was rechristened Piazza Vittorio Veneto after the First World War. The formatting of the card suggests it was issued in 1905 or shortly thereafter. Calculli published at least one other before 1920 with an image of the Largo from the same vantage point.
Postcards commonly pictured public squares. The photograph published by Calculli looks north from the Largo della Fontana across the large open space of the Largo Plebiscito and into Via XX Settembre. The latter courses into the background and creates, along with the compositional structure of the entire image, a sense of recession in depth. This adds to the impression of a spacious urban environment, as does the fact that the photograph was taken from an elevated vantage point. The Largo is animated, in the left foreground, by a small group of people. While too indistinct to offer much information about themselves, they create the impression of a lively urban space.
The large, symmetrical façade of the Convento dell’Annunziata frames the left middle ground. Completed in 1747 for Dominican nuns, it housed the Palazzo di Giustizia and the Regia Scuola Normale Promiscua at the time this photograph was taken. In the right background, a portion of the Palazzo del Governo is visible. If not architecturally noteworthy, these structures help create a formal symmetry and regularity that organises the composition in an aesthetically pleasing way. More significantly, they create the sense of a rationally planned, orderly, and well-appointed city.
 
Figure 3. Matera – Largo Plebiscito. Giacinto Calculli. Author’s collection.
This image of Matera is sustained by a group of Calculli’s postcards depicting its civic institutions, churches, public spaces, and infrastructure in more focused detail. The Convento dell’Annunziata is the sole subject of two other cards on which its function as the Palazzo di Giustizia and Regia Scuola Normale Promiscua is indicated by captions. The fact it was pictured on at least two cards by other publishers, both with similar inscriptions, suggests that the structure and its institutions were considered important features of Matera. The same is true of the town hall and the seventeenth-century Palazzo Lanfranchi which housed the Regio Liceo Ginnasio Emanuele Duni and the Convitto Nazionale at the time. Both were depicted on postcards issued by Calculli and others before 1910. Public fountains were also important pieces of urban infrastructure that symbolised rational planning and modernisation and often featured on postcards. Known as the Fontana Ferdinandea in honour of Ferdinand II, King of the Two Sicilies, Matera’s principal fountain was completed in 1832 on the site of an earlier construction from the sixteenth century. Calculli published at least two postcards depicting it shortly after 1900.
The views he offered of the Palazzo Lanfranchi are particularly interesting for the way in which they present the image of a city both historically significant and socially and culturally modern (Figure 4). The building was constructed between 1668 and 1672 to house the diocesan seminary and the Church of the Madonna del Carmine. Calculli’s two postcards featuring the Palazzo were accompanied by one depicting the city’s grandest Baroque church, San Francesco d’Assisi (completed in 1751), and another picturing the interior of the cathedral that was redecorated in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. These images emphasise the degree of architectural sophistication achieved in Matera during the early modern period and the Church’s role in fostering this. With its façade designed in a Baroque aesthetic, the Palazzo Lanfranchi indicates the city’s engagement with major historical currents in culture, architecture, and urban planning as, following its elevation to capital of Basilicata in 1663, it was developed by private, public, and ecclesiastical building projects.
This image of a historically and architecturally important city, engaged with greater cultural and political currents, is promoted by other postcards issued by Calculli. Two depict the exterior of the cathedral that was completed in the Puglian Romanesque style in 1270. One pictures the Castello 
 
Figure 4. R. Liceo Ginnasio E. Duni. Giacinto Calculli. Author’s collection.
Tramontano and suggests Matera, with its Aragonese fortification similar to that at Taranto, was closely integrated, politically and culturally, with the Kingdom of Naples. Another depicts the so- called Torre Metellana at the northwestern edge of the Cività. The claim that it was a surviving feature of Roman fortifications was made as early as the sixteenth century.  Recent research suggests the tower was constructed by the Normans who took control of Matera in the eleventh century.  Nonetheless, its attribution to the Roman period at the time Calculli published this postcard served to ennoble the city’s origins.
Yet it is also interesting that Calculli’s depiction of the Palazzo Lanfranchi is identified on both cards as the R. Liceo Ginnasio E. Duni with one adding e Convitto Nazionale. Matera’s schools and public entities were often housed in repurposed ecclesiastical buildings and the viewer of Calculli’s postcards is directed to see the Palazzo in terms of its contemporaneous civic function. Their photographs present the image of a city boasting institutions typical of a socially advanced and culturally modern community. Although their visual fields are limited, they promote an impression similar to that offered by the postcard picturing the Largo Plebiscito. The viewer looks along Via Liceo – appearing as a small piazza framed on the left by the Palazzo Del Salvatore – to the façade of the Palazzo Lanfranchi. The rectilinear and restrained sophistication of both structures, delimiting the regular space onto which they front, creates the impression of a rationally planned, even sophisticated urban environment.
In sum, Calculli’s postcards depicting the Cività and the city on the Piano foreground the architectural and urban sophistication of Matera achieved especially in the medieval and early modern periods. They present a city of historical importance that developed culturally, socially, and politically as part of the Kingdom of Naples and the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies. They also promote the image of a contemporary urban centre with schools and public institutions. Continuing and appealing to a local tradition of describing Matera in these terms, and in the context of increased interest in the assertion of local identity, Calculli’s is a proud self-portrait of what the city’s upper and middle classes had achieved. It contrasted representations highlighting the degradation of the Sassi and descriptions of Basilicata that presented it as lacking flourishing urban centres.
Furthermore, his postcards disputed an image of the Mezzogiorno promoted especially by L’Illustrazione Italiana. This popular journal often discussed the South in terms of its picturesque landscapes to the detriment of engagement with its history, cities, and culture.  There was also an ‘active depreciation of the cultural traditions, history, and monuments of the south’ relative to the ‘valorization of those of the center-north’ which were seen as integral to the creation of a national identity.  Postcards issued by Calculli and local publishers throughout the Mezzogiorno countered the neglect of southern cities and culture that had trouble gaining ‘positive recognition’ in popular media and the founding myths of the nation. 
Some of Calculli’s cards feature photographs of the Sassi that are more focused than his panoramas. These are engaging, appealing images of an integral part of the city’s urban fabric that long-featured in descriptions of it and was becoming – especially for external observers – evermore characteristic of Matera as a whole. With their vistas onto a seemingly time-worn and irregular architectural medley, Calculli’s views do not foreground urban and social degradation, nor do they depict cave dwellings. Instead, while documenting their vernacular architecture and complex spatial organisation, they view the Sassi through a picturesque lens.
One example, postmarked 1916, bears the caption Matera. Una veduta nel Sasso Caveoso on the recto (Figure 5). The colourised photograph was taken by V. Marsilio. Rising in the centre is the rock formation known as the Monterrone, home to the excavated sanctuaries of Santa Maria de 
 
Figure 5. Matera. Una Veduta nel Sasso Caveoso. Giacinto Calculli. Author’s collection.
Idris and San Giovanni in Monterrone, both probably begun in the twelfth century. At the lower left is the church of San Pietro Caveoso, perched at the edge of La Gravina. Built in the thirteenth century, this was remodelled in the seventeenth to include its Baroque-style façade. This area of the Sasso Caveoso, and the Monterrone in particular, has often been photographed and become an iconic feature of Matera. It appears on at least one other postcard published by Calculli before 1920 as well as on examples issued by the Stabilimento di Eliotipia Molfese of Torino as early as 1895, and Giovanni Vezzoso of Matera around 1900.
Although not the case on this card, the subject is often identified as Santa Maria de Idris. The only indications that the mass of rock houses a church is the stairway leading to the small, constructed façade and campanile, and the crosses perched on the summit of the Monterrone. The latter is surrounded by a jumble of structures that constitute the vicinato at its foot. While the inclusion of modest dwellings suggests a documentary intent, this is an artfully composed image created with attention to compositional symmetry; expressive juxtaposition of foreground and background; contrast of light and shade; and intriguing detail. As with all Calculli’s views of the Sassi, there is no indication of cave dwellings and there is nothing dark and foetid. Instead, the colour brightens a scene filled with warm light. An expansive sky and background, with a glimpse into La Gravina and a high horizon dotted with trees, alleviates any sense of the unhygienic density that struck Zanardelli and others. Instead, the viewer is offered an artfully composed, pleasing vista in which a focus on socio-spatial degradation is replaced by the attractively intriguing and seemingly exotic.
The fascinating nature of the image is enhanced by the fact that, while real poverty is conspicuously absent, so, it initially appears, is history. In contrast to postcards depicting the Piano, those picturing the Sassi present a time-worn, sometimes rock-hewn architecture bearing few explicit indications of contemporaneity. They depict what appears – to the casual observer – a society untouched by time. The latter is spatialised in these images; the Sassi seem situated in another age distinct from, if physically contiguous with, the rest of Matera. San Pietro Caveoso serves as a contrast to Santa Maria de Idris and highlights the seemingly age-old nature of the latter. In this picturesque image, the excavated church stands as positively representative of Matera’s ancient roots, singular history, and culturally unique architecture.
Yet San Pietro Caveoso, and other structures surrounding the Monterrone, indicate that a variety of buildings were constructed in the Sassi; in fact, the appearance of the valleys is the result of numerous architectural interventions occurring over centuries. Not simply, nor even mostly sites of cave dwelling, the Sassi were architecturally and socially complex quarters shaped by a long history of socio-spatial transformation. The presence of San Pietro Caveoso indicates that, for much of their history, the valleys were a fully integrated part of Matera’s urban fabric and home to all classes of resident. The physical, social, economic, and cultural separation of the city into two zones, and the transformation of the Sassi into a peasant ghetto of primitive appearance, largely began following Matera’s elevation to regional capital in 1663.
Ultimately, with their expansive views onto the built environment of the valleys, Calculli’s postcards do not frame them as necessarily ancient, and certainly not timeless. Their intent, considered as part of his overall portrait of Matera, does not appear to be the promotion of nostalgia for a society untouched by time, nor the value of rural existence as opposed to urbanism. Instead, they present a complex urban, architectural, and social space transformed, like that of numerous Italian cities, over many centuries.
Calculli seems to have been unique in also publishing postcards picturing the peasant inhabitants of the Sassi before 1920. Often captioned Matera – Costumi, the images range from expansive views of the architectural environment with people employed to animate the scene, to photographs which take peasants as their focus. In some, they appear informally if not candidly posed. Yet these photographs are mostly highly contrived, even artful in their composition and content. It is important to note that they were published at a time of social strife in and around the city. 
A peasant league was formed at Matera and, in June 1902, strikes involving up to 1,000 labourers resulted in arrests and the death of one peasant.  Given the number of people mobilised, their duration, and the nature of the demands, these events are understood as part of ‘il primo moderno conflitto di classe nelle campagne’.  Another peasant league was organised in 1912 and led to the winning of electoral majorities at the communal and provincial level. Calculli’s postcards provide no indication of these events. Instead, employing visual clichés, they are in keeping with the palatable representation of Italy’s social margins in middle-class culture.
One card offers a close-up view of a peasant couple seated on a mule (Figure 6). The animal is diagonally posed to provide the shallow foreground, framed by a rocky outcrop, with a sense of depth, and the ensemble of figures is set against a background offering a panoramic view of the Sasso Caveoso from the south-east. This is a sophisticated photograph that artfully combines a focus on its human subjects with an impressive vista onto their environment. It is also cleverly contrived in terms of content. The rocky outcrop framing the foreground emphasises the harsh natural environment in which these people eke out their living. To the left, a set of rough-hewn stone stairs and a chimney indicate human adaptation to the landscape, as does the panoramic view onto the Sasso Caveoso. The close connection of these peasants to their environment is also accentuated by the fact that the photograph was printed in monochrome and the figures are composed of the same hues as their surroundings. The limited tonal range lends the scene a dense materiality, the airlessness of which is relieved somewhat by the background vista.
However, there is no indication that these people are the victims of abject poverty, housed in foetid dwellings. Instead, the image depicts a situation in which peasants, although poor, are not indigent, but decent, productive, and well-adapted to their environment. Both man and woman are humbly but well dressed; they are not ragged, and both wear shoes. They sit composed upon their mule in a way that is not undignified and maintain a self-possessed demeanour. As a feature that 
 
Figure 6. Matera – Costumi. Giacinto Calculli. Author’s collection.
typologically defined peasant society, the mule occupies a conspicuous position and makes an important contribution to the image’s content. It signifies that this couple is not destitute. More particularly, the photograph pictures the relationship of this valuable piece of property to its owners as one of important work companion. There is nothing of the ‘horrible promiscuity’ of people and animals described by the Neapolitan journalist quoted above. In this respect, the postcard is notably different from photographs taken to document living conditions in the Sassi following the Second World War. In many photographs picturing the interior of cave dwellings at this time, mules are often conspicuously present to emphasise, not the relative well-being of their peasant inhabitants, but their deplorable living conditions.
It has been argued that postcard consumers are ‘attracted to traditional methods of composing pictures’.  This particular photograph, and others published by Calculli, clearly adopt some of the compositional strategies and rhetorical devices of fine art. It recalls the work of the Italian Pictorialists, photographers who produced highly crafted ‘sentimental meditations on pastoral landscapes’ that were often featured in La Fotografia Artistica, the magazine published between 1904 and 1917.  Calculli’s images are not as artistically ambitious as those of the Pictorialists. Yet they are the product of developed interpretative and expressive skill and the peasants they depict are ‘transformed into subjects of aesthetic delectation’ while the harsh realities of their lives are ignored. 
The fact that postcards depicting peasant costumes and material culture were collected by Giuseppe A. Andriulli, while he was gathering material in Basilicata for the Exhibition of Italian Ethnography in Rome in 1911, suggests Calculli’s cards also appealed to ethnographic and folklorist interest. While artful, their photographs are also ‘socially investigative’ and record information about the dress, material culture, and living environment of Sassi dwellers.  Although misery is absent, they depict something of the reality of life for many. The valleys were socially variegated spaces that were not home only to indigent peasants dwelling in caves. While many inhabitants lived precariously as tenant farmers and day labourers, others were artisans and small landholders. Many families lived in lamioni, single-room, barrel-vaulted structures built of tufa blocks with a tile roof. Others occupied larger edifices originally built for residents of higher social standing that were vacated and divided to accommodate peasant families.
Postcard publishers and their publics ‘are influenced by hegemonic ways of seeing that have a strong political edge’ and Calculli’s depictions of peasants were undoubtedly conceived in terms of the expectations of their prospective audience.  In form and content, they are in keeping with postcards picturing peasant society in all regions and, no matter his intentions, their appeal must have resided in a variety of expectations, sentiments, and interests. Inevitably, the environment they depict is a place of otherness embodying physical, social, and cultural realities intriguingly different from those of Calculli’s clientele. The picturesque aesthetic and seemingly exotic subject matter may have appealed to a taste for a ‘poetic margin’ beyond the ‘humdrum reality’ of many who purchased them.  The attraction for some may have been nostalgia for ‘an untroubled (and unreal) rustic experience that the country’s modernisation [. . .] threatened to destroy’.  Perhaps others were interested in their documentary, folkloric, and ethnographic value. Whatever their appeal, postcards of this type served to reinforce societal power relations as those who purchased them looked upon people ‘different from, more backward than, and culturally inferior’ to themselves.97
The point to be made, however, is that Calculli’s views of the Sassi and their inhabitants do not intentionally stigmatise them, nor explicitly treat them as colourful curiosities. The valleys and their inhabitants are not construed as an archaic, impoverished, and uncultured community emblematic of a tragic South. Instead, they are presented as part of a composite portrait of Matera as a city complex in its social makeup and boasting the architectural monuments of a long, intriguing history of engagement with events that shaped the peninsula at large.
Conclusion
Italy’s Fascist government suppressed public discussion of the South’s problems and Basilicata received relatively little coverage in the press beyond its borders.  La Basilicata nel mondo, published at Naples from 1924, continued to disseminate a positive image of the region from a local perspective. Recounting its history and culture, and offering biographies of eminent personages of local origin, the journal provided ‘un’inversione [. . . dell’]immagine consolidata’ presented in popular media, and was distributed in Italy and to the emigrant community.  Yet, as its regional perspective contrasted Fascist nationalism, it was forced to cease publication in 1927. At the same time, Calculli’s portrait of Matera grew in size and complexity. Publishing new images and re-issuing others, he was joined by local entrepreneurs sharing his vision. One particularly important figure was Francesco Riccardi who operated a bookshop on Corso Umberto I and issued several postcards, many picturing the architecture and public spaces depicted by Calculli. These consolidated the portrait of a respectable city befitting Matera’s status as provincial capital from 1927.
This image was promoted in media with a national distribution. In 1927, the Touring Club Italiano described the city as one of Italy’s most picturesque.  Focussing on the Sassi, it presented them as sites of rustic simplicity, not abject poverty, with photographs offering intriguing, visually pleasing images. Other publications followed Calculli’s portrait of an urbane centre more closely. An important example is Matera città sotterranea published in 1928 as one of a series of magazines entitled Le cento città d’Italia illustrate.  Only three of the forty-one photographs suggest there is anything subterranean about the city, and the text treats the Sassi in summary fashion. Instead, the magazine sustains the portrait of a developed urban space with historically significant architecture. Many of the photographs employed were first published as postcards by Calculli and others. This is also true of the guide to Puglia, Lucania, and Calabria issued by the Touring Club Italiano in 1937 which presented the same portrait, while describing Matera, once again, as ‘una delle città più pittoresche d’Italia’.  So did a postcard published by Valda in 1932, advertising its lozenges, which bears an artist’s rendition of the Castello Tramontano derived from a card issued by Riccardi. In these ways, images first published as postcards were employed to sell Matera to consumers as a historically and culturally significant southern city.
Following 1945, many locally published postcards expanded this portrait with images of new construction that constituted the partial reconfiguration of Matera’s historic centre and its growth beyond this.  These contradicted Luisa Levi’s disparaging image of Fascist-era building recounted by her brother.  Yet postcards also contributed to a process whereby Matera’s image was subsumed under that of the Sassi. The many produced today are one facet of a large volume of print and digital media sustaining a fascination with the ‘città dei Sassi’.  Informed by what are perceived to be the vestiges of a prehistoric settlement, popular representations often distort the nature and history of the valleys and city. Many visitors are drawn to Matera by the ‘romantic and essentializing notion of timelessness’ that dominates its popular image.  The inclination to believe in a place untouched by time may be grounded in a ‘popular nostalgia’ expressing itself ‘in the rush to find traces of vanishing, pre-modern ways of life, untouched, unconscious and static in opposition to how we define ourselves’.107
The popular photographic portrayal published by Giacinto Calculli before 1920 sustained a tradition of describing Matera as a historically important and well-appointed city built and characterised by its upper and middle classes. In the context of increasing condemnation of the Sassi, his postcards presented a proud, attractive self-portrait by focusing on the Cività and Piano; providing picturesque vistas onto the valleys that offered a visually pleasing encounter with their intriguing architecture and historical complexity; and artfully and selectively depicting their peasant inhabitants. Purchased by local consumers as decorations and gifts, posted to correspondents throughout Italy, and republished in media with a national distribution, they constituted a locally produced complement to a less prejudiced, sometimes positive portrayal of Basilicata that was modifying narratives often narrowly focused on foregrounding the region’s deficiencies.

***

We Will Set You Free: Representations of the ‘Antislavery 
Argument’ in British and Italian Missionary Films (1925–1939)

Introduction
During the period 1925–1939, British Protestant and Italian Catholic missionary associations contributed with their films to pro-imperial propaganda. Studying these films reveals how and to what extent missionary films and colonial governments’ films shared similar views on colonial occupation. As I will detail in the following sections of this work, typically, missionary films are documentaries concerning the main activities of missionaries, proselytism, and education, and generally depict catechism classes and religious events.  When studying this cinematography, one needs to consider that unlike private and semi-private film production companies, missionaries often had difficulties in affording visual technologies as well as professional camerawork and production, and this imposed limitations to the number of films missionary associations produced.
Missionaries active in colonized territories responded to the colonial policies regulating the economic and educational systems where their stations were located. Missionary activities coexisted with colonial governmental institutions. This work focuses on two missionary films, one British and one Italian, that were collaborative endeavors between missionary associations and colonial governments. The aim with this work is to show that the two missionary films belonging to two different cinema and colonial histories and addressing different colonial political agendas share similar portrayals of human trafficking and both construct the fight against domestic slavery as a justification for colonial occupation. This study provides explanations for the films’ striking similarities, and their differences, and addresses multiple lines of inquiry, such as a comparative 
study of British and Italian colonial histories, the study of colonial propaganda through film, and the role of missionary cinematography in constructing imperial imaginations.
The first film was produced by a British Protestant missionary association; the second one by an Italian Catholic missionary association; they both reproduce traditional missionary themes. The British one is Livingstone (1925) on the life of missionary David Livingstone (1813–1873), and the Italian is Abuna Messias (1939) on the journey in Ethiopia undertaken in the late nineteenth century by the Capuchin father Guglielmo Massaia (1809–1889).  This essay shows that the later film replicates a scene portraying enslaved people, which is strikingly like a scene from the earlier film. This work analyses this similarity in depth and argues that the British film is a model for the Italian film, which gives us a deeper understanding of the role of the so-called ‘antislavery argument’ in the Italian colonial agenda. Historian Ribi-Forclaz’s work on the ‘antislavery argument’ in Italian politics from the 1930s is crucial to this study; she explains that the main Italian antislavery group, which was a Catholic group, supported the fascist government’s invasion of Ethiopia (1935) by arguing that it was a necessary war to end domestic slavery. 
This analysis also notes some differences in the ways the two films use the representation of slavery; for instance, unlike the British film, the scenes here under scrutiny from the Italian Catholic film show that it constructed Italy as ‘unified’ nation of Catholic origins, and slavery as perpetrated by Muslims. This article explains that the film’s narrative asserts the strong ties between the Catholic Church and the Fascist government to the detriment of other religious traditions largely practiced in Italy’s colonies, and to serve this purpose the film antagonizes Muslims and Copts. Ultimately, both films use the construction of white missionaries fighting against domestic slavery to justify colonial occupation.
This research looks at the two films under scrutiny mainly through the lens of theoretical discourses on the ‘colonial gaze’ in missionary cinema and on biopolitics in British and Italian colonial cinematic reconstructions. Among the scholarship on missionary cinema, this study draws inspiration from Ann Kaplan, Tom Gunning, and Ian Aitken’s seminal works on the role of missionary films made during British colonial rule. Further, these works are combined with the findings by Maria Francesca Piredda exploring the less studied issue of Catholic missionary productions during Italian colonial rule.
Kaplan addresses the representation of indigenous communities by white Europeans ranging from missionaries, scientists, and anthropologists, to entrepreneurs, and colonial agents. Kaplan argues that British missionary productions from the 1920s and the 1930s in particular constructed the so-called ‘colonial gaze’ as a representation of indigenous people that was ‘trivializing and infantilizing’.  Gunning argues that British missionary films were ‘marked by the returned look of the people within the film, the gaze directed out at the camera and viewer which transfixes the act of looking as central to the power dynamic at the bases of these narratives’.  Like Kaplan, Gunning concludes that, overall, in these films, indigenous people are represented as primitive and petty, as opposed to the modern and civilized white man (a missionary, a colonial officer etc.). Moreover, Aitken’s study of British colonial and missionary documentary film from the interwar years in South and South-East Asia explains that the British sought to maintain their influence over those territories using different strategies, including the production and distribution of educational documentary films. 
Piredda’s recent study of Italian Catholic missionary films contends that the main themes are the missionary’s ‘heroism’, wilderness and landscapes, and indigenous communities’ traditions. Therefore, what differentiates Piredda’s conclusion from the previously described studies on British missionary cinema is that in the Italian films the focus is not on detailed portrayals of colonial institutions. Piredda not only identifies and discusses for the first time in a comprehensive study the missionary films released by Italian Catholic associations during the first half of the twentieth century, but also makes an important point that is crucial to this research. She argues that most missionary films had an ‘ethnographic eye’ on the indigenous people they represented. Piredda highlights the shared contents and techniques between the visual narratives portraying indigenous people in early ethnographic films from the 1910s, 1920s, and the 1930s, and those in contemporary missionary films. One of the ideas driving the Italian Catholic missionaries was, Piredda continues,  ‘opening their arms to the Other’, and, therefore, the missionaries shared the ethnographers’ interest in documenting the cultural patterns of the indigenous communities. Anthropologist Clifford Geertz defined ‘cultural patterns’ as ‘historically created systems of meaning in terms of which we give form, order, point, and direction to our lives’.  Ethnographic and missionary films focused on indigenous rituals, from fertility dances to funerals. The aims of the films were different, ethnographers wanted to record films for scientific purposes, while the missionaries for proselytism; however, even if moved by different purposes, missionaries produced films rich in ethnographic shots. Piredda also explains that the recurrent ethnographic material is linked to the intended audience of most of the Italian Catholic missionary films, which were both religious and non-religious people. She clarifies that reaching a wide audience was the director’s and producers’ primary concern, and most of the film’s ethnographic scenes are constructed according to that aim.
Building on Piredda’s insights on the ethnographic component of Italian Catholic missionary films, this study shows that Abuna Messias corresponds to the tradition delineated by Piredda insofar as it presents scenes of ethnographic interest, for example ritual dances and close-ups that highlight the physiognomic traits; additionally, like most ethnographic films from the period, Abuna Messias was shot on location with non-professional local actors. Yet, we know that the film was scripted and staged and, therefore, it cannot be defined as an ethnographic film.  However, it is relevant to mention that most early ethnographic films from the 1920s and the 1930s had staged components due to the limited visual and sound technologies available. Portable cameras and sound recording equipment were bulky: they hardly passed unnoticed by the observed and recorded subjects. Moreover, their use was restrained by the need of power supply. 
Overall, the above-mentioned studies by Kaplan, Aitken, and Piredda addressed the relationship between imperialist and missionary agencies with native populations, showing that documentary films by missionary groups, either Protestant or Catholic, contributed to the construction of an ‘imaginary space’ where, in Aitken’s terms, ‘imagined or idealized representations of the colonial endeavor and relations with indigenous populations were shaped’. 
Among the works focusing on the representation of enslaved people, Jacqueline Reich’s The Maciste Films of Italian Silent Cinema and Rhiannon Welch’s Vital subjects. Race and Biopolitics in Italy  offer crucial context for the study of racialized bodies in non-missionary Italian colonial documentaries. In her work on Italian cinematic narratives of identity during World War I and after, Reich focuses on the character of the enslaved man Maciste who recurs in several films released between 1914 and the 1960s. As Reich shows, in the first Italian epic film Cabiria, Maciste’s first appearance, the character’s narrative function is to link different temporalities ‘evoking Roman victories in the name of current nationalist and colonialist enterprises’.  Welch analyses early colonial and fascist Italian films. She argues that the films she selected have a shared message about Italy’s incompleteness as a nation and imperial power. The incompleteness is pivotal to Italy’s cinematic rendering of Africa and African people.
The work by Ruth Ben-Ghiat, Italian Fascism’s Empire Cinema (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2015) is crucial for defining the Italian film here under scrutiny within existing film categories. Given the nature of this visual narrative, its categorization is challenging; the director introduces the film as a documentary at the very beginning, but we know that the film is scripted and staged. There are scenes portraying ritual dances, which remind us of the core of Piredda’s study mentioned above, namely the tradition in early Catholic missionary cinema of constructing ethnographic surveys to appeal to a broad audience through images constructed according to the widespread taste of the time for the exotic. Ben-Ghiat offers an in-depth study of a selection of nine Italian features on imperial themes from the period 1936–1943 and explains their shared hybridity. ‘By the early 1940s’, she argues, ‘the close relationship between feature and documentary film had become a hallmark of Italian empire cinema culture’. 
The two films here under scrutiny are emblematic examples of this kind of imaginary. On the one hand, Livingstone and Abuna Messias construct two different imperial imaginations; on the other hand, they frame in analogous ways themes that reveal links between British and Italian colonial imaginaries. I show that their similarities reveal a mutual anti-slavery political agenda based on, in Ribi Forclaz’s terms, the idea of a ‘humanitarian imperialism’.  This study details how imperialism manifests in the mutual themes between Livingstone and Abuna Messias, which are the representation of missionaries as heroic male figures and founding fathers who are the main characters in the construction of the anti-slavery argument.
Two Scenes and Two Portrayals of Slavery from a Comparative View
Livingstone is a 90-minute long silent black and white biopic on the life of British explorer and member of the London Missionary Society (LMS) David Livingstone (1813–1873). It was directed by M. A. Wetherell, also playing the main character David Livingstone, and released in January 1925. Rice notes that in the same year, The London Times published an article titled ‘British Films and Education’ which described the film as ‘explicitly positioned as a pedagogical tool and was screened in churches and schools’.  Moreover, Rice continues, churches and schools were the places where students could acquire ‘colonial attitudes’.  After the first screenings, the film received no unfavorable reviews and it was promoted as an educational film. 
The film opens with some events from Livingstone’s childhood followed by images portraying his years spent studying medicine at home and aspiring to be a politician. During this phase of his life, the film shows that he followed Dr. Robert Moffat’s lectures on Africa’s resources and people. During one of these lectures, Livingstone applies for and is accepted to undertake missionary work in British African territories for the London Missionary Society. He then departs to South Africa where he spends most of his adult life and comes back to London only once to inform Queen Victoria about the improvements of his mission. Later, in Ujiji, near Lake Tanganyika, he meets Henry M. Stanley who is sent by the Queen to follow Livingstone in his explorations. During the expedition to the source of the Nile, Livingstone dies of fever and is carried to Chitambos Village where he is buried under a tree. The film’s concluding intertitles inform the viewers that Livingstone’s ‘embalmed remains are then carried 800 miles by loving hands to the coast’. The film’s last shot portrays a black man looking over his tomb in Westminster Abbey, as his diary entry from 1872 appears on the screen: ‘My Jesus, my King, my All; I again dedicate myself to Thee - Amen, So Let it Be’.
The idea that missionary activity is a vital undertaking is conveyed in different sequences; for example, the theme of the missionary fighting against human-trafficking recurs several times. There is a particular scene that begins with Livingstone who has just returned from his visit to Queen Victoria in London. During an expedition to Ujiji, near Lake Tanganyika, he sees a group of enslaved men (52:10). One of them, a child, is sick, and the slave trader wants to cut his throat (52:15). Livingstone prevents the slaughter (52:18). In the following shots, Livingstone negotiates a price to pay to the slave trader to free the child. The payment consists of five yards of cotton fabric (52:28). The missionary helps the child to stand up and leave (53:05).
What is relevant to this essay is that the scene that I have just described is almost entirely reproduced in the later Italian Catholic film Abuna Messias, a 93-minute black and white film with sound, released in 1939. It was produced by the Romana Editrice Film (R.E.F.), a Catholic film company launched by Don Giacomo Alberione of the San Paolo Society and directed by Goffredo Alessandrini.
The film’s composite different images and contents make it hard to categorize; it mixes ethnographic and fictionalized images portraying indigenous communities from the colonies. Scenes of ritual dances, several close-ups detailing the physiognomy of indigenous people, and the choices to shoot the film on location and with a large cast of non-professionals speak to the ethnographic nature of the film; furthermore, there is an intent to construct the film as a documentary offering the viewers an authentic portrayal of missionary work in the colonies. In the opening shots, we see on the screen some title-cards explaining the cinematic strategies used to represent reality as objectively as possible; for instance, one of these introductory intertitles reads ‘Il dialogo degli indigeni ѐ stato tradotto solo dove indispensabile’ which presents the film as an ethnographic survey. Ben-Ghiat explains Alessandrini’s choice as driven by ‘exigencies of both documentation and spectacle’.  The producers and the director used the ploy of realism to present the feature film as a valuable source to understand history.
As I mentioned in the introductory section of this essay, Ben-Ghiat investigates the varied components of spectacle and documentation of Abuna Messias and other Italian films from the 1930s. She defined the missionary film Abuna Messias as an imperial film pioneering new cinematic techniques.  Imperial films contributed to the imperial identity formation process, which was a challenge that other European imperial powers had already resolved by this time. In historian Labanca’s terms, since the ‘myth of the oltremare’ was less rooted in the Italian colonial context than in others, a ‘colonial consciousness needed to be created’. 
Abuna Messias’s plot unfolds at the end of the nineteenth century. Cardinal Guglielmo Massaia has already spent several years in Ethiopia trying to put an end to slavery, improve education, and convert people to the Catholic Church; he is known among Ethiopians as Abuna Messias and he is a friend of King Menelik. The support of the King is fundamental to spread his word and accomplish his mission. However, the Head of the Coptic Church, Abuna Attanasio, does whatever he can to break this friendship and get Massaia exiled from Ethiopia. King Menelik refuses to endorse Abuna Attanasio’s plans against Massaia. Attanasio decides to address the emperor thus triggering a war between the emperor and his subject King Menelik. To end the war, Cardinal Massaia decides to 
 
Figure 1. Film flyer, 1939. Reproduced with permission of the Cineteca di Bologna,
leave Africa. However, he has ordained a young Ethiopian priest, who will continue his mission of proselytism.
What is strikingly similar to the film Livingstone is the content of the following series of shots: a group of enslaved men walks in the direction of the missionaries, Cardinal Massaia and his travel companion (2.29); one of them falls sick onto the ground (3:05); Massaia sees him and reaches out to help (3:10); the slave trader does not allow Massaia to help the man (3:27); the trader wants to kill the sick man (3:38). After some negotiations, the missionary pays the slave trader with his most precious possession, a medallion that Massaia had received from Camillo Benso Count of Cavour, and some money (3:40). The shots of this sequence show the trader pointing at the cardinal’s medallion. Massaia at first says ‘No, questo non posso’ (3:43). The trader is not satisfied by Massaia’s refusal and lifts his right arm, a sign that commands the enslaved people to leave. Massaia, then, says ‘Wait’ (author’s translation, 3:44) and gives him the medallion because he wants to free the sick man. While handing it to the trader, he says to him ‘I hope it will make you a gentleman’ (author’s translation, 3:45). The missionaries help the man to stand up and leave. This sequence had a crucial part in the film; it is in fact the first interaction between the missionaries and the locals. Images from this sequence were used on the flyer to promote Abuna Massaia’s first screening (Figure 1).
Imaginations of Slavery and Colonial Agendas
Taken as a whole, the British missionary films Livingstone (1925) and the Italian Abuna Messias (1939) replicate the preferred themes of contemporary colonial cinema: the colonial gaze portraying indigenous people is, in Kaplan’s terms, ‘trivializing and infantilizing’ them.  The infantilization of the enslaved people is linked to scholar Annemarie Tamis-Nasello’s argument that Abuna Messias ‘through its historical portrayal of the physical and psychological “ills” of the Ethiopian people casts the colony as a space ripe for healing at the hands of Italians’. 
What I have just described occurs in both films. In the British film as well as the Italian one, in fact, slavery is represented as the main ‘disease’ afflicting the colonies (both slaves fall ill onto the ground in front of the missionaries). The intervention of the British missionary in the British film, and the Italian missionary in the Italian film is framed similarly as treatment of the slaves’ sickness. Therefore, the two scenes here under study draw a link between the ideas of sickness and slavery, and the solution these two narratives offer to the treating of this ‘illness’ is British, or Italian, involvement.
The two similar scenes portraying human trafficking can be analysed further by locating them in the larger context of the involvement of anti-slavery societies in colonized territories. Ribi Forclaz compared British and Italian antislavery cultural propaganda in print from 1932 onwards and identified a real ‘propaganda war’ between the British Anti-Slavery Society and the Italian Società Antischiavista (Anti-slavery Society). Ribi Forclaz noted that while the British Anti-Slavery Society began to launch preparations for the ‘centenary of emancipation’ commemorating 100 years since the Slave Emancipation Act of 1833, the Italian Società Antischiavista challenged the established narrative of British humanitarian leadership. The Italians increased their image as opponents of human trafficking by creating a self-aggrandizing tradition. It is within this context that the print propaganda by the Italian Società Antischiavista advertised Capuchin Cardinal Guglielmo Massaia’s missions in Ethiopia, portraying them as driven by the same ideals guiding the British explorer and London Missionary Society member David Livingstone. This propaganda advertised the two missionaries as sharing the struggle against domestic slavery in African colonial territories.
I draw a line between these films’ similar scenes and the fact that the Italian Società Antischiavista print propaganda from the late 1930s, the same period when the film Abuna Messia was released (1939), also compared Cardinal Massaia to David Livingstone. Therefore, there was a common rhetoric used in print and in cinema which connected the Italian and the British missionaries by virtue of their shared efforts in fighting slavery in the colonies. Before focusing on this link, however, it is important to note that since the late 1890s, the antislavery-societies of Britain, Italy, and France proposed on different occasions an international intervention to end slavery in North Africa, and more generally to curtail the continuation of human trafficking in Africa.
It was in 1911 that for the first time the secretary of the Italian Antislavery Society, Attilio Simonetti, in a letter exchange with the British and the French secretaries, endorsed Italy’s military invasion of Tripolitania. He justified it as a military action that was necessary to put an end to slave- trading.  This same justification for warfare and colonization was used again by the Society in the mid-1930s, when the Italian fascist regime began a war with Ethiopia (1935–1936) that ended with the annexation of Ethiopia to the Italian empire. In the months preceding the invasion, the government began a large-scale domestic propaganda campaign to promote the war. It was during these months that the emblematic hymn Faccetta Nera by Giuseppe Micheli was released. 
As mentioned above, the Italian Società Antischiavista was a strong supporter of the invasion of Ethiopia. Between 1935 and 1936, it multiplied its commentaries on the humanitarian aspects of the war, and it is in this setting that the Capuchin father Guglielmo Massaia was presented as a pioneering spirit of anti-slavery action in Africa alongside David Livingstone. On the pages of the society’s official journal, Antischiavismo, the Italian missionary was introduced as the British man’s counterpart.  Ribi Forclaz explains that ‘because the Italian society [The Italian Società Antischiavista] could not draw on meaningful jubilees and significant abolitionist achievements, it fabricated self-aggrandizing propaganda by comparing emblematic representatives like Massaia to existing and affirmed British abolitionist popular figures like Livingstone’. 
By highlighting the role of cinema along with print in promoting Livingstone and Massaia as anti-slavery heroes, the comparative and transnational study of the two selected films builds on and expands existing scholarship focusing primarily on print colonial propaganda from the same period. It was only a few years after the end of the Italo-Ethiopian war and after the Italian Società Antischiavista published the above-described print propaganda on Massaia, that the shooting of the film Abuna Messias begun. As I have shown above, a significant part of the Italian film mirrors a scene from the 1925 British film Livingstone, which denotes the intent to construct an ‘Italian abolitionist tradition’ on the British model.
Rice has also discussed what he has defined as ‘[colonial missionary films’] moralizing aesthetic,’ and argued that ‘The film [Livingstone] served to justify Britain’s continued overseas involvement through its representation of a moral imperialism’. Rice’s definition of ‘moral imperialism’ approximates Ribi Forclaz’s concept of ‘humanitarian imperialism’.  The same concept can be used to define Abuna Messias as well because this film’s representation of fighting against slavery served to justify Italy’s war crimes and annexation of Ethiopia to its colonial territories. As mentioned above, Ethiopia was a member of the League of Nations and Italy broke the non-belligerent pact among the League’s members when it invaded Ethiopia in 1935.
In 1939, Abuna Messias was awarded the Mussolini Cup at the Venice Film Festival and it received international acclaim. This film was produced and distributed with the intent to display the beneficial effects of the Italian presence in Ethiopia, particularly Italy’s efforts to suppress slavery; in Brunetta’s terms, it constructed a ‘sense of heroic idealism that was used by the regime for colonizing actions’.  In particular, the scene under scrutiny here showing Massaia’s compassion conveys the message that Ethiopians needed Italian assistance. It also constructed a misleading account of the status of human trafficking in the Italian empire. For instance, the customary law of Seraye, Eritrea, which permitted slavery and the slave trade, was codified under the supervision of the Italian Commissioner of the region (1938–1940). 
Livingstone too offers a misleading account of human trafficking. For example, reading Livingstone’s journals, we know that during his expeditions he was saved and rescued many times by slave-traders.  However, the film chooses to chiefly represent him as an antislavery hero and by watching the film the viewers do not gain a sense that he had occasionally been helped by slave traders.
In Livingstone, there is also the re-signification of one of the main products of the slave-trade: cotton fabric. In the scene analysed above, Livingstone exchanges yards of cotton fabric to free the enslaved ill man. The scene conveys the message that the British missionary owns the capital to buy out domestic traders and, therefore, buy freedom. We know that for centuries cotton fabric was the main product of the slave-trade regulated by British colonial rule, and it is striking that the film re- signifies it as an exchange product to fight domestic slavery and, therefore, justify British occupation.
The similarities between the films’ scenes portraying human trafficking are remarkable. Just as significantly, however, they differ in the portrayal of the slave-trader. Both films juxtapose shots portraying the traders and the missionaries and highlight the different ways they treated the slaves. Both films show that local traders treat the slaves harshly. The care and compassion shown by the missionaries throw the trader’s harsh treatment into sharp relief. In the Italian film, as the camera slowly pans across the lineup of bare-breasted slaves, the trader examines their bodies by touching their bodies to determine their health and strength and declares their suitability in Italian. There is a juxtaposition of some shots portraying the trader while touching the slaves’ bodies to make sure their economic value is preserved, and other shots representing Massaia’s concern with saving their lives and souls. Likewise, in the British film, the trader is concerned with the slaves’ fitness and health for their value on the market. When a slave falls ill, he wants to execute him because he may slow down and infect the others; Livingstone instead wants to save the sick man.
Unlike the British film’s representation of the trader, in the Italian film, the slave trader is portrayed as a Muslim. His white cotton vest speaks to this fact and, later in the film, the viewers get to know that his client, the man who is buying the slaves, is also a Muslim (8:38). This is an important distinction from the British film, one that gives us a deeper understanding of Abuna Messias’s political agenda. The trader in Abuna Messias appears on the screen at the beginning of the film, in the opening shots (3:40). Cardinal Massaia speaks to him after an enslaved young man has fallen sick and collapsed. The trader and the missionary are constructed with contrasting characters, and this opposition highlights the missionary’s role as ‘savior’. This same construction with these two opposite roles appears in the British film Livingstone as well. However, the Italian film adds to the trader’s representation the connotation of being a Muslim which can be explained by looking at the larger historical context in which the film was produced.
To further understand the film’s portrayals of the slave trader and the buyer as Muslims, we need to go back to the events that took place five years before the film’s release in 1939. In 1934, after the annexation of Libya to the Italian colonial territories, Mussolini proclaimed himself ‘protector of Islam’. He had a sword forged for the occasion and, during a ceremony in Florence, he displayed the sword as a symbol of his role as protector. He named it the ‘Sword of Islam’. The aim was to find allies in the newly occupied Libya, a country with a large Muslim population, and to avoid uprisings. However, in 1929, he had signed the Lateran Pacts with the Catholic Church, the agreement that regulated the relations between the fascist government and the Vatican.
Despite the Lateran Pacts, Mussolini was opportunistically constructing the image of Italy as a pro-Muslim colonial power to differentiate it from Britain and the other European colonial powers. As John Wright explains:
the rapid conquest of the Ethiopian empire in 1935–1936 had brought many more Muslims under Italian rule: those of Eritrea, Somalia, Libya, and Ethiopia were by 1936 estimated at about nine million. Italy had thus become a leading ‘Muslim’ power, conscious that her imperial record provided a means of enhancing or damaging her standing in Islamic opinion everywhere, but most particularly in the increasingly nationalistic Arab world. 
This excerpt highlights Mussolini’s intent to promote a campaign in support of Muslims to create consensus among the colonies with Muslim communities. The invasion of Ethiopia had a key role in Italy’s evolving imperial identity. In his work on the Ethiopian War, historian Angelo Del Boca explains that ‘to him [Mussolini] it was more than a war of conquest, it was the long-awaited opportunity to prove the mettle of the generation that his regime had forged’. 
The issue of Italy’s imperial identity raises several important questions. How do we understand the role of the Catholic Church in this building process? What part did the film Abuna Messias have? Why did the producers REF and the director Alessandrini choose to portray a slave trader as Muslim? How do we understand the film’s antagonizing portrayal of Copts? To answer these questions, we need to first consider historian Gian Piero Brunetta’s description of the film: ‘Questo è uno dei pochi film in cui tra cattolicesimo e fascismo si stabiliscono legami politici espliciti’.34 This film consolidates the image of fascist Italy as a Catholic nation to the detriment of other religious traditions that were largely practiced in the colonial African territories.
The fact that Cardinal Massaia gives his medallion to the trader is emblematic of the political message of the film. The medallion was a gift to Massaia from Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour, one of the politicians who had a major active part in the unification of Italy (1861), and who served as prime minister in unified Italy. The medallion is an important object with a symbolic meaning, and it also appears in later scenes in the film. Once the trader reaches the client who wanted to buy the slaves, he tells him that one slave was sold along the way to a white man who paid with money and a necklace. The client, who like the trader is a Muslim, wants to see the necklace and, in the following shots, he brings the necklace to the Abuna, the Bishop of the Coptic Church (8.40). The Abuna sees the medallion and understands that the Catholic missionary is in Ethiopia; he does not want the missionary to meet with the King because he fears the influence that the missionary might have on the King’s decisions. Therefore, he pays the Muslim to use any means necessary to put an end to the missionary’s journey (11:06).
The above-described sequence centered on the medallion conveys a core trait of Italy’s colonial propaganda: promoting the colonies as nations. The film is set in the past, at the time of Italy’s unification. Cardinal Massaia not only pays with money for the life and the freedom of a man, but also, on the request of the trader, gives up his precious medallion, a symbol of the creation of Italy as a unified nation. While in Livingstone, the yards of cotton were the only product given in exchange of the man’s freedom to the trader, in the Italian film the medallion adds a symbolic value related to the idea of nation building. The missionary is ready to give to the people from Ethiopia, even to a slave trader, his precious memory from his country, which is symbolized by the medallion. Gifting the necklace, even if after the trader’s insistent requests, is a metaphor for the fact that Ethiopia too could become a unified nation like Italy, with Italy’s help. As I mentioned above, the shots of this sequence show that Massaia does not vigorously refuse the trader’s request; at first, he says ‘No, questo non posso’. The trader is not satisfied by Massaia’s refusal and lifts his right arm, a sign that commands the slaves to leave. Massaia, then, says ‘Wait’ (author’s translation, 3:44) and gives him the medallion because he wants to free the sick man. While handing it to the trader he says to him ‘I hope it will make you a gentleman’ (author’s translation, 3:45). This sentence is indicative of the medallion’s symbology; it is an object that signifies ‘civilization’ and is linked to the history of the unified Kingdom of Italy.
Italian violence against the Copts provides a context for understanding the negative portrayals in the film. The 1937 massacre of hundreds of Copts at the hands of Italian officers obeying Mussolini and Marshal Rodolfo Graziani’s orders were recent history when filming began in 1938. The film does not address this history as it is set in an earlier period; however, the film offers a negative portrayal of the members of the Coptic Church, representing them as opponents of the Catholic mission that Massaia embodies. With Brunetta’s definition of the film as the first cinematographic narrative linking fascism and Catholicism in mind, one can understand the film’s negative portrayal of the Copts.
The Ethiopians resisted the Italian invasion both during and after the occupation was completed. There were several acts of rebellion against the Italian invader. Only a few months before the shooting for the film began, for instance, Italians accused members of the Coptic Church of supporting insurgents trying to overcome Italian rule by attempting to assassinate Marshal Rodolfo Graziani. Del Boca details that, after the attempted assassination of Graziani in Addis Ababa in May 1937, the retaliation was carried out over the next few days. Del Boca comments: ‘Obsessed with hatred, Graziani saw enemies and would-be assassins wherever he looked [. . .] he saw them in the Coptic deacons and monks of the monastery of Debra Libanos, 425 of whom were shot’.  A few days after the massacre, on 27 May 1937, the Minister for African Italy approved Graziani’s directive to execute Coptic priests in all parts of 
Ethiopia. 
Conclusions
This study began with the question of why two missionary films belonging to two different religious traditions, national cinema industries, and colonial histories, and released fifteen years apart shared a mutual colonial gaze on enslaved people and human trafficking. This essay scrutinized the two missionary films Livingstone (1925) and Abuna Messias (1938) and compared two specific scenes portraying a slave trader conducting a group of enslaved people to the slave market and the sudden intervention of the missionary to free one of the enslaved people.
The comparison of the two scenes reveals that the Italian film can be understood as an attempt to create an ‘Italian abolitionist tradition’ on the British model.  In Abuna Messias, slavery is represented as the main disease afflicting Ethiopia, one that the intervention of the Italian missionary Massaia can treat. Therefore, the film draws a link between the ideas of sickness and slavery. Like Abuna Messias, the British film Livingstone also portrays slavery through the representation of sickness through a scene representing a suffering, enslaved person treated by the British missionary David Livingstone. In this film as well as in the Italian one, then, maladies and disease are identified with domestic slavery. Both visual narratives offer a solution to treating this illness: British/Italian involvement.
The analysis of the interactions between different colonial subjects in the scenes under scrutiny is a helpful tool for understanding the different ways to create communities in the colonies that British and Italians were pursuing. Unlike the Italian Catholic film, in the British film, the slave trader is not characterized in a specific way and the payment that he receives from Livingstone for the slave, the exchange value for the freedom of the man, is cotton fabric. There is a symbolic meaning in the images of the cotton/man’s freedom exchange, as cotton was the product of British slavery, which was not legal anymore at the time of the film’s release. The film re-signifies the symbology of slavery that cotton conveys within the framework of the fight against domestic slavery.
Unlike the neutral portrayal of the trader in the British film, the Italian film frames the trader as a Muslim, and the buyer is also a Muslim. This antagonizing representation shows Muslims as profiting from human-trafficking. Similarly, the portrayal of members of the Coptic Church in other scenes of the film discredits a religious tradition that was widely practiced in the Italian African territories. These negative representations of Muslims and Copts contrast with Massaia’s portrayal as a savior of enslaved people; therefore, the film conveys the message that Catholicism is the religious tradition with the highest ethics and morality and, as Massaia and his fellow priest are the only Italians in the film, representative of Italy.
The choice of setting the plot in the past constructs a myth of origins. By creating this history of the empire, the film implies that the present condition of the Italian empire – the annexing of Ethiopia in 1936, three years before the film’s release – is the legacy of the past. This construction attempts to normalize the invasion of Ethiopia as an action that follows the course of history, a destined event that brings the benefit of the defeat of slavery.
This study has shown that the two missionary films analyzed here are essential primary sources for studying how missionary associations and colonial governments collaborated in constructing imperial imaginations. This work makes no claim to be exhaustive on the role of missionary cinema in creating imperial imaginations about human trafficking and shaping the colonial political agendas that missionary films followed.
