Durante la lunga diatriba, Ponti – esausto – finisce per rivelare la propria insofferenza per il contesto non all’altezza in cui Singer espone il suo lavoro (‘pensa a Knoll come cose, come presentazione estetica, come contorno di pezzi d’arte e di tessuti scelti. Non vende meno per questo’) e l’insoddisfazione per i tanti progetti modificati (‘sai perfettamente che solo le sedie Cassina, l’etagére Cremaschi a sei gambe e il tavolo tondo corrispondono a dei modelli intatti’).  In nome dell’etica artistica e della coerenza professionale, arriva a rifiutare le royalties per i mobili in cui non si riconosce; di questi andrà compensato solo il disegno, e dovranno essere venduti senza il suo nome.72
Intanto si è già messo al lavoro per Altamira, preparando una serie di modelli tra cui spiccano i ‘Murals’, composizioni di piccoli elementi a parete, portariviste, étagères, lampade, ecc.  Il primo luglio stipula con De Vroom un contratto per l’allestimento, con arredi di suo disegno e oggetti d’arte scelti da lui, del quarto piano nella sede della ditta al 10 East 54th Street (Figure 3); altri due piani saranno arredati da Parisi e da Melchiorre Bega, mentre il pianterreno accoglierà l’esposizione per la vendita. I termini dell’accordo, dettati da Ponti stesso, gli lasciano totale libertà creativa; Altamira s’impegna inoltre a ordinare ulteriori pezzi tra quelli dell’architetto proposti da Singer & Sons, e a menzionare nella pubblicità i ‘typical Ponti pieces’ di quest’ultima accanto ai ‘Ponti ‘d’exception’ della propria collezione. 
In pochi giorni i disegni per il quarto piano sono pronti, completi delle ‘finestre arredate’, che trasferiscono sul vetro composizioni simili a quelle delle pareti. Ponti è gratificato dalla prospettiva di una presentazione ‘totale’ del suo stile in un contesto scevro da associazioni commerciali, tant’è che vorrebbe aggiungere delle didascalie per dare ai mobili ‘un interesse intellettuale’ (nel 1954 penserà anche di trasferire da Altamira la mostra dedicatagli dall’Art Institute di Boston).  Insiste perché la realizzazione si faccia da Chiesa a Milano, dove può controllarla – ‘perché qui si tratta della mia espressione personale’ – e non a Bologna da Bega, come vorrebbe Altamira.76
Proprio a causa di Bega, che De Vroom ha coinvolto come designer oltre che come fabbricante, si aprono le prime crepe nel roseo edificio della sua collaborazione con Altamira. I modelli di Bega, di gusto pesante, gli sembrano totalmente inadatti al mercato americano. Non ne fa mistero con Van 
 
Figure 3. Gio Ponti, interno al quarto piano dello showroom Altamira, 10 East 54th Street, New York, 1954. Courtesy Gio Ponti Archives.
Hulzen (‘il rigore della mia presentazione sarà il correttivo indispensabile della intemperanza di forme, colori, materie di Bega, al quale non andava lasciata briglia sciolta’)  né con lo stesso Bega, che si sforza di persuadere a correggere il tiro:
hai completamente sbagliato scegliendo e pensando che quei tavoli colorati, ricchi, vistosi, compositi sieno [sic] quelli che ti possano far avere in America quel successo d’artista che ti meriti. Sono pericolosissimi [sottolineato nell’originale]. Mettili da parte e scegli invece espressioni castigatissime. Se è pensabile da qualcuno che gli americani del nord possano, per contrasto al gusto di Interiors del Museo of Modern Art, amare cose esuberanti e complicate devi tener conto che quelli che contano fra essi se anche aspirano a qualcosa di diverso sono educati da quegli ambienti e se apprezzano o cercano anche ciò che [è] rappresenta nuove personalità è però sempre in questo clima. 
A rinforzo dei propri incitamenti a sorvegliare il gusto, Ponti manda a De Vroom immagini degli arredi minimalisti della ditta Laverne, invitandolo a guardare ‘con che stile gli americani sviluppano i loro mobili. Se Altamira si vuole affermare bisogna che la sua scelta sia terribilmente esigente’.  Il concetto pontiano di gusto e ‘fantasia’, insomma, è abbastanza ampio da includere espressioni lontane dalla sua; non così quello di De Vroom, che rifiuta nettamente ciò che interpreta come strascico di un modernismo alla Mies ormai datato. 
Epilogo
Paradossalmente, Ponti si trova a svolgere nei confronti di Altamira un ruolo analogo a quello svolto da Singer verso di lui, di istigatore alla sobrietà e semplicità. Comunque, quando a gennaio 1954, sulla via di Caracas, fa tappa a New York a spese di De Vroom, la sua impressione della sede di Altamira è eccellente.  Domus la registra in marzo con un servizio di 12 pagine, nel quale trovano posto anche i mobili di Bega, ‘riformati’ per consiglio di Ponti.  È il momento di maggior sintonia con la ditta; la fiducia nel progetto è tale che gli altri architetti coinvolti vorrebbero costituire un ‘gruppo Altamira’ per realizzare iniziative comuni, compresa una partecipazione di squadra alla X Triennale (Ponti, avverso a ogni identità confederata, si adopererà per affossare l’idea del gruppo, mentre la partecipazione alla Triennale naufragherà in mancanza del sostegno del governo americano). 
L’entusiasmo comunque è di breve durata. A fine maggio arriva una doccia fredda: inaspettatamente, De Vroom annuncia il fallimento di Altamira, attribuendolo all’alto costo del lavoro, a uno sciopero dei portuali e ai conseguenti ritardi nelle consegne. La sede, con i lussuosi arredi di Ponti e colleghi, è stata venduta al proprietario dello stabile per coprire i costi. De Vroom minimizza il danno: liquidata Altamira Old Skills-New Forms, si è formata una nuova ditta, la Benavede Inc., che mantiene il marchio Altamira e che aprirà al 18 East 50th Street senza gli ambienti di Ponti e compagni (questi saranno – magra consolazione – riprodotti in gigantografia nei nuovi locali).84 Ponti, che ha appreso la notizia a New York, dove si trova per una settimana, si affretta ad avvisare le aziende e gli artigiani che hanno lavorato per De Vroom e che attendono i pagamenti. Questi alla fine arriveranno, non senza errori indicativi di una gestione finanziaria a dir poco superficiale (Chiesa si trova a restituire mezzo milione versatogli in più del dovuto). 
Il lancio di Altamira nella nuova sede, in ottobre, ha una discreta eco di stampa. Betty Pepis segnala la differenza rispetto a Singer, notando l’accento decorativo e la ‘linea barocca’ dei mobili Altamira, ‘non pre-selezionati per l’esportazione in America’ e più vicini alla produzione italiana per il mercato domestico.  La ditta aiuterà l’immagine del design italiano frivolo e ornamentale a resistere fino alla seconda metà del decennio: la ritroveremo ancora nella Guide to Interior Decoration pubblicata da Pepis nel 1957. 
In realtà, il divario tra gli arredi Singer e quelli Altamira è abbastanza tenue. Come aveva osservato Josef, la ‘scrivania Cremaschi’ venduta da Singer era dopotutto un esempio di ‘risky fantasy’ quanto la ‘scrivania Lucano’ venduta da Altamira;  (Figure 4; Figure 5) e c’erano pezzi che, come il tavolo tondo con piano di cristallo, Ponti aveva proposto a entrambe le aziende.  Ad assottigliare ulteriormente la distanza da Singer, dopo il tracollo finanziario De Vroom si vede costretto a rinunciare al lato più ‘exceptional’ del suo programma: si converte in parte alla produzione in serie e taglia i costi, sostituendo gli smalti di De Poli con la più economica verniciatura. o i rivestimenti in seta di Ferrari, troppo ‘fancy’, con altri più sobri;  chiede inoltre versioni ridotte dei mobili, per il pubblico femminile.  Di fronte alla reazione dei clienti, che tendono a trovare tutto troppo caro e troppo elaborato, comincia insomma a tirare il freno. Ponti, cui è rimasto in gola il nodo irrisolto del conflitto con Singer, non manca di fargli notare che è diventato impossibile mantenere la distinzione tra le due linee. 
A delusione segue delusione: oltre ai tardivi e faticosi pagamenti agli artigiani (che occasionalmente anticipa di tasca propria), Ponti trova le foto degli interni della 54th Street – sole vestigia del lavoro svolto – disastrose, il catalogo male impaginato (Figure 6),  la pubblicità non di suo gradimento.  Il tono delle lettere si fa gelido e dopo la primavera 1955 lo scambio si interrompe. ‘Mi puoi dire com’è finita l’impresa di Mr. De Vroom?’ scrive Ponti a Singer in agosto.  De Vroom, in effetti, si accingeva ormai a seguire altre passioni: le Ferrari e le corse automobilistiche, come co- fondatore del North American Racing Team e occasionalmente come pilota. Altamira si sarebbe concentrata sull’importazione di vetri di Venini e lampade, fino alla chiusura nel 1964. 
Prosegue invece il rapporto con Singer. Nel dicembre 1956 questi apre nel Fuller Building, tra Madison Avenue e la 57th Street, un nuovo showroom esclusivamente dedicato al moderno, con gli stessi designer del 1951, più Vito Latis. A curarne l’allestimento è ancora Schaefer con Kelly, ma stavolta Joe ha insistito per ‘un luogo che desse un senso di sole [. . .] un luogo di felicità che non sembrasse un monumento’.  I colori sono bianco, giallo e arancio e il tono generale, stando ai giornali, non è più ‘drammatico’ ma ‘caldo, rilassato e ad accattivante scala umana’.  Ponti esulta (‘Bianco e giallo sono colori Ponti [. . .] Josef è uscito dalla scura foresta nella luce del sole!’),99 anche se, a giudicare dalle foto, l’ambiente non era poi così diverso da quello della 19th Street.
 
Figure 4. Gio Ponti, scrivania per casa Cremaschi, 1948. Courtesy Gio Ponti Archives, Milano.
Sull’onda dell’ottimismo, Singer pensa a rinnovare il catalogo, e Gio risponde con entusiasmo: si sente in forma, ‘il periodo creativo di Ponti non è finito, comincia ora!’  Parla di allestire nello showroom un ‘angolo Ponti’,
[del] vero Ponti, con i mobili colorati in bianco e blu, con le nuove sedie Ponti ‘Superleggera’, con il gusto di Ponti negli oggetti d’arte, il gusto di Ponti in pittura [. . .] nei tappeti, nell’argenteria, nelle posate, nelle tovaglie, nelle poltrone, nelle stoffe ecc. ecc., senza limitazione [. . .] devi farlo per me, e per te. 
L’epistolario tace su questi sviluppi, mentre sulla stampa americana (e su Domus) dopo il 1956 la presenza dei mobili Singer si rarefà fino a scomparire. L’attenzione per Ponti viceversa si accentua, alimentata dalla visibilità di progetti come l’auditorium per Time & Life, la sede dell’Alitalia a New York e la torre Pirelli, ma anche dalla collaborazione con ditte come la Ideal Standard (sanitari) e Reed & Barton (posateria) e importatori come Murals, Inc. (ceramiche). Il focus della stampa non è più sul design per l’arredo: seguendo l’abbrivio preso a metà decennio, l’architetto è celebrato come genio attivo in tutti i campi e inesauribile vulcano di idee.  L’interesse destato dai mobili italiani 
 
Figure 5. Gio Ponti, scrivania per casa Lucano, 1952. Courtesy Gio Ponti Archives, Milano.
pare attenuarsi, a seguito da un lato del venir meno dell’effetto di novità, dall’altro dell’assimilazione da parte del design americano di alcune qualità che all’apporto italiano venivano associate: la fluidità di linee, l’effetto scultoreo, ecc. Il successo che nel 1952 aveva portato Singer ad aprire showroom a Cleveland e Houston è ormai lontano. Dopo ripetuti accenni al cattivo andamento degli affari, nel 1961 Singer comunica finalmente a Ponti la chiusura della ditta:
Ho cominciato a svuotare gli edifici e ho bruciato i tuoi disegni [. . .] Ho trovato una lettera scritta nel 1950[. . .] in cui dicevo che eri il più grande designer italiano e che ero sicuro che insieme avremmo fatto grandi cose. Bene, le abbiamo fatte caro Gio, e te ne sono grato e credo ancora nella grandezza di Gio Ponti. 
La vicenda Singer–Altamira si chiude per Ponti con un bilancio positivo in termini di immagine, e la collaborazione con le due ditte contribuisce in misura significativa al ruolo svolto dall’architetto 
 
Figure 6. Copertina del catalogo della ditta Altamira, 1954.
nella costruzione dell’identità italiana in America; tuttavia, l’immagine che di lui si afferma non corrisponde totalmente alla sua visione.
Per cominciare, l’idea di Ponti novello Leonardo si inscrive nella rappresentazione più generale del ‘nuovo rinascimento’ italiano sotto l’egida benigna degli Stati Uniti; una rappresentazione che l’architetto non approva. Per lui, l’exploit attuale nasce dalle premesse poste nell’anteguerra con le prime Triennali e con personalità come Persico e Pagano;  contro il mito della rinascita, sostiene un concetto di ‘continuità’ largamente diffuso in Italia,  ma condiviso solo da pochi in America. 
Ponti rifiuta ogni logica di gruppo, sottolineando l’individualità dei designer italiani. L’idea dell’individualismo italiano viene recepita in America, dove risulta funzionale a un mercato orientato verso il consumo di massa;  nondimeno, dipinto come carattere comune, l’individualismo finisce per costituire un contrassegno di gruppo, ed è contraddetto dagli stessi colleghi dell’architetto quando questi nel 1954 tentano, contro il parere di Ponti, di varare un improbabile ‘gruppo Altamira’.
Infine, Ponti insegue un equilibrio tra ricchezza decorativa e rigore progettuale; il suo ideale, l’abbiamo visto, è equidistante dallo stile vistoso di un Bega e dal purismo del MoMA. Questa immagine di equilibrio non viene però accolta se non in parte. Complice la collaborazione con Altamira, la rappresentazione del Ponti designer artigianale-decorativo dura fino alla seconda metà degli anni Cinquanta, sebbene contrasti – specie dopo il 1952 – con la relativa linearità di molti suoi modelli. Questo tipo di retorica serviva a sottolineare la subalternità dell’Italia, nel quadro di un più generale atteggiamento americano che tendeva a confinare le nazioni europee in un passato premoderno, al duplice scopo di redimerle dalla recente compromissione con i totalitarismi e di neutralizzarne possibili capacità competitive sul piano economico.  Da un lato, l’Italia viene relegata permanentemente in una dimensione di arcaismo e arretratezza, per quanto nobilitata dal mito della genialità creativa; dall’altro, viene femminilizzata attraverso gli stereotipi della frivolezza, capricciosità e inclinazione ornamentale.  Il Ponti-decorativo verrà solo da ultimo soppiantato dal Ponti-creatore universale; un passaggio che significativamente coincide con la definitiva transizione dell’Italia, a fine decennio, da Paese agricolo premoderno a nazione industriale.

***

‘Una verità totale’: The Textual and Visual Encounter With the 
Other in Franco Fortini’s Asia Maggiore. Viaggio nella Cina

This article explores the fine interplay between the literary and photographic media in Asia Maggiore. Viaggio nella Cina, Franco Fortini’s written account of his travels in 1955, published in April 1956 with Einaudi.1 The account tells of his first journey to communist China, between September and October 1955, together with two chapters detailing his trip to the Soviet Union, titled ‘Ricordo di Leningrado’ and ‘Ricordo di Mosca’. This was the first official visit of an Italian cultural delegation, of which Fortini was a member, to the People’s Republic of China (1949). It was organised by Ferruccio Parri and the new Centro studi per le relazioni economiche e culturali con la Cina (established in 1953) as a way to foster cultural and diplomatic ties between the two countries.2 The delegation was led by Piero Calamandrei and included amongst others Carlo Cassola (to whom the book is dedicated), Norberto Bobbio, Cesare Musatti, Franco Antonicelli, Corrado Pizzinelli.3 The group travelled around China solely by train, with the more prominent stages of their journey taking place in cities such as Beijing, Mukden (now 
Shenyang), Shanghai, and Hangzhou; in these cities the delegates met and interviewed a variety of Chinese citizens, ranging from peasant families to soldiers and party members, with intent to give them a voice and be able to refer to them as evidence of the post-revolution social change. The itinerary of the trip and all the meetings with Chinese people had been meticulously prepared and organised by the Chinese authorities, as was commonplace with this kind of diplomatic mission. 
One innovative feature consistent throughout Asia Maggiore lies in its photo-textual shape: the written diary of the journey comes with a selection of 17 photographic images, shot by Fortini himself and chosen from over 200 of his collected photos.  In order to understand the rationale of an author who mainly engages in poetry, translation, and critical writing, as well as his decision to publish a photo-textual travel account, it is necessary to summarise some of the biographical and historical facts of the time in which Asia Maggiore was written and edited. In 1955, Fortini and a group of other intellectuals founded the small journal Ragionamenti, a continuation of Discussioni (1949–1953), the main aim of which was to promote and discuss an alternative Marxist doctrine in the search for different and independent forms of expression. Ragionamenti in particular conveyed the voices of ‘dissident’ intellectuals who, like Fortini, pursued a ‘confronto antidogmatico tra i fondamenti del pensiero marxista e la più avanzata cultura scientifica, filosofica, letteraria dell’occidente borghese’.  One of Fortini’s aims at the time was to criticise the political and cultural line of Togliatti’s PCI, which aimed to pacify dissident intellectuals by consigning and gradually confining them to the role of specialists in arts and culture whilst excluding them from political office. Despite the fact that the Chinese travel journal was published before the Hungarian Revolution of autumn 1956, the years of Ragionamenti (1955–1958), as well as the years that followed 1948 Italy’s political elections with the victory of Democrazia Cristiana and the defeat of the left, had already seen the onset of Fortini’s intellectual and political disillusion; he became a salaried intellectual at Olivetti in 1947 and, after the publishing of Foglio di via (1946), the 1950s would bring a moment of poetic crisis resulting in Poesia e errore (1959), the fruit of ‘una fase di frustrazione e di attesa rabbiosa’.  The same period of crises (1947–1957) would result in the collection of essays titled Dieci Inverni (1957), reflecting the turbulence that arose at that time, including the Cold War and the Korean War.  It was precisely during this period of political and intellectual disillusionment that Fortini started to observe the situation in the People’s Republic of China (established in 1949) as the emergence of a new ideological and political landmark. He identified in Maoism some relevant ‘aspetti di novità e di rottura rispetto agli schemi del marxismo europeo’, as well as noting the surge in interest for Maoist China shown by the New Left and journals such as Quaderni rossi (1961– 1966) and Quaderni piacentini (1962–1984). 
Within this general context, the choice of a photo-textual travel journal may be seen as part of the search for new and different literary forms to approach intellectual problems. Fortini discusses and justifies the format of the travel journal in the introductory pages of the book, aptly titled ‘Giustificazione e conclusione’. His foreword is directed both to himself and to the reader as a means of self-absolution for writing a book mainly based on ephemeral ‘impressioni di viaggio’.  Fortini’s attempt in Asia Maggiore is in fact to write something significant about an Other whom he only met in passing, in the partially inauthentic form of ‘visite fuggevoli, fra turistiche e diplomatiche’.  His need to defend such work may perhaps come from the awareness of the insurmountable contradiction lying at the very core of it: as Edoarda Masi recounts in her afterword to Asia Maggiore: viaggio nella Cina e altri scritti, the 2007 re-edition of the book, the China he visited in 1955 was portrayed as a sort of imaginary country, which embodied a different path to socialism to that of the USSR and which more effectively epitomised the shared, collective spirit.  At the same time, the need to justify the publishing of a travel account may also be related to the relative low-status and marginal role of the travel writing genre in Italy. As a consequence of its associations with journalism, travel writing in Italy has in fact not always been considered a full literary genre.  From this perspective, Asia Maggiore, alongside the aforementioned special issue of Il ponte and Cassola’s own travel account on the Chinese journey, can be seen as one of the first attempts by an Italian intellectual to approach the ground-breaking phenomenon represented by Maoism and Maoist China. Other important travel accounts of professional writers on revolutionary China would follow, from Goffredo Parise’s Cara Cina (1966, during the Cultural Revolution) to Alberto Arbasino’s Trans-Pacific Express (1981), resulting from his 1980 journey to China within the first post-Mao Italian delegation, which included Luzi, Malerba, and Sereni.  Nevertheless, the new socialist China had its own cultural history and tradition that, for the Western imagination, represented the quintessential cultural alterity – the notion of the radical Other that had been discursively constructed by Western travellers over the centuries.  The dichotomy between the claim of objectivity in describing this alterity and the inevitable intrusion of the observer’s subjectivity, tied to his cultural roots and personal worldviews, is one of the greatest struggles Fortini faces in his attempt to write about China. The idea discussed in this article is that he chooses to openly show the contradictions between these two poles which lie in the juxtaposition between written text and photographs of the journey, as well as the combination of different literary genres, from the travel account to the partially autobiographical travel diary. The way in which this synthesis works is discussed both theoretically – by examining the nature of the photographic medium in its relation to the text and the mixing of different literary genres – and practically – by providing examples of the ekphrastic interaction of the two media in the depiction of colours and crowds. Broadly speaking, the main interpretation of Asia Maggiore and of its photo-textual form that will be suggested in the essay lies in its allegorical reading; in fact, the author himself suggests such an approach as he explicitly deters the reader from interpreting the book only as an ‘exotic’ travel journal, stating that ‘i motivi per cui la vita di popoli lontani ci dovrebbe interessare [. . .] non possono consistere che in quella parte destinata a toccarci direttamente’.  The allegorism of Asia Maggiore, which indirectly compares China to Italy, will be discussed through an investigation of the twentieth century’s notion of allegory and then through the discussion and interpretation of the frequent use of analogies.17
Implications of the Photo-Text and the Issue of Genre
The pairing of text and image does not come without contradictions. A constant doubt that can be detected by the reader throughout Asia Maggiore concerns the level of authenticity of the photographs and of the very medium of photography. On the one hand, photography appears to be the only art that can even approach the production of a fully denotative message; on the other hand, it is precisely because of this illusion of immediacy that it must be handled carefully.  While photographic images were at the time rarely presented as explicitly fictional, they could be used deceptively as part of a well-constructed lie.  The potential duplicitousness of the medium is highlighted by Fortini himself:
Era questa la Cina? Negli anni avvenire, se qualcuno mi avesse detto: ‘Com’è la Cina?’ avrei avuta nella mente una di queste immagini, paesaggi e persone fissati per sempre, falsi come istantanee. La Cina?20
Photographs can permanently imprint people and landscapes into one’s memory, regardless of veracity or reliability. The reason for such thoughts is explained by the writer in a paragraph notably titled ‘Fotografie’:
C’è sempre un atteggiamento di spedizione etnografica, in questa smania delle fotografie. [. . .] Ho in mente uno scritto di Italo Calvino contro la mania della fotografia; mi pare di ricordare che egli esagerasse per gusto di paradosso, ma certo la foto sottintende sempre un elemento di crudeltà e di distacco, è insomma uno dei modi più sicuri per far sì che l’altro sia ‘altro’, oggetto, cosa, forma. 21
One challenge inherent in white Westerners photographing people from Asian cultures is the inevitable ‘atteggiamento di spedizione etnografica’ tied to it – that is an ethnographic or even orientalist gaze that implies in its very existence an assumption of superiority and treatment of the Other as an object. Fortini himself alludes to Chinese people’s annoyance in seeing him and his comrades ‘puntare ovunque la macchina fotografica’.  It is interesting that Fortini uses the verb puntare, to point at, as though the camera were a gun that could actually hurt its subjects. A similar metaphor of the camera as a weapon is also used in Canton, where the local children ‘ci rivolgono sguardi e parole d’una allegria canagliesca, che disarma i nostri obiettivi fotografici’.23 Incidentally, the risk of objectification and mystification was especially valid in relation to revolutionary China due to the difficulty Western intellectuals faced in accessing reliable sources of information and the wider lack of well-established communication channels. 
Perhaps as a result of this paucity of information, the insertion of photographs into the Chinese travel journal was deemed necessary by the author as it functions as a proof of witnessing, as seen when Fortini describes the desolation of Shanghai’s Western districts; he writes: ‘tutto questo lo sapevo; ma bisognava vederlo’.  This witnessing aspect of the journey becomes fundamental to the traveller himself since he needs to see the Chinese reality directly; consequently it also becomes necessary to provide the reader with proof of having been there and to certify the veracity of the account, further confirmed not only by the 17 photographs in the book but also by the back cover image of the 1956 edition of the book, showing a portrait of Fortini in China. 
Another important question raised by Asia Maggiore is the one regarding the genre of the book. As already stated, the choice of the photo-textual form was relatively new in the Italian context, at least in relation to the work of writers and poets such as Fortini.  If the photo-text is a complex and mixed form in itself, then this is even more valid when applied to a genre, the travel account, that combines the search for an objective description of the new and distant country with features taken from autobiographical narratives.  In his overview of the history of the photo-text, Giuseppe Carrara includes Asia Maggiore in the proliferation of photo essays and of general encounters between non-fictional literature and photography published during the second half of the twentieth century. In his reading, this new expressive tool, which combines personal narratives with features of the account, is motivated by a common desire shared amongst non-fiction writers to narrate new places and unprecedented social contexts through a ‘terzo sguardo’ – a new gaze emerging from the coexistence of words and images.  The problem of the literary genre and of the hybrid nature of the travel journal had evidently been taken into account by Fortini, who discussed it once again in the introductory pages of the book:
Così argomentando, chi scrive cerca di giustificare un genere letterario – le impressioni di viaggio – che bene sa essere in contraddizione tanto con il suo lavoro consueto di scrittore quanto, obiettivamente, con la natura delle cose vedute [. . .] La relativa lontananza della Cina e la novità del suo regime e della sua rivoluzione consentono ancora una qualche ragione a queste pubblicazioni; e la presente non sarà inutile se addurrà qualcuno a includere nella propria mente l’esistenza di quel mondo.30
The travel journal, with its necessary convergence into diarism, becomes a useful resource as a testimony of a revolution happening in another part of the world. It is in this perspective that the hybridisation of the account with the autobiographical features of the diary shows its significance since, as Giuliana Benvenuti notices, ‘la tensione che anima la scrittura di Fortini è quella di far scomparire la distinzione fra pubblico e privato’.  In Benvenuti’s reading, Fortini accepts the diaristic feature of the travel diary since he views autobiographies as political acts, following Gramsci’s legacy, who wrote in his notes on autobiography:
Raccontando si crea questa possibilità, si suggerisce il processo, si crea lo sbocco. L’autobiografia sostituisce quindi il ‘saggio politico’ o ‘filosofico’: si descrive in atto ciò che altrimenti si deduce logicamente. 
Another important issue is that of a unifying language: one that can be both truthful and easily accessible and understandable to most readers, overcoming the problems of translation in linguistic and cultural terms.  Different points of view and doubts surrounding the issue of language are presented in Asia Maggiore through the constant dialogue between Fortini and his companion in the delegation, Fausto (actually Carlo Cassola); when Fortini calls into question the often hypocritical role of Marxist writers in the search for this supposed universal language, Fausto/Cassola argues:
Che cosa credi? Che non desideri forse di saper scrivere in modo che i più lontani da noi mi possano intendere? Ma il modo migliore è ancora quello di conoscere bene la mia provincia, il mio angolo d’Italia, quattro alberi, quattro case e quattro uomini. 
The character of Fausto/Cassola functions in some way as Fortini’s alter-ego, expressing doubts about the very likelihood of such a universal language existing, whilst Fortini himself cannot bring himself to abandon his search for ‘la via giusta, il punto d’appoggio, non soltanto in politica, ma in tutto . . . ’.  The ‘right’ way to communicate his understanding and reading of China may thus be seen in the juxtaposition between text and photography, as well as in the oscillation between the informative traits of the travel account and the more narrative and autobiographical passages in the diary. Arguably, the diary attempts to provide the reader with the most comprehensive and authentic depiction of the Chinese context. At the same time, the insertion of the narrative device represented by Fausto’s alter-ego allows the author to question, and dialectically discuss, his own doubts and beliefs, deliberately showing and therefore emphasising the relativity of his own individual positions.
Narrating the Images: Colours of China
As stated above, the aim of Asia Maggiore is not only to preserve witness testimony of revolutionary China, but also to provide a realistic and objective description of the places visited during the trip in order to substantiate the allegorical reading of the revolutionary country (which will be discussed in the last section of the article) with accurate, descriptive features typical of the travel account. Again, the documentary nature of the book can be seen primarily in its photographic element; the 17 images included in the volume represent primary evidence of the places that Fortini visited and of the people he met, from the views of landscapes and streets to the several portraits of individuals.
 
Figure 1. By kind permission of Centro Interdipartimentale di Ricerca Franco Fortini in “Storia della tradizione culturale del Novecento”.
 
Figure 2. By kind permission of Centro Interdipartimentale di Ricerca Franco Fortini in “Storia della tradizione culturale del Novecento”.
The first photograph (Figure 1), remarkably placed in the frontispiece of the book, also provides a fundamental and programmatic indication of the deep connection existing between the images as organised in the volume and the written text, since it portrays a small group of children consisting of three boys and a girl with black braids. As is observed in the next pages, children and girls with ‘trecce nere’ feature as one of the most recurring subjects of Fortini’s descriptions, often emerging from the crowd. The following two photographs, placed within the pages of the aforementioned ‘Giustificazione e conclusione’ (between pp. 16 and 17 of the 1956 version), are equally important: the first one (Figure 2) shows one of the doors of the Forbidden City in Beijing – the city described in the first chapter of the account – with people walking in the front and, again, with a child in foreground, whilst the second one is a medium close-up on a smiling girl, described in the caption as the manager of Beijing Imperial Park’s library. It is also worth reflecting here on the prominent role of the captions, which often perform a function that is not only informative but also narrative: two examples can be read under the images placed within the paragraph ‘Vigilia’ (in the Beijing section, between pages 64 and 65 of the 1956 edition). The caption to the first image, a medium close-up of a young girl with black braids, reads ‘Pechino. Si incontrano giovani madri, dalle lunghe trecce nere sulla tuta celeste, che spingono tra la folla la carrozzina di bambù’.  The following photograph, showing a scene from Beijing’s 1 October parade, is accompanied by the following lines: ‘Vigilia del Primo Ottobre. Venivano avanti, traballando sulle spalle dei portatori, immagini di Lenin, di Ciu En-lai o di Dimitrov, per essere scaricate in qualche piazzetta deserta che subito si affollava di innumerevoli bambini’.37 The presence of these captions is useful to reiterate the importance in photo-texts of what Cometa refers to as ‘retoriche dei parerga’ or paratextual elements, which play an essential role by complementing the images. 
Besides the insertion of photographic images, the other tool used to convey to the reader vivid and direct depictions of the Chinese scenes seen by Fortini is found in the frequent use of ekphrastic descriptions. From this perspective, the creation of verbal images serves to provide the reader with an accurate and rich depiction of the places and people described.  In particular, Fortini applies icastic writing through an extensive use of colours and chromatic descriptions to characterise both people and cities or landscapes. The pages of the book compose a miscellaneous and imaginative palette that enriches the narration whilst also functioning as a textual counterpart to the black and white photographs taken by Fortini. The accurate chromatic specifications complement the images to fulfil what Carrara calls the need for exactness in describing alterity and difference required by the mentioned 20th century’s photo-textual gaze on distant countries.  Throughout Asia Maggiore the reader can find an abundance of vivid descriptions of the places and cities Fortini visited, from Beijing’s ‘muraglie viola’ and courtyards ‘in pietra bianca con le gradinate bianche e pilastri vermigli delle aule’ to the ‘alberi rossicci o biondi’ in Hangchow; again, ‘tram grigioferro’ can be seen in the streets of Hong Kong, whilst in Canton ‘è diffuso sul fiume un crepuscolo rosa’.  The chromatic depictions become progressively richer, as in describing Hong Kong: ‘turchino il cielo, ocra gialla la terra, verde profonde le piante’.  A mine that Fortini saw is described as ‘non una voragine, ma come un taglio obliquo nella terra, multicolore: dall’ocra al verde degli schisti bituminosi, al rossiccio, al grigio, al nero del carbone’.  Furthermore, in Beijing during the parade for 1 October, Fortini notices ‘i veli leggerissimi delle bandiere – seta azzurra, verde, gialla, rosa, rossa’.  Some places are prominently distinguished by a single colour, such as the ‘polvere gialla’ marking the city of Mukden, or the incredible whiteness of Leningrad and of its train station, of which he describes his first impression as ‘luce bianca tra i fiori bianchi’.  The depiction of a singular site or scene can be even more specific, such as a fountain in Beijing’s Imperial Park containing
una varietà di pesci, questi obesi e verdi come rospi, quelli trasparenti come meduse. [. . .] hanno tutti le bizzarrie delle porcellane, maculati, picchiettati d’oro, striati, craquelés, cloisonnés, la maggior parte vermigli e dorati ma i più belli di color viola e azzurro, neri e argento, seppia e verde-tè. 
The presence in this segment of similes and enumerations shows the process (typical in travel writing) of instilling in the reader a ‘waterfall’ of sensations through the use of emphasis as a means to create an induced vision.  References to colours are even more impressive when the writer uses them to fix on the page the people he personally meets or just sees passing by; one vivid image for example is the ‘trecce nere’ of young girls, alluded to five times throughout the book.  The phenomenon is especially relevant in the descriptions of the clothes worn by people, such as the ‘pesca’ of policemen’s uniforms or girls dressed in ‘giubba turchina, camicetta bianca’; ‘tuniche color arancione’ of buddhist monks or ‘camicie bianche dei pionieri’ on a red terrace in Beijing during the parade for 1 October, with Mao greeting the crowd by shaking ‘il berretto grigio’; again, the ‘colore di terra bruciata delle uniformi’ of soviet soldiers and ‘agenti dal berretto nero’ in Hong Kong; ‘fazzoletti bianchi’ of young peasant girls and other ‘contadine vestite di nero con l’ampia frangia nera’ in Canton, together with omnipresent blue of the ‘giubba turchina’, the uniform worn by the Chinese population.  As seen with the policemen, soldiers, and monks, colours can be used as a metonym to symbolise the profession or status of people, such as workers in Hangchow who are ‘neri di fanghiglia’ or ‘i panni grigi della fabbrica e gli stivali neri della terra’. Furthermore, they can function as symbols for traditions and habits, as does the colour white in representing mourning: ‘due figure vestite di bianco, accanto ad un tumulo fresco, dov’erano piantate delle bandierine bianche’ or the mix of ‘bianco, pesca, argento, verde pisello’ to characterise the brilliant costumes of popular dances he saw in the streets for the parade of 1 October – besides the obvious abundance of Communist red flags (one is seen for example in Canton). 
An Experience of Choc: The Chinese (and Russian) Crowds
In addition to the attention to colours, there is also demonstrable linguistic precision and consistent effort to describe the crowds of China and Russia.  Fortini met many people throughout his entire journey, several of whom are featured in Asia Maggiore. Once again, the individual characters of Chinese peasants, workers, and party members whom Fortini met, as well as their importance as political individuals, are conveyed not only through the detailed descriptions of the delegation’s meetings with them, but also through the insertion of photographic portraits of single individuals, such as the Manchurian peasants’ supervisor shown in the paragraph ‘Draghi e melograni’ (Figure 3; in the Beijing section, between pages 80 and 81 of the 1956 edition) and the peasant at work depicted on the following page.
While Fortini was fascinated by individuals, he was even more astonished by the sheer enormity and prevalence of large, flood-like crowds of people in the Eastern city streets.  In Fortini’s depictions, these massive crowds are characterised in two ways: they are always compact – so much that they can occasionally be described as a single organism from which only smaller parts can emerge – and they are almost always miserable and poor. With regard to compactness, it is worth recalling that the modern crowd was a quintessential trope of modernist and late nineteenth- century literature, as outlined by Walter Benjamin in his influential aesthetic theorisation based on 
 
Figure 3. By kind permission of Centro Interdipartimentale di Ricerca Franco Fortini in “Storia della tradizione culturale del Novecento”.
his reading of Baudelaire. According to Benjamin, in Baudelaire’s literary experience, the confrontation with unprecedented masses of people walking in Paris produces a choc to the self that needs to be elaborated in poetic form by the author as a flâneur.  These new metropolitan masses were different from all those experienced before since they were amorphous; in Renato Solmi’s translation of Benjamin, ‘non è questione di nessuna classe, di nessun collettivo articolato e strutturato. Si tratta solo della folla amorfa dei passanti, del pubblico delle vie’.  This idea of the crowd as a soulless entity strongly impacting the writer seems to parallel that of Asia Maggiore, as can be seen in the crowd’s movements: ‘la folla muove verso le case’ in Canton or ‘la folla in salita verso la piazza Rossa’ in Moscow; the entry of masses of people to an exhibition in Moscow is described as overflowing: ‘poco dopo il nostro ingresso la folla si rovesciò, o, per esser più esatti, dilagò tranquillamente, ma sempre più fitta, in tutte le sale’.  The representation of the crowd as a river, flood, whirlpool, or anything water-related is particularly relevant: ‘la folla fa gorgo’ in front of a cinema in Hong Kong; one ‘fiume di folla’ literally invades Nathan Road in 
Hong Kong, looking like ‘un fiotto che sgorga dalle strade del quartiere del porto o vi ritorna’; again in Beijing Fortini sees ‘bambini a frotte, a fiumi’.  When not a metaphorical river, the crowd demonstrates traits of fluidity and density, such as in Hangchow, where Fortini finds himself stuck ‘nel magma della folla asiatica’ or in front of a ‘densa folla’ in Leningrad and Moscow.  Another way of depicting crowds in Asia Maggiore is by means of animal metaphors and similes: the image of the mass of people as a swarm or flock often occurs in the text, from ‘sciami di ragazze’ in one paragraph on Beijing’s streets notably named ‘La folla’ and ‘sciami di ragazzi’ in a school of Shanghai to ‘gregge tremante’ and ‘frotte di ragazzi’ in the streets of Canton; again in Shanghai, the masses of poor people ‘ti seguono senza far rumore sulle loro pantofole, come larve’.  Personifications of the entire crowd are present too, as when in Moscow Fortini sees ‘una folla fittissima e immobile, dove spiccavano i fazzoletti bianchi e le mani nodose delle contadine’, as if hands and tissues were a synecdoche for the body of the crowd.  Nevertheless one of the few notable occurrences in the text, whereby the crowd is not seen as a single unit but instead as a differentiated whole from which different personalities can emerge, is related to a reflection on class divisions in Beijing:
Si distinguono bene, in questa folla, i vari ordini della società cinese; un fondo, che direi antico più che vecchio, [. . .] di lavoratori sfiniti, animali da soma vestiti di stracci, che tirano carri o portano pesi; vecchie donne dai piedi ridotti a due monconi, che trafficano sulle soglie delle botteghe, fumando; un fondo umano fisicamente debole, come segnato dall’oppio, rassegnato. Ma da questo fondo, quasi senza transizione, l’ondata della generazione nuova: quella dei ‘quadri’ medi, funzionari, militari. 
In other words, the main distinctions that become visible amongst Chinese crowds are those related to the differences between poor and wealthier people. The second feature that characterises the crowds of Asia Maggiore is in fact their generally widespread poverty, which often emerges in opposition to the glamour of shop windows and rising consumerism. In his reading of Benjamin’s Baudelaire, Romano Luperini describes the shocked poet as ‘urtato di continuo dalla folla e dalle luci delle vetrine’.  Similarly, the choc of the crowd experienced by Fortini in Asia Maggiore is often intentionally accompanied by flashing lights of the growing consumerism and of shop windows, such as in Shanghai, in which he sees ‘filamenti al neon’ and ‘colonne illuminate degli ascensori’, as well as ‘un tumulto di luci e di folla’ in Nankin Road.  The poverty of the people reveals itself precisely in opposition to the flashiness of modernisation: the poet sees ‘portici affollati, negozi luccicanti, e una folla di miserabili’ in Hong Kong.63 The image of Shanghai’s Western Districts is particularly striking:
Si è come immersi in un turbine di cani e di stracci, dove, le carni, i capelli, i fili, gli stendardi laceri dei negozi, tutto si coagula si disfa e ribolle in una caldaia cieca. I corpi si addensano davanti alle gole buie dei negozi, non c’è angolo che non mostri una pupilla, un piede, una testa. Nell’acqua color pece di un canale si macerano imbarcazioni innumerevoli. Dove passi, ti penetrano migliaia di occhi beffardi e pungenti. [. . .] ma qui sono centinaia di migliaia di corpi premuti in una dissoluzione putrida, in qualcosa di informe e di lacerato, polvere, cenere, stracci. 
The crowd of miserable people is depicted as an enormous body incorporating flesh, hair, and banners of the shops and from which single parts (the pupil, foot, head, etc.) emerge again as a synecdoche. The use of a strongly connotative language (‘dissoluzione putrida’, ‘turbine di carni e stracci’, ‘stendardi laceri’, the verb ‘ribollire’), and of repetition through figures such as enumeration and chaotic accumulation, all contribute significantly, adding emphasis to the description. Nevertheless by ascribing a metaphorical dimension to the personified crowd, a secondary yet fundamental task is accomplished: to separate the writer from the subject, since Fortini watches the crowd or is watched by it, whilst never being part of it. He can be carried away – ‘ti senti portato dalla gente, senza che nessuno ti urti’ – or fascinated by the mass from afar; he can feel observed by it but is always integrally separated, much as photographers, are irremediably detached from their subjects as discussed previously. 
One last feature of the Eastern crowds highlighted by Fortini lies then in their silence and composure. This can be seen especially in the crowds of Beijing:
Nessun’altra folla cinese è, come quella di Pechino, composta e degna, fosse pur quella dei quartieri più miseri. Folla di ciclisti lungo i viali che paiono senza fine e che levano contro il bagliore dell’orizzonte la grigia parete d’una porta; folla di sfaccendati per le sale dei magazzini generali, folla dei tram, delle librerie, dei bazar. Ma folla tranquilla, senza chiasso, abituata a cose beneducate.66
The hammering repetition of the word ‘folla’, anaphoric in four of the five occurrences, helps the reader to visualise this vast mass of humans, all of whom remain calm and orderly in spite of their size. This idea of politeness and absence of noise in the Chinese crowd is strong in Fortini: at the Eastern Market of Beijing he meets a ‘folla silenziosa’, whilst the masses of poor people ‘guardano in silenzio’ the strangers; again in Beijing, he sees a ‘piccola folla tranquilla’. 
The (Ir)reducible Difference of the Other: Allegory and Comparison
As mentioned in the introduction, the final section of this article focuses on the allegorical reading of Asia Maggiore. Again, it is useful to start with a quotation from the book to contextualise the discussion:
Scetticismo e stanchezza. Persuasione che non sia possibile trarre da queste visite ufficiali se non impressioni, note di colore, giornalismo o autobiografia (e che altro sto facendo?), che sia impossibile toccare la realtà dell’uomo della strada, la condizione umana del cinese odierno. 
With these words Fortini begins a section notably titled ‘Un’ora difficile’, in which he expresses frustration and doubts the possibility of providing a faithful portrait of Chinese society and culture. If the allegorical value of the visit to China as a means of bearing witness to the Socialist Revolution is maintained, what the author faces here is the core issue of encapsulating the reality of ordinary people, as well as overcoming the biases of subjectivity and issues of translation (and also the highly formalised nature of the pre-organised meetings that the Chinese authorities scheduled for the delegation). Fortini’s need to substantiate the allegorical reading of Maoist China as an alternative revolutionary model – different to the Soviet precedent and with an apparently objective description of the country and its people – can be explained by referring to the general context of Western and therefore Italian political and cultural representations of Maoist China in the 1950s. As previously mentioned, the relative isolation and lack of media coverage of China made it difficult for Western politicians and intellectuals to obtain a reliable overview of the Chinese situation. Most Western interpretations of Chinese socialism were inevitably partial and flawed, oriented towards their own worldview.  In his later reflections on travelling to China, dated back to the 1970s, and in light of a second visit there in 1973, Fortini insists on the somewhat abstract significance that Western intellectual travellers tended to apply to socialist China:
In breve, si viene in Cina esattamente come negli anni cinquanta si andava in Russia: per ‘vedere il socialismo’. Ma il socialismo non si vede. Si vedono centrali elettriche e contadini al lavoro, realizzazioni scolastiche e balletti folkloristici, esposizioni industriali e sfilate, non i rapporti tra gli uomini. Questi ultimi li puoi intuire; ma la visita, turistica o politica che sia, non ti permette di comprendere i rapporti familiari, quelli all’interno di una scuola, di una fabbrica, di una organizzazione di partito. 
This later thought reinforces a tension prevalent throughout Asia Maggiore: the desire not only to emphasise the allegorical meaning of China as a revolutionary country, but also to investigate the actual ‘rapporti tra gli uomini’ and the social and cultural structures that have existed there since before the historical advent of socialism, with the aim of providing a realistic description of the country, as already discussed.
The tension in Asia Maggiore between the allegorical value of China for the Western intellectual and the more objective depiction of the country can be better understood by referring to Romano Luperini’s reading of two notions elaborated by Benjamin: the ‘contenuto di realtà’ and the ‘contenuto di verità’ of any critical writing.  These two categories are both to be placed into the framework of the twentieth century debate on the opposition between symbol and allegory. Whilst detaching himself from Lukács’s condemnation of the allegory in its ‘tendenza disantropomorfizzante’ and embracing Benjamin’s line of defence of it as the key form of modernity, Luperini reclaims the idea of writing as an allegorical act itself, due to its inherent duality.  The realistic literary composition is contradictory since ‘da un lato deve indicare un contesto reale ed è perciò legata alla oggettività della referenzialità; dall’altro si fonda su una convenzione che è arbitraria e soggettiva’.73 The objectivity of the referent (material content) and the subjectivity of the act, from which the content of truth has to be derived, are always inseparable in any text; this is also the case in Asia Maggiore, in which the partial gaze of the observer Fortini tries to acknowledge and thus provide allegorical meaning for the encounter with a different culture that exists in itself, outside and far from his eyes as an interpreter. The traveller Fortini observes the mentioned novità di rapporti between people, attempting to furnish this observation with an allegorical interpretation, valid for his historical presentation, in conjunction with objective reality. Fortini writes about the Chinese revolution as a ‘rivoluzione esemplare’, a precedent that Italy can take as a model for its own revolution.  To legitimise this model, he ties his allegorical reading to the reality shown by the photographs and the vivid descriptions in tandem between text and image so that the two media can substantiate each other. This vigilant attitude thus corresponds to what Luperini calls the ‘atteggiamento di sospetto’ or ‘ermeneutica del sospetto’, which means supplementing any reading of reality with an accurate investigation into any cultural, historical, social, and subconscious influences (the Marxian ‘insieme di rapporti sociali’ that informs it). 
Whilst photographs and vivid descriptions constitute the material content of Asia Maggiore, the interpretive element is found in the moments of explicit reflection, such as the aforementioned introduction and the paragraphs in which the contingent time of the narration of the journey is paused to allow for superstructured thoughts challenging the author’s own beliefs. An example is the paragraph ‘Un’ora difficile’, discussed previously, in which Fortini laments the fact that his position as a foreigner could have jeopardised the entire cognitive purpose of the journey. From the author’s own doubts to the debates with Fausto/Cassola, the overall question that underlies the construction of Asia Maggiore is as follows: ‘come raffigurare il mondo moderno?’.  If a partial answer has been found in allegorism, a central issue remains unsolved. The alterity represented by the Chinese cultural and historical heritage is felt to be so radical that the author simply does not have the vocabulary to approach it. Nevertheless, besides the insertion of photographs, another attempt is still made to convey on the page the perceived radical alterity of the Other through words. In particular, the description and narration of the differences between the cultural horizon of the observer Fortini and the reality of the Chinese domain that he is discovering often relies on the figure of comparison. As outlined by Sergio Bozzola regarding accounts and diaries from fifteenth- and sixteenth-century travellers, comparison is a key device in all travel writing, since it represents ‘il luogo dell’incontro fra l’alterità e l’orizzonte culturale noto allo scrivente e al lettore’, especially in the form of a ‘comparazione traduttiva’, aimed at reconnecting the unknown to a known perspective so as to provide a cultural framework shared by authors and their readers.  Likewise, Eric Leed in his The Mind of the Traveller: From Gilgamesh to Global Tourism mentions comparison as the most common rhetorical device present in travel accounts and reports, tracing his statement back to Antonello Gerbi’s studies of Renaissance voyages to the New World. According to Leed, comparison operates as a cognitive tool that dilutes the anxiety caused by the encounter with the strange and unfamiliar, which is unfamiliar by the very virtue of its relationship with the known. 
In Asia Maggiore a form of translation-like comparison serves a renewed political and social purpose: to connect the misery of China to that of Italian working classes and neighbourhoods in light of a shared solidarity amongst parallel communities worldwide. In his later essay ‘Le chinois, ça s’apprend’ (1962), Fortini stresses the importance for Western intellectuals to educate themselves and try to understand the reality of socialist China, overcoming the erroneous presupposition that a mediation between ‘them’ and ‘us’ is not possible:
Per interessarsi alla Cina (o al Terzo Mondo: cioè per studiare, leggere, discutere, pretendere che gli strumenti di informazione se ne occupino, svergognare i nostri eminenti socialisti e i nostri permanenti comunisti che balbettano o tacciono o parlano mitologicamente) la condizione prima è di essere persuasi che la realtà, per comodità di espressione ed ellitticamente, da noi chiamata la «Cina», è determinante sulla qualità della nostra intelligenza, [. . .] insomma della nostra vita, allo stesso modo, cioè qualitativamente, in cui lo è la lotta dei metallurgici italiani. 
In the 1963 essay ‘Le mani di Radek’, discussed above, Fortini outlines the simultaneity of all struggles, in the idea that ‘l’operaio cinese, il negro minatore del Sudafrica e l’insorto contadino peruviano non sono il nostro passato. Sono il nostro presente’.80 It is from this perspective of proximity and simultaneity that the significance of comparison in Asia Maggiore can be seen. In light of the shared struggle of the poorer working classes, the face of a worker in Shanghai becomes ‘tanto simile a tante facce delle nostre parti, di quelle che incontri in un cantiere, in un mercato, a un distributore di benzina’; the districts of Leningrad are ‘squallidi, le facciate scrostate, cadenti, come quelle della maggior parte delle case milanesi subito dopo la guerra’; in Leningrad’s House of Books ‘c’era movimento di gente come da noi ai Grandi Magazzini. La gente usciva con i libri sottobraccio come da noi si compra il giornale’.  The comparison can also be adjusted through the use of correctio, such as in a description of the streets of Canton, in which what can be seen is ‘non la putrefazione dei quartieri dell’Ovest a Shanghai, ma uno squallore molto simile a quello di certe vie di Genova, di Palermo o di Napoli’.  These forms of comparison are used in Asia Maggiore as analogic figures as a means to address the existence of a similarity of relationships between the elements of the comparison.  The comparability between the Chinese and Italian working classes can be expanded so that it exceeds the realm of analogic similarity to become a relationship of identity, as described in the encounter with a janitor in Shanghai:
I corridoi, le pareti spoglie, le grandi vetrate, il brusio che viene dai piani superiori, tutto ricorda le scuole nostre; anche il bidello che ci versa l’acqua del tè è uno dei nostri 
The communion between Italian and Chinese working classes, embodied in the figures of peasants and mainly divided by the mentioned issues of language and translation, is made explicit in a thought Fortini formulates in Mukden:
L’Italia non pare tanto lontana; e veramente vien fatto di pensare che questi contadini e nostri si intenderebbero benissimo e subito fra di loro, solo che non li dividesse il linguaggio, tanto simili sono i problemi e le abitudini.85
Comparable figures can then be used to outline not only the similarity between the working classes, but also to highlight the common signs of modernisation and westernisation, such as in the example of the commercial district of Shanghai, which is ‘in tutto simile a quello d’una nostra città moderna, banche, palazzi, alberghi, uffici’. 
Notably, the use of comparison and the vivid depictions of colours and crowds can also be interwoven to describe particularly striking scenes, such as the market in Beijing:
Al quadrivio del Mercato Orientale, come a Charing Cross, ti senti portato dalla gente, senza che nessuno ti urti. Un formicolio più o meno blu, dove s’inseriscono i toni grigio sabbia dei funzionari, quelli pesca dei poliziotti, qualche giubba di seta femminile, qualche lungo gabbano di taglio antico, le calzette a vivaci colori delle ragazze, i fiocchi rossi e verdi dei bambini. 
As mentioned before, the entity of the crowd pulls the writer into the midst of it whilst keeping him separate. At the same time, the addition of chromatic specifications contributes to the exactness and vividness of the portrayed image, whilst the use of comparison reconnects the Chinese scene with a more familiar setting.
Conclusions
The importance of applying techniques of both the travel account and photo-text has been addressed throughout this article. It is a means of analysing and describing a conceptually and literally new country whilst providing evidence of the journey and of Chinese social reality. It also helps to preserve and share the allegorical value of the Chinese revolution as witnessed by Fortini during his travels; this allegory, within the photo-textual format, considers the significance of the gaze and therefore a cooperation between the writer/ photographer and the reader/viewer in providing mutually accepted clarity of the subject.88 Images compensate for missing words and vice versa, in a mutual dialogue that tries to make the reality of the Chinese world and its allegorical meaning as self-explanatory as possible. Furthermore, the choice of the photo-textual account also represents, as stated before, an attempt to find new forms of expression. From this perspective, it is interesting to note that Einaudi published Asia Maggiore, as well as other Italian photo-texts from the second half of the twentieth century, in the series ‘Saggi’ – a miscellaneous collection of texts of different natures. This can be interpreted as confirmation both of the ambiguous nature of the photo-text itself and of its innovative status in the Italian post-World War 2 literary landscape.

***

Reflections on the ‘Trans’ in Jhumpa Lahiri’s In
Other Words (In altre parole)

Disciplinary Mobilities
In a recent themed number of Italian Studies focusing on the state of the discipline, Charles Burdett, Nick Havely and Loredana Polezzi invite scholars to consider established anglophone author Jhumpa Lahiri’s translingual work In altre parole (2015) in a transnational and translational framework.1 To be more precise, they invoke the author’s ‘Italian novel In altre parole and its subsequent appearance as In Other Words’.2 This invitation to work on a translingual text and its English translation has implications at institutional and infrastructural levels: who, with what scholarly credentials, is entitled to publish on this text? In what sort of academic outlets? With what accompanying metatextual commentary? First then, a disclosure: I am working from the English translation of Lahiri’s text, as I am not an Italian Studies scholar and am unable to read ‘the original’ with any degree of competence. Perhaps, following Lahiri’s wistful assertion that she can write in Italian but cannot be an Italian writer, I might say that with the Italian text set facing Ann Goldstein’s English translation, I can read in 
Italian (after a fashion) but cannot be an Italian reader.3
My interest in In Other Words began in the classroom when I included the text on an undergraduate Comparative Literature methodologies module, in a teaching block which I entitled 
‘Mother Tongues and Fatherlands’.  Students read Lahiri’s text alongside theories of the transnational and critiques of the concept of a ‘mother tongue’ or ‘native speaker’.5 Discussions of the latter and of translingualism came naturally to a class typically composed of a mixture of monolingual students, heritage language speakers and a few modern linguists. Such discussions were a natural extension of a range of language issues familiar to Comparative Literature students: the longstanding, evolving relationship between our discipline and Translation Studies; the pros and cons of reading in translation; the benefits of comparing published translations; changes in technology and marketing leading to the production of ‘born translated’ texts6 – to name just some topics students are likely to have encountered in the course of their degree programme. The need to think beyond the nation – especially the European nation – was also familiar, whether via students’ exposure to postcolonial theories, theories of reception and the circulation of texts, or the shifting formulations of World Literature. For the students, ‘the transnational’ was readily subsumed into the magpie discipline which is Comparative Literature.
My own interest extended further, to disciplinary matters: Italian Studies, it seemed, was engaging in the sort of self-reflexive disciplinary soul-searching for which Comparative Literature is renowned.7 Burdett’s and Polezzi’s discussion of the need for ‘intellectual cohesiveness’ when ‘that which constitutes the object of study and the lens through which we see it do not stay still’;8 
Burdett advocating a shift from a ‘Modern Languages’ paradigm to ‘Languages, Cultures and Societies’; Emma Bond pointing to ‘the specifically interdisciplinary possibilities’ for Transnational Italian Studies  have a familiar ring for comparatists. Similar issues can be traced through the decennial ‘State of the Discipline’ reports published by the American Comparative Literature Society. As early as the first report of 1965 comparatists were being invited to reflect on the relationship between comparative literature and other disciplines such as ‘psychology, sociology, and anthropology’.  By the time of the latest report to date, Ursula Heise was enumerating the many links between Comparative Literature and ‘x studies’ and ‘y humanities’ and the role it has to play in ‘emergent interdisciplinary humanities’.11
Comparative Literature is a mobile discipline with loosely patrolled borders. Comparatists travel to and from other disciplines with ease, albeit perhaps with periodic moments of anxious self- reflection. To what extent, I wondered, had a transnational approach to Italian Studies broken down ‘the stubborn defence of disciplinary borders’ – to cite an Italianist – when it came to publication infrastructure?  My first objective is (was) a performative one: to publish this article in an Italian Studies journal rather than in other possible outlets whose reviewers would not flinch at my lack of Italian (Comparative Literature, Transnational Studies, etc). It follows that my analysis of Lahiri’s In Other Words serves here as a test case. My second objective lies beyond the bounds of the article and is simply to promote more disciplinary discussion with comparatists. Finally, Lahiri’s text is a case study as well as a test case: my third objective is to determine whether, and how, this work, cited in several contexts as transnational (see below), merits the prefix.
Trans as Prefix
The prefix ‘trans’ has gained considerably in critical, politicised force in recent years. According to Jessica Berman, who is citing Susan Stryker’s call for the ‘disruptive potential’ of the prefix to extend beyond gender to other ‘critical crossings of categorical territories’: 
When we use the prefix ‘trans’ to mean not just ‘across, through, over [. . .] or on the other side of’ but also ‘beyond, surpassing, transcending,’ it represents a challenge to the normative dimension of the original entity or space, a crossing over that looks back critically from its space beyond. 
This stance is increasingly widespread. Berman’s influence, for instance, can be seen in Kai Wiegandt’s The Transnational in Literary Studies, which includes the statement that ‘Berman is right to argue that the prefix “trans-” in “transnational” must be understood in a strong sense’ (by which he means with a critical force which questions the concept of the nation).  With Burdett et al. and Berman in mind, and drawing also on Paul Jay’s introductory Transnational Literature: The Basics, my first reflection on the trans in In Other Words will consider just some of the issues at stake in deciding whether the text qualifies as transnational.
Berman’s piece intertwines gender and nation, urging us ‘to recognize that any discussion of world or transnational literature must also attend to the assumptions of embodiment and gender identity that are attached to the concept of the nation’.  Berman’s choice of primary texts – which include Woolf’s Orlando, Russ’ The Female Man and Morris’ Last Letters from Hav – clearly facilitates the link between nation and gender.  Lahiri’s In Other Words, by contrast, has no transgender or explicitly gendered agenda. My discussion will nonetheless introduce two more trans-prefixed words, transgender and transvestite (crossdressing):  the former proves useful in examining the implicitly gendered nature of Lahiri’s representation of the relationship between language and nation whilst the latter allows me to consider the significance of wearing ‘the wrong clothes’ in In Other Words. The edition of the text I am working with has been published with a facing translation produced by a third party (Ann Goldstein) who is translating into Lahiri’s dominant language (English).  Translations also appear as both textual and paratextual concerns. For these reasons, translation is added to my list of trans-prefixed terms subject to reflection.
As Lahiri’s first book-length work written in Italian, In Other Words demands to be read with close attention to style. This is a highly – some might say excessively – figurative work which bears out Claire Kampf’s observation that metaphors are commonly used by language learners when they seek to articulate personal experience.  Metaphor, too, is a trans word. It finds its roots in the Greek ἡ μεταφορά, meaning a carrying across or change of place, mind, condition, as well as simply ‘metaphor’ (making metaphor a metaphor). The metaphors in In Other Words are instances of linguistic carrying across (between vehicle and tenor, or source and target domain) used to convey the author’s experiences. For this reason, the reflections that follow will focus on Lahiri’s use of figurative language.
A word about process: to acknowledge my working reality, and contrary to normal practice in an Italian Studies journal, I will be citing the English text first, with the Italian in a secondary position, though in fact the notion of ‘secondary’ or ‘subsequent’ may need to be revisited. I will not be quoting from critical material written in Italian: although I could enter such texts into Google Translate or DeepL Translate, or perhaps ask ChatGPT for a summary, this would, I suggest, run counter to the spirit of disciplinary mobility I am invoking here.
Transnational
Lahiri’s work is certainly a draw for those seeking to apply the transnational label, but the term is far from stable, and the context of its deployment varies. For Burdett, Havely, and Polezzi, writing in Italian Studies, expanding the concept of Italian culture is key: the latter should be regarded as extending beyond ‘the space of the nation’ and ‘the Italian language’. Their agenda is unapologetically disciplinary: it is Italian Studies itself which should be conceived as ‘a transnational and translational space’.  Researchers and teachers are thus encouraged to consider Lahiri’s text within the figurative territory of Italian Studies:
To complicate the map even further, we may look at the impact of translingual writers who adopt Italian as their language of choice, from recent migrant writing to the case of Jhumpa Lahiri, her 2015 Italian novel In altre parole and its subsequent appearance as In Other Words (2016), a volume which includes both the original text and its English translation’. 
Spatial metaphors of this kind (‘space’, ‘map’) can also be found in the subtitle of the article’s conclusion – ‘Directions of Travel’ – and, notably, in the repetition of the phrase ‘transnational turn’, which is used five times, both with and without scare quotes.  Judith Surkis notes that the metaphor of the turn ‘implies a change of course or direction, a turning away from at the same time as a turning towards’.  Both the figurative language and, especially, the repetition, have a performative as well as a descriptive function: the expansion of the boundaries of Italian Studies territory is both naturalised and validated by mobilisation of the metaphor of the turn. As Surkis suggests, turns ‘might be better understood not as historically inevitable disciplinary trajectories, but as specifically located, imaginatively cast, at once multiple, overlapping, and dynamic constellations’ permitting ‘untimely’ thinking.  With this in mind, it is important to remember that Lahiri’s In Other Words can be categorised as something other than a transnational work; it may be desirable – to switch metaphors – to opt for a less recent, less fashionable label.
As the cover blurb of Lahiri’s text summarises, this is not a novel (as Burdett et al. describe it) but ‘an autobiographical work’ which ‘investigates the process of learning to express oneself in another language’. It might thus be analysed as an instance of ‘language learner narrative’ as theorised by Helen O’Sullivan in relation to twenty-first-century texts, or, going back further in categorising terms, a ‘language memoir’, following Alice Kaplan, who ‘found’ (and the language of discovery hints at the colonising impulse of all acts of academic categorisation) ‘an entire genre of twentieth- century autobiographical writing which is in essence about language learning’.  O’Sullivan differentiates her objects of study from Kaplan’s by noting that where the latter looks to works detailing ‘the relationship to a language and its role in memory and identity formation’, the narratives she identifies, which may be segments of text or entire texts, ‘are more concerned with language as an object in its own right’; where the language memoir captures the ‘experience’ of language learning, language learner narratives centre on ‘process’.27 In Other Words dissolves this distinction. Lahiri dwells at great length on her identity, which she expresses most often in terms of a fracture born of her experiential relationship with Bengali and English which is at least partly healed by her learning of Italian. At the same time, In Other Words declines a range of language learning processes, from using and reading with a dictionary (pp. 7–11, 41–45), to acquiring vocabulary (pp. 47–51), to mastering (or not) the vagaries of the imperfect tense (pp. 103–13).
This is not, however, simply a case of a language memoir interspersed with segments of language learner narrative. Lahiri’s prose is densely figurative, drawing most notably on the tropes of both familial and romantic love. Using a dictionary thus shifts from being an experience of parental supervision to one of fraternal companionship (p. 11); reading with a dictionary is nothing less than being in love, arousing longing and even ecstasy (p. 45); acquiring and noting down new vocabulary is likened to carefully recording the weight of the author’s growing babies (p. 51). Even passages which focus in detail on how and when to use the imperfect are expressed in experiential terms: transferring the epithet from tense to self, Lahiri states ‘I feel more imperfect than ever’ (‘mi sento imperfetta più che mai’); and, ‘The more I feel imperfect, the more I feel alive’ (‘Più mi sento imperfetta, più mi sento viva’) (pp. 112–13). 
Thinking about In Other Words in relation to Kaplan’s and O’Sullivan’s descriptors could usefully prompt a reconsideration of both the language memoir and language learner narrative genres, though that is not my concern here: the point was rather to break from the potential foreclosing of the ‘turn’ metaphor which could risk setting up the transnational as a superseding paradigm, a definitive turn away from previous scholarship. One approach need not preclude the other, though, as Surkis’ image of overlapping and dynamic constellations makes clear.  Lahiri’s text can undoubtedly be read as a new form of – let us call it a language learning memoir but is it, in fact, also transnational? Like Burdett et al., Paul Jay, in his introduction to transnational literature, teasingly ponders the status of In Other Words: ‘How are we to categorize her [Lahiri’s] writing in Italian translated into English?’ (a question he does not answer).30 Jay pinpoints a crucial tension at the core of the label ‘transnational’, suggesting that it denotes both what he calls a ‘field of study’ and ‘a type of literature’. As a field of study which focuses on ‘how forces of movement operate’, any text can be said to have transnational potential: one need only consider, say, the flows of reception and circulation, trace shifting marketing strategies in different countries, or the movement facilitated by translation, and indeed one section of Burdett et al.’s ‘The Transnational/Translational in Italian Studies’ consists of a discussion of the reception of Dante. It is hard to see how such analyses differ from Comparative Literature work on the reception and circulation of texts, or indeed studies of World Literature: it is tempting to ask what the label ‘transnational’ adds in this case. Jay, aware of the need to better narrow and define the field, in fact opts for what he sees as the more viable definition of transnational literature; that is literature defined not by methodological approach – what both Berman and the editors of the Transnational Modern Languages handbook call an ‘optic’, which can potentially be directed towards any text, or indeed, ‘question or experience relating to languages and cultures’ – but by objects of study.  Transnational literature is thus literature which engages a broad range of issues and subjects (migration, displacement, exile, the fluidity of borders both literal and figural, cultural hybridity, identity and citizenship, the status of refugees, etc.), which have become pressing in our own time. 
Judging by this (somewhat oddly parenthesised) list, In Other Words seems at first glance to fit the bill as a transnational text: not only does it explore the author’s troubled identity; it also ‘engages [. . .] the subject’ of both migration and exile. In their call to expand Italian Studies, Burdett et al. clearly associate Lahiri’s text with migrant writing – both, they suggest, potentially fall under the disciplinary remit of Italian Studies – whilst simultaneously registering a distinction (‘from recent migrant writing to the case of Jhumpa Lahiri’). Rebecca Walker, for her part, observes without pursuing the fact that Lahiri is not a migrant in any literal sense of the term.  Notably, in each case it is the author who is referenced and not the text, a conflation which could be misleading: after all, authors who are migrants are not obliged to write about migration. In fact, Lahiri is not a migrant, nor does she write of migration or exile in In Other Words in the manner suggested by Jay’s parenthesised list. The text tracks the author’s literal movement but only figurative migration from the US to Italy, a relocation which is freely chosen, interrupted then resumed (the author returns briefly to the US) and temporary (the author’s stay in Rome lasts two years).
The gap between figurative and literal migration is starkly, if unintentionally, emphasised from the outset of In Other Words, which opens with a chapter entitled ‘The Crossing’ (‘La traversata’). This is not, however, the perilous undertaking of those crossing the Mediterranean (very much part of the ‘issues which have become pressing [. . .] in our own time’, to recall Jay’s words),34 but a small lake which transmutes into the first metaphor Lahiri uses to describe her language learning experience. Drawing a distinction between types of mobility is, I discovered, central to much recent work in Italian Studies, whether expressed, for instance, as a distinction between an elite class of academics and those designated ‘undesirable’, or the difference between tourists and migrants, ‘those who move by choice and those who are moved by force’.  Were readers of In Other Words to have actual (literal) migrants in mind, the dissonance of Lahiri’s language might shock: of learning a new language we are told that ‘you can’t float without the possibility of drowning’ (‘Ma non basta galleggiare senza la possibilità di annegare’), and ‘To know a new language, to immerse yourself, you have to leave the shore.
