I componimenti redatti dal Berni includono l’epitalamio intitolato ‘Il Tebro, ovvero la Pittura Loquace del Pittor Muto’, dedicato al ritratto di Beatrice Tassoni Estense eseguito per l’occasione da Ercole Sarti. Berni rivolge al pittore rodigino versi entusiastici, celebrandone le doti da ritrattista e deponendo a favore della fama da lui acquisita come pittore di ritratti per la nobiltà estense.
Sparge muto pittor color loquace, / Cui non ebbe già mai pari l’Egitto;/ Porta il nome e ’l valor di quell’audace, / Onde il mostro Lerneo giacque sconfitto: / E, dando vita altrui, s’ei morte dava, / Col suo dotto Pennel vince la clava. / Questi con opra tal felice ladro / A Beatrice il volto avea rubato, [. . .]. La tua lingua è ’l pennello, e la favella / Sono i tuoi color loquaci onde dipingi. [. . .] E, mentre i color tuoi mesci, e confondi, / Col tuo saggio pennel puoi far più mondi.
Laddove Ercole Sarti svolse la sua attività nei centri di Ficarolo e Ferrara, la vicenda artistica di Giuseppe Badaracco si caratterizza per una dimensione geografica più ampia. Nato nel 1605 da un’agiata famiglia genovese, Badaracco fu supportato nelle sue scelte professionali da parenti e amici.  Un documento datato 1619 lo ricorda quattordicenne come apprendista nella bottega di Bernardo Strozzi, presso la quale apprese i rudimenti della pittura.  L’influenza dello Strozzi è riscontrabile nella Disputa di Gesù con i dottori al tempio (Figura 4), apparsa di recente nel mercato antiquario genovese e da considerarsi come prima opera conosciuta dell’artista. In essa il giovane Badaracco mostra un interesse per la pittura di tocco assimilabile a quello del proprio maestro, il quale, alla fine del secondo decennio del Seicento, aveva sviluppato un’affinità per questa particolare tipologia di pittura non finita grazie a contatti, stabiliti presso la casa del collezionista genovese Giovanni Carlo Doria, con il pittore milanese Giulio Cesare Procaccini.  Raffaele Soprani ricorda che dopo aver lasciato la bottega dello Strozzi, Badaracco fu posto sotto la tutela di Giovanni Andrea Ansaldo e intorno alla metà degli anni Venti si trasferì a Firenze, dove ebbe l’opportunità di studiare le opere di Andrea del Sarto e dei contemporanei Matteo Rosselli e Jan Bilevert.  Attestato da un disegno a penna e inchiostro bruno raffigurante la Vergine con il Bambino e santi (Gabinetto Disegni e Stampe degli Uffizi, Firenze), il soggiorno fiorentino di Badaracco evidenzia similitudini con l’educazione pittorica del sordo prelinguale spagnolo Juan 
 
Figura 4. Giuseppe Badaracco, La disputa di Gesù con i dottori al tempio, 1625–1635, olio su tela, 69 × 94.5 cm, collezione privata.
Fernández de Navarrete, il quale, grazie al sostegno economico della famiglia, trascorse un lungo periodo di studio in Italia. 
Badaracco fu un artista versatile, in grado di adattare lo stile e il tono della sua pittura alle diverse esigenze della committenza. Nell’ambito della pittura religiosa, egli fu esponente di quel manierismo controriformato favorito dagli scritti di Carlo e Federico Borromeo e assimilato dalla pittura genovese nei primi decenni del Seicento grazie ai contatti con artisti lombardi quali i fratelli Procaccini, il Cerano, e il Morazzone. Questi elementi, apprezzabili nel didascalico Miracolo della mula completato nel 1655 per la chiesa di San Matteo a Borghetto Santo Spirito, cominciano ad emergere già a partire dall’inizio degli anni Quaranta del Seicento nella pala con la Vergine e San Giuseppe che intercedono per le anime del Purgatorio (Figura 5), eseguita per la Cattedrale di Bastia.  Ispirata da modelli compositivi rintracciabili nella Madonna e santi che liberano le anime del Purgatorio (Galleria Nazionale, Parma) registrata negli inventari della collezione di Giovanni Carlo Doria e completata all’inizio del Seicento dal pittore toscano Pietro Sorri, maestro di Bernardo Strozzi, la pala del Badaracco si caratterizza per il linguaggio aneddotico e un’espressività che risulta tuttavia indebolita da una modesta rappresentazione delle volumetrie dei corpi.  L’opera, una delle tante eseguite dal pittore in Corsica, dove giunse a seguito dell’invito di familiari, ebbe un notevole influsso sullo sviluppo dell’arte corsa tanto che nei secoli successivi ne furono ordinate copie da artisti locali. A tal proposito, riproduzioni settecentesche realizzate da Marco Antonio de Santis sono riconoscibili nelle chiese parrocchiali di Moltifao e Ville di Paraso; una copia eseguita nel diciottesimo secolo da Severino Farinole è conservata a Meria; mentre una replica databile alla metà del diciannovesimo secolo fu dipinta da Luigi Brunetti per la chiesa di Palasca.58
La pittura di Giuseppe Badaracco si caratterizza per le espressioni eloquenti, quasi didascaliche, la gestualità movimentata, e una particolare attenzione nella rappresentazione di tessuti: un possibile retaggio del suo trascorso fiorentino. Il suo approccio, prettamente descrittivo, è 
 
Figura 5. Giuseppe Badaracco, La Vergine e San Giuseppe intercedono per le anime del purgatorio, 1642, olio su tela, 271 × 190 cm, Cattedrale di Santa Maria Assunta, Bastia.
riscontrabile non solo in varie pale d’altare dislocate nelle aree periferiche della Repubblica di Genova, ma anche nella cospicua produzione di quadri destinati alla committenza privata. Avvantaggiandosi dei contatti forniti dalle amicizie di famiglia e del florido stato del mercato artistico genovese, alimentato da ingenti proventi generati dal locale sistema bancario, Badaracco si specializzò nella produzione di quadri da camera ‘fatti con buon intendimento, vaghi di colorito e portati a fine con buona maestria di pennello’ atti a soddisfare le esigenze dell’aristocrazia ligure.  Episodi quali Mosè salvato dalle acque (Figura 6) e Achille a Sciro, entrambi in collezione privata, ben esemplificano questo aspetto della sua produzione, caratterizzato da una verve naturalistica accostabile a quella di artisti contemporanei quali Domenico Fiasella e Giovanni Andrea de Ferrari.  Ciò che distingue i lavori di Badaracco è la vivace gestualità delle figure, la cura nella rappresentazione dei panneggi e il curioso ripetersi delle medesime fisionomie femminili riscontrabile anche in una Rebecca al pozzo (Figura 7) vista di recente nel mercato antiquario genovese.  Mentre lavori come la minuta Fuga in Egitto (Weston Park Foundation, Shropshire), proveniente dalla collezione dei Conti di Bradford, testimoniano della produzione devozionale dell’artista, è possibile che Badaracco, così come Ercole Sarti, si sia cimentato nel genere del ritratto. 
 
Figura 6. Giuseppe Badaracco, Mosè salvato dalle acque, 1650–1655, olio su tela, 222 × 178 cm, collezione privata.
 
Figura 7. Giuseppe Badaracco, Rebecca al pozzo, 1650–1655, olio su tela 118 × 140 cm, collezione privata.
A tal proposito, il nome del pittore figura in una ricevuta nella quale si registra un saldo di 48 lire per il ritratto delle due figlie del nobile veneto Carlo Sangiantoffetti. 
Nella biografia dedicata a Giuseppe Badaracco, redatta a meno di vent’anni dalla morte dell’artista avvenuta a causa della peste nel 1657, Raffaele Soprani ricorda il pittore come una persona riservata, parca nei modi e poco interessata a passatempi mondani.  Giuseppe fu un membro attivo della sua parrocchia, dedito alle opere di carità e all’educazione dei figli, uno dei quali, Giovanni Raffaele, infine rilevò la bottega paterna.64 È interessante notare come il Soprani sottolinei che in realtà due dei figli di Badaracco intrapresero la carriera pittorica e che il più giovane di essi fosse a Roma a studiare. La sua identità, tuttora sconosciuta, potrebbe essere accostata a quella dell’autore di una lunetta raffigurante il Trionfo della Fede, firmata ‘D.cus: BADARACVS’ e datata 1699, attualmente nella sacrestia della collegiata di Santa Maria Maggiore a Novi Ligure. 
Un ritrattista a Napoli: Filippo Ceppaluni
Un dipinto raffigurante il Miracolo di Soriano (Figura 8), apparso dieci anni orsono nel mercato antiquario portoghese, offre lo spunto per delineare la personalità artistica di Filippo Ceppaluni, pittore attivo a Napoli tra la fine del diciassettesimo e l’inizio del diciottesimo secolo.  La tela, firmata ‘FILIPPO CEPPALUNI/FEC.T’, descrive il miracolo realizzatosi il 15 settembre 1530 nel monastero domenicano di Soriano, in Calabria, quando la Vergine, accompagnata dalla Maddalena e Santa Caterina d’Alessandria, apparve al frate Lorenzo della Grotteria recando in dono un’immagine miracolosa di San Domenico. Il dipinto, eseguito intorno al 1720, è frutto del lavoro di un artista maturo, il cui stile coniuga modelli accostabili alla bottega napoletana di Luca Giordano con una particolare attenzione per la rappresentazione delle espressioni devote, delle elaborate acconciature, e degli ornamenti, che tradisce una predisposizione per il genere del ritratto. Nel raffigurare l’episodio, il pittore adotta un impianto compositivo che si discosta dalle declinazioni italiane dedicate all’evento, ispirandosi invece a modelli spagnoli rappresentati da una serie di tele eseguite da Juan Bautista Maíno 
 
Figura 8. Filippo Ceppaluni, Il miracolo di Soriano, 1715–1720, olio su tela, 197 × 155 cm, collezione privata.
durante la terza e quarta decade del Seicento (Figura 9).  Questo elemento, associato alla provenienza iberica della tela e alla sentita devozione generata in Spagna dal culto dal miracolo di Soriano, sembra suggerire una possibile commissione spagnola.
L’autore del quadro, Filippo Ceppaluni, fu un pittore con sordità prelinguale. A differenza di Ercole Sarti e Giuseppe Badaracco, egli non beneficiò del supporto morale e materiale della famiglia, ma si avvicinò alla professione artistica essendo stato accolto in tenera età nella bottega del pittore di origini maltesi Raimondo De Dominici, presso la quale svolse le mansioni di apprendista e garzone. La fonte principale per ricostruire il suo percorso artistico è costituita dal resoconto biografico redatto tra il 1742 e il 1745 da Bernardo De Dominici, il figlio di Raimondo, il quale aveva con Ceppaluni un 
 
Figura 9. Juan Bautista Maíno, Il miracolo di Soriano, 1629, olio su tela, 228 × 124 cm, Museo del Prado, Madrid.
rapporto di conoscenza diretta.  Bernardo ricorda che Filippo fu allevato in casa De Dominici ricevendo vitto e alloggio in luogo del salario. Il suo apprendistato, incentrato sulla copia di modelli desunti dalla collezione di stampe assemblata da Raimondo, durò approssimativamente fino al 1698, quando la famiglia De Dominici lasciò temporaneamente Napoli per trasferirsi a Malta. All’inizio del diciottesimo secolo si registra l’ingresso di Filippo nella bottega di Luca Giordano, tornato da poco in città dopo un decennio trascorso a Madrid. Il maestro napoletano prese particolarmente a cuore la formazione del pittore, comunicando i suoi insegnamenti ‘con atti muti’.69 Mentre da un lato questa informazione conferma che Giordano ebbe familiarità con il linguaggio dei segni, dall’altro evidenzia similitudini con l’educazione pittorica ricevuta da Ercole Sarti, anch’essa avvenuta tramite gesti. 
Fonti ottocentesche ricordano che a seguito della morte del maestro, avvenuta nel 1705, Filippo Ceppaluni si dedicò al genere del ritratto, una scelta motivata oltre che da inclinazioni artistiche da considerazioni di carattere pratico legate all’assidua richiesta per questo genere di dipinti.  Indagini di carattere socioeconomico hanno infatti dimostrato come sin dalla prima metà del Seicento un numero sempre maggiore di artisti napoletani decise di specializzarsi in questo genere, capitalizzando sull’aumento di domanda incoraggiata in parte dalla nobiltà locale e soprattutto dall’aristocrazia spagnola, dedita a commissionare tele che andavano a decorare le stanze dei palazzi cittadini e rimpinguare le collezioni in madrepatria.  Con un pizzico di malizia, Bernardo De Dominici insinua che Filippo ‘ebbe più plauso di quel che meritava, a cagione dell’esser muto’.  Questa affermazione sembra implicare che i ritratti del pittore napoletano acquisissero un valore maggiore in luogo della sua disabilità e può essere posta in correlazione con la sopracitata lettera di Guido Coccapani, nella quale l’agente ducale lamenta il prezzo spropositato richiesto da Ercole Sarti per i suoi dipinti. Sebbene nessuno dei ritratti eseguiti da Filippo Ceppaluni sia rintracciabile, ritrovamenti d’archivio confermano il suo successo commerciale. A tal proposito, in data 20 giugno 1712 il pittore ricevette la somma di 40 ducati per cinque ritratti del viceré Carlo IV Borromeo Arese e dei suoi figli.  Un saldo datato 28 giugno 1715 testimonia il pagamento di 12 ducati per i ritratti del Marchese della Valle e di suo fratello Domenico Mendoza.  L’inventario della collezione di 
Nicola Cardinale, datato 1716, include ritratti del Principe di Montesarchio, del Conte di Galbes e della Contessa di Lemos, tutti eseguiti da Filippo Ceppaluni.  Un inventario della collezione del Principe di Cariati fa infine menzione dei ritratti dell’imperatore e dell’imperatrice regnanti eseguiti dal pittore napoletano.77 Ceppaluni ritrasse alcune tra le figure più in vista della società napoletana, un dato che testimonia a favore dall’apprezzamento della committenza per le sue doti da ritrattista. Malgrado il suo onorario non sia comparabile a cifre quali i 50 ducati ricevuti nel 1610 da Carlo Sellitto per il ritratto del Duca di Nocera, il corrispettivo da lui richiesto si colloca ben al di sopra della media dei pittori napoletani, garantendo una stabilità economica invidiata alla maggior parte degli artisti attivi nella città partenopea.  I 40 ducati ricevuti per la sola commissione legata a Carlo IV Borromeo Arese erano infatti sufficienti a pagare un anno di affitto per uno studio con locale abitativo nella zona di Piazza della Carità, la preferita dagli artisti napoletani, nella quale il canone di affitto costava tra i 30 e i 40 ducati annui e dove il pittore risiedette con moglie e figli fino alla prematura morte sopraggiunta nel 1725.
Copisti e frescanti tra Seicento e Settecento: Aurelio Martelli e Giovanni Lo Coco
La panoramica sulla presenza di pittori con sordità prelinguale nelle botteghe italiane del Seicento si conclude con un accenno alle carriere di Aurelio Martelli e Giovanni Lo Coco, due artisti certamente non di primo piano attivi a partire dalla seconda metà del secolo e protagonisti di percorsi artistici dimenticati: Martelli, nato a Siena, non lasciò mai la casa natia, lavorando come decoratore e restauratore per le chiese della sua città; Lo Coco, originario della Sicilia, trascorse una parte della sua carriera a Roma prima di far ritorno ad Acireale, dove si distinse come frescante.
Nato nel 1644 da Carlo Martelli e Caterina Umoroni, Aurelio Martelli si avvicinò alla pittura grazie all’intercessione dello zio paterno Jacopo, sacerdote nella parrocchia di San Desiderio, il quale facilitò il suo apprendistato presso la bottega del sacerdote e pittore dilettante senese Giovanni Battista Ramacciotti.  Riconosciuto da Ettore Romagnoli intorno alla metà del diciannovesimo secolo, il legame tra la pittura del giovane Aurelio e lo stile amatoriale del Ramacciotti è confermato dalla prima opera del pittore: una Natività della Vergine (Museo della Contrada del Leocorno, Siena) (Figura 10) firmata ‘AURELIO MARTELLI FECIT 1667’, eseguita per la cappella della Madonna della Pace nella chiesa di San Giovanni in Pantaneto e parzialmente riprodotta in uno studio preparatorio del pittore (Gabinetto dei disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Firenze) che ne riprende in controparte il gruppo centrale con la levatrice e gli angeli.  Ispirato ad una simile composizione eseguita su scala minore dal Ramacciotti conservata a Palazzo Pitti, il dipinto evidenzia la personalità di un artista che, nonostante la giovane età, guarda ben oltre l’esempio del maestro, ponendosi in relazione con i modelli della scuola bolognese portati a Siena dalla 
 
Figura 10. Aurelio Martelli, La natività della Vergine, 1667, olio su tela, 150 × 264 cm, Museo della Contrada del Leocorno, Siena.
Circoncisione eseguita nel 1636 da Guido Reni per la chiesa di San Martino, e soprattutto con la pittura classicista di Raffaello Vanni, come si evince dal confronto con la Natività delle Vergine completata originariamente dal pittore senese per il tempio di San Biagio e oggi nella chiesa di Sant’Agnese a Montepulciano.
Martelli fu apprezzato dalla committenza, come dimostra il suo impiego per la realizzazione di dipinti e pale d’altare in prestigiosi edifici della città di Siena quali la cattedrale di Santa Maria Assunta, la chiesa di San Giacomo in Salicotto e la sede della locale Compagnia degli Artisti.  Nonostante alcune commissioni di rilievo, il suo impatto sullo sviluppo dell’arte senese della seconda metà del Seicento fu tuttavia limitato e le sua pittura non sufficiente a consentirgli di assumere un ruolo da protagonista. Una ricevuta datata 20 gennaio 1676 segnala che il pittore lavorò in qualità di restauratore per la chiesa di Sant’Antonio Abate, presso la quale fu ingaggiato per la ‘pulitura e laccatura della tavola del altare e per numero otto lunette e otto tondi della volta’.  Un ulteriore documento testimonia come l’artista si impegnò a restaurare i quadri e le pitture a fresco nell’oratorio della Compagnia di Santa Caterina della Notte, evidenziando come grazie alle doti da copista il Martelli riuscì a trovare sbocchi lavorativi alternativi rispetto alle più competitive commissioni di carattere religioso e alla produzione di tele per il mercato privato.  Al pari di Ercole Sarti, Giuseppe Badaracco e Filippo Ceppaluni, Aurelio Martelli si cimentò nel genere del ritratto. Una lettera firmata dal nobile senese Ottavio Sansedoni identifica il pittore come autore del Ritratto di Giovanni di Ambrogio Sansedoni, registrato nella quadreria del palazzo di famiglia e intravisto nel 2015 sul mercato antiquario fiorentino.  Allo stesso modo, un inventario della collezione di casa Bargagli include ‘un ritratto della Signora Girolama Bargagli del Martelli mutolo’. 
Le sparute attestazioni documentarie riguardanti la carriera del pittore tra la fine del Seicento e l’inizio del Settecento sembrano suggerire che egli si sia dedicato alla pratica artistica in modo discontinuo. A tal proposito, le uniche opere da lui completate in questo periodo sono eseguite ‘per carità’ a beneficio della Compagnia di Santa Maria della Notte, un’istituzione caritatevole della quale egli fu confratello. Originariamente consacrata a San Michele Arcangelo e rinominata nel 1479 in onore di Santa Caterina, la compagnia, ospitata nel cuore dell’Ospedale di Santa Maria della Scala, era dedita alla cura degli infermi e alla pietà per i defunti. Tra il 1701 e il 1703 Aurelio completò quattro tele destinate ai locali dell’oratorio, tra cui una Decapitazione di Niccolò di Tuldo e Santa Caterina di fronte a Gregorio IX, per le quali ricevette un modesto rimborso vòlto a coprire il costo dei materiali.  La carità del Martelli evidenzia un interessante punto di contatto con il lascito testamentario del pittore milanese Luca Riva, il quale destinò una generosa porzione del suo patrimonio all’Ospedale Maggiore e alle istituzioni caritatevoli della città di Milano.87 Il dato non sorprende, specialmente se si considera che in Italia, a partire dalla seconda metà del sedicesimo secolo, gli ospedali, le confraternite e le istituzioni caritatevoli recitarono un ruolo primario nell’offrire supporto morale e materiale alle persone con sordità, favorendone l’integrazione sociale.
Un autoritratto affrescato nel 1715 in una lunetta del chiostro del convento di San Biagio ad Acireale (Figura 11) ritrae Giovanni Lo Coco vestito di tutto punto, con una folta parrucca, le guance arrossate e la tavolozza impugnata nella mano sinistra. L’affresco, completato dal pittore all’età di quarantotto anni, è un raro autoritratto di un pittore con sordità e costituisce il punto di partenza per ricostruire la vicenda di questo artista 
 
Figura 11. Giovanni Lo Coco, Autoritratto, 1715, affresco, Convento di San Biagio, Acireale.
sconosciuto, la cui carriera è brevemente citata nelle note settecentesche dello storico acese Carlo Carpinato e di Mariano Leonardi Gambino, entrambe conservate presso Biblioteca Zelantea di Acireale.  L’abbigliamento alla moda sembra suggerire i natali nobili dell’artista, un’ipotesi avvalorata dal fatto che, dopo un breve apprendistato con il pittore acese Giacinto Platania, Lo Coco si recò a Roma per studiare nella bottega dell’incisore palermitano Pietro Aquila. Leonardi riferisce che il pittore ebbe in moglie la figlia del maestro e adottò lo stile di maniera che imperava in quel tempo nella capitale.  Sebbene nulla rimanga dell’esperienza romana, un confronto tra la Gloria di Sant’Agata (Figura 12) affrescata da Lo Coco nella tribuna della chiesa catanese di Sant’Agata al Borgo e la medesima composizione di Paolo Gismondi nel catino absidale di Sant’Agata dei Goti a Roma (Figura 13) – un’opera certamente visionata da Giovanni, data la devozione per la santa catanese – conferma l’affinità tra lo stile del pittore e i modelli del barocco proposti a Roma intorno alla metà del Seicento.
Lo Coco rientrò in Sicilia entro la fine della prima decade del diciottesimo secolo, come indicato da un saldo per la decorazione di un portoncino ligneo per la cappella di Santa Venera nella basilica della Santissima Annunziata ad Acireale, datato 1711.  Il suo ritorno coincise con l’attuazione di un vasto programma di ristrutturazione dell’edilizia catanese attuato dal governo spagnolo a seguito del disastroso terremoto che aveva interessato la Sicilia orientale nel 1693. A tal proposito, nel 1695 il viceré Uzeda inviò a Catania il duca di Camastra con il compito di sovrintendere alla ricostruzione della città con fondi derivati da esenzioni fiscali e lasciti di benefattori locali.  Una particolare attenzione fu dedicata alla ristrutturazione degli edifici di culto, le cui pareti furono decorate con tele barocche 
 
Figura 12. Giovanni Lo Coco, Gloria di Sant’Agata, 1715–1720, affresco, Chiesa di Sant’Agata al Borgo, Catania.
 
Figura 13. Paolo Gismondi, Gloria di Sant’Agata, 1633–1636, affresco, Chiesa di Sant’Agata dei Goti, Roma.
e affreschi ispirati alle raffigurazioni eseguite in area palermitana da Pietro Novelli, Antonino Grano, Filippo Tancredi, e Guglielmo Borremans.  Forte dell’esperienza maturata a Roma, Giovanni adattò le sue doti di copista e frescante alle esigenze committenza catanese. Nella seconda decade del Settecento egli fu difatti impegnato nella decorazione di alcuni tra i più importanti edifici ecclesiastici della provincia, molti dei quali afferenti all’ambito conventuale francescano. Il pittore completò la decorazione dell’abside e la volta della navata principale della basilica di Santa Caterina d’Alessandria a Pedara con un programma iconografico vòlto ad illustrare le storie di Santa Caterina e quelle del Battista. Le scene, racchiuse in quadrature 
 
Figura 14. Giovanni Lo Coco, La predica di San Giovanni Battista nel deserto, 1705–1710, affresco, Basilica di Santa Caterina d’Alessandria, Pedara.
incorniciate da decorazioni grottesche e motivi floreali, presentano uno stile fantasioso, espressione di una vena narrativa che porta il pittore a sovraffollare le partizioni spaziali quasi a voler raccontare più di quanto sia possibile. Se da un lato il racconto appare artificioso, le figure, caratterizzate da connotazioni facciali diverse l’una dall’altra, evidenziano la spiccata abilità del pittore nella rappresentazione delle espressioni e dei volti (Figura 14). A seguito del completamento dei lavori a Pedara, Lo Coco si spostò ad Acireale dove tra il 1713 e il 1715 decorò la chiesa e il chiostro del convento di San Biagio, di recente ricostruiti a seguito del terremoto. Gli affreschi, dedicati alle storie della vita di San Francesco, si caratterizzano per la medesima foga narrativa riscontrata presso la fabbrica di Pedara, pur differenziandosi per una maggiore cura del dettaglio nella rappresentazione dei paesaggi, in cui le torri svettanti della città, le catene montuose stagliate in lontananza, e le distese marine agitate dai venti danno vita ad uno sfondo naturalistico descritto con dovizia di particolari. La maniera eclettica ma piuttosto frettolosa del Lo Coco è infine riconoscibile nel refettorio del convento di San Francesco a Biancavilla, dove il pittore affrescò un’Ultima Cena nella quale spicca la rappresentazione anacronistica di un apostolo còlto nell’atto di riposizionare gli occhiali. In aggiunta alla pittura a fresco, è possibile che Giovanni si sia cimentato nella realizzazione di pale d’altare: a tal proposito la Pinacoteca Zelantea conserva una Adorazione dei pastori, una copia di un dipinto di Guido Reni, sul cui margine si legge ‘HOC OPUS FECIT JOANNES COCO’. 
Conclusione
Ercole Sarti, Giuseppe Badaracco, Filippo Ceppaluni, Aurelio Martelli, e Giovanni Lo Coco sono solo alcuni dei pittori con sordità prelinguale rintracciabili nei meandri della storia dell’arte moderna, non solo in Italia, dove a partire dal diciottesimo secolo le fonti menzionano i nomi dei fratelli bolognesi Giovanni Andrea e Ciro Maria Paris Porroni, di Francesco Comi e di Gaetano 
Sabatini, ma anche in Europa. A tal proposito, il tedesco Wolfgang Heimbach ebbe una straordinaria carriera come ritrattista e pittore di genere lavorando presso dimore aristocratiche in città quali Oldenburg, Roma, Vienna, Napoli, Praga, Amsterdam, e Copenaghen. Nella Spagna del sedicesimo secolo Juan Fernández de Navarrete fu nominato pittore di corte da Filippo II, mentre nel secolo successivo Alonso del Arco diresse una delle più apprezzate botteghe artistiche di Madrid. In area fiamminga, Hendrick Avercamp descrisse paesaggi invernali; Maerten Boulema dipinse eleganti nature morte; e Jan Jansz, al quale le fonti ascrivono un breve apprendistato presso la bottega di Rembrandt, si affermò come ritrattista.  Le loro storie offrono spunti essenziali per lo studio dei rapporti tra pratica artistica e disabilità uditiva all’inizio dell’era moderna. Esse smentiscono la convinzione che a lungo ha relegato le persone con sordità ai margini della società dal medioevo all’inizio del diciannovesimo secolo, e sottolineano come questi artisti utilizzarono il primato culturale accordato all’arte della pittura al fine di affermare le loro capacità intellettive, aprendo la strada per lo sviluppo di una nuova sensibilità nei confronti della disabilità uditiva.

***

Vicissitudes of a Dantean Collection: The 1527 ‘Giuntina delle rime’

The most comprehensive sixteenth-century printed collection of pre-Petrarchan lyric poetry, the anthology Sonetti e canzoni di diuersi antichi autori toscani in dieci libri raccolte, was printed by Bernardo di Giunta in Florence at the beginning of July 1527. It was the result of some extensive philological work by an editorial team of Florentines. From later annotations by Vincenzio Borghini, we know that this équipe included Bardo di Antonio Segni, who was also involved in the edition of Boccaccio’s Decameron produced by the same Giunta press in April of the same year.1 This essay advances a new interpretation of this collection, widely known as the ‘Giuntina delle rime’. I argue that the collection was developed in the first instance as a Dantean anthology and as a reaction against Pietro Bembo’s codification of Petrarch and Boccaccio as supreme models for poetry and prose, respectively, and his devaluation of Dante in his seminal dialogue Prose nelle quali si ragiona della volgar lingua (1525).2 The article examines how, in the Florentine environment, its most important publishing house, the Giunta, attempted to modify and correct Bembo’s canon with its strong privileging of Petrarch, by countering his negative judgement on Dante. Rather than attempting to defuse Bembo’s criticism by defending Dante’s major work, the Commedia, on which Bembo’s attacks notoriously focused, the strategy adopted in the ‘Giuntina’ was one of promoting Dante’s lyric production and his status as model author for lyric poetry. 
In this way, the ‘Giuntina’ also attempted to reinstate a previous pre-print poetic canon, one made up of Dante and Petrarch as the supreme models for poetry and especially lyric poetry, which half a century before had already greatly influenced the Raccolta Aragonese, the most important vernacular manuscript collection in the later fifteenth century and one that a team of editors including Poliziano had famously assembled c. 1477 at Lorenzo de Medici’s behest. Here, in the prefatory letter penned by Poliziano, these two poets were called the ‘due mirabili soli’ (‘two suns’).  The Giuntina’s opening letter, which is addressed to youthful lovers of Tuscan poetry and acts as a preface to the anthology, explicitly adopts such language and a similar formula, ‘lucidissimi occhi’ (p. [III]r, ‘most shining eyes’), in reproposing the canonicity of Dante and Petrarch as lyric poets. The Dante-Petrarch lyric canon, as we might call it, is embodied in a number of manuscripts associating Petrarch’s vernacular works and Dante’s lyric poems, and in many instances these are decorated luxury copies on vellum, several of them with a Florentine provenance.5 The same canon was also more or less explicitly expressed in numerous other sources, including poetic compositions such as ‘Quel divo ingegno, qual per voi s’infuse’, the capitolo presented by Mariotto Davanzati at the Certame coronario of 1441, the literary contest organised by Leon Battista Alberti in Florence with the aim of promoting vernacular literature. After the traditional invocation of the Muses, Davanzati opens his poem by appealing for help to Dante and Petrarch, addressing them as ‘due sacri lumi’ (‘two sacred lights’).  The formula is similar to the ‘due soli’ of the epistle opening the Raccolta Aragonese (which transmits Davanzati’s capitolo) but might be a closer antecedent for the 1527 ‘lucidissimi occhi’, since ‘lumi’ are often used as a metaphor for ‘eyes’, in both Dante and Petrarch and their imitators.
Many more fifteenth- and early sixteenth-century poems and prose texts of different sorts (letters, dedications, apologias . . .) mention the two authors together, as predecessors and models to be followed, and – what is more – as the two principal components of a canon.  The reach of this canon was not limited to Florence, but it seems especially strong in Dante’s city, as demonstrated for instance by Giovanni Pico della Mirandola’s 1486 letter to Lorenzo de’ Medici, presenting Dante and Petrarch as the most celebrated poets in Florence.  Before Bembo, this canon seems therefore to have been rather stable and quite prevalent.
The hypothesis proposed here contradicts several previous interpretations of the 1527 collection. As stated by Nadia Cannata in her own important study of the collection,9 there have been three main stances taken to understanding the work: by Domenico De Robertis in his introduction to the 1977 facsimile reprint of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’; by Guglielmo Gorni one year later; and finally by Carlo Dionisotti in 1980. According to De Robertis, the 1527 collection reacts against Bembo’s codification countering his choice of Petrarch as unique and timeless model with a whole tradition, and on the whole the work can be considered a polemic against Petrarch (‘polemica antipetrarchista’).  Dionisotti disagrees. For him, Bernardo di Giunta, in his preface to the volume, clearly accepts Petrarch’s primacy, and only pleads with the youthful lovers of Tuscan poetry to give some recognition to his predecessors. In this way, Bernardo takes a stance which is exactly the same as Bembo’s – the only slight difference being a rather more significant role accorded to Dante.  Guglielmo Gorni takes the same stance as Dionisotti but goes even further. According to him, the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ does not show any hostility at all towards Bembo and his model of choice, Petrarch. In Gorni’s opinion, the Giunti edition has merely an antiquarian and documentary value; its aim is not of proposing alternative models but of providing to its readers the texts of many authors mentioned by Bembo at the beginning of the second book of his dialogue. Thus, it complements Bembo’s work and takes a collaborative stance towards him. 
These contrasting perspectives on the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ by these three most distinguished scholars stem in all likelihood from the fact that the objectives of the editorial team and printer’s work are far from obvious to a modern scholar. The hypothesis here presented is quite different. I argue that the original intentions behind the collection and the scope of the anthology of poets were transformed during the process of preparing and then printing it. This study will start by scrutinising these developments and will then reconsider the collection as a whole and propose a new interpretation of its original aim. The article has four main sections. First of all, I will examine the last stages of the preparatory work leading to the collection, stages which probably took place immediately before the print process or even during it. Secondly, I consider the choice of authors in light of the results of the previous analysis. And finally in the final two sections the analysis turns to several other elements supporting the hypothesis here presented, chiefly through a close study of the preliminary editorial work in section three and of Bernardo di Giunta’s preface in the fourth section.
Planning the Collection. 1. Material Layout
Let us start with a rather confusing element – the title of the collection, and the prefatory letter by Bernardo di Giunta addressed to youthful lovers of Tuscan poetry which opens it. The confusion is that both these elements announce ten books of poems. And yet, only nine of these books are listed in the frontispiece. Even more bewilderingly, the whole collection is actually made up of eleven books. This fact was considered remarkable by both De Robertis and Gorni,  and, according to Cannata, it can simply be explained by the extraordinary and chaotic circumstances during which the printing took place. The last Florentine republic – proclaimed only at the end of April 1527 after the second removal of the Medici from Florence, in connection with the turbulent events which also led to the Sack of Rome – was in fact weathering an outbreak of plague that, in the weeks surrounding the publication of the anthology, was especially severe and led many citizens to seek refuge in the countryside. Cannata hypothesises that Bardo and other members of the editorial team were caught up in this flight from the city. Cannata also considers this to be the underlying cause for a series of other mistakes, affecting especially the paratexts; she argues that the compositors and other workers, left to their own devices, did not bother correcting these errors.  One of many examples (not mentioned by Cannata) concerns the running titles of a section where we can read a pair of sestine ‘ritrovate in uno antichissimo testo insieme con la sestina di Dante’ (fol. 130v – r2v). This section can be considered a sort of appendix to the tenth book (fols 130v–32r, or following the bifolium signature r2v–r4r). However, the running title of fol. 131r (r3r) is not ‘X’. or ‘DECIMO’ but ‘XI’., like those found throughout the following eleventh book, while that of fol. 132r (r4r) reads ‘DECIMO’. As a result, the section of the anthology with the two sestine seems to have an ambiguous status.
The sheer number of mistakes highlighted by Cannata and listed by De Robertis could seem an element that rules out all possible hypotheses of an underlying strategy on the part of the Giuntina’s editors. However, one cannot help but wonder how and why such errors could arise, thereby creating contradictions between the actual collection, its title, and its frontispiece, even in what concerns the precise number of books. In this respect, the discrepancies in these areas actually appear to offer a clue as to how the anthology evolved in line with a hypothesis first proposed by Pasquale Stoppelli.  It seems plausible, that is, that a book has been added subsequent to the original planning of the volume, perhaps while this was being printed, or maybe in a stage of work immediately preceding the setting and print process.  Before substantiating more fully this argument, however, we need to provide more details about the ‘Giuntina delle rime’.
The anthology contains 289 poems, attributed to twenty-three authors. These numbers are quite impressive for a sixteenth-century printed collection of early vernacular poetry. The earliest print anthology of pre-Petrarchan lyric poetry, the 1518 print collection Canzoni di Dante, Madrigali del detto. Madrigali di m. Cino & di m. Girardo Novello (Venice: Guglielmo da Monferrato), first printed in Venice on 27 April 1518 and then republished a few months later in Milan by Agostino da Vimercate (2 September 1518), only contained sixty-six poems, attributed – very often incorrectly – to a mere five authors.
In spite of this wealth of authors and texts, the volume printed in Florence is rather small. The octavo print consists in fact of 20 gatherings or quires, only the first and last are binions (two bifolios, thus four leaves), all the others are quaternions (four bifolios and eight leaves; collational formula A4, a-s8, t4). In total, then, there are 152 folios. The number of authors distributed across each book and the number of poems per author are uneven. The full list of books with their content according to the 1527 rubrics are as follows:  
Let us now compare this list with the one on the frontispiece. The latter is obviously incomplete, because, as already noted, there are only nine books instead of ten or eleven. However, this can help us to narrow down the list of candidates for the book or books that could have been added later. We can in fact assume that all books listed in the frontispiece were already in the original planning of the collection.
SONETTI E CANZONI DI DIVERSI ANTICHI AVTORI TOSCANI IN DIECI LIBRI 
RACCOLTE 
In the above list, we can easily identify and thus exclude from the preceding one the first eight books, those containing the poems attributed to Dante Alighieri, Cino, Cavalcanti, Dante da Maiano, and Guittone. The last book mentioned in the frontispiece is in all likelihood book X of the anthology, since all its poems are unattributed (‘senza nome d’autore’), even though it only contains canzoni and no sonnets. I will consider the possibility that it could be a last-minute addition in the following section, but for now let us focus on books IX and XI.
In order to understand which of these books is most likely to have been a later addition to the project, we must take into account two things. First of all, the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ is a commercial operation. Secondly, it is an octavo print. This means that each printed sheet, once folded, results in a gathering of eight folios (sixteen pages), i.e., a quaternion – exactly like almost all the gatherings of the 1527 anthology. A later insertion should reasonably occupy a number of folios multiple of this. In the whole print, there are only four blank pages (fols h4r, p3r, r2r, and the back of the frontispiece): Bernardo di Giunta was obviously not keen on printing half a sheet or less. We must also bear in mind that he could avoid blank spaces almost effortlessly. The ‘Giuntina delle rime’ being an anthology of poetry, the number of lines could be counted beforehand. Moreover, the printer knew how many lines would fit on a page, and he could therefore calculate rather easily how many poems he could or should add to fill a whole sheet (or gathering) but no more than that, even in case of late changes to the planning.
Now, the ninth book of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ extends over fourteen folios, the poems taking up twenty-six pages, while its rubric, as with all other rubrics preceding each book and the section with the two sestine, stands alone on the left-hand page opposite the recto of the folio where the first poem of the book begins. Book XI instead is composed of ten folios for the poems, plus the verso of the second folio that is taken up by the two sestine for its rubric. The most plausible hypothesis is therefore that there has been a last-minute addition to the anthology comprising the ninth book and the two sestine, which are also not mentioned in the frontispiece. The twenty-six pages taken by the poems of the ninth book, plus three for the two sestine, plus the two pages of the respective rubrics, add up to thirty-one pages, which translates into sixteen folios, or two quires: that is to say, two additional printed sheets.
This hypothesis is also coherent with the fact that most of the poems of the ninth book are taken from the same source, the late thirteenth-century collection Florence, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale, Banco Rari 217 (formerly Palatino 418), and almost all of them seem to have been copied from one single manuscript. This is even more remarkable when we take into account that the 1527 collection is considered especially notable because of the philological work of its editorial team, exploiting a number of manuscripts to create what has often been called a ‘critical’ text. In fact, the aforementioned Palatino manuscript is the basis for the last five canzoni of the ninth book, by the Sicilian poets Giacomo da Lentini, Guido delle Colonne, Pier delle Vigne, Re Enzo, and his father Frederick II. The canzone that immediately precedes, ‘Ben mi credea in tutto esser d’Amore’ by Bonagiunta da Lucca, is only transmitted by the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ (fols 108r–109r – o4r–o5r); however, it is possible that it was originally copied in a now lost folio of this same manuscript, especially considering that the loss of this specific folio happens after the fifteenth-century foliation. 
Towards the beginning of book nine, the celebrated canzone ‘Al cor gentil’ by Guido Guinizelli (the only one in this book which has clearly been corrected using other sources) comes mostly from the Palatino (fols 107r–108r – o3r–o4r), while the preceding ballata ‘La partenza che fo dolorosa’ by Onesto da Bologna is wholly derived from that manuscript (fols 106v–107r – o2v–o3r). The four remaining poems in the ninth book are the ballata ‘Per fuggir riprensione’ by Franceschino degli Albizzi (fols 102r–103r – n6r–n7r), which is its opening poem, a canzone by Fazio degli Uberti, ‘Lasso, che quando immaginando vegno’ (fols 103r–104v – n7r–n8v), which follows immediately, and then a canzone by Lapo Gianni (fols 104v–105v – n8v–o1v) and a ballata by Noffo Bonaguide (fol. 106r-v – o2r-v). Noffo’s poem is only transmitted by the Giuntina, Franceschino’s ballata is apparently taken from a copy of the Raccolta Aragonese, which was thus one of the sources of its later print counterpart,  Lapo’s canzone comes from one among three closely related manuscripts (Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, Pluteus 40.49; Florence, Biblioteca Riccardiana, 1094; and Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, it. 557), and Fazio’s is drawn from the same source of the two above-mentioned sestine, the Mediceo Palatino 119 (Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana), contaminated with another manuscript that the editors also used for two sonnets by Guittone.  Though there are some other sources being used in Book IX, the main one is clearly the former Palatino 418.
One last remark should be made concerning the ninth book of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’. Here, the poems are presented in reverse chronological order, from Petrarch’s friend Franceschino to the Sicilians. The same reverse chronological order is respected in the whole collection,  as explicitly stated by Bernardo in his opening address to the youthful lovers of Tuscan poetry (‘da i più moderni di mano in mano a gli più antichi procedendo’ – ‘proceeding from the most recent towards the earliest’, fol. [IV]r). Once more, however, book nine presents us with a major inconsistency, since here and only here we leap forward to Petrarch’s contemporaries before moving back to poets of the same generation as Dante and Cavalcanti, then their predecessors Guinizelli and Bonagiunta (both living at the same time as Guittone), and finally the most ancient Sicilians, with Frederick II coming last after his son Enzo. This incongruity can now be explained by my hypothesis that the ninth book was a later addition to the original planning of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’.
Planning the Collection. 2. Authors’ Choice and Distribution
In the light of my hypothesis that its ninth book was not present in an earlier stage at which the collection was first conceived, we can now reconsider the content and structure of the 1527 collection from a new perspective. Let us do that from a slightly less obvious vantage point, that is to say, the eleventh and last book, the remaining one not mentioned in the frontispiece.
As mentioned previously, book XI contains correspondence sonnets. The first three are the responses garnered by the first sonnet of the Vita nova, ‘A ciascun’alma presa e gentil core’, which is also the first poem in the opening book of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ anthology. The first of these responsive sonnets in book XI could be a case of misattribution: ‘Naturalmente chere ogni amadore’ (fol. 133r – r5r) is disputed between Cino da Pistoia, to whom it is ascribed here, and Terino da Castelfiorentino.  Then there follows Cavalcanti’s esoteric interpretation, ‘Vedeste, al mio parere, ogni valore’ (fol. 133r-v – r5r-v), and finally Dante da Maiano’s witty reply, ‘Di ciò che stato sè dimandatore’ (fol. 133v – r5v).
Now, if we return either to the frontispiece or the plan of the anthology, we can clearly see that the authors, real or assumed, of these three responsive sonnets, are also the authors of the poems collected in the three books following the four Dantean ones, and they are introduced in the same order at the beginning of book XI that we find in the books of the collection that contain their poems. This ordering and likely connection also sheds a new light on the editors’ puzzling decision to dedicate a whole book to the otherwise unknown Dante da Maiano, whose production is transmitted almost exclusively by the ‘Giuntina delle rime’. The eleventh book in fact contains a lengthy correspondence in sonnets between the two Dantes. In light of this, the entire anthology can be understood as a volume concerned with Dante and then with poems addressed to or related to him. First, we have four books of poems by Dante (I–IV); then, three books of poems by Dante’s friends or correspondents, one for each of them (V–VII); and then a book of poems by Dante’s arch-rival, Guittone d’Arezzo.
As for the tenth book, its unattributed canzoni by uncertain authors are actually attributed to Dante in other sources, chiefly the most obvious one, that is, the above-mentioned 1518 print collection Canzoni di Dante, Madrigali del detto. Madrigali di m. Cino & di m. Girardo Novello. Ten out of thirteen canzoni of book XI of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ are attributed to Dante by this collection. The other three are ‘Patrïa degna di trïumfal fama’ (fols 128v–129v – q8v–r1v), ‘Io non posso celar lo mio dolore’ by Cino da Pistoia (fols 126r–127r – q6r–q7r), and ‘Nel tempo che s’infiora e cuopre d’erba’ by Fazio degli Uberti (fol. 116r-v – p4r-v). The first is attributed to Dante by several manuscripts.  The second is one of the three canzoni that in the Raccolta Aragonese – a source that, as already mentioned, was available to Bernardo’s editorial team – are erroneously repeated twice, first in the section on Dante and then in the one on Cino. Finally, the third canzone is attributed to Dante by Parma, Biblioteca Palatina, Parm. 1081. This is not a known source of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’, and, according to the most recent edition, the readings of this text as it is transmitted by the 1527 print anthology are not related to its readings transmitted by the manuscript now in Parma. The Giuntina’s editors are, however, clearly innovating here, either correcting the text themselves or exploiting currently unidentified sources.25 It is therefore possible that, in one of these, the text was attributed to Dante.
In short, the tenth book of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ can be considered an appendix of lyric poems of dubious attribution to Dante and as such was originally intended as a mainly Dantean collection. This finding helps us to rule out the hypothesis that it was not the ninth book but this one which was added to the original plan of the collection in a second moment. Support for this hypothesis comes from the number of folios occupied by it (fourteen, for twenty-eight full pages). What is more, the two sestine, as we have seen, are also part of this later insertion, and they follow the tenth and not the preceding ninth book. The possibility that the tenth book has been added to the planning of the anthology is, however, also ruled out by its presence in the frontispiece as well as on account of its Dantean content. Dante is, then, clearly the lodestone of the collection. Even the correspondence sonnets in the eleventh book which follow the first three are all part of exchanges involving either Dante or at least one of his correspondents. There is no exception to this rule. And once again, this explains the otherwise mystifying prominence of Dante da Maiano in the ‘Giuntina delle rime’. The collection started from Dante Alighieri, with other poets and poems added attracted by and on the basis of his aura. Other elements pointing to this and a hypothesis about the genesis of the 1527 ‘Giuntina delle rime’ and its purposes will follow in the next sections.
Preparing the Collection. Dante as the Originating Point
I have already argued for the centrality of Dante in the collection. Let us now look in detail at its nature and extent. The first – and most obvious – element demonstrating Dante’s central role is his primacy and prominence in the anthology, a point already remarked upon by other scholars.  The 1527 print is opened by his poems; four full books are dedicated to him compared to one at the most for all other authors, and on the whole, almost three poems out of ten in the collection are attributed to him, taking up more than one third of the pages. Compared to those by other authors, these poems seem also to have been subject to an especially painstaking level of attention. All of the mistakes corrected in the final list of errata (fols 147v–48r – t3v–t4r) concern poems by Dante. This could be due to the fact that they are the poems which open the collection, probably in the gatherings which were printed first, and it is possible that the proofreading and error tracking in the following ones was deemed too time-consuming and therefore expensive for the additional commercial value provided. Indeed, it may also be that there was not enough space left at the end of the volume to list all the numerous mistakes.
However that may be, notable too is the table of textual variants which immediately precedes the list of errata (fols 143v–47r – s7v–t3r), since it provides variant readings mainly for Dante’s poems, and only his name is mentioned in the second and final address to the readers (fol. 143r – s7r) that explains the reason and scope of the following table of variants. Actually, variant readings are provided for only one text besides those of Dante, Cavalcanti’s canzone ‘Donna me prega’, and the greater part of the philological preparatory work seems to have been on Dante’s texts. This is quite clearly evident from De Robertis’ research on the sources exploited by the editors of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’. Cavalcanti’s and Cino’s textual traditions are rather recognisable, with their texts mostly coming from the so-called ‘Venetian’ tradition of the Stilnovo. With a few exceptions, Guittone and Dante da Maiano’s poems seem to have been copied from single manuscripts, as we have already verified for the various authors of book IX, with the lone exception of Guinizelli. In the case of Dante, however, so many sources have been used that De Robertis – the pre-eminent scholar of the manuscripts pertaining to the lyric Dante – found it quite arduous to ascertain the provenance of his poems’ readings.27
The difficulties experienced by De Robertis in identifying the sources used by the editors of the 1527 Sonetti e canzoni for Dante’s poems can seem paradoxical, when we consider that we know several collectors of variants apparently hailing from Florence. In many cases, we can assume that these collectors of variants date more or less shortly before 1527, because their copyists do not avail themselves of the readings in the ‘Giuntina delle rime’. The success of the 1527 collection was in fact such that it became the point of departure and base text for later philological work, and a remarkable number of its extant copies presents variant readings collated against manuscript collections. What is more, several sixteenth-century anthologies of early Italian poetry have been copied as manuscript supplements for the 1527 Sonetti and canzoni, where their copyists transcribed from their sources only the poems that had not already been published in print by Bernardo di Giunta. A renowned and early example is the so-called ‘Raccolta Bartoliniana’ (Florence, 
Accademia della Crusca, 53), copied from three main sources before 1533 by the Florentine abate Lorenzo Bartolini, from whom we also have a copy of the 1527 Sonetti and canzoni where he added in parallel the different readings that he could find for its poems in these same sources. 
One such pre-1527 collector of variants is the Pluteus 40.49 (Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana), where an early sixteenth- or possibly late fifteenth-century hand has added readings from four different sources, distinguished by as many symbols.  The variant readings in two other manuscripts (Vatican City, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Chigi M.IV.79, and Florence, Biblioteca Riccardiana, 1156) have been recently attributed to the hand of Lorenzo di Filippo Strozzi (1482– 1549), better known as the patron of Machiavelli.  In all of these manuscripts, only Dante’s texts are provided with variant readings, and therefore, we can assume that the philological work is centred upon him. It is currently in doubt whether Lorenzo di Filippo Strozzi should be counted among the members of the group of Florentines involved in the editorial work for the ‘Giuntina delle rime’.  It is, however, apparent that the philological work on Dante’s texts started in Florence well before 1527.32
The most plausible hypothesis concerning the genesis of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’, then, seems to be that, when Bembo’s Prose with their damning judgment on Dante arrived in Florence, they were received by an environment where there was an ongoing philological work on Dante’s lyric poetry. This work grew in intensity (it seems less plausible that it began at this point) in order to react against Bembo’s proposed codification and counter his strictly Petrarchan choice by promoting Dante – and therefore the ‘due soli’ lyric canon, that we have seen as being a classic one especially in Florence. This intended reaction was to take the form of a Dantean lyric collection printed by the leading Florentine publishing house.
It seems highly relevant in this context to attend to the last (but not least important) element to be mentioned in order to demonstrate Dante’s central role in the ‘Giuntina delle rime’, that is to say, its abbreviated title as given at the beginning of each of its gatherings. This is in fact ‘Can. di Dan’., and as such it hints at something quite similar to the title of the above-mentioned 1518 print anthology of pre-Petrarchan lyric poetry. As noted in the preceding section, this work begins in fact with ‘Canzoni di Dante’. It is possible that the original title of the 1527 Sonetti et canzoni was different, and it highlighted to a greater extent the central role of Dante in the collection. What seems certain though is that, as we demonstrated here, the initial aim of the editorial work was to provide a collection of his lyric poems.
At the same time, however, an anthology containing only Dante lyric poetry would have been a rather scant addition to the textual canon. A volume solely made up of the four Dantean books would have amounted to at best a quarter of the space Bernardo assigned to Petrarch when he printed the Rerum vulgarium fragmenta in 1522. The same is true for the three vernacular Petrarchs printed by Bernardo’s father, Filippo, in 1504, 1510, and 1515. It may be that the appearance of such a relatively thin book likely risked being at odds with the ambitious aim of correcting Bembo’s canon. Hence the choice of expanding the selection of poems beyond the central Dantean nucleus, adding not only the unattributed poems by uncertain authors that could possibly be Dante, and the poetic exchanges involving him, but also dedicated sections for the poems of his correspondents and arch-rival, and other poetic exchanges involving said correspondents. Finally, quite late in the process and possibly while the print was already in progress, a miscellaneous section of poems by different authors was also added. The end result is that the anthology to some extent retains its original design, which is still recognisable, albeit with some effort. However, its scope and nature have obviously changed.
Reacting to Bembo. Bernardo di Giunta’s Preface
We have seen, then, how the original stance on the canon of authors promoted by the collection becomes blurred, and the letter which presents it has to take a different direction. This letter ends by further weakening the original case, insisting less on Dante and more on these early authors coming before Petrarch, the first ones to write in the vernacular, on the reconstruction of a genealogy for Petrarch, and on an historicising perspective. The final result allows for a different hypothesis on the real nature of the reaction against Bembo by the Florentine editors of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ and Bernardo di Giunta, and on their perspective towards Bembo’s proposed canon. Despite this, Dante with his lyric poetry is still presented in the letter as perfectly deserving of having equal standing with Petrarch and is considered with him one of the two ‘most shining eyes of our language’ (‘lucidissimi occhi de la nostra lingua’, fol. [III]r). This amounts to another re- proposition of the ‘due soli’ canon, albeit one dimmed by the wider context of the letter.
Further traces of the 1527 anthology’s original character and design as what one might call a backlash against the canon proposed by Bembo can be found in this very same letter. In this regard, it is especially striking to note the comparison between the poems, retrieved and restored by the Florentine editors, and the artful statues of the ancient masters, broken and dispersed until someone assembled and cleaned them, bringing them back to light and the general admiration. This passage seems to have influenced Gorni’s remark concerning the antiquarian meaning of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’, while Corrado Bologna judges at least the inclusion of the earlier Tuscan poets ‘archaeological collecting’, and Stoppelli when mentioning the comparison openly declares that the anthology was thus an archaeological recovery operation.  However, these observations seem to conflate current value judgements about archaeological relics and excavations with a comparison that had a very different meaning in 1527, not least because it is a rather transparent allusion to a key passage of Bembo’s Prose, the very beginning of its third book.
The comparison between visual arts and literature was to some extent commonplace in the Renaissance, in parallel with the usual classical counterparts, and can actually be found in other prefaces signed by Bernardo di Giunta.  However, the letter opening the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ recalls an activity taking place in a very specific historical moment and place. The statues were ‘raccolte’ (the same past participle is used only four lines below for the choice of poems) between the sublime ruins of the ill-fated Rome (‘fra le eccelse rovine de la infelice Roma’) not so much time before its current cruel and extreme misfortune (‘poco innanzi a queste sue così crudeli, ed estreme calamitati’).  This is clearly a reference to the Sack of Rome, that started exactly two months before the print of the ‘Giuntina delle rime’, 6 May 1527 (the anthology is dated in its colophon 6 July 1527). The third book of Bembo’s Prose begins with the evocation of what was happening in the same city of Rome, in the moment when Bembo pretends to be writing his book, between 1516 and 1517. The passage also discusses the statues that either lay dispersed here and there (and the adjective, ‘sparse’, is the same one used for the statues ‘in molte parti spezzate e sparse’ in the 1527 letter) or were studiously preserved by private citizens, and the monumental buildings that were at least in part still standing. The two texts therefore refer explicitly to the same place, in the same historical moment (a contemporary one for Bembo, the recent past for the 1527 Florentines), and the same artworks. The texts also refer to similar actions, performed by groups of people that are to some extent overlapping. We now need to go back to Bembo, and remember the function of his mentioning these many ancient works of art.
The beginning of the third book of the Prose contains the last authorial address to the dedicatee Giulio de’ Medici. It is also the last intervention of the author, and in truth and crucially the only passage where it is Bembo himself who advocates for his linguistic authoritative solution, founded on the literary canon, above all Petrarch and Boccaccio, and historicising views that he established in the previous books, above all through the character of Carlo Bembo. The image of Rome and its innumerable works of art which opens the third book of the dialogue is immediately and inextricably entwined with the many contemporary Renaissance artists who converge there to study and imitate the masterpieces of the past. It is because of their knowledge of the past that their present works are more artistically refined than those created in a later period. The results obtained by contemporary artists are all the more excellent the more closely they imitate the ‘antichi buoni maestri’.  One notes here the same phrase ‘antichi maestri’ that is used in Bernardo di Giunta’s letter to refer to the creators of the statues, thereby revealing the letter’s deployment of two different expressions from this passage in the Prose in the space of a couple lines.
Bembo takes his cue from the behaviour of contemporary artists in what for him are still ‘minor’ arts to state the general and universal necessity of such an imitation of the ‘ancients’ in all artistic endeavours, and especially the one which concerns him the most – literary writing. In this passage, which has such a prominent position in his dialogue, he exploits the excellence of Renaissance art and artists, explicitly mentioning Michelangelo and Raphael as the finest examples, as well as a very successful historical paradigm (the Golden Age-Decline-Revival one) and one of the most clichéd topoi of his age (the excellence of the Ancients), to advocate forcefully for his proposed canon, with all the might of his Ciceronian rhetoric and most elevated style.37
We can find a similar Ciceronian rhetoric in the passage with the comparison between early vernacular poems and antique sculptures of the letter opening the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ – here, as in Bembo’s final address to Giulio de’ Medici, we are confronted with an almost unbearably involuted syntax resulting in sentences of hundreds of words. But, in light of the allusion to Bembo’s dialogue, we can now understand that the reference to the ancient statues in the ‘Giuntina delle rime’ letter, as neither belittling nor merely ornamental, but instead rather deliberate and programmatic. Considering the purpose of Bembo’s evocation of Rome and its ancient masterpieces, as well as the transparent allusion to it in the text signed by Bernardo di Giunta, it appears that the latter is implicitly replying to the former. The comparison with the antique sculptures actually elevates the early Italian poems printed in the anthology and implicitly reasserts their status as models. The focus on the moment of recovery and restoration of the statues/poems, instead of their imitation as in the Prose, could be interpreted as yet another facet in the strategy of this response to Bembo, either as an implicit critique of Petrarch’s editor or more likely as an attempt to play on the strengths of the Florentine anthology.
From the broader context of the 1527 address to the lovers of Tuscan poetry, it is clear that the aim could not be to entirely replace Bembo’s canon, but instead to integrate it, resulting in a richer range of models of imitation. Moreover, as stated before, the change in scope and nature of the anthology obscured in part its original aims, and it is well known that its opening letter bears traces of some restrictive judgements on early vernacular poets, notably for their obscurity and even roughness (the latter being however attributed more to their age than to the poets themselves: ‘oscurità che loro solamente arrecò la rozza povertà dei primi tempi’; ‘modo di scrivere toscano rozzamente da i primi trovato’ (fols [III]r, [III]v)). Nevertheless, it must be remarked that these critiques do not concern Dante, Cavalcanti, or Cino, but only the other early authors – that is to say, those added to the original plan in later stages. The final responsibility for these additions in all likelihood lies with the publisher Bernardo di Giunta, who despite the fact that most modern scholars downplay his contribution and actually deny that the letter signed by him is actually his,  seems to have had quite a pivotal role. In this respect, the opening letter is a fitting preface for the anthology, since both seem to reflect a compromise between cultural and editorial wishes that were perhaps not perfectly aligned.
To conclude, then, this article has shown that the 1527 ‘Giuntina delle rime’ was initially planned as a Dantean anthology, and that it was a Florentine reaction to the publication of Bembo’s Prose in 1525, building on philological work on Dante’s lyric poetry that was probably already underway. This reaction and the publication of a number of Dante’s lyric poems and related texts intended to counter Bembo’s proposed canon. The aim however was not to propose a new and entirely original choice of models, but to reinstate an old and well affirmed one, what we called the Dante–Petrarch lyric canon. This original intention is difficult to discern in the eventual print because the poems of one of the two authors, i.e., Petrarch, are absent from the anthology, while those of the other, i.e., Dante, have been complemented and surrounded first by texts of related authors and then at a later stage by a miscellaneous and rather heterogeneous book of poems by different authors, as we have also shown. Despite all these changes, the Sonetti e canzoni di diuersi antichi autori toscani’s nature as a response to Bembo’s linguistic dialogue stands even in its final form.

***

(Extra)ordinary Sensation and Visionary
Perception in Dante’s Purgatorio XV and XVII

While Dante does not articulate his understanding of visions in explicitly theoretical terms in the Commedia or elsewhere in his oeuvre, the closest equivalent to an implicit visionary theory can be found in the central cantos of Purgatorio. In Purg. XV and XVII, as the pilgrim traverses the terrace of wrath, visions take over Dante’s mind, offering him first the examples of gentleness rewarded, then of anger punished, as per the regular pattern of purgatorial learning that instructs Dante in virtues to cultivate and vices to avoid. In just the first fifty lines of Purg. XVII, Dante rehearses most of the terms that describe visionary perception in the Vita nuova and medieval vision literature more broadly: forms of imagine (imagine, imaginativa, imaginar) at ll. 7, 13, 21, 31, 43; vedere (vedessi, veder, vista, visïone) at ll. 2, 8, 27, 34; and the word fantasia at l. 25. According to Robert Hollander’s count, the episode contains more than one-fourth of all occurrences of this group of words in the poem.  For Teodolinda Barolini, this linguistic emphasis confirms that the central cantos of Purgatorio are ‘a mise-en-abyme of the visionary Commedia as a whole’,  even if, thanks to their narrative framing, the status of the purgatorial exempla as visions is much less controversial than 
While Dante’s writing has often been described as ‘visionary’ to recognise the far-reaching impact of his art that engages with some of the most radical philosophical and scientific theories of his day,4 what concerns me here is Dante’s ‘visionary’ writing in the stricter sense of the word, namely, as vision literature that describes receiving impressions and obtaining knowledge by means of visions. Much has been written about Dante’s visionary models,5 indebtedness to the medieval vision tradition,6 as well as the poem’s prophetic claims.7 What interests me instead with regard to the central cantos of Purgatorio is how Dante understands the pilgrim’s visionary perception to function: according to the Commedia, how does the human sensorium receive visions, and how can visionary experiences be conveyed to others who do not share them experientially?
Given the extreme concentration of imagine, vedere, and their cognates in Purg. XV and XVII, the importance of the cantos for understanding the visionary dimension of Dante’s writing is undeniable. What has received less scholarly attention is the ways in which Dante examines the differences and overlaps between everyday and extraordinary perception in the cantos. Therefore, this article attempts to understand in what ways Dante’s visionary vedere is both like and unlike everyday seeing if, as we shall see later, it involves senses beyond just sight.
In a direct address to the imaginativa, the faculty of the mind traditionally associated with the reception of external sensory input but also prophetic inspiration,8 Dante suggests that, similarly to 
everyday situations of extreme inward absorption, the inner visions in Purgatorio involve a complete withdrawal from the surrounding sensory environment: 
O imaginativa che ne rube talvolta sì di fuor, ch’om non s’accorge perché dintorno suonin mille tube, chi move te, se ’l senso non ti porge? 
(Purg. XVII, 13–16)10
Paradoxically, while the poet insists that the divinely implanted images do not employ perceptually derived phantasmata, or sensory impressions (“l senso non ti porge’, XVII, 16), the visions in the canto are characterised by extremely intense multisensory descriptions. The poet creates the effects of sensory experience for his readers in the effective absence of such experience; the gesturing, speaking, and moving inward representations function as a form of imaginary ekphrasis addressed to readers whose minds ‘solo da sensato apprende’ (Par. IV, 41).
Even when in Purg. XVII, Dante emphasises that his experience circumvents regular perceptual pathways, the terms that he uses in describing his extra-sensory visions remain characterised by an equivocal degree of physicality and materiality. This ambiguity is inherent in medieval perceptual vocabulary. When Dante refers to his vision of Haman as ‘questa imagine’ (Purg. XVII, 31), his language is influenced by an earlier visionary lexicon, which assumes that visions are transmitted through some form of images or image-like configurations of perception.  This language draws upon terminology describing ordinary perceptual processes, such as the communication of images via rarefied yet material units streaming from a perceived object, variously called eidōla, simulacra, and phantasmata in intromission theories of vision, as well as in theories that combine intromissive and extromissive features.  Insofar as the language bearing traces of physicality penetrates the medieval visionary vocabulary, Dante’s ‘imagin[i]’ (Purg. XVII, 31) and ‘vision[i]’ (XVII, 34), which the pilgrim receives in his body, remain marked by a degree of ambiguous sensoriality. For all the effort that Dante makes to underline that his visions rain directly into the imagination from above without the mediation of the external senses (‘piovve dentro a l’alta fantasia’, Purg. XVII, 25), in order to describe a vision, even an internal one, the poet cannot completely avoid the language of ordinary perception. Dante’s address to the imaginativa thus amounts to an invitation for his readers to wonder to what degree the celestially derived images resemble the simulacra we receive through the regular perceptual pathways.
We see this questioning in practice in Dante’s description of receiving the visions, which emphasises the speed and even violence with which they overwhelm the mind and then cease, allowing for an abrupt immersion into the visionary reality and for sudden transitions from one vision to another: ‘Poi’ (XVII, 25), ‘rompeo/sé per sé stessa’ (31–32), ‘cotal si moria’ (27). Dante’s visions eschew the regular perceptual patterns in which images come into view more incrementally, presenting less of an unanticipated impact on the mind. Glossing Dante’s use of the word apparve in the line ‘ne l’imagine mia apparve l’orma’ (XVII, 21), Anna Chiavacci Leonardi notes that it allows Dante to place emphasis on the suddenness with which the vision is received, ‘senza saper come’. While in everyday perception, the imaginativa manages sensory input that is introduced more gradually, Dante’s visions are characterised primarily by sensory-cognitive surprise and shock. 
For the purpose of this study, ‘visions’ will be understood as episodes limited in scope within the text, with clearly marked moments of beginning and ending, and explicitly introduced as visions thanks to Dante’s use of terminology that also signposts heightened visionary reality in other Trecento texts.14 However, I will maintain awareness of the difficulty of speaking about ‘extra- visionary’ episodes in the poem that has sometimes been treated as a visionary construct in its entirety.15 In examining how Dante’s poetic language makes connections between ordinary and extraordinary perception, I will first address Dante’s depiction of the faculties of imaginativa and fantasia, involved both in ordinary and visionary sensation. I will then examine the ecstatic nature of Dante’s visions and the poet’s subjective and multisensory portrayal of ecstasy. Finally, with the help of the images that accompany Purg. XV in British Library, MS Egerton 943, the article will analyse the complexity of perceptual layers in Dante’s visions produced without direct sensory input, yet written in such a way as to appeal to readers who think with, and through, their senses.
(Extra)ordinary Faculties: imaginativa and fantasia
In medieval faculty psychology, there remained plenty of uncertainty about the workings of the so- called inner senses, or inward wits, even in ordinary perceptual circumstances, let alone visionary contexts. Their very number was debated: while the estimative faculty and memory appear in most theoretical models of medieval inner faculties, the common sense was often discussed as a connective force separate from the inward wits, and phantasia was sometimes treated as part of the vis imaginativa, sometimes as a distinct faculty.  It might be precisely this existing ambiguity that gave Dante a degree of creative freedom in imagining the imaginativa and fantasia at their most receptive in Purg. XV and XVII. The conceptual openness of these faculties attracts Dante to ponder how the inner senses operate when confronted with divinely implanted visions, which presumably involve even greater cognitive demands than everyday states in which imaginativa and fantasia were thought to participate, such as the manipulation of images in memory recall. 
In Purg. XVII, alongside imaginativa, Dante introduces a sequence of lexical items derived from the terminology of scholastic psychology: ‘l’imagine mia’ (XVII, 21), ‘l’alta fantasia’ (25), ‘mia visïone’ 
(34), and ‘l’imaginar mio’ (43). Based on how these terms function in the canto, it would appear that the writer treats them as synonymous or nearly synonymous. This is the view most frequently found in Dante scholarship, endorsed by Michele Barbi, Charles S. Singleton, Umberto Bosco and Giovanni Reggio, and Nicola Fosca, which Chiavacci Leonardi summarises as follows: the canto describes ‘la vis imaginativa [che] è, nella filosofia scolastica, la facoltà dell’anima che riceve e conserva le immagini [. . .], detta anche phantasia’.  The conceptual overlap between the imaginativa and the fantasia appears justified by the words’ everyday use  and even Thomas Aquinas’s influential linguistic conflation of the two in the Summa theologiae: ‘phantasia sive imaginatio’ (I, q. 78, a. 4). 
Elsewhere in the Commedia, fantasia is called upon to highlight the novelty of Dante’s art and to indicate its supernatural or otherwise extraordinary sources. Upon encountering the heavenly eagle in Par. XIX, Dante struggles to find a suitable form of expression for the unity of voices he experiences: while the eagle’s beak utters ‘io’ and ‘mio’, it really means ‘noi’ and ‘nostro’ (Par. XIX, 11–12). What Dante must describe was never reported by voice, nor written in ink, nor presented to the human fantasia:
E quel che mi convien ritrar testeso, non portò voce mai, né scrisse incostro, né fu per fantasia già mai compreso . . . 
(Par. XIX, 7–9)
Both Fosca and Chiavacci Leonardi treat this fantasia as identical with the previously encountered image-receiving faculty of the mind: ‘né fu mai colto (compreso) da fantasia, cioè capacità di ricezione delle immagini’ (Fosca); ‘fantasia è la virtù immaginativa, che accoglie (comprende, riceve) nella mente le immagini’ (Chiavacci Leonardi). In Paradiso, the merely receptive function of fantasia is particularly appropriate in the context of a novelty topos (‘né fu per fantasia già mai compreso’, XIX, 9): the heavenly realities taken in by the human fantasia exceed the limits of the familiar and anything that the mind could invent based on previous experience. 
If the faculty involved in processing images in Par. XIX is the same as in Purg. XVII, this allows Dante to assert the distinctiveness of his experience in the heavenly realm compared to the visions seen before. While Dante’s visions in Purg. XVII offer a fresh and direct insight into the well-known biblical and classical stories of Procne, Haman, and Queen Amata, Par. XIX proclaims the extreme unfamiliarity that Dante’s fantasia has to mediate. Dante thus announces that the paradisiacal reality encountered by the pilgrim with his external senses is even more surprising and overwhelming than the images previously received in the visionary trance of Purg. XVII. This emphasis in Par.
