Under the new paradigm, information became quantifiable and monetisable, and thus a commodity to be exploited.1 Moreover, the production and exchange of information ceased to be a human prerogative and was extended to mechanical actors.2 Finally, new technologies – the computer, but also the television and other electronic media – marked a progressive dissociation between the material and informational aspects of reality, as well as between consciousness and embodiment.3 Italo Calvino was certainly not alone in appropriating ideas from the field of information science and cybernetics. However, the comparison this study wishes to draw between Calvino’s book Le città invisibili and the work of Ted Nelson and Arata Isozaki is noteworthy because, far from simply investigating similar issues at the same time, they adopted virtually identical images and metaphors to express and conceptualise their work.
In 1965, the visionary computer scientist, Ted Nelson, coined the word ‘hypertext’ and began to develop a system capable of storing and organising information, especially written text, but also audio, video, and mixed media, for which he came up with the word 
‘hypermedia’.  Anticipating many of the features that would later characterise the World Wide Web, he called his hypertext project – even now not yet fully realised – Project Xanadu, after the mythical palace of emperor Kublai Khan. The inspiration came to Nelson, as discussed in the next section, from reading Coleridge’s famous poem ‘Kubla Khan: or A Vision in a Dream. A Fragment’, as his idea of a hypertext shared a number of features with the verses, such as a non-linear and fluid structure, and a visionary quality. The first hypertext project in history and Le città invisibili both referenced Kublai Khan and, even more significantly, were devoted to mapping and ordering information, favoured a rhizomatic structure, and embraced the oneiric fluidity they derived from a literary text. 
The second point of convergence is with the work of Japanese architect, Arata Isozaki, who began his career working in close collaboration with the Kenzō Tange lab and with the Metabolist Group of Japanese architects, who applied cybernetic principles to urban planning and architecture.  In 1966, Isozaki, at the time a young but promising architect, published a theoretical essay titled ‘Invisible City’.  The text presented his plan for a cybernetic city, in which the flow of information organises a now dematerialised and constantly evolving urban space. In Isozaki, as well as in Calvino’s Le città invisibili, the positive traits of lightness and invisibility are the quintessential characteristics of the urban space at the time of information technologies. However, this environment can easily degenerate into its negative double: the shapeless and continuous megalopolis, the self- consuming city, the rubbish dump.
Calvino, while writing Le città invisibili, was likely unaware of Ted Nelson’s project, Xanadu, and Arata Isozaki’s conceptualisation of ‘invisible city’. Nonetheless, they ended up inhabiting the same ‘imaginary continent’, to use one of Calvino’s expressions.  The following comparative analysis focuses on these convergences: first, it will consider the similarities with Nelson’s work on the impact of information science on the definition of knowledge and textuality; second, it will examine the convergence with Isozaki on the issues concerning urban spaces and their perception under the new cybernetic paradigm. The intent is to situate Le città invisibili within the debate on the effects of the new concept of information brought by cybernetics – at the theoretical level – and by the advent of computers – at the technical level. Still, this convergence should not be taken as a mere coincidence, but rather as evidence of how in each era new ideas tend to take on similar visual referents and to cluster around the same semantic fields without having to postulate a common source. By exploring such convergences and contextualising these metaphors and themes and their selection by Calvino, Nelson, and Isozaki, I demonstrate that Le città invisibili was part of an interdisciplinary and intertextual dialogue that expanded across disciplines and cultures. Thus, my analysis offers a new perspective of Calvino’s book, connecting it to the author’s interest in cybernetics and information technologies, and asserts the active role of literature in shaping computer culture.
Le città invisibili and the New Concept of Information
Among the many critical interpretative keys applied to Le città invisibili, the one linking the book to Calvino’s Oulipian experiments with combinatory literature and, therefore, to his interest in computer and information science counts several proponents.  Le città invisibili was published only five years after his famous 1967 conference ‘Cibernetica and fantasmi’,  which left a mark in the debate on computer-generated literature, and it preceded by only one year the publication of the second extended edition of his combinatory book par excellence, Il castello dei destini incrociati. Expectedly, Le città invisibili shared with these two texts the same fascination towards the antinomic relation between mathematical constraint and open structure, chaotic multiplication and geometric selectivity typical of cybernetic literature – a label I understand as embracing not just computer- generated texts, but rather literary works informed by the new concept of information. 
However, possibly because of the oneiric and poetic quality of its prose, Le città invisibili is not generally recognised as informed by Calvino’s interest in cybernetics and information science as much as other texts that engage with techno-scientific knowledge more openly, such as the ‘deductive stories’ in Ti con zero, or the Oulipian experiment ‘L’incendio della casa abominevole’.  Yet, when we consider the two fundamental issues addressed in the book, it is readily apparent that the epistemological and ontological implications of the new concept of information, brought about by the advent of computers, must have influenced Calvino.
On the epistemological level, computers changed the way people archived and parsed information. At the technical level, the unprecedented capacity of computers to store information allowed for an indiscriminate and vast collection of data, which in turn created the problem of information access and retrieval. On a more abstract level, cyberneticians, such as Claude Shannon and Norbert Wiener, theorised that meaningful communication happens only when it is possible to discriminate information from noise.  This creates a precarious and ever-changing balance, as any communication system risks being saturated with messages to the point of them becoming unintelligible, and thus, noise. Calvino was well aware of these issues and, as I shall discuss in the following sections, engaged with them in his theoretical and artistic production. Suffice it to say that his interest in computer-generated literature was motivated by the possibility to entrust the machine with the task of multiplying and then selecting between plots and narrative solutions.  Furthermore, he addressed the antinomic relation between noise and information in a number of stories, such as ‘Un segno nello spazio’ and ‘La memoria del mondo’. 
Le città invisibili, too, can be considered part of this discussion. The narrative framework presents us with a series of dialogues in which Kublai Khan attempts to map his kingdom on the basis of Marco Polo’s reports. The emperor’s continuous – and inexorably doomed – effort to organise and select among the many detailed descriptions, presented to him by the Venetian traveller, can rightfully be considered a meditation on the classification and selection of information. His palace is the space where data is analysed, ordered, decoded, selected – or at least where this activity is attempted. This quest for a clear map to navigate the network of information, referred in the book as the ‘labyrinth’, was likely informed by cybernetic theories on how to store and discriminate between information and noise.
On the ontological level, the cybernetic paradigm, established since the mid 1950s, asserted the preponderance of informational aspects over material ones, or at least established that the latter directly depend on the first ones.  Famously, Norbert Wiener, the founding father of cybernetics, equated humans and intelligent machines on the basis of their shared ability to store and exchange messages.  The informational paradigm applied to living organism was further supported by the discovery of the DNA structure by Watson and Crick, who identified how biological matter is coded.  Tellingly, in the already mentioned ‘Cibernetica e fantasmi’, Calvino made reference to Wiener’s theories, as well as to Watson and Crick’s discovery so as to explain how the informational metaphor, which describes the world in computational terms as ‘discreet’ rather than ‘continuous’, originated a new forma mentis adopted well beyond the realm of science. 
Calvino understood that this new paradigm established the predominance of information over matter, as he posited, for instance, in the story ‘Priscilla’, in which the process of cell duplication and the transmission of genetic codes takes on informational and existential tones.  Moreover, the computational nature of reality posited the concept of virtualisation as a third option in between abstraction and actualisation. It was Pierre Levy who, while rejecting the equation between virtualisation and derealisation proposed by Jean-François Lyotard and Jean Baudrillard, defined virtualisation as ‘the movement of actualization in reverse’, entailing ‘a displacement of the center of ontological gravity of the object considered’.  Thus, according to Levy, while the actual is the materialisation of one among the many possible outcomes, the virtual points instead to the network of potentialities, from which that one actual realisation spurred. The ontology of an object lies not in its material, visible, realised shape, but rather in the sum of its unfulfilled, potential forms.
If we read the book against the idea of ‘littérature potentielle’, to which Calvino subscribed in the same years that saw the gestation of Le città invisibili, it is evident how the ontology originated from the new concept of information is at work in this text.  First, the cities visited by Marco Polo are places where invisible networks of information are encoded into the material space, from which they receive their concrete shape. Dreams, desires, memories, fears literally build the space – ‘Le città come i sogni sono costruite di desideri e di paure’ – in the same way the genetic code determines biology.  Second, the cities described do not have a fixed and stable form: evanescent, constantly evolving into their opposites, split into their doubles, threatened by disruption and oblivion, they put forward an idea of the urban space as a network of potentialities, thus conforming to the ontology of the virtual.
In keeping with this interpretative key, it is possible to read the two narrative spaces of Kublai Khan’s palace, were the dialogues take places, and the ‘invisible cities’ that Marco Polo visits as dealing respectively with the epistemological and ontological questions raised by the advent of information science. Indeed, while the descriptions investigate the informational nature of reality – the city as an emblem, a text, a sign –, the dialogues deal with how to best represent and record information – the chessboard, the atlas, the catalogues as means through which Kublai Khan tries to make sense of his empire.
The Palace of the Kublai Khan and the Hypertext: Connecting Calvino and Ted Nelson
Attempting to sketch a profile of Ted Nelson and to frame his contribution to computer culture is not an easy task. On the one hand, this has to do with his desire to position himself and his work across different fields so as to contest the idea of computers as technological rather than cultural tools. Indeed, on his personal website he proudly defines himself not as ‘a tekkie’ but rather ‘a systems humanist’ as well as a ‘philosopher and [a] poet’.  On the other hand, his visionary approach to computer culture has invited diverging opinions, spanning from deep admiration to derision. Another pioneer in the field of computer and network culture, Howard Rheingold, humorously summarised the polarised feeling surrounding Nelson by stating that ‘[t]ime will tell whether he is a prophet too far ahead of his time, or just a persistent crackpot’. 
Divergent opinions notwithstanding, Nelson undeniably left a mark in the history of computer culture when in 1965, at the age of twenty-eight, he published a paper in which he coined the word ‘hypertext’ and used, for the first time, the word ‘links’ to refer to the connections between different texts in a digital document.  His ambition was to create a universal digital library in the shape of a network, in which all the links – references and direct quotations – between documents – written or otherwise – would be traceable and modifiable. The creation of a new version of an existent text, or the quotation of a source would have left a permanent record in the network. For his vision, Nelson took inspiration from the work of Vannevar Bush, who in his famous 1945 essay ‘As We May Think’ envisioned an electromechanical device called ‘memex’ capable of compressing, storing, and cataloguing all the existing books and documents, accessible on microfilm. 
In order to implement his vision, Nelson created what he called Project Xanadu aimed at developing a software to support his hypertext system. At first, the project attracted considerable attention and, in 1988, the American software company Autodesk invested in the project.  However, to this day, Nelson has not yet managed to release his program, prompting his detractors to describe it as the ‘longest-running vaporwave project in the history of computing’.  In 2014, a version called OpenXanadu and described as ‘a working deliverable’ was made available to the public.  And yet, it was far from capable of fulfilling the promises made by Nelson decades before of giving ‘you a screen in your home from which you can see into the world’s hypertext libraries’. 
The image of users provided with a window through which they can access and map the world’s entire knowledge without leaving home is reminiscent of the character of Kublai Khan in Le città invisibili who, sheltered in his palace, receives information on his empire through Marco Polo’s reports. However, to unveil stronger similarities between Nelson’s and Calvino’s vision, it is essential to understand why the programmer named his hypertext project after the royal palace of Xanadu, of which he read in the celebrated poem by Samuel Taylor Coleridge ‘Kubla Khan. 
A Vision in A Dream: A Fragment’.  Coleridge’s text itself constitutes a further point of contact between the work of Calvino and Nelson, as they both specifically reference it.
In spite of the lukewarm reception received upon publication in 1816, which occurred almost twenty years after its composition in 1797, ‘Kubla Khan’ is considered today one of the pinnacles of Coleridge’s literary production.  The palace of Xanadu is the setting for a series of oneiric descriptions and evocative images of mysterious and fascinating places, described in the first three stanzas. The poem, by its author’s admission, is incomplete, a circumstance that adds to the sense of magical suspension created by the verses. The story of its composition is as famous as the poem itself and thus indispensable to its interpretation. The first published version of the poem, by Lord Byron’s suggestion, was prefaced by a text in which Coleridge explained its genesis. He recounted that, while having an opium-fuelled dream, he saw Kublai Khan’s palace Xanadu and composed a poem about it. Once awake, he immediately tried to put on paper the verses conceived in his dreams, but a visitor – the now proverbial ‘person from Porlock’ – knocked at his door and distracted him, which caused him to forget the rest of the poem. The 54 lines published, Coleridge maintained, are thus the only fragment he was able to recollect.
Several key elements of this poem seeped into Le città invisibili as well as in Nelson’s conceptualisation of hypertext and ended up taking on a different meaning in light of the epistemological implications of the advent of information science. First, dreams as a concept that speaks to the idea of virtuality – as defined by Levy – as unrealised potentialities implied in the network. Second, the tension between remembering and forgetting as two opposed and equally essential strategies to store and access information and, ultimately, to create meaning. In Le città invisibili, this is expressed through the opposition between Kublai Khan’s desire to organise and select what information about his empire to keep and to discard, and Marco Polo’s exuberant narrative which constantly produces new data and, in a way, disorder. In Nelson’s Project Xanadu a similar tension is at work, as the hypertext was tasked to map but also to multiply the links between texts. Finally, and most importantly, both Calvino and Nelson shared with Coleridge’s poem the idea of fluidity and non-linear narrative. These last two elements were central to a new epistemological approach that, far from being a prerogative of digital tools and electronic literature, nonetheless received a novel impetus from the advent of computers.
The most evident aspect that the two borrowed from the poem ‘Kubla Khan’ is the oneiric atmosphere evoked by its Far Eastern and atemporal setting, as well as by the circumstance of its composition. Indeed, this was one of the main elements considered by Calvino, when, in 1960, he first attempted a reworking of the characters of Marco Polo and Kublai Khan for a film screenplay, which will later influence the composition of Le città invisibili.  In a letter dated 2 September 1960 to Suso Cecchi D’Amico, the author stated that Coleridge’s poem was the main model helping him to channel the ‘carica visionaria’, the visionary power he wanted to express in his own work:
Insomma, ho cercato di seguire il metodo di Coleridge, che fumando oppio e leggendo Il Milione compose in sogno ‘In Xanadu Kublai Khan . . . ’ Io non ho oppio a disposizione e non so cosa mi salterà fuori, comunque mi pare che quello su cui dobbiamo puntare è lo spettacolo delle meraviglie del mondo come poteva esser concepito in un tempo in cui il mondo era sconosciuto. 
Such oneiric atmospheres and a sense of wonder were not all that Calvino borrowed from the poem ‘Kubla Khan’. Coleridge masterfully blurred the lines between dreams and reality to the point that the reader is unsure of what is fiction and what is a factual account. The same happens in Le città invisibili where Kublai Khan often entertains the possibility that Marco Polo’s reports might be unreliable or, better yet, visions and reveries rather than objective descriptions. Tellingly, also the traveller often calls into doubt his own memories.  Additionally, the line demarcating the boundaries between dreams and reality is directly put into question in the famous passage in which Marco tells the emperor that only his eyelids separate his mental world from the real one and, yet, it would be forever impossible to distinguish between the two.  But in order further to understand why Coleridge’s poem should be considered an important source for Le città invisibili, and not simply one of the many reworking of Marco Polo’s story in Western literature to which Calvino makes reference in passing, we ought to consider another possible source that might have worked as an intermediary between Coleridge and Calvino: Luis Borges. In his 1952 collection of essays Otras Inquisiciones, which combines literary criticism and philosophical analysis, Borges published two articles dedicated to the English poet: ‘La flor de Coleridge’ and ‘El sueño de Coleridge’, the second one offering an analysis of the theme of dreams in ‘Kubla Khan’.  Borges tells the story of how, like the poem came to Coleridge in a dream, also the historical ‘Kublai Khan built a palace according to a plan that he had seen in a dream and retained in his memory’.39 This information, Borges explains, is found in a Persian book titled Compendium of Histories written in the fourteenth Century by Rashid al-Din, a book that was first translated and circulated in Europe twenty years after Coleridge published his poem. Borges thus concludes that a dream generated both the real Xanadu, as well as its literary rendition, a consideration that leads him to equate real and imagined spaces: ‘Perhaps an archetype not yet revealed to mankind, an eternal object (to use Whitehead’s term), is gradually entering the world; its first manifestation was the palace; its second, the poem. Whoever compares them will see that they are essentially the same’.  Borges’ influence on Calvino’s literary production at large, and on Le città invisibili in particular, has been long established by the critics. It is thus far from unplausible that Borges’ reading of Coleridge’s ‘Kubla Khan’ oriented Calvino’s interest in this text, specifically when it came to the relationship between reality and dreams.  
However, it is the structure of the book that more significantly exposes Calvino’s reworking of the English poem’s visionary elements and Chinese setting in light of his interest in computer culture. Among the many organisational models considered in relation to Le città invisibili, the chessboard is the one that attracted most critical attention, as Calvino overtly employs it to mark the analogy between textual and geographical spaces.  Nonetheless, another model that points towards the convergence between literary practice and computers’ combinatory logics should also be considered. This is the Chinese ancient divination book called I Ching or Yi Jing, also known as the Book of Changes, which scholars in the field of Chinese Studies have only cursorily compared to Calvino’s conceptualisation of ‘literary machine’.  Over the centuries, the complex structure of the I Ching has lent itself to several philosophical interpretations. At the most superficial level, the book is composed of two parts, a divination text, and a commentary. The divination text is made of sixty- four units, or hexagrams, each composed of six lines, either continuous or broken, which result from the combination of two trigrams. For each hexagram and trigram, the book provides a brief description of their meaning. The answer to the divination comes from the combination of a certain number of hexagrams and their interpretations, not unlike Tarot cards – another narrative machine familiar to Calvino.
There are several reasons for considering the I Ching one of the possible models that Calvino took into consideration when writing his book. The first one is the obvious reference to Chinese culture that the book’s setting elicits. More significantly, the structure of Le città invisibili is consistent with the model: like the I Ching, Calvino’s book is made of sixty-four parts, as it counts fifty-five descriptions of cities and nine dialogues between Marco Polo and Kublai Khan. Furthermore, each city functions as an enigmatic emblem dense with meanings, which prompts many different and open interpretations, like the hexagrams in the I Ching. Finally, the combinatory logic that operates in the divination book replicates the one employed by Calvino and fellow Oulipo writers in their literary experiments informed by mathematical constraints. The appropriation of the I Ching by the field of mathematics is another circumstance suggesting that Calvino might have been intrigued by this model.
The I Ching holds an important role in the history of Boolean logic and computing as its visual language is at the base of computers’ binary code.  Gottfried Leibniz, the philosopher and mathematician who refined the binary number system in its modern form, derived it specifically from the I Ching, which he first introduced in Europe in 1703, as he interpreted the broken lines of the hexagrams as the ‘zero’, and the continuous lines as the ‘one’.  Calvino, an admirer of Leibniz’s thought, was certainly aware of it and so it was, years before him, Borges. The Argentinian writer, equally influenced by the philosopher, mentioned Leibniz’s debt to the I Ching more than once in his 1940 book review of ‘Edward Kasner & James Newman, Mathematics and the Imagination’ and in his 1942 essay ‘El idioma analítico de John Wilkins’.  Additionally, the divination book provided an inspiration for his poem ‘Para una versión del I King’. While this last text could not have influenced Le città invisibili, as it was published four years later in the collection La moneda de hierro,47 it is nonetheless testament to Borges’ interest in the I Ching.
One might retort that such convergences could very well be a coincidence, as Leibniz, Coleridge, and Borges are common references in Western culture. However, it would have been quite unlikely for Calvino, while writing Le città invisibili, to be unaware of a Chinese text dealing with dreams and emblems that combines narrative imagination and mathematical principles – the same book, one might add, that inspired Leibniz and interested Borges, both essential points of reference for his work. For Calvino, modelling Le città invisibili on the I Ching meant referencing a text that did not merely employ combinatory logic, but one which originated the binary system and, eventually, computer coding and framed dreams and vision within a mathematical constraint. The visionary quality of Coleridge’s ‘Kubla Khan’ and its Chinese setting were thus channelled by Calvino in Le città invisibili with the additional reference to information science. The feverish dream of Coleridge, and the divinatory power of Romantic literature were implicitly entrusted to the computer’s binary code.
Nelson, too, aimed at channelling in his work Coleridge’s oneiric atmosphere – a surprising circumstance, considering that he was operating in the field of computer science rather than literature. This has to do partially with his attempt to fashion himself as a digital guru, sharing with the world his revolutionary vision supposedly capable of changing the way people created and accessed information. Furthermore, Nelson’s idea of hypertext was born in the era of computer counterculture, when bottom-up, community-led approaches to the new technology were imbued with psychedelic culture and new age philosophies. Fittingly, Nelson’s writings on Project Xanadu are full of references to pivotal texts in psychedelic literature such as Alice in Wonderland and The Wizard of Oz.  However, Nelson’s interest in Coleridge’s treatment of dreams, beyond lending to his hypertext a prophetic and visionary quality, should also be connected to the actual structure of Project Xanadu. ‘Kubla Khan’, according to its author, is but a version of the original text – in fact, the only one that he was able to reconstruct. Returning to the already mentioned theorisation by Levy, the ‘original’ of this poem is not ‘real’ as in ‘realised’, but as in ‘virtual’: it is the sum of the potential texts of which only one was actually written down and published by Coleridge. It was precisely this network of potentialities that Nelson was interested in while envisioning his hypertext.  In contrast to the eventual fate of the hypertextual model and its modern understanding, he aimed at presenting writers with a technical tool allowing them to experiment outside the constraints of linear writing. This is exactly what Calvino attempted with Le città invisibili. As Peter Schmideg, one of Nelson’s personal friends, explains, ‘Project Xanadu is Proust wired, electronically/digitally expanding stream of consciousness’ for which the model, Schmideg adds, was Coleridge’s poem. 
A second element from ‘Kubla Khan’ that influenced Calvino and Nelson alike is the opposition between remembering and forgetting. In Coleridge the supposed inability to recollect the entire text is what gives the poetic fragment its evocative and allusive power, since what is missing is more loaded with meaning than what is actually written. When we transport this concept from the poetics of fragment into the field of information science, it is clear that the equilibrium between forgetting and remembering is a crucial one in order to discriminate between what is worth being archived, and what instead needs to be erased, as its preservation would only increase the level of noise, finally leading to the loss of all meanings. This tension is explored by Calvino in his short story ‘La memoria del mondo’, in which the protagonist, tasked with selecting what of the entire human knowledge should be archived for posterity, is faced with the question if what is left out of the archive, thus forgotten, were instead the most meaningful information. Its absence thus speaks louder than the data on record. In Le città invisibili, while the reference to information science is not as explicit, Kublai Kahn is faced with the same unsolvable dilemma, as he tries to discern between essential and accessory information so as to draw maps and atlases of his kingdom. What Nelson tried to accomplish with Project Xanadu was essentially the same endeavour attempted by Calvino’s character: to draw a map to navigate knowledge.
Additionally, both Coleridge’s poem and Le città invisibili use the image of troubled waters to express vanishing memories that the teller tries to retain. In Calvino, Marco Polo confesses to the emperor his fears of forgetting his hometown, Venice, which is fading away because erased by the memories of other cities he visited – his file being overwritten by new information. The narrator’s admission is preceded by an image that is, tellingly, almost a calque from the passage in Coleridge’s preface. In this text the poet explained how the reminiscences of his dream about Xanadu palace were troubled ‘like the images on the surface of a stream into which a stone had been cast’. Similarly, in order to visually express Marco Polo’s fear of losing his mental image of Venice, Calvino wrote: ‘L’acqua del lago era appena increspata; il riflesso di rame dell’antica reggia dei Sung si frantumava in riverberi scintillanti come foglie che galleggiano’. 
The danger that the proliferation of data can lead to a loss of information or to chaos is central to Nelson’s idea of hypertext system. Much unlike modern standards, Nelson envisioned – and still envisions – a hypertext in which sources are connected by two-way links, which are meant to keep a record of all the correspondences between texts. For instance, in Nelson’s system, every time the Divine Comedy quotes, directly or indirectly, a passage from the Bible, a two-way link would be created that it is accessible either to the readers of the Divine Comedy file and to the ones of the Bible. This solution, in Nelson’s intention, preserves the memory of all the connections between the texts.  Furthermore, in contrast with Berners-Lee’s Web, Nelson’s hyperlinks are not meant to take the user from one page to another but, like in Vannevar Bush’s initial plan, the texts are supposed to appear on the screen side by side.  Failing to do so, Nelson decries, is an oversimplification that leads to the erasure of the complex and meaningful connections between documents, as the user is left navigating without a map.  In an interview with director Werner Herzog – one of his few genuine admirers – for his 2016 documentary on Internet culture Low and Behold, Nelson criticises today’s hypertext computer systems for ‘[r]educing a tapestry of interconnections to a narrow sequence’ and states that ‘this is a wrongful compression of what should spread out’.  Berners-Lee’s vision, he maintains, prevented the fluidity that is instead crucial to his idea of the hypertext intended as a system of ‘ever-changing relationships and structures’.  The visual representation of his hypertext, Nelson explains, comes from Coleridge’s poem, in which streams of water surround the palace of Xanadu as a symbol of fluid consciousness and imagination.
This last image of flowing water points to the last converging point between Nelson’s hypertext and Le città invisibili: the preference accorded to non-linear narrative.  While non-linearity is peculiar to all hypertexts, what differentiates Project Xanadu is the focus on text production rather than consumption. Indeed, Nelson was mostly interested in creating the condition to allow for ‘nonsequential writing’, of which he identified a literary model in Julio Cortazar’s Rayuela, and Vladimir Nabokov’s Pale Fire.  The expert in electronic literature Espen Aarseth identifies these two texts, together with Nelson’s hypertext and the I Ching, as the main examples of a particular kind of textual structure that he famously defined ‘cybertext’.  Cybertexts, according to Aarseth, are not necessarily electronic texts. What distinguishes them from any other narrative form is that they allow for different reading paths, a feature that invites the comparison between cybertexts and multicursal labyrinths.  Texts comparable to unicursal or linear labyrinths, while giving the illusion of losing oneself in the narration, still guide the readers towards the exit, as the reading path is only one. Texts analogous to multicursal labyrinths – meaning cybertexts – instead require a concerted effort to be traversed. This is clearly the case in Nelson’s hypertext, as the challenge posed by non-linear structure is instrumental in liberating people from a coercive and hierarchical system of information: ‘[t]he purpose of computers is human freedom, and so the purpose of hypertext is overview and understanding’, Nelson emphatically states.  The same idea of multicursal labyrinth as a topographic rendition of cybertext can be applied to Le città invisibili, as Calvino described his text as a challenged posed to the reader: ‘un libro [. . .] è uno spazio in cui il lettore deve entrare, girare, magari perdersi, ma a un certo punto trovare un’uscita, o magari parecchie uscite, la possibilità d’aprirsi una strada per venirne fuori’.  Interestingly, Aarseth, while excluding Calvino from the list of writers experimenting with cybertexts, gives the same exact definition of ‘ergodic literature’, a synonym he uses to express the same concept: ‘in ergodic literature, nontrivial effort is required to allow the reader to traverse the text’. 
The reason for this lack of inclusion of Le città invisibili in the category of cybertext is possibly due to a confusion between the definition of combinatory literature and the one of non-linear narrative structure, as both are instances of ‘open works’. Of all of Calvino’s texts belonging to the so-called ‘combinatory phase’ only Le città invisibili is an example of ergodic literature. Indeed, Pierpaolo Antonello points out that ‘[l]a struttura de Le città invisibili non è una vera e propria contrainte, ma una griglia ordinativa di tessere che avrebbero potuto essere disposte altrimenti’.  In Il castello dei destini incrociati and Se una notte d’inverno, as well as in ‘L’incendio della casa abominevole’, the author experimented with combinatory logic and with the idea of literature as a permutational operation. In Le città invisibili, however, it is the reader who is invited to play the permutational game, as the numeration of the descriptions, as well as their grouping into different sections by their titles, provide with a grid of reference to attempt different paths. While the other three texts follow the structure chosen by their author, therefore drawing a linear labyrinth, Le città invisibili presents a network in which the reader can roam freely. Thus, the book can be considered the only hypertext that Calvino ever wrote, in which the concept of literature machine does not apply simply to its composition, but to its consumption as well.
Nelson, too, explored similar ideas in his second book, suggestively titled Literature Machine, in which he delved into his project of developing Project Xanadu in service of a new concept of literature, intended as a vast and constantly in-progress assemblage.  The preface, featuring his usual bombastic and visionary tone, encourages to ‘[i]magine a new libertarian literature with alternative explorations so anyone can choose the pathway or approach that best suits him or her . . . imagine a rebirth of literacy’.66 As with many of Nelson’s statements, its vagueness has more to do with a confused vision rather with Coleridge’s poetic reticence. Project Xanadu did not revolutionise literature, nor this analysis aims to claim that Calvino took inspiration from Nelson’s hypertext. Nonetheless, the many shared elements and their convergence on the same literary source do invite to consider the palace of Xanadu as an emblem of early hypertext culture that summarises and maps a network of heterogeneous ideas.
Invisible Cities and Cybernetic Architecture: Connecting Calvino and Arata Isozaki
While it is very unlikely that Calvino was ever aware of the work of Ted Nelson, the same cannot be said about Arata Isozaki. Letizia Modena, in her monograph dedicated to Calvino’s informed involvement in the debates in the fields of architecture and urbanism, makes a compelling case in support of an interpretation of Le città invisibili as the author’s attempt to contribute to the discussion. However, and quite surprisingly, she does not include Isozaki in the list of architects who possibly influenced Calvino. To be fair, there appears to be no textual evidence indicating that he had any familiarity with the work of the Japanese architect, although the young member of the Metabolist movement, formed around Kenzo Tangē, was far from unknown in Italy at the time when Calvino was working of his book.
In March 1963, the architectural and design magazine Casabella devoted an issue to Japan.  The section presenting new trends in Japanese architecture contained a visually striking drawing of Isozaki’s project for an aerial city – on which we will return later – that mixed Classical and futuristic elements. More importantly, Isozaki was invited to participate in the infamous Milano Triennale of 1968, which was occupied by protesters soon after its opening. For the occasion, Isozaki created an interactive environment called Electronic Labyrinth composed of twelve reflecting panels, each one displaying a combination of images from Japanese classic paintings of demons, and pictures of Japan in the aftermath of the nuclear bombing. A number of sensors were designed to pick up the visitors’ presence and movements and respond in real time with visual and audio effects. 
On its opening day, the Triennale was occupied by the contesters, joined in solidarity by Isozaki, as a way of challenging the status quo in architecture and rejecting the concept of exhibition tout court.  A very limited group of journalists and people in the field had the chance to view the installations. However, the event was announced in the Italian press as an important showcase for national and international architecture and design, and received a lot of attention because of the disruption. Calvino indubitably followed the Triennale, and it is thus highly likely that he encountered the name of Isozaki, the Japanese architect who presented an evanescent multimedia labyrinth of ruined cities. It is, however, not crucial to determine whether Calvino had actual knowledge of Isozaki’s theorisation of the ‘invisible city’ as the urban space informed by cybernetics. Indeed, the essay, titled ‘Invisible City’, in which Isozaki formulated such concept was first published in Japan in 1966 but translated from Japanese only several years later the publication of Calvino’s book.  As in the case of Nelson’s Project Xanadu, the intent of this analysis is to draw a comparison between similar visualisations of the same issues, rather than to identify Calvino’s direct sources of inspiration.
Isozaki’s conceptualisation of ‘invisible city’ has to be contextualised within his involvement with the Metabolist movement and the general interest towards the application of cybernetic principles to architecture. Metabolism is an architectural movement established in Japan in the post-war period and led by Kenzo Tangē and his Lab.  As one can infer from the group’s name, the core principle informing this new tendency was the belief that urban spaces function as living organisms, forever mutable and evolving. Accordingly, the architect’s duty is to embrace and guide such variations and to design buildings that fit with this fluid environment, hence expanding and mutating depending on the changing needs of society.  Beside the biological metaphor, Metabolist architecture was also informed by principles derived from cybernetics, as they too were apt to describe a fluid and unstable system shaped by mutual interactions between its constitutive elements.  Like Calvino in those same years, Metabolists embraced the shift in the ontology consequent to the advent of information science that recognised the preponderance of informational over material aspects of reality. The influence of cybernetic theories and the role of information technologies in urban planning was even greater in the work of Isozaki, who, while collaborating with Tangē Lab, was never officially part of it.  The projects that best demonstrate his involvement with cybernetics are the already mentioned Electronic Labyrinth and the Festival Plaza that he designed for the 1970 Expo in Osaka. This too was a multi-media environment shaped by human-machine interactions and located at the centre of the exposition, under a roof-like structure designed by Tangē.  Isozaki, with the help of a computer engineer, built two giant robots equipped with sensors and tasked with collecting information from the surrounding environment, meaning from the crowd of people visiting the Plaza. The robots were connected to a computer that elaborated the data collected and sent back information to instruct the robots on how to behave: where and how to move, what sound and light effects to play. A cybernetic feedback loop between the Expo visitors, the robots, and the computer was shaping the ever-changing space of the Plaza, defined by a stream of data rather than by material buildings.
It is in his 1966 essay ‘Invisible City’ that Isozaki fully articulated his vision for a cybernetic environment, later achieved in Electric Labyrinth and in the project for the Expo. There are two key concepts formulated in this programmatic text that invite a comparison with Calvino’s discourse on urban spaces in Le città invisibili. First, the idea of cities as network of signs and information. This, on the one hand calls for a connection between semiology, information science, and urbanism, while on the other prompts to recognise the centrality of process over realised form. Second, Isozaki asserted the power of simulation, intended either in the technical sense of computer simulation and combinatory logics, as well as in a theoretical and more general sense of a network of potentialities posited by a cybernetic ontology.
While in Calvino’s book the critics have connected the invisible quality of the cities described with a variety of meanings, in Isozaki the same trait of ‘invisibility’ attributed to the new urban space is directly linked to Wiener’s cybernetics, the field that theorised the predominance of informational over material aspects of reality, and predicated the dependence of latter on the first ones.  Cybernetics, in Isozaki’s view, did not simply provide an explanation for the increasingly liquid state of the new urban environment, but also with a tool to approach such disorienting changes. The answer, he maintained, was to develop a cybernetic approach to architecture that recognised how physical spaces had become subordinated to the flow of energy and information consequently to the diffusion of electronic media. Failing to see beyond the material aspects was to miss the real forces shaping the city. He explained:
For me, the modern city is a nest of invisibilities, a place, like the labyrinth in Through the Looking Glass, where it is impossible to grasp the things that fly out toward one. It is still impossible to know its true form or to make forecasts about the future behind the looking glass. Cybernetics lies at the foundation of the predicted spaces [. . .]. The space itself can be called cybernetics environment. Adopting this attitude may provide an Ariadne’s thread to lead us out of the maze of the city interior. 
In Le città invisibili, Kublai Khan experiences the same sense of disorientation when presented with the dematerialisation of reality: ‘nella mente del Kan l’impero si rifletteva in un deserto di dati labili e intercambiabili come grani di sabbia’.78 Not unlike Isozaki, Calvino’s character also responds by attempting to grasp ‘le ragioni invisibili di cui le città vivevano, e per cui forse, dopo morte, rivivranno’.79 Indeed, as Isozaki declares that ‘process alone is trust worthy’.  Calvino’s emperor is conscious that not the material shape, which is transeunt, but the invisible laws governing a city’s evolution is where its very essence resides: ‘Kublai rifletteva sull’ordine invisibile che regge la città, sulle regole cui risponde il loro sorgere e prendere forma e prosperare e adattarsi alle stagioni e intristirsi e cadere in rovina’.81
In Le città invisibili, the idea of the urban space as shaped by a complex network of relations is ascribable, as Modena maintains, to Calvino’s interest in the applications of semiology to urbanism.82 This is a topic widely debated at that time in the field of architecture.83 Modena traces it back to the author’s reading of Roland Barthes, who in 1967 published a decisive essay titled ‘Semiologia e urbanistica’.  However, the image of the city as a network of signs, constantly subjected to rewriting and interpretations, and the equivalence between spatiality and textuality are crucial in Calvino’s work at least since Marcovaldo.85 Le città invisibili is the book where this life-long meditation on ‘the city and the signs’ reaches its highest semantic density and becomes the focal point of interest. Nonetheless, when considering the many aspects indicating Calvino’s engagement with information science, it is possible to imagine that his semiotic reading of the city might have been reinforced and further confirmed by cybernetic theories asserting the informational nature of reality.
The connection between semiology and cybernetics is, again, made explicit by Isozaki. In the already mentioned essay he explains that his model of ‘invisible city’ belongs to what he calls the ‘semiotic, or symbolic, stage’ in urbanism, which ‘has evolved from electronics theories’.  At this stage, itis not the material realised shape of a city what matters, but the interaction between the actual and the potential. This is because, if the urban space is determined by the flux of information, like in the case of the project for the Festival Plaza, imagining possible cities equals to shaping and influencing the existing ones. Computer simulation is what makes this possible, as it allows to create a feedback loop between the abstract models conceived by the architect and the material environment. However, such computer simulations, Isozaki clarifies, are inherently different from the ‘fantasy and utopian plans of the twenties’.  This is because, like in the process of virtualisation theorised by Levy, they do not represent an alternative to the real, but rather the network of potentialities from which the real stems. Isozaki’s understanding of the process of simulation as inherent to his definition of ‘invisible city’ is in line with what Calvino writes of Kublai Khan’s atlas as an open model preceding and determining any concrete actualisation: ‘l’atlante ha questa qualità: rivela la forma delle città che ancora non hanno né una forma né un nome [. . .]. Il catalogo delle forme è sterminato: finché ogni forma non avrà trovato la sua città, nuove città continueranno a nascere’.  Interestingly, the catalogue of model cities compiled by Calvino shares many similarities with to the one proposed by Isozaki, who writes: ‘all kinds of cities can be planned: City on the Sea, City in the Air, Labyrinth City, City for the Dead, and so on’.  The architect – not unlike Kublai Khan with his atlas – manipulates these archetypical cities through computer simulation ‘so that they overlap with the real city’. 
There is one final aspect worth of being considered to further connect Calvino’s and Isozaki’s vision. It is the tension between growth and disruption, intended as two interconnected and equally essential moments in the life of a city, which leads to the double interpretation, in Isozaki and in Calvino, of the invisible city as a utopic as well as dystopic space. To explain these antinomies simply as the result of their common interest in cybernetics would be of course reductive. For Isozaki, the optimism guiding the Metabolist vision of an urban environment organically evolving under the guidance of far-seeing architects, was at best disingenuous, at worst the expression of a nationalist discourse aimed at promoting the image of Japan as a thriving international power, fully recovered after the disaster of WWII.  Having witnessed the effect of the nuclear bombing of his country, instead, Isozaki was aware that fluidity does not necessarily mean steady progress, but rather an infinite cycle of growth and disruption. Better yet, like in Benjamin’s Angelus Novus,  he considered ruins to be the true essence of a city, as they constitute the origin from which any urban conglomerate emerges, as well as the shape towards which any city tends. This tension was expressed in the already mentioned drawing published on Casabella, which illustrated Isozaki’s imaginary project – yet another case of simulation – for the requalification of the Tokyo area of Shinjuku. Suggestively titled Incubation Process, the project presented a superimposition of a modern megastructures of elevated highways to the ruins of the Greek temples of Agrigento.  When first published in Japan in 1962, the drawing was accompanied by a poem by Isozaki himself, which translates into verses his architectural vision:
Future cities are themselves ruins
Our contemporary cities . . . are destined to live only a fleeting moment
Give up their energy and return to inert material
All of our proposals will be buried
And once again the incubation mechanism is reconstituted That will be our Future.94
The exact same theme is displayed in his collage titled Re-ruined Hiroshima, displayed at the Milano Triennale as part of his project Electric Labyrinth. In this case, to the picture of the wasteland left behind by the bombing of Hiroshima, Isozaki superimposed the drawing of two futuristic Metabolist buildings, also in ruins.  The fate of every city, as much as its past, is disruption, Isozaki maintained.  Evidently, the concept of ruins, while originating from his personal lived experience, was further shaped by considerations on the cybernetic theory of the opposed poles of entropy and negentropy. In information science, order – equal to information – and disorder – equal to noise – coexist in a precarious and ever-evolving relation. Excessive order, however, leads to homogenisation and loss of meanings, which means that information is finally transformed into noise.  Isozaki’s claim that cities originate from and are destined to ruins builds directly on the concept of information as arising from noise, while also fated to return to it. Moreover, the annihilation of Isozaki’s ‘invisible city’ does not entail its material destruction necessarily, but, like in a cybernetic system, a saturation of information. This is symbolised by the shapeless, hypertrophic megalopolis, of which Tokyo was a perfect example.
Calvino too, much like the Japanese architect, develops the theme of a city threatened by destruction, leading to ruins and disappearance. On the one hand, hypertrophic growth may lead to an amorphous structure, much like Isozaki’s megalopolis. In ‘Invisible City’ Isozaki describes the threats looming over modern cities by mentioning Los Angeles and Tokyo. Calvino uses the same examples when writing of physical places that expanded to such a point that they entirely unravelled, losing any meaningful shape and structure, thereby reaching a point of failure because of information overload: ‘dove le forme esauriscono le loro variazioni e si disfano, comincia la fine delle città. Nelle ultime carte dell’atlante si diluivano reticoli senza principio né fine, città a forma di Los Angeles, a forma di Kyoto-Osaka, senza forma’.98 Much like the Japanese cities in Isozaki’s drawings, the ones in Kublai Khan’s empire can be swallowed – by the desert, by garbage, or even by oblivion. This concern is best conveyed through the image that opens the book – the one of a kingdom threatened by its own ruins: ‘è il momento disperato in cui si scopre che questo impero che ci era sembrato la somma di tutte le meraviglie è uno sfacelo senza fine né forma’.  In playing with the tension between destruction and growth, the book ends with a very different image – that of a joyous city. As Calvino warns, this image is not intended to cancel out the memory of decline and ruins, a message with clear existential implications.  It goes without saying that this conclusion can be read as having an existential and philosophical meaning. However, Philosophical teachings aside, this contrast can also be traced back to the tension between entropy and negentropy as a foundational concept in cybernetics, which can also be found in other works by Calvino – for example, in the short story ‘Il guidatore notturno’.101
What is even more notable is that Isozaki too worked on a literary transposition of this cybernetic approach to urban design focusing on the tension between growth and destruction. In September 1962, he published a story titled ‘City Demolition Industry, Inc’. in a Japanese architectural journal.  The protagonists are a former contract killer, now a demolition entrepreneur, and an architect. Their names, Shin and Arata, are the two possible readings of the same character that spells Isozaki’s first name. The tension between the author’s Doppelgänger, the destroyer and the urban planner, symbolises the complementary and contrasting urges informing his architectural vision. The similarities with Calvino’s production are clear: consider, for example, the opposition between the two characters of Palomar and Mohole, or the characters from the short story ‘L’inseguimento’, the latter being overtly indebted to information theory.  While the Metabolists held a utopian view of the city, Isozaki’s vision was, at the same time, utopian and dystopian. Similarly, in Calvino’s Le città invisibili, Kublai Khan’s atlas comprises both promised lands – a veritable catalogue of literary utopias, including the ones of Campanella and Moore – and infernal ones, such as the biblical cursed cities of Babylon and futuristic dystopias such as Huxley’s Brave New World. 
Isozaki and Calvino’s reflections are the expression of a profound engagement with the Zeitgeist and, despite their striking similarities, it would be impossible to easily trace them back to any single common ancestor. There is some allure, however, in reflecting on the potential influence of the exponent of French Neoclassical architecture Claude-Nicolas Ledoux and of his utopic architecture, whom both Calvino and Isozaki considered in relation to their work. Ledoux’s imaginary project The House of the Farm Guard, representing a sphere-shaped building, was used by the former as the cover for the paperback version of Le città invisibili, and by the latter as inspiration for one of his projects, Kaijima House in Tokyo.  Ledoux’s engraving is an example of ‘architecture parlante’, a concept he invented to describe buildings that function as emblems, edifices that denounce their purpose through their visual appearance. As claimed by Sylvia Lavin, Ledoux’s ‘architecture parlante’ aimed at correcting ‘[a]rchitecture’s original sin’ of not being capable of telling ‘stories in the manner of poetry and painting’.106 It was a way of encoding information into material buildings and attempting to establish a link between spatial and textual elements. The advent of information science decades later would have allowed to further fulfil this utopic vision by asserting the written and coded nature of reality. In both Calvino and Isozaki, the idea of invisible city is situated in such a space, one which recognises the generative power of the cybernetic ontology, while at the same time acknowledging the threatening possibility that the network of potentials may give birth to the amorphous continuous city, where the saturation of information coincides with the obliteration of any meaning.
Conclusion
In analysing the convergences between Le città invisibili with Nelson’s hypertext and Isozaki’s cybernetic approach to architecture, this study has separately addressed the issues concerning the impact of the new concept of information on epistemology in connection to Project Xanadu as a strategy to organise and manage information, as well as on ontology in relation to Isozaki’s concept of ‘invisible city’, as an example of virtualisation. However, the demarcation is not as clear as it might seem.
Ted Nelson did not intend his hypertext to be a home system, but he rather envisioned the creation of dedicated public spaces where a community of mind-like people could gather and collaborate. In his book, Literary Machine, he explained: ‘the intended public operation of the system will be in a chain of suburban or roadside stations, called Silverstands. New users will learn the operation of the system at such stands, and local users may dial into their nearest Silverstand’.  The new concept of textuality promoted by his hypertext was imagined to be capable of creating a sort of hippy computer counterculture utopia, functioning as a cybernetic space intended in the sense already defined in relation to Isozaki’s projects as an environment shaped by human-machine interaction and streams of information.
Arata Isozaki, as already pointed out, was keen in expressing his architectural vision in literary texts, poems short stories. While this unconventional way to theory was certainly suggested to him by his long-lasting collaborations with Tokyo bohemian community of artists of the Neo-Dada movement,  it is also important to connect his literary activity with his concept of simulation: literature as a way of expressing a network of potentiality. As explained by William Gardiner in his analysis of Metabolist imagination in Japanese architecture and science fiction, computer simulation like literary writing introduced a temporal element to which Isozaki was drawn more than any other exponent of Metabolism. Gardiner explains that ‘[l]ike computer modelling, literary forms can allow for a process of simulation, which can include the meeting of base assumptions of reality with an element of the unfamiliar’. 
Textual and spatial issues explored in Le città invisibili are thus also intertwined in Nelson and Isozaki. This connection, while not explainable only through Calvino’s interest to cybernetics, nonetheless must have received further theoretical evidence from the advent of a new concept of information defined within the field of cybernetics. The new paradigm brought by the World Wide Web in the following decades, which completely reshaped the approach to knowledge and space conjunctly as two essentially interconnected aspects, was anticipated in Le città invisibili. Reading the book against the work of Nelson, the man who invented the concept of hypertext, and of Isozaki, one of the most prominent architects reimagining the urban space in the age of information society, aimed at demonstrating how attuned Calvino was to the issues and debates of the time.
Sketching his idea of literature as a living interconnected system of information, Ted Nelson attempts a comparison between with James Lovelock’s Gaia hypothesis.  According to Lovelock, Nelson writes, the Earth ‘brings to the surface of the water those calciferous blooms that are required to adjust the temperature of the planet’,  thus letting emerge what is most needed at the right time. Literary systems too, Nelson speculates, ‘bring to the surface those issues that the time is right to concentrate on’.112 The convergences explored in this study might be considered in the same way: as calciferous blooms belonging to the same literary system, surfacing at the same time.

***

Italo Calvino’s Spatial Imagination: Between
Intellectual Abstraction and Embodied Experience

Introduction
Italo Calvino is usually regarded as an eminently cerebral author. His metanarrative and self- reflexive works as well as his experiments with storytelling and combinatorics contributed to gain him such fame. Kathryn Hume described him as a writer dominated by the intellect and distrusting of the body’s sensations.1 Even though recent research on the posthuman sparked some new interest in the questioning of anthropomorphic and anthropocentric motives in Calvino’s work, the overarching critical impression of Calvino as an author characterised by a strong tendency toward disembodiment remains largely unchallenged.2
In this article, I aim less to challenge the assumption of Calvino as a pre-eminently mental author as much as to rebalance it by reappraising the embodied and experiential dimension 
behind his seemingly more abstract operations. My suggestion is that to recognise the prominent role of spatiality may open up a way to reconcile tendencies toward abstraction and the experiential features of Calvino’s imagination. In other words, I do not deny Calvino’s penchant for abstraction but rather seek to remind us how, even in its wildest and highest flights, our imagination is always fundamentally embodied.
If my first hypothesis concerns the mind of the author and is thus admittedly more speculative, my subsequent claim considers the impact of spatiality in Calvino’s fictional work and on the designed strategies of readerly engagement, whose embodied roots have been largely neglected in favour of a mode of engagement that is more intellectual and abstract. Instead, I propose that Calvino’s stories powerfully tap into the readers’ experiential background, which in turn bears traces of the experience of the body in space.
In order to do so, I gather different critical insights to describe what may be called Calvino’s spatial imagination. Calvino’s imagination shall be described as spatial for two interrelated reasons. First, as I will show in the first part of the article, because it is informed by embodied experience of space. Research in cognitive psychology and cognitive linguistics is lending increasing support to the view that human higher-order cognitive functions (including imagination and abstract concepts) are irreducibly grounded in the early spatial experience of the individual. Building on this general claim, it has been suggested that people may exhibit regularities and privileged pathways in weaving their arguments and thoughts, thus developing a more or less distinctive cognitive style. In a descriptive and non-normative sense, narrative theorist Uri Margolin describes cognitive style as the ‘tendency to process information in a particular way which constitutes an interface between cognition and personality’. 
In the case of Calvino, I suggest that his cognitive style was significantly informed by the landscape of his childhood, the topography and particular arrangement of elements of which encouraged him to privilege certain types of relations between things, thus affecting his own personal way of producing meaning. It goes without saying that this kind of experiential trigger does not exist in a cultural void: Calvino’s personal readings – above all, structuralism and semiology – undoubtedly guided and catalysed the formalisation of the relations derived from the environment. Without denying the impact of these influences, it seems to be rather a matter of convergence between theoretical ideas and personal insights. These mutually endorse and reinvigorate one another in a felicitous way, constituting a productive feedback loop between repeated perceptual experience and higher-order, culturally shaped ideas.
The second reason why I propose to describe Calvino’s imagination as spatial is because it tends to manipulate its material – ideas, structures, and images – as if they were spaces through which characters and readers may move and with which narrators and characters may interact. I shall especially focus on works in which spatiality plays a more disguised role than its usual purview as a setting. In these works, spatiality is a dimension informing the structure of images and narratives. Although as part of a larger project I ultimately aim to trace a broader trajectory, in this article I shall focus first on some autobiographical writings (particularly ‘Dall’opaco’) to examine the link between overt representations of space and closer evidence of Calvino’s own cognitive style. Then, I will move on to consider how Calvino integrates these strategies and insights in his literary project, discussing at greater length the cosmicomical tales, which constitute a significant turning point in Calvino’s approach to spatiality and offer some fruitful instances to confirm my hypothesis.
My purpose in this article is therefore to demonstrate the significance of two undervalued aspects of Calvino’s writing: the significance of spatiality in Calvino’s fictional work, and its implications regarding the role of embodiment. Taken together, these counterbalance the view of Calvino as a univocally mental and disembodied author by reappraising the experiential dimension.
The Geographic Perspective
The centrality of space in many of Calvino’s works has not gone unnoticed.  To date, geography has been the most straightforward entry point to the exploration of spatiality, which mostly consisted in studying the representation of space as narrative setting and its interrelation with storytelling practices. Even in the Nineties, Pierpaolo Antonello had reflected on the ‘dimensione geografica del mentale calviniano’, which he sees as structured by an oriented and positioned gaze.  In a more recent article, Michele Maiolani reiterates this point as he discusses some of Calvino’s writings which could be grouped under a hybrid genre that encompasses a range of texts halfway between the essay and the short story, usually inspired by the account of a place or journey.  For these works Maiolani proposes the label of ‘narrazioni geografiche’ to suggest that the relationship between the discipline of geography and these geographical narratives is akin to the relation linking the natural sciences to Le Cosmicomiche. In both instances, the scientific fields contribute stimuli which serve as triggers for the narrative: Le Cosmicomiche is inspired by pseudo-scientific principles, whereas the geographical narratives draw from landscape explorations and panoramic overviews. Thanks to this geography-oriented lens, Maiolani aims to foreground the importance of geographical space and to capture a distinctive methodological concern. He argues that Calvino deploys geography – and especially cartography, as the art of representing geographical space – to remind readers of the inescapability of a situated point of view. In addition to highlighting the narrative nature of any description (e.g., ‘Il viandante nella mappa’), this disciplinary approach would serve Calvino to emphasise subjectivity in cartographic representations, which are only seemingly objective for any map entails a scale and thus the potential user’s perspective. 
Continuing the dialogue with cartography, also Kerstin Pilz observes that ‘Calvino’s perception of literature as a form of mapping the labyrinth is a fitting one for an author who is well known for his predilection for geometrical narrative structures. Indeed, all of Calvino’s narratives can be described as a form of map-making’.  Foregrounding the ordering intention underpinning Calvino’s operations, she shows how Le città invisibili, Il castello dei destini incrociati, Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore, Palomar, and Sotto il sole giaguaro may be all regarded as mapping attempts.
But how, if any, is this ‘dimensione geografica del mentale calviniano’ different from my proposed idea of spatial imagination? Offering a different way of framing the question and foregrounding embodied cognition not only does usher in new concepts, but also offers an innovative lens to look at Calvino’s reflection on a broader scale. By speaking of spatial imagination, I emphasise the experiential roots and cognitive nature of Calvino’s predilection for arranging ideas and stories as if they were spaces, rather than framing them in terms of influence exerted by the discipline of geography. In fact, Antonello goes in a similar direction when he claims that ‘dicendo cartografia non mi riferisco a un livello metaforico ma cognitivo’.  I believe the argument can be taken a step further, and I try to use it to reconcile two seemingly juxtaposed lines of Calvino’s work: one verging towards increasing abstraction, and the other towards perception and the senses.
While a geography-oriented approach brings along questions of representation, gaze, and perspective, the cognitive and enactive approach I shall propose here allows one to recuperate the embodied quality of the position-taking which, in my view, strongly shapes Calvino’s writing. In previous readings, even when perceptions are involved, the focus mostly remains on visuality, a privileged entry point that has been criticised also by Elio Baldi, who describes it as accurate and misleading at the same time.  As Antonello remarks, ‘l’orientamento fornisce il campo della visione, inquadra il mondo’.11 The enactive perspective I introduce helps illuminate how Calvino’s use of the eye as a sensory organ belies his understanding of cognition as a multisensory phenomenon. Calvino himself occasionally touches upon this interpretation, for instance in his 1982 review of Ruggero Pierantoni’s book L’occhio e l’idea, where he attempts the following synthesis: ‘Insomma il cervello comincia nell’occhio’. 
By speaking of spatial imagination, therefore, I focus less on the relevance of setting or the abundance of isolated spatial images in Calvino’s work. Rather, I advance an overarching hypothesis about privileged patterns characterising Calvino’s imagination: about how his imagination is triggered by, and works through, the mental manipulation of the relations identified in such images in a way that resembles our relation with space. In order to make this point, I shall start by introducing a few theoretical ideas underpinning my argument, which concern the nature and development of the human capacity for abstract thought.
The Cognitive Perspective
Research in cognitive linguistics and cognitive developmental psychology has provided ample evidence by now that even abstract concepts and higher-order cognitive functions – including long- term memory, language, propositional imagination, conceptual thought, narrative comprehension – are ultimately rooted in our sensorimotor experience. This means that abstract conceptual structures arise to some extent from our everyday observation of and interaction with the world around us by means of the body we have.13 As narratologist and literary theorist Marco Caracciolo pointed out as follows:
Our physical make-up and sensorimotor capacities inform all the other levels of our experience. This means that not only mental processes are made possible by our body, but that the structure of our body has a profound influence on the way we perceive, feel, and think about the world. Human cognition cannot be replicated in non-human bodies. 
Hypothetically speaking, if Calvino did not have the human body he had or even just the type of mobility and range of action afforded by his specifically abled body and historically situated lifestyle, he might have conceptualised the space around him very differently, thus inferring other types of major relations among things. 
In order to explore the relationship between embodied experience and conceptual structures, George Lakoff and Mark Johnson proposed the notion of image schema.  Image schemas are preconceptual patterns derived from sensory and perceptual experience, which also play a crucial role in structuring abstract concepts through metaphorical ‘mappings between concrete and abstract domains’.  Because they are ‘generally viewed as redescriptions of perceptual events, or even more broadly, as generalizations over perceived similarities’, image schemas are more abstract than events. And yet, at the same time, image schemas retain their experiential origin and multi-modal nature, as they are not simply visual but also auditory, kinaesthetic, and tactile. 
Image schemas capture essential movements and relations as they are experienced and understood while the individual gains familiarity with their body and immediate surroundings, mostly within the first year of life (examples of image schemas include UP-DOWN, CONTAINER, or SOURCE-PATH-GOAL). Interestingly for our discourse on spatiality, Jean Mandler and Cristobal Pagán Cánovas emphasise that our very first, pre-verbal schemas are exquisitely spatial in nature and even more thoroughly derived from interactions. In other words, at very early stages infants pay more attention to the mutual interactions between two objects than to the objects themselves. This supports the idea that abstract thought significantly relies not simply on experience but on spatial experience more specifically.19
Empirical studies also indicate the importance of the action system alongside with the visual system.  While image schemas help understand how abstract thought (and cognition more broadly) is embodied, this point about action brings me to introduce the view of cognition as enactive – the second theoretical pillar of my discussion.
Enactivism is a paradigm currently at the forefront of research into the nature of cognition.  Its key idea is that cognition is not something that happens only in the head (mentalism), or in the body (embodied mind view), or in the tools we use to support our thinking process (extended mind view): cognition is co-constitutive with the environment and is crucially defined by our moving in and interacting with the world. This means that the subject (cogniser) and the world are not two separate entities; instead, they are relational and mutually shaped. Perception, in turn, is not something that happens to us but something we do, it ‘is an active exploration of the world that relies primarily on bodily movement’.  As I will explain through the article, the enactivist perspective foregrounds ideas such as imagination as a form of active manipulation and the entanglement of subject-cogniser and the world, which I believe represent fruitful and yet neglected issues in Calvino’s work.
Drawing on this philosophical research strand and transferring it to the field of narrative studies, Caracciolo proposed an enactivist understanding of imagination, which is based on the assumption of a structural resemblance existing between perceptual and imaginative experiences. According to this model, people imagine (or simulate) perceptual experience by relying on memory of real interactions, called ‘experiential traces’.  This means that the link between perceptual experience and simulated perceptual experience does not lie in the object of representation, but rather in the structure of sensorimotor patterns involved. If we think of Calvino, moreover, the key role played by structure in the workings of experience as explained by enactivism also resonates with its centrality in structuralism.  An enactivist approach to narrative particularly stresses that ‘while the imaginative contents and experiential qualities of reading fictional narrative may deviate from real-world engagements, the underlying structure of interaction is the same: readers respond to narrative on the basis of their experiential background’. 
Since the development of image schemas takes place over the first months of life of the infant, it should be clear that, for the purposes of my argument, I do not intend to fully build upon the peculiarity of any of these structures. The studies I mentioned maintain that spatial basic constructs and image schemas operate virtually in everyone and, although they are not innate because they arise from sensory and perceptual experience, they are by no means distinctive of Calvino’s experience, and I do not advance any claim regarding the specificities of his early cognitive development. In fact, image schemas are so deeply embedded in our conceptual system that most of the times we are not even conscious of their activation.
Nonetheless, this body of research foregrounds the fundamentally embodied nature of abstract thought, and thus helps me undermine the false assumption that abstraction and perceptual experience should be dichotomously juxtaposed.  Furthermore, as Charles Forceville and Marloes Jeulink point out, the pre-conscious nature of image schemas does not exclude that one can be made aware of them again.  This means that, even though image schemas operate widely, individual intellectual paths or experiences may lead one to employ certain image schemas more systematically and with increased awareness. In addition to the influence of the embodied experience of certain spaces (which represents the original contribution of this article), I would not exclude that intense engagement with structuralist theories may have made Calvino more sensible to arrangements of narrative structures that resonate with certain image schemas. At the same time, structuralism cannot be the only source of such interest: Calvino’s work on the folktale, whose mechanisms attracted him ‘per interesse stilistico e strutturale, per [. . .] la logica essenziale con cui sono raccontate’, dates back to the Fifties and thus precedes the encounter with structuralism.28 From the folktale genre, Calvino already enucleates the idea that the system of internal relationships among elements might be more meaningful than the elements themselves, a view that made him receptive to the questions explored by structuralism ten years later. 
Finally, the embodied cognitive framework provides us with suitable conceptual tools to substantiate the intuition that Calvino, while pursuing abstraction, may have striven more or less consciously to integrate it with a preconceptual, experiential dimension which, in fact, does pertain to the abstract relations he emphasises. What I do argue, therefore, is that some of Calvino’s texts may mirror or mimic an imaginative process that exhibits significant similarities with the process underpinning image schema formation.
