4.	‘Dall’opaco’: In Search for Calvino’s Personal Image Schemas
Let us build on these concepts by looking at Calvino’s text ‘Dall’opaco’. Due to its autobiographical nature, ‘Dall’opaco’ has been often regarded as a pivotal link between Calvino’s own way of looking at reality and the type of perspectival dynamics enacted in his fictional works. ‘Dall’opaco’ was written in 1971 and later published in the collective volume Adelphiana 1971. It is a deeply fragmented text in which the author muses on the long-lasting impact of the landscape of his childhood on his way of seeing the world, moving swiftly between early impressions of the Ligurian topography and his perspective on it as an adult. On the one hand, the text thematises precisely the process of abstraction that, from a lived and experienced environment, isolates the basic relations that constitute something analogous to image schemas; on the other hand, it captures instances of how Calvino’s imaginative process mirrors a kind of engagement with reality that is distinctively enactive in nature.
Examining it in the frame of a discussion of the relationship between nature and culture, Antonello describes ‘Dall’opaco’ as a ‘modello di narrativa cartografica’ and argues that Calvino draws his cognitive and perceptual maps from the geographical context of his youth, grounding the roots of his perceptual and affective organisation of reality in this early autobiographical experience.  In a sense, I fully concur with this claim, which seems very much in line with what I have argued so far. In ‘Dall’opaco’, Calvino thinks about the shapes that imprinted his memory and perceptions – he reflects on how the physical environment has informed his conception of space in ways that closely recall passages to be later found in the cosmicomics (‘che forma ha il mondo’; ‘quante dimensioni ha lo spazio’). 
Claudio Milanini describes the potential book entitled Dall’opaco as ‘un libro sulla forma della mente, sul paesaggio mentale, cioè sui modelli primari attraverso cui ogni singolo individuo guarda il mondo’, and these ‘primary models’ cannot but recall the concept of image schema proposed by cognitive linguists.  The arrangement of human dwellings along the Ligurian coast develops across multiple levels in steep and narrow steps cut between the sea and the mountain. This primed Calvino to recognise vertical and horizontal lines as dominant and to reproduce this pattern when it comes to make sense of the world as he sees it now, which thus ‘conserva la prima impronta delle cose’.34 This essential structure inferred from the childhood landscape (‘forma [. . .] in pendenza, con dislivelli irregolari, con sporgenze e rientranze [. . .] il mondo è composto di linee spezzate ed oblique, con segmenti che tendono a sporgere fuori’) persists through time (‘Se allora mi avessero domandato [. . .] e così anche adesso se mi chiedono’) and is applied to his surroundings in the present, irrespective of whether he is actually looking at the Ligurian coast: 
Forme del mondo più complesse o più semplici ma tutte derivate da questa, molto più complesse e nello stesso tempo molto più semplici in quanto tutte contenute o deducibili da quei primi strapiombi e declivi, da quel mondo di linee spezzate ed oblique tra cui l’orizzonte è l’unica retta continua. 
A few additional examples will serve to demonstrate how also this secondary image schema (secondary because it is more consciously re-elaborated than the truly primary ones, which are developed in the first months of life) may have an effect as pervasive as basic ones. The pattern of oblique and orthogonal lines further typified by internal irregularities constitutes a structure that functions as a private image schema for Calvino – a pattern that we shall find again underpinning the organisation of quite different things, including: (a) the multifarious potential unfolding of a situation; (b) the complex relationships among three friends, and even (c) an elusive, higher-order concept such as that of identity:
[a]	Dal punto spaziotemporale in cui mi trovo si diparte un fascio di possibilità che più procedono nel tempo più divergono a cono verso futuri completamente diversi tra loro [. . .].  
[b]	Tutte queste linee oblique incrociandosi dovrebbero delimitare lo spazio dove ci muoviamo io e Valeriano e Irina, dove la nostra storia possa affiorare dal nulla, trovare un punto di partenza, una direzione, un disegno.  
[c]	L’identità è un fascio di linee divergenti che trovano nell’individuo il punto d’intersezione. [. . .] così l’identità di gruppo è definita dal rapporto in cui si situa rispetto a chi non d’identifica col gruppo, cioè il resto dell’umanità, il mondo esterno in cui la presenza del gruppo fa breccia, il campo d’influenze e d’onde che partono e arrivano. È il fuori che definisce il dentro, nell’orizzontalità dello spazio così come nella dimensione verticale del tempo.39
In ‘Dall’opaco’, Calvino individuates horizontal and vertical relations between elements which are actually visible in the landscape (palm trees, balconies, houses, streets, seashore, etc.), but in these three instances, the pattern attempts to describe the abstract structure of something which is much less concrete. The image schema, therefore, comes to play a much stronger and more constitutive role. In example [c], conceptualising identity as a set of diverging lines – rather than, say, a closed circle – reveals two profoundly different images to build on and thus offers (or, in James Gibson’s term, it affords) very different ways of thinking about identity.  An enactive understanding of cognition acknowledges that the heuristic potential of an image does not consist only in its form and internal relations: crucially, the imaginary manipulation of such images also enables the cogniser to experience new mental operations. For instance, thinking about identity as something open toward the exterior would probably encourage one to think of it as more intersubjective in nature.
At the same time, it should not be forgotten that this structure, albeit abstract, is derived from perceptual and embodied experience in the first place. When Calvino admits that ‘ogni indagine non può che partire da quel nucleo da cui si sviluppano l’immaginazione, la psicologia, il linguaggio’, he seems to endorse attempts to retrace the source of pivotal image structures in this early environment. 
The main problem with geography-oriented descriptions of ‘Dall’opaco’ as a reflection on the impact of landscape on Calvino’s mind is that they already presuppose and replicate a separation (if not a juxtaposition) between landscape and subject as well as between mind and body. To exploit the perspective of geography – like Antonello’s or Maiolani’s readings do – surely is compatible with the images employed by Calvino (first of all, the image of the map). And yet, it arguably does not help one get rid of this implicit bias.
My impression is rather that in ‘Dall’opaco’ Calvino reflects precisely on the co-constitution – or, borrowing a term from physics, we could say the entanglement – of cognising subject and world.  At the beginning of the piece, Calvino specifies that disregarding the ahead–behind axis and holding as relevant the right–left axis are consequences of the specific type of landscape lived and experienced by the subject:
La prima cosa da dire è che la dimensione dell’avanti a me non sussiste, in quanto lì sotto comincia subito il vuoto che poi diventa mare che poi diventa orizzonte [. . .] poi passerei alla dimensione dell’indietro a me che non va mai molto indietro perché incontra un muro [. . .] e poi c’è la dimensione che si prolunga alla sinistra e alla destra e che per me corrisponde più o meno al levante e al ponente, e questa sì che può continuare dalle due parti perché il mondo continua [. . .]. 
The text describes how the subject-protagonist integrated this bias in his own way of looking at the world and reproduced it in later contexts. 
In this sense, the shape of the world becomes forma mentis, the shape of the mind, as Antonello also notes when he writes that ‘forme della natura [. . .] diventano forme del pensiero’.  However, it is not so because the world or the landscape do have such shape. Because Antonello structures his argument around the nature-culture dialectic, he ends up crystallising in objectivist terms nature and self, arguing that ‘queste categorie mentali sono prodotte dalle strutture stesse del mondo’.  Instead, I suggest that Calvino’s reflections rather imply that these structures do not belong either to the subject or to the object, but are produced by (enacted through) our embodied experience of the world. Similarly, Maiolani claims that ‘Dall’opaco’ is influenced by methodologies and questions raised by the discipline of geography because it thematises the importance of subjective positioning in the representation of any environment.  But in my view, the enactive paradigm better captures the core of Calvino’s meditation, which is not just a matter of subjective perspective but of co- construction between self and the environment. Indeed, ‘it is through the interaction (which [Varela, Thompson and Rosch] term “structural coupling”) between the organism and the environment that the organism’s environment constitutes itself as such’.  Through such manoeuvres, enactivism articulates itself as a middle ground between objectivism and subjectivism.
The cognising self and the world thus mutually shape and determine one another: ‘le proprietà dello spazio variano a seconda delle direzioni in cui guardo in rapporto al modo in cui mi trovo orientato’ (see discussion below around ‘La spirale’).  Calvino’s comment evokes an embodied and enactive experience of space which is more vivid than the mere practice of using a map. In fact, when he writes ‘se domandassero a quel me stesso che continua a non sapere le cose che s’imparano per avere un codice di convenzioni’, he seems to refer to an experience of space that is pre- conventional and strongly experiential. 
It also follows that Calvino’s conclusion that the self only serves the world’s need to know that it exists (‘l’io che serve solo perché il mondo riceva continuamente notizie dell’esistenza del mondo, un congegno di cui il mondo dispone per sapere se c’è’) is hardly a way of undermining or bracketing the subject. Nor the self becomes ‘un medium privo di qualsiasi individuazione e specificità’, as Maiolani argues.  The self may lack in psychological complexity, but it is through its embodied and value-laden experience that the subject defines what features of the world are relevant and thus contributes to define the world itself; vice versa, it is equally true that without a world with which to interact, the cogniser would not be able to isolate any kind of structure – any image schema – through which start organising its own experience and, ultimately, defining itself as a thinking and self-aware subject.
In fact, scholars tend to equate perhaps too quickly Calvino’s emphasis on abstraction with the erasure of the self. Donnarumma, for instance, draws a strong connection between the encounter with structuralism and the author’s enhanced esprit de géometrie and tendency towards abstraction.  He argues that, on the one hand, the exploration of structuralism fostered the development of fruitful metanarrative interests but, on the other, it also led to a ‘svuotamento del suo [del racconto] significato esperienziale’, also adding that the transformation of the self into a mere function of the system and the progressive erasure of the individual are particularly visible in the cosmicomical tales. 
Although I appreciate Donnarumma’s larger point, I think it is worth emphasizing that experience – and specifically embodied experience of space – still plays a significant role in Calvino’s work, even though psychology is sometimes stereotyped or marginalised as explanatory category for action and plot construction. Experience not only shapes the roots of Calvino’s spatial imagination, but also serves as the foundation for his strategies of readerly engagement. In other words, the marginalization of psychologism does not equate to the marginalization of experience. Furthermore, despite being devoid of psychological contours, the self which is invoked by Calvino does not cease to own a body. As I will show later, this is sometimes an absent or metamorphic body in the cosmicomics, yet this erasure evokes deeply defamiliarising effects. Here, the body is denied only after the narrator has used it as a vehicle to structure the representation of its own experience – and to design the type of readerly engagement, too.
This point brings me back to the second dichotomy or bias I think may be overcome by embracing an ante litteram enactivist perspective – namely, the relationship between mind and body. Even though I previously used the expression forma mentis myself, it emerges strongly from ‘Dall’opaco’ that it is thanks to the body and the perceptual experience of the environment that thought as a higher-order cognitive function is possible in the first place.
Another reason why the enactive understanding of cognition may be fruitful is that it stresses the constitutive role of interaction and the nature of cognition as active exploration.  Antonello previously pointed out that, the ‘esercizio prospettico’ recounted in ‘Dall’opaco’ reveals a propensity, inherited from his father’s profession, not only to include nature in his discourse on reality, but also to actively manipulate it.  This mention of manipulation, although Antonello does not elaborate it further, proves once again that my argument does not contradict his line of thought as much as supplements it. The experiential dimension is already implicit in Antonello’s analysis, though perhaps it has not been stressed sufficiently. A reading that is mindful of an enactive view of cognition helps recognise how for Calvino the concept of perspective tacitly entails experience and, above all, the potential for active exploration.
In ‘Dall’opaco’, therefore, Calvino dramatises the idea that moving through space may serve not only to gain knowledge about a specific territory, but also to acquire those properties and relationships (image schemas) through which the subject can begin to structure itself. By imagining moving in space and changing his position and orientation as subject, Calvino explores how these adjustments lead to the emergence of continuously different properties of space and thus to different ways of approaching and understanding the world. Something quite similar to this point about the epistemological importance of movement is overtly acknowledged also in a later piece, ‘Ipotesi di descrizione di un paesaggio’, in which Calvino asserts as follows: 
D’altra parte lo scrivere è un’operazione di movimento di per sé [. . .] gli occhi interiori che anche loro corrono avanti e indietro tra le cose sparpagliate nella memoria, e cercano di dare loro una successione, di tracciare una linea tra i punti discontinui.57
This passage provides an effective opportunity to shift from a discussion of Calvino’s way of building on experience in order to understand the world to a reflection on imagination and its application in literary writing. Unlike in ‘Dall’opaco’, the sort of mental movement evoked here does not describe the exploration of a mimetic setting – not even an imaginary one. ‘Scrivere’, in this case, does not refer to the practical activity of writing as to the inner workings of imagination. In a way that enticingly aligns with an enactivist perspective, Calvino describes imagination as active exploration, a practice of mentally moving not only through a mimetic space (be it actual or fictitious) but also of navigating through memories, structuring ideas, and arranging elements of a story. This is a striking example of the sort of feedback loop between low-level perceptual experience and higher-order cognitive functions, such as imagination or storytelling, in which image schemas and modes of interaction developed in real life are re-employed to shape abstract ideas. It epitomizes the sort of structural coupling between real-life experience and imaginative experience hypothesized by Caracciolo. Although Calvino mentions eyes, the verb used to indicate their movement is to run back and forth, thus suggesting that the eye metonymically acts for the whole body, rather than performing the strict action/perception of seeing.
Later on in Palomar, images of this kind will occur repeatedly. In his recent article on visual instruments and technologies in Calvino, Baldi points out that Palomar casts a ‘mobile glance’ rather than a fixed gaze, and that, if Calvino may be sedentary as he writes, his protagonist is an ambulant character.  He concludes that ‘the scientific influence on Palomar is clearly visible but nonetheless not straightforward. Palomar’s eyes move too much to produce a truly stable gaze and his use of instruments is more metaphoric than real’.  But what if at stake here is not the influence of science, but an implicit, still-to-be-named enactive approach to knowledge? Baldi himself tentatively observes that ‘the body is more important than usually acknowledged in the book: in Palomar seeing is optics, instances of vision, eyes that watch and that are part of a body, environment and mind, not just the disembodied eye of Descartes’.  Consequently, also the type of mental simulation triggered in readers is a kinesic action that involves the body in its entirety. In this light, we may argue that for Calvino visuality is very close to standing for cognition more broadly.
In this section, therefore, I suggested that, through his acquaintance with the Ligurian landscape both unconsciously and consciously re-elaborated, Calvino inferred some preferred spatial patterns or private image schemas which he used to structure conceptual ideas and, as I show momentarily, narrative structures. Considering these issues through a cognitive lens encourages to dismantle the dichotomy between mind and body, and the false juxtaposition between experience and abstraction.
Antonello remarks that from a cognitivist perspective Calvino should be regarded as a monist because he does not posit any separation between res cogitans and res extensa.61 However, adding that Calvino would not have framed the question in these terms, he proposes to resolve this dualism through the irreducible interdependence between the two faces of the world, ‘aprico’ and ‘opaco’, neither of which can exist without the other. By formulating the matter in this way both sides are reappraised and regarded as equal, and yet the dichotomy remains. Admittedly, Calvino did not think in enactivist terms either. However, what I tried to show is that there is enough textual and critical evidence to argue that even his most abstract and cerebral ideas (including what I call here his spatial imagination) are ultimately rooted in embodied experience. At the same time, this claim does not deny the crucial impact of theoretical influences in the formalisation and further development of these initial intuitions.
From Topography to Narrative Structure
In this section, I aim to ground claims about the embodied roots of recurrent abstract patterns more firmly in some textual examples. Looking in particular at the cosmicomical tales, I show how spatial imagination is at work in fiction and how this concept may serve to reconciliate the co-existence and interrelations between a strong penchant for abstraction on the one hand, and an equally marked reliance on embodied experience on the other. My focus will include both the first collection Le Cosmicomiche, and its follow-up volume Ti con zero, proposing some suggestions for future directions of research in the conclusions of the article.
Among Calvino’s fictional works, the cosmicomical tales are worth particular attention because they mark a shift in the author’s engagement of spatiality.  While Marcovaldo offered a distinctive thematisation of (urban) space, in Le Cosmicomiche spatiality occupies a different position: its function as mimetic setting is merely nominal and articulated at the level of structure. As Gabriella Gabbi notes, the title reference to the cosmos does something more than circumscribing the setting. It rather works as a spatial metaphor, ‘una metafora che aggiunge all’oggetto nominato [le comiche] un oggetto secondo, lo spazio, come connotazione, la cui presenza viene introdotta dalla sola forma del discorso’.  The cosmicomical tales are thus not simply triggered by scientific anecdotes about the history of the universe. In many instances, they consist in the unfolding, humorously transfigured, of such anecdotes; they are images narratively unwound and fantastically explored, as if the narrative potential were already implied in the image and it simply needed to be developed. In the Norton lecture on ‘Rapidità’, Calvino describes the design behind his narrative in similar terms as he explains that ‘ho puntato sull’immagine, e sul movimento che dall’immagine scaturisce naturalmente’; referring precisely to Le Cosmicomiche and Ti con zero, he specifies how he wanted to give ‘evidenza narrativa a idee astratte dello spazio e del tempo’.  What interests me is precisely this connection between an initial image or idea and its narrative development: it is this nexus that can be fruitfully illuminated by the notion of spatial imagination.
French poet and mathematician Jacques Roubaud – affiliated with the Oulipo, of which Calvino was also a honorary member – captures this distinctive narrative feature of the Cosmicomiche as he notes that they are based on an ‘axiomatic principle’ – namely, the narrative development of an initial assumption – whereas the semiotic trilogy (Il castello dei destini incrociati, Le città invisibili, Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore) are based on a geometrical model.  From a narratological perspective, space in the cosmicomics is no longer just a setting because the way Calvino plays with its spatial properties is central to the narrative mechanism. In the first collection, this strategy is not applied as consistently and overtly as in Ti con zero, but nonetheless there is a continuity in how narratives in the cosmicomical tales generally foreground the relations between elements, reify them in various ways, and turn them into vectors constructing more or less virtual spaces for the narrative to unfold.  Indeed, this idea resonates with Calvino’s own comment on the cosmicomical tales as explorations of ‘segnicità’ – namely, the nature of something as a sign – inasmuch as they entail ‘uno sviluppo d’una immagine di partenza secondo una logica interna all’immagine o al sistema d’immagini’. 
In his review of Ti con zero, Angelo Guglielmi juxtaposes two types of imagination at work in the collection: he calls them ‘abstract’ and ‘concrete’ imagination.  Concrete imagination encompasses a repertoire of discourses, feelings, attitudes, and linguistic expressions typical of the everyday man, of an individual (Qfwfq) who, despite being formally positioned in a physically or temporally unrealistic scenario, is strikingly similar to the reader, historically and culturally situated in the contemporary Western world. Guglielmi does not seem to appreciate exceedingly the results of this type of imagination; on the contrary, he strongly praises the instances of abstract imagination, which he sees at play particularly in the second part of the book, ‘Priscilla’, in which Calvino starts from an initial, highly improbable premise (e.g., what if a cell could think) and thoroughly develops it following its internal logic. Indeed, Calvino acknowledges the ‘furore razionalistico’ spotted by Guglielmi as well as the deductive nature of many stories composing the collection. Calvino also confirms that the encounter – or better, the clash – between these two modes of imagination lies at the heart of the cosmicomics and that he had been pursuing the abstract mode (‘la linea coerentemente astratta’) since Le Cosmicomiche, giving it full implementation in stories such as ‘Un segno nello spazio’, ‘Gli anni-luce’, ‘La forma dello spazio’. 
I find this exchange quite telling. On the one hand, it shows that Calvino deliberately pursued a literary quest aimed at the imaginative exploitation of certain formal constraints: that across the cosmicomical tales he experimented with such constraints; that the formal features of this initial image should be regarded as premises to be ‘logically’ developed in the narrative; and that he associated these explorations with a process leading towards abstraction. On the other hand, however, both Guglielmi’s and Calvino’s comments reveal that this strong drive towards abstraction is coupled with an equally robust concreteness. At this point, my reading takes a more critical stance, because I disagree with Guglielmi’s assertion that ‘concreteness’ should be juxtaposed to the workings of abstract imagination. On the contrary, I argue that the interaction between these two modes produces an effect of defamiliarisation that is profoundly engaging and contributes significantly to the success of the cosmicomical project. I believe that the concreteness perceived by Guglielmi is not merely a give-in to realism, and it is ultimately linked to the presence of that embodied and experiential dimension that is part and parcel of abstract imagination.
Putting this issue aside for the moment, let us focus on the use the logical principle of deduction as a narrative trigger, which is the operation at which both Guglielmi and Calvino hint. To my understanding, it consists of isolating the essential properties of a situation or image by turning them into a concrete (if fictional) space to be narratively explored. To look comparatively at the first cosmicomical collection and the deductive tales of the third part of Ti con zero may help grasp such imaginative strategy. The difference between these two sets of stories is arguably a matter of degree rather than kind: it consists of the extent to which Calvino makes the structural relations between the elements of the story visible and metanarratively manipulates them. In ‘Ti con zero’, ‘L’inseguimento’, and ‘Il guidatore notturno’, the relations holding between elements are stripped bare of any pretence of psychological verisimilitude. The narrativity of the stories lies in the vivid foregrounding and reification of the interactions between human and nonhuman agents (characters as well as lions, arrows or cars) into vectors along which they may move. Thus exposed, these dynamics are crystallised into a fictionally actual space for the narrator to explore. If we think of the preliminary imaginative operation through which Calvino turns specific elements into a space, there is no substantial difference in the following two passages:
Il sole è in fondo soltanto il rapporto del mondo col sole, che non cambia se si considera l’arco concavo percorso dal sole come un arco convesso, è il rapporto d’una sorgente di raggi [. . .] con un corpo o insieme di corpi non importa se fisso o se mobile che riceve i raggi, cioè il sole consiste nelle proprietà dei raggi ricevuti dal mondo [. . .] in ogni caso dunque non è l’esistenza ipotetica di questa sorgente che conta ma il come i suoi raggi cadono sulle superfici del mondo [. . .].  
Quello che non cambia è il rapporto tra me freccia leone in quest’attimo di incertezza [. . .] all’interno di t0 io 
Q0 non sono affatto determinato dal mio passato Q−1 Q−2 Q−3 eccetera ma dal sistema costituito da tutti i buceri B0, pallottole P0, virus V0, senza i quali non potrebbe stabilirsi che io sono Q0. 
The first excerpt is from ‘Dall’opaco’, the second one from ‘Ti con zero’. In both cases, Calvino isolates the reciprocal relations between elements and pulls them in the foreground. By doing so, Calvino not only makes this cognitive operation explicit, but he also turns it into the authentic matter of his narrative. He dwells on alternative potential arrangements and types of relation, taking delight in the nuances between the various hermeneutic implications these adjustments would have for his assessment of the overall topic – be it the tricky predicament of the hunter-narrator in ‘Ti con zero’ or the explanation of his own practice of meaning-making applied to the Ligurian landscape of his youth. However, as I illustrated in the first part of the article, this operation is far from objective and disembodied. If the isolation of relationships to be turned into the defining axes of a fictional space may be guided by a process of abstraction, the manipulation of such newly imagined structure is often profoundly embodied.
‘La forma dello spazio’ fascinatingly illuminates this entanglement between conceptualisation and manipulation, the complex tapestry of abstract-oriented drives and embodiment-rooted strategies continuously intersecting in the cosmicomics. In this story, it is not only the existence of things that modifies the space around them, but also acts of cognition, which give rise to the capability for active manipulation. Let us unpack this claim. ‘La forma dello spazio’ features three characters – one of those love triangles that would recur so often throughout Calvino’s narrative: Qfwfq, the narrator; Ursula H’x, the object of his desire; and Lieutenant Fenimore, his rival in romance. At the outset of the story, all three of them are said to be constantly falling through space, following parallel trajectories that seem geometrically bound to never cross each other’s path. However, while observing Ursula and longing for her, Qfwfq realises that by trying to see things differently, by striving to understand the reality around him under a new light, his cognitive action actually has the power to modify it:
Forse era questo il segreto: immedesimarsi tanto nel proprio stato di caduta da riuscire a capire che la linea seguita cadendo non era quella che sembrava ma un’altra, ossia riuscire a cambiare quella linea nell’unico modo in cui poteva essere cambiata cioè facendola diventare quale era veramente sempre stata. [. . .] Bastò questa fuggevole impressione a farmi vedere la situazione in modo nuovo [. . .]. 
It is this kind of co-constitutive moves between subject-cogniser and environment which is arguably aligned with, and illuminated by, an enactivist view of cognition. On the one hand, to conceptualise the movements of the characters’ bodies through space in terms of lines reveals a reductionist tendency comparable to the formation of image schemas: it turns narrative relations into a structure which scaffolds the space of the story. This type of abstraction procedure reaches its peak in the deductive tales of Ti con zero, particularly ‘Ti con zero’, ‘L’inseguimento’, and ‘Il guidatore notturno’.
On the other hand, once these lines have been defined, Calvino features a protagonist who manipulates them like concrete elements of the environment, thus giving rise to a sort of fictional re-elaboration of the intuited entanglement between the cogniser and the world. In fact, it may be even argued that the reification of interpersonal relations between characters into visible and manipulatable lines makes them more concrete, in a sense, instead of more abstract. Importantly, it is thanks to his own and the other characters’ movement that Qfwfq slowly gains awareness of how the elements of the universe actively contribute to shape the universe itself. An equally important point is that this cognitive engagement and mutual shaping of self and the world is not a solitary practice. Instead, it is crucially triggered by Qfwfq’s intentional projection toward Ursula H’x: ‘ma non fu concentrandomi su me stesso che mi venne quest’idea, bensì osservando con occhio innamorato’.73 Once again, the self does not exist in a void, and action is always interaction.
The tellability of the narrative is achieved by means of the intentional manipulation of these interrelations.  The deliberate nature of this process is increasingly enhanced, up to the point when the tale takes a decidedly metaliterary turn and the trajectories traced by the moving bodies of the characters in space transform into lines of writing. It might be argued that this final twist is a mere experimental closure, a divertissement meant to surprise. And yet, the impression remains that Calvino is using the shortcut of fictional imagination also to explore a deeper intuition about the nature of life, consciousness, and the world. He does not wish to pin these down intellectually, yet still entertains intuitive connections via these metaphorical transfigurations.
A similar entanglement can be found also in the last story of the first cosmicomical collection, ‘La spirale’, in which the world brings about the necessity for eyes to exist through the creation of a form worth seeing. From an evolutionary perspective, this causal link is erroneous (loosely Lamarckian in nature, it might be interpreted as a parodic take on pre-Darwinian finalism). However, the mutual shaping of world and cogniser – the heart of the enactivist paradigm – is staged here, albeit in a paradoxical manner. Alternatively, this passage can be regarded once again as the narrative exploration of the interrelations between events (which in reality are linked by neither causality nor correlation) which are transfigured into a space to be moved through at will.
The importance of movement and manipulation are not the only strategies through which Calvino’s cosmicomical narratives exhibit their roots in embodiment and experience. ‘La forma dello spazio’, the story I just commented upon and which relies so significantly on a process of abstraction, opens as follows:
Cadere nel vuoto come cadevo io, nessuno di voi sa cosa vuol dire. Per voi cadere è sbattersi giù magari dal ventesimo piano d’un grattacielo [. . .]. Io vi parlo invece di quando non c’era sotto nessuna terra né nient’altro di solido [. . .]. Ripensandoci, non c’erano prove nemmeno che stessi veramente cadendo: magari ero sempre rimasto immobile nello stesso posto, o mi muovevo in senso ascendente; dato che non c’era né un sopra né un sotto queste erano solo questioni nominali e tanto valeva continuare a pensare che cadessi, come veniva naturale di pensare. 
In contrast with views that emphasise the disembodied nature of the cosmicomics, this beginning shows how Calvino strongly relies on his readers’ experiential background in order to engage them and ensure the premises for his narrative machinery to work. To say it with Caracciolo, Calvino taps into sensorimotor patterns readers are likely to be familiar with and uses their experiential traces to produce what he calls story-driven experiences that are new and imaginative. Spatial imagination itself, therefore, is spatial in both an abstract and a concrete sense: on the one hand, it derives its cognitive power from the metaphorical application of relations apprehended through the embodied experience of space; on the other, when enacted, it consists of the manipulation of abstract elements as if they were spaces, endowed with their experiential qualities and properties. In neither case is it fully and irrevocably disembodied.
This strategy is employed widely across the cosmicomics. The following excerpt is from ‘Sul far del giorno’, in which Calvino narrates the arousal of the first perceptual feelings:
– Qui si tocca! – un’espressione senza significato (dato che prima d’allora niente aveva mai toccato niente, si può esserne certi), ma che acquistò un significato nello stesso istante in cui fu detta, cioè significò la sensazione che cominciavamo a provare, lievemente nauseante, come una lama di fanghiglia [. . .].  
Cominciai a camminare [. . .]. Dico: camminare, cioè un modo di muoversi in superficie, fino a pochi minuti prima inimmaginabile, e che adesso era tanto se si poteva accennare [. . .]. Or again, from ‘Tutto in un punto’:
Ho detto “pigiati come acciughe” tanto per usare un’immagine letteraria: in realtà non c’era spazio nemmeno per pigiarci. Ogni punto d’ognuno di noi coincideva con ogni punto di ognuno degli altri in punto unico che era quello in cui stavamo tutti.78
These examples show how Calvino repeatedly employs linguistic expressions that inherently presuppose bodily and perceptual possibilities in order to draw on the readers’ experiential background at the bodily and perceptual level, triggering their embodied engagement with the story. Reverting to the exchange between Calvino and Guglielmi, I hope these brief excerpts manage to show that it is not possible to completely uncouple abstract from concrete imagination. Or better: the two general drives can be distinguished for heuristic purposes, but they are nonetheless deeply intertwined and each contributes to the readerly experience.
It has been observed that the spatio-temporal coordinates adopted and deformed in the cosmicomics cannot be reduced to the realm of experience.  I would suggest, however, that the operation staged by Calvino is more complex than merely opting for the uncommon side in the familiar/unfamiliar or representable/unrepresentable pair. These stories do not simply hint at an unimaginable experience. Rather, Calvino uses the tension to produce a clash: he deliberately triggers commonly familiar sensorimotor patterns, only to reject them. But because he does not offer anything else with which to replace them, the activated memory of these perceptual experiences keeps on lingering in the readers’ mind.
The ensuing story-driven experiences thus entail a defamiliarising dimension determined by the clash between the familiarity of evoked bodily movements and their overt denial on Qfwfq’s part, as he immediately dismisses them as absurd. Far from undermining engagement, however, this strategy arguably enhances it, in two different ways. First, as Caracciolo points out, since experiential qualities are unrepresentable, they must be triggered by the representation of actions or events with which the reader is familiar with and which may be associated with a certain experience in real life.  In this sense, Calvino’s stories do provide ample signposting for the type of actions and bodily movements that may produce the type of experience he construes in his narrative.
Secondly, by prompting the memory of certain experiences and then denying that they can be of any use, Calvino produces a strong mismatch between the story-driven experience and the readers’ background. This determines a heightened and intense experiential quality of the reading experience.81 The cosmicomical narratives often dwell precisely on the disorientation caused by analogous mismatches between certain ways of communicating – they juxtapose familiar bodily and deictic categories with a physically unknowable state of affairs. It is worth reiterating: this does not mean that Calvino represents disembodied experience. On the contrary, the puzzling effect derives precisely from the reliance on deeply embodied experience – a strategy Caracciolo calls ‘bodily defamiliarisation’. 
An interview from 1968, later re-elaborated in the essay ‘Due interviste su scienza e letteratura’, arguably confirms this seemingly contradictory point. Referring to the cosmicomical tales, Calvino objects that:
le storie che scrivo si costruiscono all’interno d’un cervello umano, attraverso una combinazione di segni elaborati dalle culture umane che mi hanno preceduto [. . .]. [N]egli ultimi racconti di Ti con zero ho cercato di fare diventare racconto un mero ragionamento deduttivo e forse – qui sì – mi sono allontanato dall’antropomorfismo: o meglio, da un certo antropomorfismo, perché queste presenze umane definite solo da un sistema di relazioni, da una funzione, sono proprio quelle che popolano il mondo attorno a noi, nella nostra vita d’ogni giorno. 
At first, Calvino acknowledges that his stories metaphorically borrow from logic and the deductive method to move away from anthropomorphism and, with it, from values and ways of experiencing the world that are commonly regarded as typically human. Then, however, he immediately adjusts his position to clarify that he only places so much distance between himself and anthropomorphism. In another sense, the seemingly abstract structures and sets of interrelations which he deliberately foregrounds in the cosmicomics are derived precisely from the same human embodied experience that permeates everyday life. 
Conclusions
In this article, I aimed to analyse and reappraise the embodied and experiential dimension of Calvino’s writing. By embracing a cognitive-oriented angle, I proposed a fresh way of looking at the role of spatiality in Calvino, arguing that it is more pervasive than usually acknowledged and that it impacts on his fictional work not only at the level of representations of setting but also structurally. The idea of spatial imagination I advanced captures both the renewed importance of the experiential dimension and the influence of spatiality.
Looking ahead, the notion of spatial imagination and the embodied-cognitive approach could be fruitfully employed to extend and further articulate the exploration initiated here to Calvino’s larger oeuvre. My tentative hypothesis is that spatiality represents a protean yet irreducible presence across Calvino’s production, operating sometimes more locally, sometimes more structurally.  Furthermore, Calvino’s reliance on embodied experience is particularly worth exploring in light of the later phase of his broader trajectory, which explicitly moves toward the attempted reconciliation between abstraction and experience, already in Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore and even more so in the drafts for Sotto il sole giaguaro.  The proposed perspective could lead to illuminate the continuities between what is commonly thought of as the abstract Calvino, of his semiotic phase, and this later Calvino, which recuperates sensuous experience. This further step of Calvino, however, should be framed not as a change of heart, but rather as the exploration of a different entry point in looking at the complex relationship between self and the world.
From a broader perspective, an investigation of this kind could make a case for the general argument that spatial experience may impact on sense-making patterns along the same lines of other types of experience (among others, trauma may be a strong example). Similarly, it shows how landscape and the environment may entail a cognitive priming that goes deeper than the simple description or evocation, opening up potentially productive avenues for research in relation to other authors and works.

***

Calvino and Japanese Gardens: A ‘Trajectivity’ between the Human and More-than-Human

Introduction
In Zen, enlightenment can be attained through silent meditation, but also through the repetition and refinement of everyday tasks, such as garden design and maintenance. Common to all Zen gardens is the incorporation of the kokoro (‘spirit’) of the rocks, trees, and other elements comprising the overall composition, made by humans for humans but in accordance with the different needs of the various materials.1 An extensive understanding of the self and eventual enlightenment in the garden is thus strictly connected to an acknowledgement of the interconnection between this very self and the multiplicity of surrounding forms of existence. To what extent did these dynamics influence a prehensile intellectual like Italo Calvino, who had the opportunity to visit many Japanese gardens in the autumn of 1976?2 How can 
a material-ecocritical approach help illuminate the significance of such spaces for Calvino’s trajectory? What kind of meanings and narratives did these material realities inspire? The present article argues that, by reflecting on how artifice and natural elements meld in Zen gardens, Calvino moves towards a posthumanism where the human is always already intertwined with the more- than-human, thus gesturing towards an understanding of self and other in their mutually constitutive relations.
Calvino’s stay in Japan lasted two weeks, during which he visited Tokyo, Kyoto, Nara and Nikko, but he engaged with Japanese literature and Buddhist, particularly Zen, philosophy over a longer time span, as attested by the ‘Japanese shelves’ of his library in Rome.3 The development of a rounded cross-species awareness, the seeds of which were certainly present in Calvino’s early production, is further encouraged by Calvino’s unceasing rethinking of his sense of what nature and culture mean. Starting from the Japanese articles later collected in Collezione di sabbia, this awareness deepens in many texts brought together in Palomar. At the same time, the nuanced dialectical mode through which Calvino makes sense of Japanese gardens prompts his conception of an ecology of signs encompassing all living systems in ‘The Written World and the Unwritten World’, as well as a potential, if ultimately unrealised deconstruction of gendered dichotomies in the Japanese chapter of Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore.
Calvino’s works have prompted a rapidly increasing number of ecocritical analyses, to which the present contribution seeks to add a cross-cultural nuance by exploring the influence of the author’s Japanese experience on the development of his posthumanism.4 Japanese gardens are designed to encourage various forms of mental abstraction and might act as post-ideological points of reference, in relation to which Calvino’s reflections on cross-species interactions expand to include a radical and all-encompassing posthumanist stance. As a consequence, Palomar, Calvino’s last book, can be read as a (provisional) synthesis of fiction and abstraction, ideology and post-ideology, practice and theory, wherein Japan represents one pole of an ever-changing ecological dialectic.
 
3 In Calvino’s library at Campo Marzio, in Rome, Japanese literature was granted a shelf of its own, with around sixty volumes of Italian, English, French, and Spanish translations of novels and short stories by Abe Kobo, Akutagawa Ryunosuke, Endo Shusaku, Kawabata Yasunari, Mishima Yukio, Oe Kenzaburo, Natsume Soseki, and Tanizaki Jun’ichiro, among the most represented. A different shelf housed a number of Buddhist texts: modern editions of classics by Aśvaghosa, compilations of Zen koan by Mumon, Senzaki Nyogen, and Paul Reps, as well as secondary sources by Eugen Herrigel, Maurice _ Percheron, and Alan Wilson Watts. I wish to thank Prof. Di Nicola for granting me the unprecedented opportunity to access the list of books collected in Calvino’s library, which she has thoroughly classified and described. See Laura Di Nicola, ‘I libri di Italo Calvino’, Bollettino di italianistica: Rivista di critica, storia letteraria, filologia e linguistica, 10 (2013), 275–94; Laura Di Nicola, ‘Una biblioteca mia non riesco mai a tenerla assieme: gli scaffali reali e ideali di Italo Calvino’, in Il privilegio della parola scritta: gestione, conservazione e valorizzazione di carte e libri di persona, ed. by Giovanni Di Domenico and Fiammetta Sabba (Rome: Associazione Italiana Biblioteche, 2020), pp. 99–111. 4 See, among others, Angela M. Jeannet, Under the Radiant Sun and the Crescent Moon: Italo Calvino’s Storytelling (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2000); Silvia Ross, ‘Calvino and Animals: The Multiple Functions of Marcovaldo’s Poisonous Rabbit’, Spunti e ricerche, 18 (2003), 29–40; Kerstin Pilz, ‘Literature as Natural Philosophy: Italo Calvino’s (Post)modern Re-evaluation of Cosmogony’, Annali d’Italianistica, 23 (2005), 191–210; Serenella Iovino, ‘Quanto scommettiamo? Ecologia letteraria, educazione ambientale e Le Cosmicomiche di Italo Calvino’, Compar(a)ison (2007), 107–23; Serenella Iovino, ‘The Wilderness of the Human Other. Italo Calvino’s The Watcher and a Reflection on Third-Wave Ecocriticism’, in The Future of Ecocriticism: New Horizons, ed. by Serpil Opperman et al. (Cambridge: Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2011), pp. 65–81; Serenella Iovino, 
‘Hybriditales. Posthumanizing Calvino’, in Thinking Italian Animals: Human and Posthuman in Modern Italian Literature and 
Film, ed. by Deborah Anderson and Elena Past (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2014), pp. 215–32; Adele Sanna, ‘The Hybrid 
“Biocitizen” in Italo Calvino’s Marcovaldo or the Seasons in the City’, in Ecocritical Approaches to Italian Culture and Literature: The Denatured Wild, ed. by Pasquale Verdicchio (Lanham: Lexington Books, 2016), pp. 31–42; Miriam Aloisio, ‘Impegno ecologico: Malerba e Calvino a confronto’, Ecozon@: European Journal of Literature, Culture and Environment, 8 (2017), 154–75; Niccolò Scaffai, Letteratura e ecologia: Forme e temi di una relazione narrativa (Rome: Carocci, 2017), pp. 151–54, 193–99; Serenella Iovino, ‘Italo Calvino and the Landscapes of the Anthropocene: A Narrative Stratigraphy’, in Italy and the Environmental Humanities: Landscapes, Natures, Ecologies, ed. by Serenella Iovino, Enrico Cesaretti, and Elena Past (Charlottesville, London: University of Virginia Press, 2018), pp. 67–77; Serenella Iovino, Italo Calvino’s Animals (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2021).
The ‘Trajectivity’ of Japanese Gardens
According to the 1977 edition of the Japan Foundation Annual Report, Calvino was in Japan between 5 and 18 November 1976.  In Kyoto he visited Katsura Imperial Villa, Sento Imperial Palace, temples and gardens of Ryoan-ji, Daigo-ji, Manju-in, Ginkaku-ji (also known as the Silver Pavilion), as well as the district of Arashiyama and the commercial area around Shijo-dori and Kawaramachi-dori. He also attended a meeting at the Nihon-Itaria Kyoto-Kaikan with a number of scholars of Italian literature, language, and culture. A postcard to Giorgio Manganelli speaks to Calvino’s visit to Nikko, where he collected a number of yellow and red leaves which he unexpectedly extracted from his pockets during a later dinner in Tokyo.6 Finally, the Tokyo Italian Cultural Institute organised a formal event for the author, attended among others by Yonekawa Ryofu, the first Japanese translator of Calvino’s works. 
Despite the variety of experiences characterising Calvino’s Japanese travels, a specific space recurs with marked persistence in the articles first published in the Corriere della Sera a few months after Calvino’s return, then re-elaborated in L’Approdo letterario, and finally collected in the section ‘La forma del tempo’ of Collezione di sabbia – the space of the garden.8 Whereas Nara, one of the old capitals of the Japanese empire where deer roam freely around parks and streets, is barely mentioned by Calvino, his attention is consistently attracted by gardens: spaces where nature is tamed by human will, while exerting its control over the human. In order to understand the relevance of Japanese gardens for the development of Calvino’s dialectical interaction with the surrounding environment, it is worth recalling that, conversely, the Tule tree he visited in Mexico did not seem to inspire similar cross-species dialogues:
Come se da quella nuvola o montagna vegetale che si profila nel mio campo visivo venisse l’avvertimento che qui la natura, a lenti passi silenziosi, è intenta a mandare avanti un suo piano che non ha nulla a che fare con le proporzioni e dimensioni umane. 
If Calvino interprets this Mexican natural monument as the epitome of an environment that is beyond human scale, thus independent from human rationalisation, in Japanese gardens he is exposed to a culture that is traditionally supposed to see nature ‘as fundamentally indistinct from the self’. 
As Kalland and Asquith emphasize, ‘the Japanese understandings of nature are as varied as those found in the West and we should not fall into the trap of talking about Japanese (or Western) perceptions in the singular’.11 Moreover, if Zen is usually assumed to represent the underlying factor beneath allegedly consistent Japanese modes of being, it is important to remember, following Nina Cornyetz, that the canonisation of Zen as ‘the aesthetic sentiment of Japan throughout the ages is [. . .] a modern construct’, connected to the environment and ethnically connoted in response to Western imperialism.  As a consequence, while the present analysis takes into account a number of canonised features of Zen gardens in light of Calvino’s interpretation, it does so in order to highlight how a contemporary cross-cultural discourse can problematise forms of essentialism that were taken for granted in the past, contextually acknowledging the productive harmonies these forms have been able to generate over time.
Since nature is among the elements that most fuel Orientalism and self-Orientalism (nihonjinron) with regard to Japan, it is worth considering the extent to which Calvino himself was subjected to similar Orientalist views.  Indeed, the two writers who most profoundly shaped Calvino’s image of Japan are both representatives of self-Orientalism, each in different and ever-changing ways: namely, Kawabata Yasunari (1899–1972) and Tanizaki Jun’ichiro (1886–1965). Not only did Calvino own many of their books, he also referred to them when retracing the inspiration for his Japanese chapter in Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore, named the former among his favourite authors of the twentieth century, reviewed the latter’s In Praise of Shadows in La Repubblica (in an article entitled ‘Un viso bianco nel buio’), and quoted the same book in the essay ‘La luce negli occhi’, in Collezione di sabbia, when discussing different theories of colour and vision.14
Kawabata, in particular, touches upon some general features of the Japanese art of landscaping in his Nobel lecture, and attentively names and describes a number of popular Kyoto gardens in his Beauty and Sadness (both of which are present in Calvino’s library: see footnote 14). The opening of the chapter ‘A Stone Garden’ from Beauty and Sadness is particularly relevant in retracing Calvino’s points of reference when visiting Japan. In its English translation, Kawabata’s opening reads as follows: ‘Among the many famous old stone gardens in Kyoto are those of the Moss Temple, the Silver Pavilion, and Ryoanji; indeed, the latter is almost too famous, though it may be said to embody the very essence of Zen aesthetics’.15 In this passage, as in many others in his work, Kawabata openly refers to an alleged ‘essence of Zen aesthetics’, which must have almost certainly reverberated in Calvino’s mind during his experience in Japan. As a further proof of this proximity, Calvino refers in Collezione di sabbia to ‘un tempio a Kyoto il cui giardino è interamente ricoperto di muschio’ – that is the Moss Temple – and to the sand gardens of the Silver Pavilion and Ryoanji: 
C’è nei giardini zen di Kyoto una sabbia bianca a grossi grani, quasi una ghiaia, che ha la dote di riflettere i raggi della luna. Al tempio Ryoanji, questa sabbia, rastrellata dai monaci in solchi diritti paralleli o in circoli concentrici, forma un piccolo giardino intorno a cinque gruppi irregolari di basse rocce. Al tempio del Padiglione d’Argento, invece, la sabbia è disposta in un monticello tondeggiante, isolato, a tronco di cono, e s’allarga in una distesa rastrellata a onde regolari. 
Calvino’s cross-cultural encounter proves to be strongly influenced by literary and aesthetic idealisations of Japanese gardens. The concept of a mutual embedding of nature and culture recurs in such idealisations and is supposed to weave contemporary, Buddhist, and Confucian philosophies into a peculiar seamless fabric, which also contains elements of Shinto, characterised by a common harmonic fusion of ecocentrism and cultivation. 
Above all, Calvino is intrigued by the interpenetration of self and environment, as canonised by Watsuji Tetsuro (1889–1960) in his Fūdo, a cornerstone of Japanese philosophy, translated into English as Climate and Culture: A Philosophical Study. Watsuji’s essay presents a highly- pronounced sensitivity to atmospheric phenomena as an objective reality of Japanese culture, allegedly proven by the existence of seasonal words in Japanese, by the long socio-cultural history of rice growing, as well as by themes and structures of haiku, landscape painting, and other forms of art. To borrow Augustin Berque’s words, ‘Japanese culture, as a collective subject’, is supposed to cause ‘its own environment to live in it as subject’.  Japanese gardens seem to epitomise effectively this ‘subjectivation of the environment’ and ‘environmentalisation of the subject’, in the words of naturalist Imanishi Kinji (1902–92).20 Unlike the symmetry of a space like the park of Versailles, which cannot but be identified with culture, the Japanese garden, while premised upon a ‘reductionism’ that allows gardeners to condense broader landscapes, is intended to give the impression of being entirely natural. 
The traditional Sakutei-ki (‘Notes on garden techniques’), a short collection of precepts that, after circulating secretly for centuries, is now considered a classic of the Japanese art of gardening, expresses this apparent paradox clearly: it provides norms for a cultural construction of the garden, but also consistently invites the gardener to follow nature, to do what the stone demands. In ‘I mille giardini’, Calvino shows how subtle his understanding is of this feature:
Le pietre che affiorano in mezzo al muschio sono piatte, staccate l’una dall’altra, disposte alla distanza giusta perché chi cammina se ne trovi sempre una sotto al piede a ogni passo; ed è proprio in quanto obbediscono alla misura dei passi, che le pietre comandano i movimenti dell’uomo in marcia, lo obbligano ad un’andatura calma e uniforme, ne guidano il cammino e le soste. 
Calvino also tunes in to Japanese gardens’ harmonisation of humanity with culture and nature when visiting the garden of Sento Imperial Palace, described in ‘Il rovescio del sublime’:
C’è una cosa che mi sembra di cominciare a capire, qui a Kyoto: attraverso i giardini, più che attraverso i templi e i palazzi. La costruzione d’una natura padroneggiabile dalla mente perché la mente possa ricevere a sua volta ritmo e proporzione dalla natura: così potrebbe definirsi l’intento che ha portato a comporre questi giardini. 
Gardens in Japan are designed by human beings and created using natural elements, which in turn engender a reciprocal influence on human minds. Not only are these peculiar cultural spaces embedded in a natural dimension – with the assumed nature/culture dichotomy being exposed in its fundamental fallacy – but they also represent on a microscopic scale the interaction of human and more-than-human agencies, which the human mind is able to conceive macroscopically as a consequence of its own wilful decentralisation and of a rational renunciation of dominant rationalism.
Anthropological and semiotic analyses of Japanese cultural configurations have reflected upon this mechanism extensively. Drawing on Louis-Adolphe Bertillon’s definition of mésologie as the study of the reciprocal reactions between organisms and their environment, Augustin Berque has proposed the definition of milieux as spaces that are both natural and cultural, subjective and objective, collective and individual.  Japanese gardens, in particular, are considered to be milieux that enshrine a dynamic ‘trajectivity’, a continuous mediation of the borderline between subjective, assimilatory impulses, and the objective intimations emanating from the cosmos. Berque has advanced the notion of ‘trajectivity’, drawing upon the root trans-, which encompasses the idea of transcending dualism and making connections between the extremes of subjective and objective, thus overcoming the inherently centripetal implication of the pro- in projection. 
The Buddhist net of Indra is an image that recurs in many analyses of ‘trajectivity’: ‘all relational events are likened to shining jewels reflecting all other jewels in the net from the standpoint of their own perspective’.  In such a holographic or fractal model, the whole can only be understood through the parts that constitute it, resulting in the absence of a dominant standpoint. Indeed, as far as Zen gardens are concerned, Calvino writes:
Ogni pietra corrisponde a un passo, e a ogni passo corrisponde un paesaggio studiato in tutti i dettagli, come un quadro; il giardino è stato predisposto in modo che di passo in passo lo sguardo incontri prospettive diverse, un’armonia diversa nelle distanze che separano il cespuglio, la lampada, l’acero, il ponte ricurvo, il ruscello. 
The ‘naturalness’ of similar gardens is a cultural construction itself, but one ‘which emphasizes the quest for unity with nature’.  The human being relativises its own position in the surrounding environment, seen as a fractal where tout se tient, through a deliberate refusal to consider the rational tools that brought to the conceptualisation of such reality as the only viable point of reference for navigating space.
Kawabata addresses the reciprocal interaction between nature and culture in his Nobel lecture, bringing into the discussion what he refers to as ‘the highest pinnacle of Japanese literature’: ‘[t]he Genji [the Tale of Genji, by Murasaki Shikibu] was a wide and deep source of nourishment for poetry, of course, and for the fine arts and handicrafts as well, and even for landscape gardening’.  In his reference to landscape gardening, Kawabata identifies a cultural model of nature – emerging from the Genji – to adhere to when operating on nature itself. Indeed, from the late twelfth century, Zen Buddhist gardens were also designed based on Chinese poetry.  In ‘Il rovescio del sublime’, Calvino develops a similar thought:
Seguendo il filo delle mie riflessioni, mi viene da pensare che qui poesie e giardini si generano gli uni dagli altri a vicenda: i giardini venivano composti come illustrazioni a poesie e le poesie venivano composte come commento ai giardini. Ma mi viene da pensarlo più per amore della simmetria nei ragionamenti che perché ne sia veramente convinto: ossia, trovo ben plausibile che si possa fare con la disposizione degli alberi l’equivalente d’una poesia, ma sospetto che per scrivere una poesia sugli alberi gli alberi veri servano poco o nulla. 
In order to create gardens – as distinct, for example, from composing a poem – the human being has to take into account the specificities of natural materiality. Calvino’s ability to recognise the autonomy of poetry, and language tout court, from the surrounding world can only emerge in retrospect. Thus, Japanese gardens stimulate awareness of the ‘intersections of materiality and discursivity’, which, as Serpil Oppermann notes, ‘create agentic fields of mutual emergence of all life forms, and connect human knowledge practices with biosemiotic emergences’. 
Human and More-than-Human Interrelations: From Calvino’s ‘Japanese Shelf’ to Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore and Palomar
According to Shintoism, all natural objects have spiritual qualities; similarly, in Zen everything possesses the Buddha-nature.  Many of the prevalent conceptions of the world in Japan descend from this idea of a spirituality and agency diffused among all beings, which inevitably influences a number of the Japanese books Calvino had the opportunity to read. This section will survey the most significant examples of the multifarious literary transpositions of such cross-species interrelations, with a specific focus on the agency that Japanese authors attribute to plants and landscapes. Ultimately, it will discuss the extent to which Calvino’s mature production bears the mark of his contact with the representation of cross-species interconnections in Japanese nature and culture.
Kawabata, the champion of the alleged ‘essence of the Japanese mind’, often rejects any artificial separation of the animate versus the inanimate, man versus beast, man versus plant, instead seeing all things as organically related as in one gigantic flow of a river.  In The Old Capital, the story of twin sisters Chieko and Naeko who, separated after their birth, progressively reconstruct an affective and existential connection, Chieko ‘sometimes [. . .] was moved by the “life” of the violets on the tree. Other times their “loneliness” touched her heart’.  In Kawabata’s earlier novel Snow Country, particularly in its final pages, even the Milky Way takes on a human quality and the fire inspires inanimate objects with life. 
Japan’s second Nobel Prize in Literature winner, Oe Kenzaburo (b. 1935), firmly rejected Kawabata’s aestheticisation of Japanese culture. He even responded to Kawabata’s Nobel Prize speech Japan, the Beautiful, and Myself with a provocative counter-speech titled Japan, the Ambiguous, and Myself, when awarded the prize in 1994. However, Oe’s texts also speak of visible and invisible forces that interweave across human and nonhuman bodies. In Oe’s A Personal Matter, the protagonist rides a bike in a state of utter confusion occasioned by learning that his son has just been born with a defective cranial bone structure. Not only does he encounter ‘thick and dark’ ginkgo trees that reflect his inner state, but he even feels ‘threatened by the trees’, as if they were properly living and agentive beings as much as himself. 
Forms of botanic agency recur with a particularly strong emphasis in those texts where the permeability of human and more-than-human bodies and natures is actually triggered by states of mental disturbance. Akutagawa Ryunosuke (1892–1927), for instance, lets his paranoid voice confuse trees with human beings when representing his physical and psychic malady in the short story ‘Cogwheels’.  In The Box-Man, by Abe Kobo (1924–93), the landscape communicates, plays with, and even smiles at one of the human characters 
He had the impression that the whole view had turned into eyes that reproached him. [. . .] He looked playfully at the street beyond the mirror. And the street returned the smile of the amorous boy. Just by looking at it, the world was happy for him. In his imagination he put his signature to a peace treaty between himself and the world. 
In Calvino’s selection of Japanese books, the dynamic interaction between the human and more- than-human is consistently bi-directional and multifaceted: what originates from the human is not only projected onto the surrounding environment, but welcomes the counter-influence that this movement of ‘trajectivity’ entails.
In order to convey the sense of harmony that characterises Zen gardens in Collezione di sabbia, Calvino similarly describes natural elements in human terms:
Anche di cascate d’acqua il giardino Sento ne ha due: una maschio e una femmina (Odaki e Medaki), la prima a picco tra le rocce, la seconda che mormora saltellando tra gradini di sassi in una crepa del prato [. . .] 
([. . .] ogni caratterizzazione troppo estrema ci allontana dal vero spirito del giardino giapponese, dove mai un elemento prende il sopravvento su un altro). 
[. . .] un greto di ciottoli levigati e tondeggianti, grigio-chiari e grigio-scuri, che continuano sotto l’acqua verde del laghetto come godendo della sua trasparenza. 
Contextually, arboreal features are located within human bodies:
Molte vecchie in Giappone sono ingobbite e contorte come per una parentela con gli alberi nani coltivati in vaso secondo l’antica arte del bonsai [. . .]. [B]asse di statura sotto grandi fagotti di foglie secche e cesti di rami, armate di rastrelli e di roncole, non si capisce se vecchie o giovani ma già nodose e contorte come per un adattamento ambientale. 
According to an aesthetic logic of identification, sharing a common attribute entails an intersubjective shift, where becoming together prevails over merely being. In Japanese gardens, this shift is premised upon the permeability of the self and the environment, which Calvino does not fail to notice and creatively re-elaborate.
Calvino’s most overtly Japanese narrative, ‘Sul tappeto di foglie illuminato dalla luna’, the eighth chapter of Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore, applies this reciprocity to intricate male-female relationships. This incipit, set in an undefined and yet easily recognisable Japan, deals with shady sexual affairs and psychological connections. The main character is involved in academic research in the library of Mr Okeda, whose taciturn and pensive traits seem to evoke the temperament of a Zen master.  Besides spending his days discussing perceptions with Mr Okeda, he eventually seduces the man’s daughter and has a sexual encounter with his wife. In the idiosyncratic context of Se una notte d’inverno un viaggiatore, Calvino stages Japanese literature by highlighting one of its most characteristic themes (eroticism) and narrative paces (a rather slow and analytical one), which are abundantly present in several of the novels on his ‘Japanese shelf’.44 When Mr Okeda’s wife (Miyagi) and daughter (Makiko) make an appearance alongside the two men, Calvino is compelled to confront his own discomfort at writing about sex, in order to express the sexual charge that their presence entails.45 The heavy descriptivism of the chapter turns from trees and flowers to the two women’s bodies and beauty, and the story acquires the distinctive erotic mark of several Japanese books, as well as of the erotic prints Calvino describes in ‘Eros e discontinuità’, in the Japanese section of Collezione di sabbia. 
Calvino’s Japanese text reproduces and stylises the androcentric gaze that dominates Kawabata’s and Tanizaki’s novels, among others.  At the same time, the enunciating self, while observing and approaching the body of Mrs Miyagi, realises more than once that he is also scrutinised not only by Mr Okeda, but also by Ms Makiko:
[Makiko] spalancava gli occhi seguendo i sussulti di sua madre e miei con attrazione e disgusto. Ma non era sola: al di là del corridoio, nel vano d’un’altra porta una figura d’uomo stava immobile in piedi. Non so da quanto tempo il signor Okeda era là. Guardava fissamente, non sua moglie e me, ma sua figlia che ci guardava.48
The observer thus turns out to be observed, with the female pole triggering the same reciprocity of perspectives that in Japanese gardens arises from natural elements. If this mechanism potentially reinforces what has long been assumed to be the natural inferiority of women, something which feminist theory has questioned and deconstructed, Calvino’s stylisation seems to turn this problematic dynamic upside down.  By describing the intricate connection of female and male gazes, he gestures towards a dialectical mode of understanding the interaction between genders, where different viewpoints (and identities) emerge in their reciprocally structuring relations.
In Palomar, Calvino’s last book, a dialectical approach to the interplay of different perspectives finally involves both non-anthropocentric forms of life and non-logocentric modes of expression. In ‘L’aiola di sabbia’, the text where Calvino describes his visit to the Ryoanji Zen garden in Kyoto, he states that in the relation between stones and sand ‘si intuisce un’armonia possibile come tra due armonie non omogenee: quella del non-umano in un equilibrio di forze che sembra non risponda a nessun disegno; quella delle strutture umane che aspira a una razionalità di composizione geometrica o musicale, mai definitiva . . . ’.  From this text, which is the only one among Calvino’s earlier articles about Japan to filter through to Palomar, Japanese influence echoes throughout the book, and the harmony between non-homogeneous harmonies mainly informs what Roberto Marchesini would call ‘animal epiphanies’.51
In ‘La pancia del geco’, for instance, Palomar recurrently compares some features of the gecko to human organs (its claws are likened to actual hands, its legs to human elbows), without dispensing with parallels with other animals (the tip of the gecko’s chin, ‘hard and all scales’, is compared to that of an alligator). Alongside this description, there is an attempt to understand a troublesome aspect of human morality:
[Il geco:] una macchina elaboratissima, studiata in ogni microscopico dettaglio, tanto che viene da chiedersi se una tale perfezione non sia sprecata, viste le operazioni limitate che compie. O forse è quello il suo segreto: soddisfatto d’essere, riduce il fare al minimo? Sarà questa la sua lezione, l’opposto della morale che in gioventù il signor Palomar aveva voluto far sua: cercare sempre di fare qualcosa un po’ al di là dei propri mezzi? 
The entire book is filled with similar questions arising from the observation of the forms and behaviours of animals, connecting them to specific aspects of human interior and exterior life.53 As Serenella Iovino states, Calvino deploys ‘the heuristic usefulness of anthropomorphism to shed light on ethical and ontological similarities across the species’.54 To quote a few other examples, a sense of climate anxiety is triggered by the passage of migratory birds in ‘L’invasione degli storni’: ‘Sarà perché questo affollarsi del cielo ci ricorda che l’equilibrio della natura è perduto? O perché il nostro senso d’insicurezza proietta dovunque minacce di catastrofe?’.  In ‘La corsa delle giraffe’, the clumsy movements of giraffes and their inharmonious yet perfectly functioning bodies offer food for thought as far as the world’s and Palomar’s very movements are concerned:
Il signor Palomar [. . .] si domanda il perché del suo interesse per le giraffe. Forse perché il mondo intorno a lui si muove in modo disarmonico ed egli spera sempre di scoprirvi un disegno, una costante. Forse perché lui stesso sente di procedere spinto da moti della mente non coordinati, che sembrano non aver niente a che fare con l’uno e con l’altro e che è sempre difficile far quadrare in un qualsiasi modello d’armonia interiore. 
An albino gorilla who never abandons a car tyre recalls human investment in things, in the search for an escape from the pain of living, which triggers Palomar’s ‘simultaneous alienation and camaraderie’ with the animal57
Nell’enorme vuoto delle sue ore, «Copito de Nieve» non abbandona mai il copertone. Cosa sarà questo oggetto per lui? Un giocattolo? Un feticcio? Un talismano? A Palomar sembra di capire perfettamente il gorilla, il suo bisogno d’una cosa da tener stretta mentre tutto gli sfugge [. . .]. Di lì gli si può aprire uno spiraglio verso quella che per l’uomo è la ricerca d’una via d’uscita dallo sgomento di vivere: l’investire se stesso nelle cose, il riconoscersi nei segni, il trasformare il mondo in un insieme di simboli. 
In ‘L’ordine degli squamati’, the iguanas in a reptile house of the Jardin des Plantes in Paris – again described by means of parallels with human and other animal bodies, and even with flora and stones –59 renovate the interrelation between a cross-species proximity and the understanding of human relativity: ‘sono queste le sensazioni di chi s’affaccia fuori dall’umano? Al di là del vetro d’ogni gabbia c’è il mondo di prima dell’uomo, o di dopo, a dimostrare che il mondo dell’uomo non è eterno e non è l’unico’.60 In all these instances, Calvino is anticipating what Rosi Braidotti has defined as ‘a relational ethics that values cross-species, transversal alliances with the productive and immanent force of zoe, or nonhuman life’.61 The harmony between non-homogeneous harmonies of the Ryoanji Zen garden constitutes the embodied validation of such relational hypotheses.
Finally, in ‘Il fischio del merlo’, Palomar advances a parallel between the modes of communication of blackbirds and humans: by cohabiting a shared material and discursive Umwelt, animals and human beings form what Dominique Lestel would define as ‘semiotic community’, where mutual understanding is made possible by the overlapping of each species’ semiosphere.62 The blackbird’s whistle is said to be always almost identical to itself, thus breaking the basic rule of human language, which has to be variable in order to convey variations of thought. What changes in the communication of blackbirds is rather the duration of silence between each whistle. Therefore, either the whistle has a merely phatic function, or what truly has meaning is silence.63 Through this parallel, Calvino envisages two key factors behind human communication: not only is it possible that human beings do not understand each other, but silence must be considered a viable, alternative form of expression, and by no means a less productive one. Again, it is by means of a perception of the dissimilar that a previously unexplored potentiality behind human language becomes intelligible, thus proving the epistemological relevance of a dialectical interaction among beings.
The Language of Gardens: between ‘The Written World and the Unwritten World’
In the text ‘I mille giardini’, in Collezione di sabbia, Calvino connects in a decisive way Japanese attentiveness towards changing perspectives and the idiosyncratic silent language of meditation, at once subsuming the human experience in the garden under a broader conception of life, where the human does not assume a privileged position:
Qui [nel giardino di villa Katsura] è il percorso la ragione essenziale del giardino, il filo del suo discorso, la frase che dà significato a ogni sua parola. Ma quali significati? [. . .] il contrasto tra la civiltà e la natura? [. . .] una lezione sul modo di muoversi nel mondo? Ogni interpretazione lascia insoddisfatti; se c’è un messaggio, è quello che si coglie nelle sensazioni e nelle cose, senza tradurle in parole.64
Here Calvino reiterates a parallel, already suggested in ‘Il rovescio del sublime’ (‘qui poesie e giardini si generano gli uni dagli altri a vicenda’), between human and more-than-human systems of signs: both are based on a finite number of units (phonemes on the one hand, plants or stones on the other), whose combinations constitute ever-expanding mechanisms of signification.65 But he also advances a notion of signification as bursting forth from things, without any linguistic counterpart, which is one of the main tenets of material ecocriticism: ‘All matter [. . .] is a “storied matter”. It is a material “mesh” of meanings, properties, and processes, in which human and nonhuman players are interlocked in networks that produce undeniable signifying forces’.66
Calvino further expands on this concept in a later paper delivered at the Institute for the Humanities of New York University on 30 March 1983, under the title of ‘The Written World and the Unwritten World’. Here Calvino declares that he is not totally convinced by the thesis 
 
bianca crestata’. Calvino, Romanzi e racconti, II, p. 946: ‘[I]l Cordilo gigante africano dalle scaglie puntute e folte come pelo o foglie’; ‘bestie e piante e rocce si scambiano squame, aculei, concrezioni’.
60Calvino, Romanzi e racconti, II, p. 947.
61Rosi Braidotti, ‘Posthuman Critical Theory’, in Critical Posthumanism and Planetary Futures, ed. by Debashish Banerji and Makarand R. Paranjape (New York: Springer, 2016), pp. 13–32 (p. 23).
62Dominique Lestel, ‘The Biosemiotics and Phylogenesis of Culture’, Social Science Information, 4 (2002), 35–68.
63Calvino, Romanzi e racconti, II, p. 893.
64Calvino, Saggi, p. 583.
65Ibid. p. 576.
