66Serenella Iovino and Serpil Oppermann, ‘Introduction: Stories Come to Matter’, in Material Ecocriticism, ed. by Serenella Iovino and Serpil Oppermann (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2014), pp. 1–17 (pp. 1–2).
according to which ‘il mondo non esiste; esiste solo il linguaggio’, nor by the opposite view claiming that ‘il linguaggio comune non ha senso; il mondo è ineffabile’.  He denounces the impossibility of doing without language, at the same time acknowledging that there also exists in the world a ‘silenzio pieno di significato’, towards which language strives.  Hence his pragmatic view:
In un certo senso, credo che sempre scriviamo di qualcosa che non sappiamo: scriviamo per rendere possibile al mondo non scritto di esprimersi attraverso di noi. Nel momento in cui la mia attenzione si sposta dall’ordine regolare delle righe scritte e segue la mobile complessità che nessuna frase può contenere o esaurire, mi sento vicino a capire che dall’altro lato delle parole c’è qualcosa che cerca d’uscire dal silenzio, di significare attraverso il linguaggio, come battendo colpi su un muro di prigione.69
In other words, Homo legens (Calvino coins this expression in the essay) cannot but approach reality by means of language, but this operation is viable only if accompanied by an awareness of the partiality of this same language, and of the fact that the entire universe is ‘perfused with signs’, as Peirce remarked. 
In the final text of Palomar, ‘Come imparare a essere morto’, Calvino takes this relativisation of human language to extreme and original consequences. Here Palomar dies while describing his surrounding environment and the book ends contextually. In this way, the subject achieves his own dethronement, undermines his own centrality, at the same time acknowledging the ungraspable objectivity of the world and proposing a way of representing such inaccessibility. Palomar’s death is inherently close to forms of awakening characterising both Buddhism and, in the Western context, Platonism: it is prepared by a discursive path in which logos is still present, and in which a triadic, traditionally dialectical structure is deployed; but this very logic ends up being subverted from within – or perhaps sublated – when the protagonist dies and represents through embodiment his own fusion with the surrounding world in its entirety. 
It is notable that Palomar initially tries to read the surrounding environment (‘Lettura di un’onda’), whereas he ends up dying while writing it (‘Come imparare a essere morto’). When reading, the subject unavoidably keeps the read object at a distance and set apart. In the act of writing, on the other hand, the border between subject and object blurs significantly, for a specific deliberation of the subject: ‘scriviamo per rendere possibile al mondo non scritto di esprimersi attraverso di noi’.  This increased, wilful proximity – if not fusion – recalls the condition of the human being exploring a Zen garden and feeling part of an all-embracing and non-hierarchical reality. The complete removal of any strong distinction between the inside and the outside of the human, towards an integration into the surrounding whole, represents the highest intellectual and narrative consequence of Calvino’s contact with the material reality of Japanese gardens, where the human being characteristically fuses with nature in its widest, cosmic extension.
Conclusion: A Post-Ideological (Japanese) Posthumanism
As Gian Carlo Ferretti has argued, Calvino’s essayistic and journalistic production reveals a long- standing awareness of the role of the animal gaze in relativising the centrality of the human.  However, Calvino initially expressed this awareness only in journalistic form and under a specific ideological influence.  All the early articles where he acknowledges the ethical need to consider more-than-human points of view in order to better understand human responsibilities (‘Le capre ci guardano’, ‘Soggezione di un cane’, ‘Il marxismo spiegato ai gatti’, and ‘Da Esopo a Disney’) were published in L’Unità, the official newspaper of the Italian Communist Party, in 1946. In ‘Il marxismo spiegato ai gatti’, Calvino comments: ‘Io [. . .] propendo per una concezione dell’uomo come non staccato dal resto della natura, di animale più evoluto in mezzo agli altri animali, e mi sembra che una tale concezione non abbassi l’uomo, ma gli dia una responsabilità maggiore, lo impegni a una moralità meno arbitraria, impedisca tante storture’.  Marxism surfaces again in the animal- centred short story ‘La gallina di reparto’ (1958), whose political reading has been observed by Iovino, as well as in a passage from La giornata d’uno scrutatore (1963) when the relationship between human beings and nature is discussed:  ‘Il comunista Amerigo Ormea cercò in Marx. E vide, nei Manoscritti giovanili, un passo che fa: “[. . .] La natura è il corpo inorganico dell’uomo, precisamente in quanto non è essa stessa corpo umano. Che l’uomo viva della natura vuol dire che la natura è il suo corpo, con cui deve stare in costante progresso per non morire . . . ”’.  Later, especially after Calvino’s decision to resign from the Italian Communist Party in 1957, ideology gradually attenuates in Calvino’s texts, as does his early interest in possible dialectical relations between human and more-than-human beings. 
This article has argued that it is only after Calvino’s acknowledgement of the agency of the botanic other – which he experiences in Japanese gardens, reads about in a number of Japanese literary works, and discusses in his own Japanese articles – that his deconstruction of several hierarchical conceptualisations of the surrounding world emerges with renewed strength, perhaps made even more pervasive by the absence of any manifest ideological charge.  Indeed, Japan epitomises the tendency of Calvino’s mature discourse to distance itself from overt forms of impegno, standing as a post-ideological, aesthetic function that contrasts with Calvino’s own previous travelogues from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and United States of America, and with the predominance of committed reportages of Italian writers travelling around the East in the late 1950s and 1960s. 
On the one hand, the choice to disengage from previous political frameworks leaves Calvino unequipped to recognise ideologies of different kinds in Japan, when he encounters and rather uncritically absorbs Kawabata’s and Tanizaki’s self-Orientalist tropes. On the other hand, the non- anthropocentric humanism that arises from this cross-cultural experience is able to unleash its radical potential precisely by virtue of its disengagement from a connoted, Western ideology like Marxism. Of course, the heuristic position according to which the human is recognised as materially permeable with other natures can only be theorised after a series of practical experiences such as the ones that Palomar undergoes, and precisely this praxis – the interrelation of theory and practice – is at the core of both Marxism and Buddhism.  This article has sought to demonstrate, however, that Calvino’s late non-anthropocentric humanism ultimately resonates more profoundly with the forms of Buddhism he explored while wandering around Japanese gardens, which consider any being on the same level, contextually paving the way to the deconstruction of widespread forms of androcentrism and logocentrism.
Calvino’s awareness of being part of an interconnected universe results in a renewed understanding of the non-hegemonic role of human beings, who must approach, describe, and potentially blend with all other forms of life in order to truly appreciate their own and other beings’ role in the cosmic whole. This opening towards the world, to realise that the world is already open within every human and more-than-human being, is not only a tenet of Buddhist thought, but also operates effectively in the atmosphere of Calvino’s last book: after all, Calvino once stated that ‘il signor Palomar è quanto di più vicino si possa immaginare a un monaco, se vogliamo buddista’.  Calvino’s Japanese experience thus bears a posthuman and ecological significance that enriches our comprehension of the author’s mature production, while also highlighting the need to engage in cross-cultural dialogues in order to gain a more nuanced understanding of contemporary Italian literature and culture.

***

‘Occhi Fissi’: Fixing the Gaze in Dante’s Commedia 

Fixing the gaze was a multifaceted act in the intellectual and poetic environment in which Dante wrote the Commedia. It was discussed in a spectrum of literary arenas from lyric poetry to prayer manuals, philosophical sententia to medical treatises and theological texts. While the complexity of Dante’s engagement with the science and culture of gazing has been the topic of numerous important studies, the specific connotations of his depictions of visual fixity have yet to be fully explored, although the trope appears in several key episodes with different emphases across the poem.1 When Dante fixes his gaze on Beatrice in the opening canto of Paradiso, for example, his focused vision is presented as a devotional act, 
a catalyst for the metamorphosis that will allow him to enter heaven (‘Beatrice tutta ne l’etterne rote/fissa con li occhi stava; e io in lei/le luci fissi, di là sù remote’, Par. I, 64–66).  When he fixes an equally intense gaze on Beatrice in the Earthly Paradise, however, Dante is criticised by heavenly intermediaries as ‘too fixed’ (‘troppo fiso’, Purg. XXXII, 9), leading to the first of the many temporary blindnesses that accompany his journey through Paradise. Readers since the fourteenth century have sought to explain this visual failure as a fault in the pilgrim’s intention: more focused on Beatrice’s physical appearance than on her celestial promise, a failing, therefore, in intellectual or spiritual capacity. The interruption of Dante’s ‘too fixed’ gaze is rarely considered from the perspective of its textual performance as a dramatization of a literary trope disrupted, modulated, and transformed before the reader’s eyes.
Tracing the use of the term fiso and its cognates through Dante’s poem, where these refer to the gaze, this article explores the ways in which Dante’s depictions of visual fixity draw on and nuance contemporary optical theories, tapping into wider cultural discourses on the fixed gaze to construct an innovative visual mode comprehensive enough to communicate the multi-layered nature of his otherworldly vision.  As well as drawing on technical theories of sight, this article argues that Dante explores the metaphorical transference between sight and attention, presenting the gaze as a privileged site for investigating questions of focus and, as analysis of the depiction of fixed gazing the central canti of Purgatorio reveals, the workings of desire. Close reading of the multiple gazes staged in the dream of the Siren in Purgatorio XIX reveals that Dante includes a spectrum of different cultures of gazing in his poem, drawing on recognisable tropes to invite his reader to compare, contrast, and recombine their emphases to come to her own conclusion about the connotations of certain acts of gazing. The entanglement of this discussion with some of the poem’s most recognisable metapoetic imagery points to the potency of the fixed gaze as an arena for negotiating the reader’s attention. Applying this metapoetic awareness to the interruption of Dante’s ‘too fixed’ gaze in the Earthly Paradise, this article argues that the disruption to the pilgrim’s vision can be read as a literary technique designed to expose and explode the differences between multiple cultures of gazing.
The roots of this trope are traced in Dante’s early rime, where interruptions to the gaze are shown to work as a specific innovation on a lyric topos, expanding the connotations of fixating on the beloved to encompass a notion of philosophical and theological inquiry.  Locating the coordinates of the fixed (and interrupted) gaze in Paradiso reveals its unique suitability to negotiating the representational challenges posed by the transcendental nature of the final cantica, drawing attention to (and denying) the gaze of the text to invite the reader to fulfil the poet’s vision in her imagination.  Focusing on the function of the (interrupted) fixed gaze as a literary technique, this article adds to recent scholarship on the intellectual pluralism of Paradiso, identifying another example of the ways in which Dante’s text contains ‘site[s] of participatory action’, as Heather Webb has termed them. These textual openings invite the reader to share both pilgrim and poet’s vision through innovative poetic tropes that accompany the dance of embodied, spiritual, and intellectual sight leading pilgrim, poet, and reader, under the watchful eye of the beloved, towards a vision of God. 
Dante and the Gaze
The breadth of Dante’s scientific, scriptural, classical, and vernacular references to sight has fuelled a rich field of scholarship.7 In his studies on optical theory in the works of Dante, Simon Gilson has even suggested that the Commedia ‘might well be termed “plurivisual”, or at the least one might argue that it offers us a veritable encyclopaedia [. . .] of the different modes and models of vision available to medieval culture’.  The dynamics of visual fixity deserve to be explored in this context, as close reading of Dante’s employment of the term fiso and its cognates reveals.9 Several of the physical processes that were related to fixing the gaze in the optical theories circulating in the Italian trecento appear in Dante’s text. External sight, which was thought to operate by means of the emission from or penetration of the eye by semi- physical beams, was the precondition for the apprehension of external images in the internal spaces of the heart and mind, where vision could become understanding as the viewer meditated upon things seen.  The gaze was thus thought to catalyse a spectrum of mental acts that resulted in cognitive clusters including imagination and memory.11 In order for vision to pass from external to internal sight, the eyes were said to need a clear view of the object under consideration and multiple emotions and physical impediments were thought to be potential hindrances in this process, as Dante notes with a personal anecdote about weakening his eyes through excessive study in the third book of the Convivio (III. ix. 13). 
Fixing the gaze is explicitly related to understanding and cognition in the Commedia in moments in which the pilgrim’s gaze is directed to locative effect, drawing attention to details in the landscape when Dante peers into the depths of Limbo (‘fiso riguardai/per conoscer lo loco dov’io fossi [. . .] ficcar lo viso a fondo’, Inf. IV, 5–6; 11) and in Inferno XXI (‘io là giù fisamente mirava’, 22), or through the branches of the tree on the terrace of gluttony in Purgatorio XXIII (‘Mentre che li occhi per la fronda verde/ficcava ïo’, 1–2). This also occurs in several of Virgil’s directives to the pilgrim’s sight: when exhorting him to look at the river of blood in Inferno XII (‘Ficca li occhi a valle’, 46), at the punishment of the proud in Purgatorio X (‘guarda fiso là’, 118), or through the dense clouds on the terrace of envy (‘ficca li occhi per l’aeare ben fiso’, Purg. XIII, 43). This active verb construction presents the gaze as a penetrative force, emphasising the embodied nature of the optical process and endowing it with a certain level of tactility, exploited with sexual overtones during the encounter with Brunetto Latini (‘ficcaï li occhi per lo cotto aspetto’, Inf. XV, 26), and to convey the intensity of interpersonal recognition when Dante encounters Cavalcante dei Cavalcanti (‘Io avea già il mio viso nel suo fitto’, Inf. X, 34), Manfred (‘Io mi volsi ver’ lui e guardail fiso,’ Purg. III, 106), and Beatrice (‘Tant’ eran li occhi miei fissi e attenti,’ Purg. XXXII, 1).  Such intensity is equally present in the use of the fixed gaze to signal other characters’ interest in Dante, particularly in Purgatorio, where the souls enter into relational conversations with the pilgrim and marvel at his embodied state.14 This practical application of the gaze as an indicator of desire for knowledge or human connection points to its metaphorical potential as an external representation of internal focus, alluded to when Dante reassures Brunetto Latini that his ‘cara e buona imagine paterna’ is ‘fixed’ in his mind (“n la mente m’è fitta,’ Inf. XV, 82), and when he employs the lexicon of fixity to describe the effect of being emotionally moved (‘la vostra condizion dentro mi fisse’, Inf. XVI, 53). 
Such fusing of internal and external expression privileges vision as a mediating process and fixation as its primary mode. This transference is brought to the fore in Paradiso, where the embodied nature of Dante’s ‘vision’ is consistently blended with a transcendental notion of the ‘visionary’ nature of his paradisiacal journey.  In the final cantica, the pilgrim’s attention is frequently commanded through instructions to focus his mind as well as his gaze on sights that require intellectual as much as physical vision to be fully understood: Dante is directed to consider the contemplative souls in the Heaven of Saturn (‘Ficca di retro a li occhi tuoi la mente’, Par. XXI, 16); to gaze at the ‘abisso/de l’etterno consiglio’ (‘Ficca mo l’occhio per entro l’abisso/de l’etterno consiglio, quanto puoi/al mio parlar distrettamente fisso’, Par. VII, 94–96); and the souls making up the image of the eagle in the Heaven of Justice (‘“La parte in me che vede e pate il sole/ne l’aguglie mortali”, incominciommi,/“or fisamente riguardar si vole”’, Par. XX, 31–33). 
The locative function of fixing the gaze also gives way to a transcendental, heavenward pull in the final cantica: from the solar gazing of Paradiso I (‘Fissi li occhi al sole oltre nostr’ uso,’ Par. I, 54); reprised by Beatrice in Paradiso XXIII (‘Fiso guardando pur che l’alba nasca’, 9); to the pilgrim’s gazing at the sight of God (‘fiso nel punto che m’avëa vinto’, Par. XXIX, 9), into the Empyrean, when the pilgrim’s intellect and gaze fuse in one act of ‘marvelling’ (‘Così la mente mia, tutta sospesa,/mirava fissa, immobile e attenta’, Par. XXXIII, 97–98).18 The relational capacity of the gaze is similarly transposed in a paradisiacal key through the climactic series of fixed gazes that Dante shares with his heavenly intermediaries as he raises his gaze to God in the final canti of Paradiso: from the fixity that causes Saint Bernard to turn his gaze with Dante, to Mary (‘li occhi miei/nel caldo suo caler fissi e attenti,/li suoi con tanto affetto volse a lei’, Par. XXXI, 139–41), to the Virgin’s answering stare (‘li occhi da Dio diletti e venerati,/fissi ne l’orator’, Par. XXXIII, 40–41), and the intensity of the pilgrim’s own vision of God (‘io presunsi/ficcar lo viso per la luce etterna’; ‘Così la mente mia, tutta sospesa,/mirava fissa, immobile e attenta’, Par. XXXIII, 82–83; 97–98).19 The progression of Dante’s fixed gaze to these paradisiacal heights is predicated by a series of purgatorial encounters in which the pilgrim’s vision, and the reader’s critical awareness, are trained and strengthened through innovative explorations of the ethical implications of fixing the gaze. To better understand the nuances informing these depictions of fixity and their role in mediating between physical (embodied) processes of sight and less tangible intellectual acts, it is useful to review the major discourses on sight informing the cultures of vision constellating the writing and reading of Dante’s poem, from secular love poetry to devotional manuals on Christian contemplation, many of which are alluded to in his text.
‘Io la mirava’
In widely read treatises on love and lovesickness, as well as contemporary moralising texts and vernacular poetry, the physical process of fixing the gaze was often depicted as an erotic pathology.  Uniting scientific terminology with poetic tropes, fixing the gaze was used as a capacious metaphor in the battle of innamoramento, capable of conveying both the penetrative force of love’s arrows and the obsessive fixation of the lover on the object of their attention.  This conflation of mental obsession and the fixed gaze is particularly frequent in the Tuscan literary environment in which Dante wrote his youthful poems in the 1280s and 1290s, where the rhyme between ‘viso’ (face or gaze) and ‘fiso’ (fixed) is common.22
Exemplary of this usage is Dante’s portrayal in the rima ‘I’ mi son pargoletta bella e nova’, where the poet pathologizes his fixed gazing at the donna’s eloquent viso as a potential route to death: ‘e io per veder lei mirai fiso/ne son a rischio di perder la vita’ (LXXXVII, 20–21).  Withheld until the final stanza, this moment of fixed gazing presents a reversal in which the positive tone of the opening sections, conveyed by the angelic attributes of the donna (‘dal cielo’, 4; ‘un’angioletta’, 19), gives way to a pessimistic depiction of the psycho-pathological violence of love (‘ch’io vo piangendo e non m’acchetai pui’, 24) the moment at which the external sight of the woman is internalised and can begin to torment the memory.24
The role of fixation in the visual/cognitive process underlying such erotic scenes is laid out particularly clearly in a canzone by another of Dante’s contemporaries, Lapo Gianni. Describing the progression from seeing his donna to being tormented by an obsessive memory of her, Gianni uses a semi-technical language, reminiscent of optical science, to describe a progression from vision to recollection:
E-ss’i’ vedea Madonna ch’ha il bel riso, le sue bellezze fiso – imaginava e poi, for de la vista, tormentava
(‘Amor, nova ed antica vanitate’, 11–13) 
In these lines, Gianni places fixation at the heart of a cognitive process in which sight ('s’io vedea’), catalysed by fixation (‘fiso’), moves to imagination (‘imaginava’) and produces memory.  The negative outcome of this amorous event is underlined in the pessimistic tone of the canzone, crystallised in the assertion that love is responsible for divorcing individuals from knowledge: ‘m’hai diviso/di savere e di bene’ (8–9), a variation on the negative psychopathology of love explored with particular intensity by Dante’s ‘primo amico’, the poet Guido Cavalcanti. 
As critics including Tristan Kay and Olivia Holmes have pointed out, this pathological gaze can be identified in an episode at the heart of Purgatorio, the dream of the Siren in canto XIX, an encounter that presents a mis-en-scene of the discourse on desire (and the gaze) carried out in the surrounding canti. Upon falling asleep, the pilgrim dreams of staring attentively at a ‘femmina balba’, a stuttering hag who transforms into a deceptively ‘dolce serena’ under his marvelling gaze: ‘Io la mirava [. . .] lo sguardo mio le facea scorta/la lingua [. . .] cominciava a cantar sì, che con pena/ da lei avrei mio intento rivolto./“Io son”, cantava, “Io son dolce serena”’ (Purg. XIX, 7–19). The gaze that the pilgrim turns to the Siren can be read as a form of erotic pathology, a mental obsession catalysed by focused sight.  This strong conflation between the eyes of the body and the eyes of the mind is not unique to this canto but arises consistently throughout the discussion of love and free will that takes place in the surrounding canti, where earthbound and heavenward gazing are notably contrasted.29 Culminating this visually focused sequence, the dream of the Siren is permeated by cultures of gazing. In fact, the pathological gaze is only one of at least three modes of gazing that can be identified in the scene.
‘Occhi fitti’
In Purgatorio XIX, the pilgrim is saved from his seductive vision by another fixed gaze as Virgil looks with ‘occhi fitti’ towards a ‘donna Santa’ who intervenes on the pilgrim’s behalf (‘el venìa/con li occhi fitti pur in quella onesta’, Purg. XIX, 29–30). Acting as a corrective to the pilgrim’s pathological fixation, Virgil’s heavenly focus recalls another visual paradigm, this one captured in popular religious exhortations in which the lexicon of visual fixity was mobilised to oppose the temptations of carnal desire. In these moralising texts, emphasis is placed on repressing the gaze to avoid fixing it on unworthy objects of attention. A key example is the anonymous Liber de Modo Bene Vivendi Soror, a treatise instructing nuns on best practice (long attributed to Bernard of Clairvaux on the event of his sister’s joining a convent between 1122 and 1124). In this text the language of love’s arrows is combined with the notion of the gaze to exhort the believer to avoid thinking about carnal topics: ‘Through the eyes the arrows of love enter into the mind: the sight of the eyes sends forth arrows of fornication. Therefore, sister in Christ, repress your eyes, therefore cast down your gaze. Do not fix your eyes on carnal sights’.  The lexicon was also joined to notable misogynist discussions of the repression of the sexual gaze, such as in the manual for preachers, Liber de eruditione praedicatorum, by the Dominican Hubert of Romans, widely circulated post-1263, in which the repression of the sexualised gaze is directly connected to a misogynist presentation of women as physically repulsive. 
The circulation of such approaches in thirteenth-century Italy is suggested by its appearance in the Laudario Urbinate, a successful collection of religious praise poems containing the works of the Franciscan friar Jacopone da Todi, a figure operating in Umbria in the final decades of the duecento.  In the unattributed poem ‘O peccator dolente’, heavily influenced by Jacopone’s style, the reader is encouraged to fix their gaze to avoid negative temptation: ‘Tu déi stare affissato, non déi gir molto atorno,/ché nuoce de uedere le uanità del monno’ (LXXXXVII, 39–40).  The fixation of Virgil on the eyes of the donna santa in Purgatorio XIX can also be understood in light of this tradition, presenting a repression of the erotic gaze fixed by the pilgrim on the Siren, her stuttering, stinking body redolent of the misogynist tradition.
The complexity of Dante’s engagement with diverse cultures of gazing is further amplified when we consider the gazes that conclude this sequence. Upon waking from his nightmare, the pilgrim fixes his gaze upon the ground, a visualisation of the spiritual abasement suffered during his dream, clarified during his exchange with Virgil (‘“Che hai, che pur invèr la terra guati?” [. . .] “novella visïon ch’a sè mi piega”’, Purg. XIX, 52; 56). Encouraging the pilgrim to raise his gaze to the heavens, Virgil calls on an avian metaphor, constructing a positive recontextualization of visual fixity as a route to spiritual elevation:
‘Li occhi rivolgi al logoro che gira lo rege etterno con le rote magne’.
Quale ‘l falcon, che prima a’ piè si mira, indi si volge al grido e si protende per lo disio del pasto che là il tira,
tal mi fec’ io [. . .]
(PurgatorioXIX, 62–67)
Cast as a skyward gazing bird of prey, the pilgrim is thus encouraged to refocus his eyes and continue his spiritual journey through a lexicon of vision; the negative effects of fixing the gaze on earthly (and erotic) concerns are contrasted with the celestial pull of divine contemplation.  This image base interacts with another visual paradigm, one whose main coordinates can be found in widely read texts on Christian devotional meditation, a strand of mystical writing well-known to Dante and a tradition that presents a potential third coordinate in the depiction of the fixed gaze in the Commedia. 
Aspectus animae
Scientific discussions of the gaze in pre-modern Christian contexts were deeply enmeshed with theologies of sight, according to which vision provided a privileged site for epistemological and gnoseological investigation, moving beyond the physical and reaching towards the symbolic as an example (and manifestation) of the spiritual connection between the human and the divine.  In Augustine’s early dialogic treatise, the Soliloquia, written between 386 and 387 CE, the metaphor of sight is used to explain the processes required to successfully contemplate God.  Terming this process the aspectus animae (gaze of the soul), Augustine writes that: ‘God Himself will be shown to your mind even as the sun is shown to the eyes’ if the mind is ‘pure of all corporeal taint and cupidinous desire for earthly things is purged and removed’ (Sol. II. 6. 12).  Fixation and love are key to this process as, ‘unless the gaze be fixed [infixerit] with great love and not turned away from gazing for any reason, [the soul] cannot remain in that most blessed vision’ (Sol., II. 7. 14). 
This visual metaphor and, in particular, the focus it places on fixing the gaze was taken up by later contemplatives and filtered into the writings of figures who were well-known and well-read by Dante.40 In the works of Richard of Saint Victor – a twelfth-century Augustinian prior who Dante introduces in the Heaven of the Sun in direct reference to his pre-eminence in contemplation (‘Riccardo,/che a considerar fu più che viro’, Par. X, 131–32) – fixation is frequently used to define best contemplative practice and the joys of contemplative thought.  In his manual on contemplation, known as the Benjamin Major, Richard emphasises the connection between contemplation and vision, likening the ‘soul of the contemplative’ to the ‘eye of the mind’.  As well as using fixation to describe contemplative focus, Richard construes fixation as a necessary frame of mind for achieving a vision of the divine, an intellectual experience that he describes through the analogy of an eagle’s flight: ‘having fixed its gaze [fixis obtutibus] on the light of eternity which shines from above, [the mind] can fly through all the clouds of earthly changeableness and transcend them with the force of a soaring eagle’ (4. X). 
Similar discussion of the fixed contemplative gaze appears in the works of the Italian theologian Bonaventure who, like Richard, draws on the figure of the eagle to represent the ideal gaze.  In the lectures he delivered in Paris in the 1270s, collected under the title Hexameron, Bonaventure presents the eagle’s focused gaze as a positive model for the contemplative mindset: ‘it is fitting that the contemplative be fixed [sit fixus] and that he remain, not vacillating nor with a bat’s eyes, but with the eyes of an eagle, fixed [fixus] on the ladder of heavenly hierarchy’.  The productivity of the eagle as an image for contemplative thought (‘aquila, propter contemplationem’, Hex. I. I. 35) is repeated at several points across the collections in the Hexameron, in which the bird’s ability to gaze at the sun is even construed as an image for spiritual (anagogical) interpretation (‘per faciem aquilae, anagogiam [. . .] facies aquilae irreverberatis oculis solem intuetur’ – ‘the eagle represents anagocial meaning [. . .] it looks upon the sun almost without flinching’, Hex. I. III. 11).  By presenting visual fixation as a metaphor for positive devotional practice, these references to the fixed gaze in the contemplative tradition open out into a veritable interpretative paradigm, encouraging consideration of visual fixity as both a model for intellectual focus and as a symbol of spiritual consistency, the very mindset necessary for achieving an encounter with the divine. The presence of this avian imagery in the celestial gaze that Virgil encourages the pilgrim to turn to God as the final corrective to his encounter with the Siren places this tradition within the nexus of gazes represented at the centre of pilgrim (and reader’s) journey through Purgatorio XIX.
The notion that the reader is encouraged to recognise these diverse cultures of gazing and consider their interaction as a core element in this purgatorial scene is, I think, supported by the entanglement of the lexicon with a strong strand of metapoetic imagery also present in this episode. The dream of the Siren in Purgatorio XIX replays elements from the encounter with another mortiferous mythological figure, the Medusa in Inferno IX. During this episode, the diegetic danger of looking at the Medusa results in a separation of the pilgrim – whose eyes are averted by Virgil (‘“Volgiti ‘n dietro e tien lo viso chiuso”’, Inf. IX, 55) – and the reader – who is directly addressed by the poet and exhorted to “look” closely at the symbolic meaning of the lines: ‘O voi ch’avete li ‘ntelletti sani,/mirate la dottrina che s’asconde/sotto 'l velame de li versi strani' (Inf. IX, 61–63).  This metapoetic language is reprised in Purgatorio VIII, when the reader’s intellectual gaze is directly invoked during the theatrical enactment of the Fall through a recognisable reference to the metapoetic lexicon of the “veil” of the text: ‘Aguzza qui, lettor, ben li occhi al vero,/ché ‘l velo è ora ben tanto sottile,/certo che 'l trapassar dentro è leggero” (Purg. VIII, 19–21).  As Suzanne Akbari has argued, comparison between these two invocations reveals an intensification in the reader’s invitation to participate in a critical reading of the text, raised from the capacity to “mirare” into a potential entering into the discourse (“trapassar dentro”). 
Although Purgatorio XIX contains no direct address to the reader, repetition of the language of textual ‘covering’ signals the presence of the same metapoetic potential as Dante is freed from his enticing nightmare by the slicing open of the Siren’s clothing: ‘dinanzi l’aprìa/fenendo i drappi, e mostravami ‘l ventre;/quell mi svegliò col puzzo che ne uscìa’ (Purg. XIX, 31–33). As Elena Lombardi and David Bowe in particular have highlighted, this is a clear reference to textual exegesis.  During the encounter with the Siren, the ‘stripping’ of the text is embedded at the level of the diegesis, turning the pilgrim’s realisation into an invocation to the reader’s interpretative gaze which is activated here without an invocation from the poet. The heightened critical awareness requested by this more subtle metapoetic opening encourages scrutiny of the interpretative breadth of the visual paradigms employed in this scene and elsewhere in the text, especially where the pilgrim’s (fixed) gazing is foregrounded by the narrative action, most notably perhaps when Dante first locks eyes with Beatrice, a figure whose metatextual potential is manifested in her ‘aggregate nature’ (the donna of Dante’s youthful, secular writings; the devotional guide of his mature, spiritualised text; and a real, historical woman, whose veracity is left to the reader to decipher).  In meeting Dante’s fixed gaze head on, in all her syncretism, Beatrice provides a collision site for a kaleidoscopic combination of cultures of gazing, encouraging a slippage between the eyes of the body and the eyes of the mind that explodes the differences between devotional and erotic fixity, opening the trope out to even wider interpretative paradigms, including the philosophical and theological inquiries that will become central to negotiating the representational challenges of Paradiso.
‘Troppo fiso’
The moment at which Dante fixes his gaze on Beatrice’s in Purgatorio XXXII is anticipated by a series of references to the language and tropes of vision.52 This careful interweaving replays the polarity of temptation and salvation seen in the encounter with the Siren.  In the sequence leading up to this encounter, Dante’s desire for the sight of Beatrice’s eyes is expressed through direct allusion to the erotic ‘piercing’ of the lover by the beloved’s weaponised gaze, a lexicon that is married to a depiction of Beatrice’s eyes as a positive locus for spiritual guidance.  This variation in the connotations of Dante’s gaze climaxes in the highly theatrical interruption of the pilgrim’s sight at the start of Purgatorio XXXII:
Tant’ eran li occhi miei fissi e attenti a disbramarsi la decenne sete, che li altri sensi m’eran tutti spenti.
Ed essi quinci e quindi avien parete di non caler – così lo santo riso a sé traéli con l’antica rete! –;
quando per forza mi fu vòlto il viso
ver’ la sinistra mia da quelle dee, perch’ io udi’ da loro un ‘Troppo fiso!’ e la disposizion ch’a veder èe
ne li occhi pur testé dal sol percossi, sanza la vista alquanto esser mi fée. (Purg. XXXII, 1–12)
The dramatic interruption of the pilgrim’s longed for visual encounter with Beatrice follows the shockwaves produced by her authoritative address in Purgatorio XXX, a ‘volcanic eruption of an unexpected female voice’, as Heather Webb has described it, which requires Dante’s ‘very gaze [to] be reconstructed from the rubble of the old model’.  The reason behind Dante’s visual failure in this scene, the collapse of ‘the old model’ that may have governed the connotations of sight before this climactic encounter with his beloved turned spiritual guide, has divided critical opinion.56 Medieval commentators who read Beatrice as an allegory of theology or scripture tend to identify Dante’s visual failure as a metaphor for intellectual or spiritual inadequacy.  Many modern commentators, meanwhile, take the notion of excess implied in the Grace’s rebuke as an indication of the erotic misdirection of Dante’s (‘too fixed’) desire, a replaying, that is, of the pathologized fixation of the lyric lover.58
As Elena Lombardi in particular has highlighted, Beatrice’s figuration in this scene is deeply hybrid: her eyes and smile might be an ‘antica rete’ (Purg. XXXII, 6) but they are also a productive, holy point of focus (‘lo santo riso’, Purg. XXXII, 5).59 This co-presence brings the erotic and the spiritual into touch, inviting us to hold both interpretations together, much as they are held together on the page: in the same subclause on subsequent, touching, lines. Indeed, although the admonishing tone of the Graces’s warning reflects the didactic redirection of pilgrim’s attention in earlier scenes,  the main coordinates of this encounter more closely reflect the experiences of blinding that accompany the pilgrim throughout Paradiso, where Dante’s gaze is repeatedly overwhelmed and strengthened by the brilliance of the heavens.  Rather than viewing one of these foci as overwhelming the other, their co-presence might rather refocus our attention on the productivity of interruption as a method for exposing and exploding the differences between multiple traditions and syncretising them into a single dramatic encounter, a technique that constructs a certain level of ambiguity at the level of the plot, inviting the reader to fulfil the incomplete visual act in her imagination.
The notion that interrupting the fixed gaze might serve as a syncretic technique aimed at engaging the reader in the construction (and interpretation) of the text is supported by consideration of Dante’s employment of the same trope in several of his early rime, particularly the poems ‘Donne ch’avete’, ‘Oltre la spera’, and ‘Amor che ne la mente’, all of which display noted lexical and thematic similarities to the depiction of the gaze in Purgatorio XXXII.  Together with their respective glosses in the Vita Nova and Convivio, these texts propose a suggestive background for the nuances subtending the interruption of fixed gazing in the Earthly Paradise. 
Interrupting the Fixed Gaze
In ‘Donne che avete’, a canzone that Dante places at the centre of his first holistic text, the Vita Nova, and the heart of his lyric career (when he uses it to characterise his youthful writing in Purgatorio XXIV, 49–51), the possibility of gazing fixedly on the beloved donna is explicitly denied as part of a laudation of her spiritual excellence: ‘non pote alcun mirarla fiso’ (56).  This interruption is the final element in a series of descriptions that shift the emphasis in the donna’s portrayal from an eroticised to a spiritualised register: a ‘miracle’ (‘maraviglia’, 17), the donna’s eyes are weaponised with wounding arrow-like spirits (‘de li occhi suoi [. . .] escono spirti d’amore inflammati,/che feron li occhi a qual che allor la guati’, 51–53) but they only threaten those who are unable to ennoble themselves as a result of the encounter (‘qual soffrisse di starla a vedere/diverria nobil cosa, o si morria’, 33–35), turning the violent tropes of optical innamoramento into a form of Christian salvation.  The negation of the fixed gaze in this context presents a restructuring of the connotations of visual fixity in the lyric tradition.  As the donna cannot be the object of fixation, Dante’s description denies the possible development of the pathologized gaze, simultaneously reinforcing his description of the donna’s transcendental effect with an echo, ex negativo, of the secular (erotic) trope. 
The sonnet that concludes the Vita Nova, ‘Oltre la spera’, is equally interested in modulating the erotic gaze, using the interplay between physical sight and spiritual insight to construct a vision of Beatrice in heaven that overwhelms the poetic-self, disjointed into a pneumatic spirit/sigh: ‘l sospiro ch’esce del mio core [. . .] vede una donna, che riceve onore,/e luce sì, che per lo suo splendore/lo peregrino spirito la mira./Vedela tal, che quando ‘l mi ridice,/io no lo intendo, sì parla sottile’ (2; 6– 14).  Glossing the visual element of this intellectual failure in his divisione of this sonnet in the penultimate chapter of the Vita Nova, Dante relates the image to an Aristotelean sententium in which the metaphor of failed sight represents the limits of human understanding: ‘la vede tale, cioè in tale qualitade, che io non lo posso intendere, cioè a dire che lo mio pensiero sale ne la qualitade di costei in grado che lo mio intelletto s’abbia a quelle benedette anime sì come l’occhio debole a lo sole: e ciò dice lo Filosofo nel secondo de la Metafisica’ (VN LCI. 6). Several scholars have argued that the Aristotelean passage in question is Metaphysics II. 1, 993b7-11, which compares the human intellect to the eyes of a bat during the day.69 This citation was used by Aquinas and other scholastic theologians to discuss the limitations of contemplating complex theological arguments, including the ontology of the trinity, and it was widely present in thirteenth-century Florentine contexts, as Lorenzo dell’Orso’s recent examination of surviving manuscript evidence has shown.  In the Vita Nova, the inability to gaze fixedly at the beloved is thus associated – through the metaphor of failed sight – with the very limits of human epistemology in light of the divine.
The relevance of this literary transformation to the specific trope of fixing (and interrupting) the gaze is, I think, cemented by its presence in the canzone ‘Amor che ne la mente’ and Dante’s later commentary on that poem in the Convivio.71 In ‘Amor che ne la mente’, the beauty of the donna is spiritualised in terms similar to those expressed in ‘Donne che avete’: through a focus on her eyes and smile, which are said to ‘mostran de’ piacer del Paradiso’ (56).  The failure of the poet’s vision in this canzone is again cast as a form of transcendence, a point underlined in the fourth stanza through a combination of intellectual and physical gazing, in which expansion of the erotic gaze is aided by the association of the beloved with the theological resonances of the sun:73
Elle soverchian lo nostro intelletto come raggio di sole un frale viso;
e perch’io non le posso mirar fiso, mi convien contentar di dirne poco. (‘Amor che ne la mente’, 59–62)
Since it is the poet’s intellect that cannot ‘mirar fiso’, the erotic connotations of the gaze, signalled by the rhyme ‘viso/fiso’, are directly associated with intellectual vision in this canzone.  Visual disruption is thus construed as an intellectual block not just to the poet’s gaze, but to the gaze of the text, as communicated (and threatened) via the poet’s speech (‘mi convien contentar di dirne poco’, 62).75 Glossing the visual and cognitive failure that results from this encounter in the lengthy philosophical commentary constructed around the canzone in his Convivio, Dante once more links the depiction of the failure of vision to the theme of the limits of human intellect, drawing on the Aristotelean metaphor of overwhelming light and embedding it within a clearly theological context:
elle soverchian lo nostro intelletto, escuso me di ciò, che poco parlar posso di quelle per la loro soperchianza. Dove è da sapere che in alcun modo queste cose nostro intelletto abbagliano, in quanto certe cose [si] affermano essere, che lo ‘ntelletto nostro guardare non può, cioè Dio e la etternitate e la prima materia che certissimamente si veggiono e con tutta fede si credono essere, e pur quello che sono intender noi non potemo, se non cose negando si può apressare alla sua conoscenza, e non altrimenti. (Cvo III. Xv. 6). 
Here Dante explicitly connects the ‘blinding’ of the poet’s intellect to a kind of negative theology, a form of apophatic expression present in scholastic debate in which complex religious topics were affirmed through negation.  In so doing, Dante theologises the spiritualisation of the donna described in the canzone, transforming the failure of the poet’s amorous gaze into a statement of faith in the transcendental reality of God.78 If we remove the canzone from the theologising context of this later gloss, the emphasis in the poem on intellectual transcendence (presented through the metaphors and tropes of vision) still constitutes a notable engagement with this theoretical development, intellectualising the amorous gaze and innovating the trope of erotic vision by interrupting visual fixity to present an apophatic statement on the ineffability of intense spiritual experience, a theoretical development mediated through the figure of the beloved.79
The concatenation of fixed gazes that climax into the visio Dei at the end of Paradiso share key coordinates with these earlier poetic configurations. Consistently focused on the overwhelming sight of a beloved viso/riso, the gazes depicted in Paradiso can be seen to harness the dramatic power of interruption to negotiate the representational challenges of transcendental topics, encouraging the reader to imagine impossible descriptions by disrupting the gaze of the text and so creating space for her to come to her own conclusions about the emphases and images present in the poem.  If, as Zygmunt Barański has recently argued, ‘when reduced to human capabilities, the problem of talking about God becomes one of representation and culture’, the interrupted fixed gaze offers a veritable kaleidoscope of cultural references, which the reader is invited to turn over in her mind’s eye, recognising and recombining diverse theological, philosophical and poetic connotations into a single loving gaze, generous enough to encompass the overwhelming sight(s) of Paradise.81
Fixing the Gaze on God
The act that catalyses the narration of Paradiso is an act of concentrated sight: ‘Quando Beatrice in sul sinistro fianco/vidi rivolta e riguardar nel sole:/aguglia sì non li s’affisse unquanco’ (Par. I. 46–48). This avian reference emphasises both the intensity and productivity of Beatrice’s heavenward gaze, recalling the aquiline vision of the contemplative tradition, now offered as a model for the pilgrim, who copies his guide, sustaining the blinding light of the (theologised) sun for a remarkably long time (‘fissi li occhi al sole oltre nostr’ uso,’ Par. I, 54) before turning his eyes back to his beloved.  Beatrice’s eyes are the site for his heavenly transformation: ‘Beatrice tutta ne l’etterne rote/fissa con li occhi stava; e io in lei/le luci fissi, di là sù remote’ (Par. I. 64–68).83 By concentrating the pilgrim’s first transformational paradisiacal gaze on (and through) Beatrice, Dante orients his depiction of heavenly concentration via the coordinates of erotic vision, enhancing the interpersonal nature of the divine encounter by lacing the devotional gaze with a lyric trace. 
This syncretism remains operative in the later gazes that Dante fixes on Beatrice in Paradise. In canto X, the doubleness of the vision required to focus on the beloved and focus on God is emphasised and elided through a notable interruption of the pilgrim’s gaze.85 Having encouraged Dante to devote his attention to praising God (‘ringrazia il Sol de li angeli’, Par. X. 53), the sun to which both Dante (poet/pilgrim) and reader raise their (minds’) eyes at the start of the canto (‘Leva dunque, lettore, a l’alte rote/meco la vista’, Par. X. 7–8), Beatrice smiles, disrupting the pilgrim’s unified concentration and simultaneously permitting him to perceive in more detail the heaven around him: ‘ma sì se ne rise,/che lo splendor de li occhi suoi ridenti/mia mente unita in più cose divise’ (Par. X, 61–63). The light of Beatrice’s smile, momentarily forgotten in Dante’s initial contemplative zeal (‘Cor di mortal non fu mai sì digesto/a divozione e a rendersi a Dio/[. . .] sì tutto ‘l mio amore in lui si mise,/che Bëatrice eclissò ne l’oblio’, 55–57; 59–60) is the disruption that allows pilgrim (and reader) to continue the heavenly journey.  Interrupting the fixed gaze, as suggested in Dante’s innovative inversions of visual tropes in his rime, thus allows for an intensification in the depiction of transcendental experience, a pattern that continues throughout the cantica.
In Paradiso XXI, the pilgrim’s concentrated sight is once more interrupted as he gazes at Beatrice with a fixity that recalls the ‘too fixed’ gaze of Purgatorio XXXII: ‘Già eran li occhi miei rifissi al volto/ de la mia donna, e l’animo con essi/e da ogne altro intento s’era tolto’ (Par. XXI, 1–2).87 Withholding her smile, and so breaking the pattern established in the Earthly Paradise, Beatrice highlights the potentially erotic tenor of the pilgrim’s desire, not only by disrupting his (amorous) gaze but also through her striking reference to the classical myth of Semele, a kaleidoscopic combination of pagan cupiditas and Christian allegory that encourages a multi-stable reading of his denied visual fixity as simultaneously indicative of unfulfilled contemplative ecstasy and of averted incendiary eroticism (‘S’io ridessi [. . .] tu ti faresti quale/fu Semelè quando di cener fessi’, 4–6).88 The revelation of Beatrice’s ‘santo riso’ two canti later intensifies the syncretising effect of the pilgrim’s visual failure, reuniting pilgrim’s gaze and poet’s vision at the level of the metatext. The encounter is predicated by another reprisal of fixed gazing, channelled through a decisively lyrical lexicon, as the avian simile that characterises Beatrice at the start of Paradiso XXIII is a recollection of her fixed gazing at the sun in Paradiso I, the elevated spiritual connotations of the eagle replaced by an evocative vernacular augello (‘come l’augello intra l’amate fronde [. . .] fiso guardando pur che l’alba nasca’, 1; 9).  Despite directly encouraging the pilgrim to face her smile in this canto, Beatrice’s riso remains the contact point for the failure of pilgrim’s sight and poet’s vision as Dante, declaring himself unable to describe the longed-for smile, combines the language of the impossible gaze (‘come quei che si risente/di visïone oblita’, Par. XXIII, 49–50) with a statement on poetic incapacity (‘convien saltar lo sacrato poema’, Par. XXIII, 62).  By creating a vanishing point around Beatrice’s santo riso, Dante unites the failure of the pilgrim’s vision with the incapacity of the poet’s words, inviting the reader to fulfil the gaze of the text through her combined imagination of a beloved smile and the indescribable pleasures of Paradise, taking on the very act of ‘figurando il paradiso’ (Par. XXIII, 61). 
The affective power of the earthly beloved, far from being rejected, is here deliberately evoked through the lexical field of amorous gazing, a configuration of visual failure and spiritual ineffability that is repeated and intensified in Paradiso XXX, when, having obeyed Beatrice’s command to ‘turn his eyes back to the straight path’ (‘ritorci/li occhi oramai verso la dritta strada’, Par. XXIX, 127–28), Dante occupies the role of ardent gazer and looks into the centre of the heavenly host.  Distilled to a single point (‘punto che mi vinse’, Par. XXX, 11) the pilgrim’s vision falters (‘a poco a poco al mio veder si stinse’, 13) and he turns his eyes and verses back to Beatrice (‘per che tornar con li occhi a Bëatrice/nulla vedere e amor mi costrinse’, Par. XXX, 14–15).  Blinded by God, the gaze of Dante’s text is unable to express the sight of his beloved, whose ‘trans-moded’ beauty – transformed into a different visual mode (‘La bellezza ch’io vidi si trasmoda’, Par. XXX, 19) – prompts a repetition of the metapoetic crisis that resulted from the failed gaze in Paradiso XXIII. It is now extended over Dante’s entire poetic oeuvre, idealised as a single loda, which the poet must at last leave off, overcome by his theme, a nexus of spiritual and poetic experience that is refined into a single, impossible visual encounter with a beloved riso: ‘ché, come sole in viso che più trema,/così lo rimembrar del dolce riso/la mente mia da me medesmo scema’ (Par. XXX, 25–27). 
Fusing the trope of interrupted visual focus with the topos of divine ineffability, Dante invites the reader to take on the role of the poet-lover (in the guise of Christian contemplative) whose amorous gaze must fulfil the interrupted gaze of the text, combing an ineffable, beloved smile – the point of overwhelming, transcendental focus in the lyric tradition – with the apophatic blind spot of God himself, their boundaries blurred in the blinding light of the sun. The trope of the (interrupted) fixed gaze emerges as a powerful textual strategy in this innovative attempt to overcome the representational challenges posed by the Christian notion of spiritual transcendence, employing a syncretic combination of multiple allusions to activate the reader’s imaginative engagement with the construction of the text at the very point in which the topic under discussion must necessarily elude human understanding. The resonances of this multi-layered gaze can be felt in the final acts of fixation that climax into Dante’s vision of the divine, an encounter that ends in another form of visual interruption as, fixed on the impossible task of defining the trinitarian nature of God (‘Qual è ‘l geomètra che tutto s’affige/per misurar lo cerchio, e non ritrova’, Par. XXXIII, 133–34), the pilgrim’s focus is interrupted by a lightening flash (‘la mia mente fu percossa/da un fulgore in che sua voglia venne’, 140–41) that turns the theophanic event into another blind spot, a final vanishing point that invites the reader to square the difference between devotional fixity and disruptive epiphany to arrive at her own understanding of Dante’s encounter with the divine. 
Not simply a devotional contemplative act nor solely an erotic pathology, the fixed gaze (and its ever-present potential for interruption) presents a multi-layered trope that is uniquely suited to negotiating the representational challenges of apophatic expression, encouraging the reader to recombine elements drawn from a spectrum of traditions encompassing religious contemplation, amorous gazing, and philosophical speculation, to imagine transcendent experience in imminent terms, an approach that is both practical (in its representational aims) and radical (in its subtle recuperation of earthly elements at the heart of the divine). The metapoetic opening provided by this trope is thematised as a veritable poetic theology in Paradiso, where episodes of interrupted visual fixity take on the role of apophatic statements, constructed on the basis of multiple traditions (including devotional literature and affective lyric poetry) to confront the ineffability of transcendental experience and offer it back to the reader as a poetic performance in whose very figural construction she plays a role. Through a progressive conflation of embodied and intellectual sight, Dante weaves a representation of the unrepresentable, built on statements of visual and verbal failure that, by interrupting the gaze of the text, hand over the role of image construction to the reader who, at the failure of the pilgrim’s gaze and the poet’s words, can continue to ‘mirar fiso’, fulfilling Dante’s vision in the mind’s eye of her imagination.

***

When the Serenissima is No Longer Serene:
Staging Chaos in La Veniexiana

La Veniexiana, an anonymous comedy whose title can be translated either as ‘a play about Venice’ or ‘a play about a Venetian woman’, is one of the most original texts of the Italian Renaissance. The play offers a detailed representation of early Cinquecento Venice, both geographically – with its canals and calli – and historically – with its references to the socio-political background. Realistic details about languages, fashion, house décor, and cultural customs are richly provided throughout the five acts. But the main reason why La Veniexiana gained critical attention is that it unapologetically stages sexual affairs, to the point that it is even considered one of the earliest examples of erotic theatre. Most remarkably, it is women who actively lead the love game: a newly married lady and a widowed woman take the initiative and compete for a young foreigner’s attention.
Evidently, the text represents a rare recognition of female carnal desire and the conquest of male prey. Given its explicit erotic tones and gendered dynamics, modern scholars read the play as representing an exceptional reversal of the patriarchal order and social norms.  However, in this article, I take issue with the straightforward proto-feminist interpretation. I posit that, rather than a systematic subversion of gendered norms, the comedy depicts a state of temporary chaos, which is especially evident in the sexual encounters. Sexual power dynamics are continuously shifting, portraying, at times, dominant women in control of the situation but then immediately subjugated to male authority – with a clear return to order in the end.Moreover, unlike plays such as Niccolò Machiavelli’s Mandragola, La Veniexiana is not presented in leading interpretations as a socio-politically engaged drama.  Scholars agree that the unknown playwright devoted their attention exclusively to the realistic exploration of love and sex. This reading should not be absolute: it is precisely the focus on interpersonal chaos – that is to say, confusing sexual roles and disorienting power struggles – that makes La Veniexiana a complex allegory for the turbulent socio-political reality. My claim is that the contemporary crisis of the Venetian Republic in the first decades of the sixteenth century is crucial to La Veniexiana’s investigation of the relations between gender, sexuality, and geopolitical power.
The play presents a distinctive portrayal of Renaissance Venice, with its unstable morphology, social features, and political framework. Firstly, Venice is not a neutral background. Its labyrinthine streets hiding secret encounters, bridges and gondole enabling swift transfers, and periodic tides constantly transforming the cityscape not only parallel the characters’ fluctuating emotions, but also actively shape the narrative. Secondly, the play’s engagement with contemporary Venice emerges emphatically from the unsteady social dynamics and linguistic melting pot portrayed: the play’s characters speak Venetian, Bergamask, and Florentine.  Lastly, the fact that Giulio, the male prey, is a foreigner from Milan is central to the comedy’s meaning. The play’s erotic chaos evokes, mirrors, and dramatises Venice’s contemporary chaotic socio-political situation. Composed in the complicated years after the War of the League of Cambrai, this rich text reflects endlessly shifting political alliances by depicting endlessly shifting passionate power struggles.
This contribution will demonstrate that La Veniexiana resists a rigid, exclusive interpretation. I maintain that the fluctuating sexual dynamics of the play directly expose Venice’s chaos in terms of social concerns, anxiety about geopolitical power, and fears regarding foreigners. Can Venice resist the territorial and cultural invasions from the rest of Italy and retain control of the Mediterranean? Will the Republic preserve its unique status and supremacy over its land, culture, and language? Will Venetians eventually end up being overpowering conquerors or complaisant conquered? And, ultimately, could the self-proclaimed Serenissima Republic really be serene in the first half of the Cinquecento? These and other major issues brought up by La Veniexiana deserve further investigation.
The first section addresses the leading scholarship regarding the play in order to challenge the idea that La Veniexiana is merely a drama which revolves around sex. Even though this reading is sustainable, it is incomplete. Absolutizing the focus on sex is potentially misleading and could lead to a reduction of the comedy’s scope. Having set the stage for the demonstration of my argument, the article then turns to reading La Veniexiana in relation to the main contemporary socio-political issues in Venice at the time in order to show that the play is deeply engaged with its context and prompts audiences to wonder about the future of the Venetian state. Finally, I reflect on the relevance of a revised reading faithful to the complexity of a thus-far largely underestimated Renaissance play.
Just an Erotic, Proto-Feminist Play?
It is only by chance that one can read La Veniexiana today: a comedy composed to be performed, probably just once, in the context of exclusive parties held in noble palaces.  Ever since Emilio Lovarini discovered it in 1928 among the manuscripts of the Biblioteca Marciana in Venice, an aura of mystery has surrounded the comedy.  Indeed, both its playwright and exact dating remain unclear. Ludovico Zorzi proposed that the author, or authors, are to be found among the members of the Compagnia della Calza, a club of young aristocrats in charge of the city’s entertainments in the first half of the Cinquecento.  Concerning the date of composition, Giorgio Padoan has convincingly demonstrated through his deep analysis of political references, numismatics, and fashion, that the play was written between 1535 and 1536, during the troubled years after the war with the League of Cambrai. 
La Veniexiana begins in medias res. Giulio, a young foreigner, has just arrived in Venice with little money, looking for a wife – provided she has a dowry. He has already ardently admired Valeria (a young woman of good family) from a distance, and is determined to take her back to Milan. He asks Oria, her maid, to intercede; even though he soon understands that Valeria is already married, he continues courting her, encouraged by the woman’s reciprocated attentions. In the meantime, we learn that Angela, a widowed noble lady, is burning with an intense sexual attraction to Giulio. She aims to get him into her house, and to do so, she asks her maid, Nena, and the porter Bernardo for help. Giulio, in the erotic crossfire, decides to accept Angela’s mysterious invitation, and spends a passionate night with her. The night after, he intends to meet Valeria but, jealous and proud, she rejects him. However, the following day, Valeria abruptly changes her mind and decides to forgive Giulio, so that she too can enjoy a sexual encounter with him.
As one of the title’s connotations implies, La Veniexiana is very much about women. In the play, four out of the six characters are female: two wealthy bourgeois – Valeria and Angela – and two servants – Oria and Nena.  The maids are strongly characterised: Oria is timid and fears authority; on the contrary, Nena is a great ally to Angela, even willing to substitute Giulio in an intimate encounter with her mistress. Angela displays a remarkable sensual inclination; Valeria seems haughtier at first but in the end, she cannot resist temptation. Contrary to other more celebrated Renaissance comedies, where, despite their titles referring to female characters, women have a marginalised visual and audible stage presence, La Veniexiana gives a significant voice to women.  Women play an active role in the love conquest: as two ladies are contending for one man, the traditional scheme is overturned. Perfectly at ease with strategies and intrigues, they are the real leaders, even though they always remain indoors. 
On the other side, there are two very different men. Bernardo is an impertinent handyman from Bergamo who acts like an anti-Charon, driving his gondola towards what he calls a paradisiac destination – namely, Angela’s palace.  Giulio is the prey. He is young, beardless, with black braids, and tends to wear elegant, luxurious clothes. His usual accessories are a sword and a plumed bonnet: overall, he has the look of a dandy, suitable for someone who likes to show off. Indeed, his sleeping quarters are called the Pavon Inn – a gentle reminder of his pretensions and demeanour. Despite his attempts to exhibit his masculinity, Giulio is always defined in feminine terms. He speaks well, with a delicate voice and gentle manners, so that Bernardo believes that he displays an ‘ari da fomnella’ (II. iv. 76).  With his rosy cheeks, he really looks like an angel (II. v. 138). Even though he aspires to be a ‘Casanova in erba’, it is clear that, at least at first, Giulio is instead a hesitant puppet at the mercy of strong-willed damsels, ready to take advantage of his apparent shyness.  Therefore, by portraying two eager women who compete for one weak, inconsistent man, the traditional social roles are indeed turned upside down.
Yet, the Prologus already shows symptoms of the comedy’s profound ambiguity, as it expresses misogynistic observations. With an anti-Stilnovistic rhetoric, it begins by talking about the damage caused by love.14 The overpowering passion ‘maggior effeto però produce nel femineo sexo, quanto lo senso grande suppèdita la parvità del suo intellecto’ (Prologus, 3).  After this sexist premise, the Prologue continues by anticipating that the spectators will see for themselves ‘quanto Amor in donna sii potente, e qualmente siàn vinti da soa forza’ (Prologus, 4–5), where the possessive here can ambiguously refer to love’s power or to the woman’s power.16 Towards the conclusion, the text reaches its didactical apex by warning the audience to love with their intellect and not with their senses, as this will only lead to sorrow.
The final words are quite obscure: ‘E non ve imaginate altrimenti donne, se non quanto lo vederete, vestite: che poi, spoliate, siano non amate, ma amanti insieme cun voi’ (Prologus, 7).  This closing remark seems to acknowledge the fact that women are also active subjects in love, and not merely passive objects as social and literary conventions portray them. This is precisely what happens in the play; if there is one sexually objectified person, it is Giulio. The objectification becomes quite literal when Angela wishes that he were ‘un bùsolo da zibeto, ché ti portaria cusì sempre in sen, sempre sempre’ (III. ii. 112).  Yet, some critics read the Prologue’s last sentence in a different way. Lovarini, for instance, interprets it in light of the common theatrical practice of having male actors play female characters: male spectators should not get too excited, as the women, under their stage clothes, are ‘amanti’ too – that is to say, male lovers.19
Therefore, the play does not allow for any straightforward proto-feminist reading. Although interesting, Laura Giannetti’s recent take that the ‘patriarchy seems to be asleep with Valeria’s old husband safely locked away’ seems to not be fully supported by the play’s text.20 Rather than a clear and consistent reversal of the patriarchal order, La Veniexiana presents the idea of a shifting, mutable, and ever-changing order, which emerges particularly in sexual encounters. When the timorous yet excited Giulio-the-prey is brought to Angela-the-predator’s house, the woman clearly holds the power. Showing up with a shroud protecting her identity, she is the one who makes the first move. However, as soon as she begins to undress him, Giulio abruptly repulses her attempt, saying that he could not permit that: ‘Vostra Signoria se svesta, che io la adiuterò lei’ (III. ii. 61).21 At this point, Angela fears that she has been indiscreet and draws back respectfully. Worried about his virile authority, Giulio feels the need to reinstate the traditional status quo, regaining his power over her. Then, after their intercourse and a passionate dialogue, Angela tells him: ‘Dormi, sera li ochii; ché volio far a mio modo [. . .] Tasi e dormi, ché voio far a mio modo’ (III. ii. 120; 124).22 The woman, now much more self-confident, recovers control of the situation.
The end of the play is similarly characterised by a series of reversals. While Giannetti argues in her reading that the ‘refusal to submit to the ideal roles of chaste widow and virtuous, loyal wife, is not softened by any return to order at the comedy’s conclusion’, it seems to me that the text ends on a more ambiguous note.23 The day after Valeria rejects Giulio because of her jealousy, she changes her mind and calls him back to her palace. When she sees him, she very boldly declares that he the man will from now on be her ‘mazor. Vu savé ben che pena m’avé dà, perché ho volesto esserve mazora; ma da qua avanti voio esserve menora in ogni canto’ (V. iii. 65).24 Power dynamics are, therefore, constantly oscillating. What is shown is not a consistent reversal, but rather a confusing chaos. If we prefer a more definitive reading, order is indeed re-established in the end: the man ultimately manages to recover his power over the woman, precisely because of Valeria’s last words in the final scene of the final act. It is true that Valeria fools her unaware husband, suspending patriarchy momentarily; at the same time, however, her final submission to another male lover signals a clear return to the conventional order. After all, the role reversal followed by the re- establishment of traditional order at the end of the play is a topos that seems very fitting to La Veniexiana’s Carnivalesque dimension.
Another argument in defence of the patriarchal reversal interpretation of the play is an alleged nocturnal homoerotic scene between women, at the end of the Primus Actus. Angela embraces and kisses Nena while she is dreaming about Giulio. Certainly, the maid ambiguously provokes the mistress by saying that she would kiss her better than he would and that, after all, no matter how gentle a man might appear, ‘tuti xè uomini’ (I. iii. 54).25 In this regard, Giannetti claims that the typical cross-dressing is not needed in this play, as women characters play sexually together in bed.26 Mary-Michelle DeCoste is persuaded that the queer simulation is propaedeutic to the 

intercourse between Giulio and Angela, where she displays a similar degree of authority.  Yet, the text does not seem to allow such a ground-breaking reading, at least in a definitive way. No homosexual tension is self-evident: Angela is replacing a male figure in her thoughts, by pretending that Nena is Giulio, and therefore staging a heterosexual relation. Burning with passion, she projects and actualises her sexual fantasies on Nena, stating that she would like to ‘butarghe cusì le braze al collo, zicar quelle lavrine, e tegnirlo streto streto’ (I. iii. 63).  Then, she starts giving directions to the maid, embracing her with vigour and guiding her arms around her body. She becomes so violent that Nena is almost suffocated. Indeed, Angela replicates a mistress-servant dynamic, exercising her power over someone judged as inferior. Patriarchy is therefore very much present at this point, only being introjected and re-staged. Angela continues to play the traditional ‘male role’ when she reveals her strategy to seduce Giulio: she will conquer him ‘cun danari e cun presenti’ (I. iii. 77). 
Then again, a new change: Angela, still embracing Nena and trying to visualise Giulio, suddenly asks Nena to ‘biastemar, azò che ti creda omo [. . .] Biastema el corpo de Cristo, menzona le parolle sporche: co’ fa i omeni’ (I. iii. 89; 91).  After having replicated the ‘male role’ (or what society traditionally considers as the dominant, aggressive, conquering role), she returns to her ‘female role’ (being submissive, docile, and conquered). Indeed, Angela directly urges Nena to act like a male bully and shout the kind of filthy words men typically utter in brothels.  The scene is a complex play-within-a-play, and the characters are impersonating different and shifting roles. First, Angela pretends that Nena is Giulio; then, she personifies a man who sexually assaults a woman; lastly, she becomes again a woman who wants to be a sexual slave. Of course, if the scene were performed by male actors – as was probably the case – the situation would be even more complex to decipher, as a male homoerotic sex scene would stand in for a female one, which in turn would stand in for a heterosexual one. In any case, even though I do not entirely dismiss an interpretation centred on the gender reversal, any absolutizing proto-feminist reading may end up flattening an otherwise deeply ambiguous text, and possibly risks anachronisms.  As I will show, more accurate keys to understanding this multifaceted comedy appear to be those of internalised patriarchy and, above all, mutable power struggle.
Speaking about the richness of interpretations, here I challenge another prevalent opinion about the play; namely, that this comedy exalts love and passion as a sensual experience for no particular purpose, as an end in itself. For instance, Zorzi recognises the realistic uniqueness of La Veniexiana by setting it in stark opposition to all Renaissance productions, such as Latin imitations, satires of corrupted societies, as well as pastoral plays. According to the critic, this comedy’s artistic principle is merely ‘un realismo obiettivo, documentario, un’assoluta assenza di intenti [. . .] per il semplice gusto delle cose in sé’.  Again, by contrasting it with La Mandragola, unanimously recognised as a bitter denunciation of society’s corruption, Bodo Richter considers La Veniexiana a play outside of morality, or ‘the spectacle of the passions that dominate the mind of man, passions which should not be repressed but satisfied’.34
However, I believe that such emphasis on the play’s originality, allegedly due to the display of passions for their own sake, risks overshadowing the context in which the comedy was composed. La Veniexiana may stand out as different, but to decontextualise a work from its background is a mistake. Theatre, as a live performance in a precise historical sociocultural context, with a particular audience, inescapably reflects deeper issues of that historical sociocultural context. This is true for any kind of play, even for the ones that might appear as playful, erotic, and disengaged farces. Sexual topics are frequently used to convey analyses of other societal/cultural aspects, such as in Pietro Aretino’s works.35 Antonio Vignali’s Cazzaria is an extreme example, but not uncharacteristic, of the Italian Renaissance’s frank theatrical discussions of sex and love. As several scholars have discussed, even in this desecrating dialogue sex is not investigated as an end in itself.36 Composed ‘in a world of shifting and unstable political allegiances, La Cazzaria is the prototype of the political pornography that appeared with increasing frequency in the mid-seventeenth and eighteenth centuries’, in Paula Findlen’s words.37 If we interpret La Veniexiana in light of Venice’s political chaos, then we might realise that this text is both a mirror of and a commentary on its socio-political reality.
La Veniexiana is a topical text that is closely tied to the time and place of its composition. Indeed, it could have only been made in early-sixteenth-century Venice, because of the Republic’s unstable geomorphology, social dynamics, and political situation. In my view, the intimate chaos displayed in the play is a direct reflection of a broader public socio-political chaos. The crisis of the Republic is fundamental to La Veniexiana’s exploration of the relations between sexual power and linguistic, political, and cultural power. The title of ‘Serenissima’, with which Venice self-crowned herself, turns out to be nothing more than self-deception to conceal deeper concerns upon which La Veniexiana thrives.38
A Socio-Politically Engaged Play
La Veniexiana is a ‘comedy about Venice’ par excellence. The representation of the Queen of the Adriatic as a city and a society is very realistic, to the point that the text has been considered a romanticised version of events that actually happened. Indeed, the manuscript states in the end that the play is ‘non fabula non comedia ma vera historia’.39 In this regard, Padoan goes so far as to 
 
identify the real protagonists in the local chronicle.  For sure, when reading La Veniexiana one feels the vivid presence of the city, with its calli and campi, narrow canals, elegant palaces, and bell towers.  Real places and districts appear in the play: the aforesaid Osteria al Pavon – even mentioned by Aretino;  Campo San Barnaba, where Valeria and Oria live; and the Galipoli’s warehouses, which Bernardo frequented. The shape of the city, with its winding streets and canals, can be puzzling, especially for a foreigner like Giulio, who is often lost.  Indoor spaces are analogous: the palaces’s mezzanines precisely parallel the city’s features. In addition, gondole and bridges facilitate swift clandestine movements. For all these reasons, Venice’s geomorphology assists its citizens’s promiscuous behaviour and the play’s intrigue.
Naturally, the greatest particularity of the city is represented by its periodic tides: the alternation of acqua alta and acqua bassa continuously changes the look of the cityscape. Water, in itself, is the perfect symbol for a fluid situation in an uninterrupted flow. But even more accurately for the Venetian case, water undulation is the objectified transposition of the spectacular chaos represented on stage. By quite literally muddying the waters, Venice matches the Venetians’s mixed feelings and unsettled power struggle.  Furthermore, as I will discuss later, even territorial borders are continuously shifting in these turbulent years, constantly putting to question the citizens’s self- perceptions and identity.
The Venetian geomorphology is similarly responsible for another distinctive aspect of the Serenissima. It is not by chance that the Veneto area developed so many plurilingual comedies: as Gianfranco Folena noticed, the double linguistic imperialism of Florentine and Venetian languages, together with the ‘duplice opposizione linguistica fra metropoli lagunare e Stato di terraferma, e fra città e campagna’, inevitably influenced the language of theatre in the Veneto.  The Renaissance city was a linguistic melting pot: a diverse tapestry of languages – from Italian dialects to Arabic, Turkish, Greek, and Yiddish – could be heard from diplomats, travellers, pilgrims, and merchants.  The plurilingualism in La Veniexiana undoubtedly reflects such a variegated situation. Indeed, the comedy is an example of what Benedetto Croce defined as ‘letteratura dialettale riflessa’, since the use of different dialects is purposeful and characterising.
