That is to say, the linguistic choices imply precise connotations. Even though we cannot expect a faithful representation of the exact dialects spoken in a certain area and time, as the author may have over-characterised for expressionistic purposes, at least four different languages can be recognised within the play.
Following the conventions of the genre, the lists of characters and acts are indicated in Latin, just like some liturgical formulae and the brief description appearing at the end.  This choice attests to the playwright’s ambition to include this comedy within literary conventions. Female characters speak Venetian, which is never used with parodic intent; Bernardo speaks Bergamask, the typical language of porters and manservants; and Giulio speaks pretentious literary Florentine. These choices are never neutral. The realisation in the first half of the Cinquecento that one valid literary language for Italy was being standardised and imposed gave an impetus to theatre – especially comedies – to deliberately include dialects in an attempt to remain faithful to particular languages, in contrast with what was generally accepted as the norm.  The Venetian idiom, spoken by the women, has a patina of realism that conveys spontaneity and immediacy. The male characters do not speak Venetian; they are both outsiders but belong to opposite classes. Bernardo’s dialect is rough and down-to-earth, matching his pragmatic personality. Since Quattrocento theatre, Bergamask had been the language of uncouth porters; the citizen (probably aristocrat) author’s biting caricature of the migrant peasant is clear. On the contrary, Giulio’s words are refined and artificial, paralleling his superficial, self-centred behaviours. The antagonism between folkloristic Bergamask and polished Florentine is a literary topos and may reveal a parodic implication for both languages. 
Florentine (although with some Venetian influences) is also used in the intermezzi and in the controversial Prologue, where the emphasis on pain and sorrow – and the overturning of female loved ones into lovers – is a sharp anti-Stilnovistic move. The prevalent use of Venetian in the play overtly shows a literary and linguistic criticism against the poetic idealisation of love, and the artificiality of the Tuscan language. Local language and culture vis-à-vis other languages and cultures was a major preoccupying issue of the whole Cinquecento, related to political sovereignty. Giulio is the only character who speaks Florentine, and a very formal and affected version of it, mediated from the literary tradition. His words are sweet, and his speech is always as gallant as his looks. Giulio is very aware of his own charm, so he knows that he can convince Valeria just through his ‘paroluzze’ that ‘produriano algun effecto’ (I. i. 1).  As Paolo Trovato scrupulously demonstrated, Giulio’s use of Florentine is not always accurate.  Perhaps the Venetian author’s intent was not to make him seem trustworthy but rather just to ridicule the character. Giulio is Lombard, but his language distinctively tends towards Latinising terms and pre-Bembian Tuscan; this in itself speaks about artificiality. All in all, his language seems to depict a courtly koine, in line with his playboy persona. Not only does Giulio use Florentine, the soon-to-be Italian lingua franca, but he also refers to the chivalrous courtship typical of the Florentine literary convention.
Therefore, the clear resistance to the Tuscan language parallels the resistance to Tuscan culture. As Ronnie Ferguson explains, ‘in a climate where Neoplatonic and Petrarchan treatments of love were the rule [. . .], passion is examined without a trace of idealism’.  The trickster Giulio is the only character who embraces idealistic speech and manners in his courting. Even his falling in love is very Petrarchan: Giulio recounts that he fell in love with Valeria when he first saw her in a church. This rejection of idealistic love, and promotion of cynic pragmatism, represents Venice’s deliberate cultural opposition to Tuscan hegemony. In this sense, Giulio’s name calls to mind Poliziano’s hero, Giuliano de’ Medici. The author of the Stanze is the emblem of the renewed Florentine poetic tradition, saturated with Petrarch, Stilnovismo, Neoplatonism, and the most etherealised Florentine idiom possible.
The choice to write the play in the Venetian dialect signals an affinity for the popular novellistica and the voice of the bourgeoisie, set against, in Antonio Gramsci’s words, the ‘aulico, cortigiano, anazionale’ Italian.  The conscious employment of the Venetian dialect – perceived as spontaneous – over Italian – considered insincere – is clearly an attack on the Venetian Pietro Bembo, who allowed himself to be seduced by the Tuscan dialect of the ‘three crowns’, from which the Italian language developed.  Venice, then, let herself be conquered by Tuscany's – and, by extension, mainland Italy's – soft power. A similar linguistic preoccupation emerges in Ruzzante’s theatre, for which Florentine is the fabricated, ridiculed moscheta language of hypocrisy spoken in the cities, in strong opposition to the genuine Paduan language of the peasants.  Cultural anxiety runs deep in the Veneto; the local culture must face that of the mainland. The powerful allure of Italian culture evokes a threat to Venetian autonomy and identity, which are to be swallowed up by that hegemonic culture.
Still, with regards to social dynamics, a brief analysis of the socio-economic scenario might be useful. La Veniexiana is very much about wealthy and otiose women, left alone by absent husbands who are abroad, involved in mercantile affairs. Women were the ones who managed the masserizia, dealing with money, goods, and servants. The dowry’s financial contribution to the solid Venetian élite gave more and more economic independence to women, and authority within the household.  It comes as no surprise, then, that this play talks about powerful women as the real agents of the love conquest, looking for foreign sexual prey. Clearly, adultery and fornication threatened the stability and order of Venetian families and communities. In this respect, it is interesting that the reigning doge of these years, Andrea Gritti (1523–38), promoted a programme of renovatio urbis that would first and foremost transform the institution of marriage from a private transaction into a matter of supreme governmental concern, in an attempt to encourage a rebirth after the prestige loss in the War of Cambrai a quarter century earlier.  As Zorzi notes, La Veniexiana puts the privileged élite in the spotlight, a hypocritical bourgeoisie that craves a break in the monotony, sure of its impunity.  Venetian society was, indeed, quite free by the standards of the time; especially before the Council of Trent, Venice was a hub of freedom of speech, press, and manners. However, as Doge Gritti’s policy revealed, chaotic domestic affairs went hand in hand with chaotic politics.
Indeed, one last frequently overlooked aspect is Venice’s political situation of that time. Even though the play does not engage with politics directly, the political situation does inform the comedy’s atmosphere. It is crucial, for example, that Giulio, the first character to appear on stage and the contended prey, is a ‘iuvenis foresterius’ (29). Certainly, his origin is functional to the love game – as Valeria admits, ‘el xè forestier, che se ne puol piàr piasèr, e po’ va fuora, che no ti sta sempre in gli ochii.’  (III. i. 7) – but this choice is not just a narrative one: sometimes the storyline follows the ‘history-line’. Venice had always turned its back on mainland Italy, in proud autonomy or isolation. This xenophobic predisposition is documented by Marino Sanudo the Younger, historian and diarist, who defined Venice as a ‘terra libera né mai da niuno subiugata come tutte le altre, edificata [. . .] non da pastori come Roma, ma da populi potenti, et ricchi’.62 The fact that Giulio was a foreigner, then, must have had strong political implications. If we then reflect on the fact that he is from Milan, there must be much more going on here.
At the beginning of the century, the rivalry between the Republic and the Duchy was particularly intense.  During the Quattrocento, Venice had to go to war against the expansionism of the Dukes of Milan. Giulio is disquietingly described as an alluring menace from the start, when we learn that he came to Venice with his military accessories just to enjoy the ‘vita dulcedo’ (II. i. 21).  Despite maintaining a suspicious attitude, he continuously praises the city as worthy and welcoming; after all, it lets him, or even encourages him, to take possession of two Venetian women. From the very beginning, the fear that a random foreigner could come and take advantage of the land freely is exposed. The sexual conquest resembles a territorial conquest, with the local women’s rape as the first result of the invasion. However, to be precise, no rape occurs here: women take the initiative, believing that they are in control. Such unstable power dynamics are also expressed linguistically: 
when Bernardo captures Giulio to bring him to Angela’s palace, he calls him a ‘preson’ (II. v. 136). 
These tensions reflect the unstable outcomes of the wars and territorial possessions of the time. Indeed, after the peace of Lodi (1454), Venice appeared to be the predominant power and a threat to the political balance of the Italian peninsula and other European forces.  Formally a Republic, Venice became a de facto empire when it conquered Cyprus and gained control over several other Mediterranean bases. This threat triggered the formation of the League of Cambrai (1508–11), an anti-Venetian alliance joined by the pope, Spain, the Holy Roman Empire, and others, such as the Duchy of Milan. The League’s goal was to curb Venice’s territorial expansion in northern Italy by militarily invading the Serenissima and splitting its lands. No real winner emerged in the end (1516). If it is true that Venice aborted any territorial ambitions in Italy, it managed to defend and retain control of its borders only by constantly overturning coalitions.
The results of the war manifested in various ways in those instable years.  Political damages corresponded to economic damages, as the loss of terraferma territories inevitably meant the end of tax revenues and lucrative commerce. As Stanley Chojnacki clarifies, it was right in the first decades of the Cinquecento that the ‘myth of Venice’ blossomed: the insistence on Venice’s exceptional political stability, constitutional perfection, and wise government – the so-called Serenissima Republic – ‘was a response to economic and political blows suffered in the decades around 1500’.68 La Veniexiana demonstrates that prosperity, balance, and stability were only the product of a distorted propaganda created to recover lost prestige. But, even more importantly for this reading of the play, the centuries- long belief in the Republic’s invincibility took a hit in the collective subconscious. Venice’s ‘myth’ was built upon the uniqueness of the city, its independence, and its inherent superiority. The city had always been seen by Venetians as impregnable, or ‘virginea’, never conquered by any ruler.69
In the following years, Venice started regaining territory, but only by making compromises; for sure, it had to switch from being an imperialist conqueror to a benevolent conquered, frequently forming new alliances and altering the power dynamics. In 1510, Julius II left the League of Cambrai to ally with Venice against France, further convincing all the others to join the anti-French Holy League. A foreigner, then, could quickly become an enemy.  This unstable geopolitical situation, with its related uncertainties and concerns, is directly transposed in the romantic instability shown in the play. With the Turkish threat from the Mediterranean, and wars in the mainland against all of Italy and Europe, it seems quite implausible that the Venetians’s ‘secretti et archani del pecto’  did not find a place in La Veniexiana. Venice wanted to believe that its citizens were in control, that they would never be defeated; indeed, in the play, Venetian women truly think so when conquering Giulio-the-foreigner. Yet, in the end, they understand that they are dominated by that foreigner, who tricks and conquers them all. This is only the first step of the territorial invasion, presented as having already happened: Venetians let the invader in. After all, toying with Giulio’s name, the anonymous playwright aimed perhaps even at evoking the prototype of an Italian foreign invader: historically and symbolically, the dictator Julius Caesar; more recently, the Warrior Pope Julius II.
Conclusions
As modern scholars, we need to rethink how we read and interpret representations of sex and erotica in early modern Italian literature. La Veniexiana’s richness and complexity, in particular, invites multi-layered and sometimes contradictory readings. Rather than mere delightful additions, the ambiguous amorous manoeuvres staged in the play are a powerful metaphor for a world in chaos and a Venetian social order at risk of subversion. Throughout the play, the sexual power dynamic continuously shifts. During Giulio and Angela’s encounter, she first actively attracts him to her bed, then Giulio reprimands her insolence, and ultimately, she regains sexual control over him. The same applies to Valeria: she first rebuffs Giulio with pride, only to declare complete submission in the end. Rather than a reversal of the traditional gendered hierarchy, the play evokes an introjected patriarchal order, where women are in competition for one male object of desire.  One can even read the play as an experiment in shifting the roles of oppressors and oppressed. As Giulio says trying to justify himself for being so inconsistent, ‘lo experimentar è cosa belissima, per aver avantaggio in cognoscer’ (IV. iii. 16).  The temporary experiment causes unremitting chaos that ends only when traditional order is re-established in the end: Valeria surrenders to her conventionally subjugated role, passively accepting Giulio’s previous (and possibly future) betrayals.
La Veniexiana is a comedy engaged with its external socio-political reality, and Valeria’s adultery and Angela’s sexual freedom are a metaphor for Venetian social disorder. The city is not merely an ideal setting for erotic adventures but is the image of a society that has lost all its certainties. With regards to its foreign policy, the Serenissima was dealing with an unstable position in Italy and Europe and with its reduced power in the whole Mediterranean. For the locals, Giulio is a dangerous threat from abroad; he could be an ally or easily turn into an enemy. As for domestic policy, the Republic was transforming from a mercantile economy into a territorial one. Furthermore, it was becoming a confusing Babel, with Florentine (Giulio’s unnatural language) imposing itself as the linguistic model. Finally, with regards to culture, many Venetian humanists were debating about whether to embrace the Tuscan hegemony or desperately try to resist its literary and artistic traditions – especially with respect to its idealistic conceptions of love.
Interpreted through a socio-political lens and a contextualising gaze, La Veniexiana fully reveals its relevance as it ultimately exposes the inherent lie behind the Venetian self-proclamation of ‘La Serenissima’. At the beginning of the sixteenth century, the Republic was not at all serene, but rather tormented and in chaos. What was to be the role of Venice in this territorial and cultural penetration? Could the anonymous author’s fellow citizens resist this invasion, protecting the sovereignty and autonomy of their beloved Republic and language? If read attentively, La Veniexiana prompts audiences and readers to wonder about greater issues at stake concerning the Venetian state. Giulio could have simply come to Venice to have sex with a sex worker; instead, he chooses forbidden erotic encounters with two rich women. When the boy is torn about whether to choose Angela or Valeria, he begins his reasoning by what looks like praise of the city: ‘O Venezia, benigna a’ forrestieri, cortese a gioveni!’ (IV. i. 2).  Instead of a tribute, the anonymous playwright might have inserted here a hidden critique of the Serenissima. If so, the scenario of this supposed romantic comedy is definitely darker: the sexual and political invasion has already happened, and the complaisant Venetians have welcomed the foreign invader with open arms.

***

Leopardi’s Disaster

Introduction
This article concentrates on the early poems which Leopardi called Canzoni, a group of works written between 1818 and 1822 that harness his early poetic aspirations to themes of civic virtue and military heroism. The writing is under intense moral and rhetorical pressure as Leopardi responds in a defiant and often polemical way to what he sees as the decadence of Italian modernity. The tone of these poems is quite different from that of the so-called Idilli, which, as we shall see, focus more on the movements of personal memory than on larger cycles of historical change. For most readers, this second group of poems constitutes Leopardi’s major achievement, leaving behind the ostentatious erudition of the early Canzoni and preferring seemingly natural contours of feeling to the overreaching rhetoric of the previous work. My article suggests, however, that the ambition of the early Canzoni sets the parameters for a distinctly modern poetics that seeks to exceed the limits of the romantic lyric voice.
Leopardi is a poet of extremes whose work constantly exceeds the register of melancholy self-pity to which the Victorians consigned him (even T. S. Eliot would later acquiesce in that kind of judgement, dismissing Leopardi as just ‘a gloomy cuss’ ). My article proposes that larger issues are at stake in the poet’s early work and that, though differently staged, his reckoning with modernity is arguably as penetrating and as corrosive as that of his near-contemporary Baudelaire. What we do not find in Leopardi, though, is that responsiveness to innovation which galvanises Walter Benjamin’s landmark writings on the French poet. It is not, say, the first appearance of gas lighting, the first use of iron as a building material, and so on that fires Leopardi’s imagination; rather, it is his chilling sense of modernity as something already ruined by the failure of Enlightenment values and the French Revolution.  Like Baudelaire, Leopardi pours scorn on the new religion of ‘progress’, 
 
though unlike Baudelaire he finds no promise of intoxication in modernity. We live, he says simply but absolutely in his Canzone ‘Ad Angelo Mai’, in a ‘secol morto’, a century whose true lineaments can only be grasped in the light of disaster. 
Signs of Trouble
One notable development in the last decade of Leopardi studies has been a renewed interest in the poet’s vocabulary. In issues of the Lessico Leopardiano since 2011, scholars have scrutinised items in his lexicon that, like the word ‘assuefazione’, have acquired special, complex meanings both in the poetry and prose. These pivotal words can seem to have no adequate synonyms in standard Italian and, as one critic puts it, they constitute ‘un’idiolessi fortemente personalizzata, al servizio del proprio sistema di pensiero’.  Repetition in different contexts allows these ‘parole-chiave’ ‘di scorrere da un piano all’altro dell’esperienza (dal personale all’universale) senza perdere la sua peculiarità semantica’.  One example of this semantic mobility that I shall consider is ‘sciagura’: ‘disaster’, ‘calamity’, ‘catastrophe’. It is loosely associated by Leopardi with a series of words which express pain, grief, damage, and dark catastrophe: ‘danno’, ‘dolore’, ‘errore’, ‘ruina’, ‘atra’, ‘cura’, ‘pianti’. ‘Sciagura’ appears six times in the Canti as a singular noun, twice in the plural, ‘sciagure’, and twice in its older, contracted form, ‘sciaura’. It mainly figures in the early poems which Leopardi called Canzoni, the one exception being the ‘idyll’ ‘La vita solitaria’ where we find both ‘sciagure’ and ‘sciaura’. It is not used at all in the poems Leopardi would write after the break in his poetic career (1823 to 1828), though it does appear occasionally in the Operette morali and the Zibaldone.
The word has, for the most part, drawn little attention from commentators, though it operates across a range of collective and personal meanings that are central to Leopardi’s early thinking. So, for example, in ‘Sopra il monumento di Dante che si preparava in Firenze’, the poet warns his readers of the misery to come if they forget the work of his great precursor:
. . . e dalle nostre menti
Se mai cadesti ancor, s’unqua cadrai,
Cresca, se crescer può, nostra sciaura,
E in sempiterna guai
Pianga tua stirpe a tutto il mondo oscura. (ll. 81–85) 
‘[M]ay our unhappiness,/if possible, increase’, translates Jonathan Galassi, while Geoffrey Bickersteth renders ‘sciaura’ as ‘woes’ and J. G. Nichols as ‘ills’.  The problem for the translator is clear, for the words that most readily suggest themselves for ‘sciagura’ – ‘unhappiness’, ‘woe’, and so forth – derive from a conventional idiom of lyric complaint that emphasises personal suffering rather than a general tragedy or disaster. Later in Leopardi’s poem, though, the word reappears to describe the terrible end of the Italian soldiers on the Russian steppe:
Anime care, Bench’infinita sia vostra sciagura,
Datevi pace; e questo vi conforti
Che conforto nessuno
Avrete in questa o nell’età futura. (ll. 162–66)
Galassi translates ‘sciagura’ here as ‘agony’, while Bickersteth offers ‘calamity’, and Nichols ‘trouble’. Bickersteth’s ‘calamity’ seems closest to the sense of the original, since etymologically it suggests the damage caused by a blow from fate or fortune. The full implications of this become clearer in the third canzone, ‘Ad Angelo Mai’, when the poet addresses his predecessor, Torquato Tasso:
Torna torna fra noi, sorgi dal muto
E sconsolato avello,
Se d’angoscia sei vago, o miserando
Esemplo di sciagura. Assai da quello Che ti parve sì mesto e sì nefando,
È peggiorato il viver nostro. (ll. 136–41) 
Tasso is remembered as the victim of disaster: the Latinism ‘esemplo’ (from ‘exemplum’) honours his tragic life, but he figures also as the first poet of modernity since, like Leopardi after him, ‘Ombra reale e salda/Ti parve il nulla, e il mondo/Inabitata piaggia’ (ll. 130–32). Leopardi recalls his own ‘passaggio dallo stato antico al moderno’ in 1819, the year of his physical and mental breakdown, when, deprived of his sight, ‘e della continua distrazione della lettura, cominciai a sentire la mia infelicità in un modo assai più tenebroso’.  Crucially, this set of personal disasters is taken by Leopardi to recapitulate the universal history of humanity: ‘Nella carriera poetica il mio spirito ha percorso lo stesso stadio che lo spirito umano in generale’ (Z143). The poet had begun with a world of ‘fantasia’, his creations ‘pien[e] d’immagini’, but he was then increasingly disabled by ‘l’infelicità certa del mondo’ and finally reduced to ‘uno stato di languore corporale, che tanto più mi allontanava dagli antichi e mi avvicinava ai moderni’ (Z143-44). Disaster, then, ‘sciagura’, especially in the singular, transcends personalised lyric melancholy to define a crisis at once historical and metaphysical. As a philologist, Leopardi might well have seen the formation of this word as a graphic enactment of that sudden reversal of fortune Aristotle had called ‘peripeteia’, with the privative particle sc- (Latin ex-) transforming ‘augurium’ (in Italian, ‘augurio’) into a sign of tragic misfortune. ‘Sciagura’, with its modern hard ‘g’ and its emphatic vowels is, appropriately perhaps, a rather graceless word that seems to violate the Italian preference for harmony and elision.
The translation of ‘sciagura’ as ‘disaster’ retains its dominant sense of the unfavourable aspect of a star or planet, and while Leopardi does sometimes use it to refer to personal misfortune,  for the most part the word, for him, is synonymous with ‘calamità’ and indicates a general or national disaster (as, for example, Darius’s sacking of the Greek city Miletus which was famously regarded as a catastrophe too moving to be represented on the stage).  In his 1816 translation of the second book of the Aeneid, Leopardi had used ‘sciaura’ to translate Virgil’s ‘supremum laborem’, ‘the final agony’ of Troy’s destruction, and in the Canti the word generally denotes exactly this idea of some universal and immemorial disaster which shakes the very foundations of the social order.  Even the plural form ‘sciagure’ can, in some contexts, express this sense of catastrophe as Leopardi would have recalled from the last lines of Ugo Foscolo’s Dei sepolcri (1807), where the need for mourning promises to last ‘finché il sole/risplenderà su le sciagure umane’.
Leopardi’s trusty Latin Lexicon by Egidio Forcellini (1771; second edition 1805–12) confirmed the universality of the word’s implications, showing its root in the Latin verb exaugurare, ‘to desecrate, to profane’, as did Tommaseo and Bellini’s later Dizionario della Lingua Italiana (1861) which gave the contemporary meaning as ‘Malavventura, Disavventura, Disgrazia’.  Leopardi would generally use the word ‘sciagura’ in this expanded sense, partly in defiance of ‘la nuova scuola’ (Romanticism) and its attachment to ‘quella che chiamano psicologia, della quale reputa e dice a tutte l’ore se stessa maestra e regina’.  With this new tendency came, as historians have shown, ‘an increasing interiorization of the concept of disaster’ which Marie-Hélène Huet, for example, discerns in Chateaubriand’s Mémoires de l’outretombe (1849–50).  Modern dictionaries nonetheless continue to define the word as collective disaster, the Vocabolario Treccani, for example, offering ‘Grave disgrazia, calamità, di solito con perdita di vite umane’. 
It is no surprise to find that this motif of ‘disaster’ barely figures in the group of poems Leopardi called ‘idylls’, poems that, he said, concern ‘situazioni, affezioni, avventure storiche del mio animo’ and that recall mainly events of childhood.  For all their obvious differences, though, the poems named as, respectively, Canzoni and Idilli do share a concern with the theme of past happiness. As Luigi Blasucci summarises, ‘l’uno storico, proprio degli antichi o dei primitivi, vissuti in età ancora immuni dai guasti della filosofia; l’altro biologico-esistenziale, proprio dei fanciulli, non ancora pervenuti alla cognizione dell’ ‘arido vero’, triste appannaggio dell’età adulta’.  The division between Idilli and Canzoni is not, however, quite as clear-cut as this suggests, and not surprisingly given that Leopardi composed both sets of poems within a period of just four years.  Indeed, the idea of the ‘idyllic’ can be misleading since the poems thus described are not altogether free of the dark tones that pervade the Canzoni. Noting this, Franco D’Intino has quoted Georg Lukács’s description of idylls as ‘set against a background of danger threatening them from the outside’, and we might add that even in cases like Leopardi’s ‘L’infinito’, where the poetic imaginary seems hermetically self-enclosed, it is at the same time obscurely troubled by something external to it. This ‘outside’ is nothing other than poetic language itself which as it attempts to evoke the original ‘illusions’ of childhood and antiquity is haunted by an after-knowledge of loss and unrepeatability. 
Smiling eyes might also shed tears (Silvia’s are ‘ridenti e fuggitivi’), and the pastoral vision, present now only as memory, is always (to use Leopardi’s description of Moschus’s ‘Lament for Bion’) ‘lugubre pastorale’21 – ‘lugubre’, from ‘lutto’, expressing tears of mourning, specifically here the grief occasioned by the passing of a great poet, but more generally the sadness that must attend any modern attempt to reanimate a pastoral convention, now disastrously lost to us. This, too, encodes an intensely personal tragedy, for to Leopardi it seemed that his own ‘età verde’ had somehow been denied him: ‘La fortuna ha condannato la mia vita a mancare di gioventù: perchè dalla fanciullezza io sono passato alla vecchiezza di salto, anzi alla decrepitezza sì del corpo come dell’animo’.  That involuntary ‘leap’ leaves it to poetry to recover a consolatory synthesis of childhood experiences and classical myth,  even though that consolation is burdened with the knowledge that the days of childhood are also ones in which ‘le lagrime erano giornaliere’. 
The idylls strive nonetheless to remember, from the damaged vantage-point of modernity, the time of ‘infancy’ when, says Leopardi, ‘tutto ci era nuovo o disusato’. This was a world where the things of nature seemed instinct with life to such a degree that children were left feeling that they were ‘in nessun luogo soli’.  It is the time of mysterious presences and unearthly sounds, of a music that cannot be physically heard and that the young Leopardi associated with the pastoral images that decorated the ceiling of his bedroom, images of a paradise ‘non d’uomini ma d’immortali’.  These experiences are especially striking in the brief prose piece of 1819 titled ‘Vita abbozzata di Silvio Sarno’.  The sparsely punctuated draft weaves together a series of recollections of Leopardi’s early years around two main organising motifs: first, the child’s positioning at a window that gives on to what will later be a keenly remembered scene (‘Scena dopo il pranzo affacciandomi alla finestra . . . effetti della musica in me sentita nel giardino, aria cantata da qualche opera’ [pp. 54–55], ‘aprì la finestra ec. era l’alba ec. ec’. [p. 81], ‘si ricordi quella fenestrella sopra la scaletta ec. onde io dal giardino mirava la luna o il sereno ec’ [p. 93], ‘mi posi a una finestra che metteva sulla piazzetta ec’ [p. 108]). The literal ‘framing’ of a scene by the window is what makes it ‘uno spazio immaginario’, for if the eye is permitted to roam freely it will see only what is simply there, and ‘il reale escluderebbe l’immaginario’ (Z171). In this passage from the Zibaldone, which offers a tempting gloss on ‘L’infinito’ (‘L’anima s’immagina quello che non vede, che quell’albero, quella siepe, quella torre gli nasconde’ [Z171]), Leopardi explains the fascination of bounded spaces in which ‘il fantastico sottentra al reale’: ‘Quindi il piacere ch’io provava sempre da fanciullo, e anche ora nel vedere il cielo ec. attraverso una finestra, una porta, una casa passatoia, come chiamano’.  This ‘seeing’, then, is not simply a matter of visual perception, for the object ‘seen’ is purely imaginary.
Such looking remains unconditioned by the objects it seems to confront, and in that respect it coincides with the other main motif of the poet’s recollected childhood, the idea of experiences permeated by a ‘musica senza parole’.  In each case, we are dealing with a ‘pre-linguistic moment’, as Claudio Colaiacomo has called it, ‘quel periodo, verso la fine dell’infanzia, quando il linguaggio e la memoria non sono compiutamente formati’.  In a passage of the Zibaldone, Leopardi ponders ‘la mancanza di linguaggio ne’ bambini’ (Z1103) and concludes that this existence before language is one that is by definition free from both memory and desire. This may seem paradoxical since, as he notes:
le più antiche reminiscenze sono in noi le più vive e durevoli. Ma elle cominciano giusto da quel punto dove il fanciullo ha già acquistato un linguaggio sufficiente, ovvero da quelle prime idee, che noi concepimmo unitamente ai loro segni, e che noi potemmo fissare colle parole. Come la prima mia ricordanza è di alcune pere moscadelle che io vedeva, e sentiva nominare al tempo stesso. (Z1103)
Once we have entered that system of naming, however, we are caught up irrevocably in its play of presence and absence, of singularity and universality. Where once there was no memory, now there is only memory, and while we might pleasurably recall a particular event from childhood, we are always aware, says Leopardi, that ‘la sensazione presente non deriva immediatamente dalle cose, non è un immagine degli oggetti, ma della immagine fanciullesca; una ricordanza, una ripetizione, una ripercussione o riflesso della immagine antica’ (Z515). The image is, we might say, doubly displaced in time (much later he will write that ‘il mondo e gli oggetti sono in certo modo doppi’ [Z4418]), conjuring again with the ‘reechoing’ of the real in the imaginary). This doubleness is also a feature of poetry itself which, in so far as it approximates to song and music, provides some measure of compensation for the pre-linguistic world we have lost, but in so doing it also registers the enormity of that loss. Leopardi would soon abandon the ideal of a ‘musica senza parole’, returning to it only intermittently, as in the later poem ‘A Silvia’ (‘Lingua mortal non dice/Quel ch’io sentiva in seno’), where his memories are intimately bound up with the rich sound of the lost girl’s name, in anagram (‘salivi/Silvia’), and in the intricate patterning of /v/ sounds (‘le vie, avevi, tua voce, soavi, vedevi’, etc.).  More generally, though, the effect of Leopardi’s necessary ‘acceptance’ of linguistic limitation was to compromise the ideal of a pure lyricism, presenting it as something damaged by an earlier disaster or containing the threat of an impending one.
This would be a major theme of some of the Canzoni, and one broached also in ‘L’infinito’. This short poem ends with a shipwreck, though the ‘sweet’ cadencing of the closing line – ‘E il naufragar m’è dolce in questo mare’ – suavely manipulates disaster into metaphor. As with Silvia’s tearful and smiling eyes, the emotional tonality at the end of the poem is subtly paradoxical, as the poet’s thought drowns in ‘this sea’ (‘s’annega il pensier mio’). As Colaiacomo observes, however, while thinking and imagining are processes which are intricately intertwined in the poem – ‘Io nel pensier mi fingo’ – the two are not dialectically resolved: ‘Alla fine fra la coscienza e l’estasi, il prima e il dopo, si stabilisce una compresenza contraddittoria’.  This is, then, a poem about thinking and its costs, with the passage before the emphatic caesura of line 8 showing the poet ‘sedendo e mirando’, as if scrutinising the process by which illusions are formed, while the poem’s second half shows these figures of the imagination being interrupted by rational thought – ‘vo comparando’, he says, almost surprised by the form his own thoughts are taking. Gavazzeni and Lombardi aptly gloss the reference to ‘comparison’ with a passage from Condillac’s Traité des sensations (1754): ‘comparer n’est autre chose que donner en même temps son attention à deux idées’ [to compare is nothing but giving one’s attention to two ideas at the same time].  We may recall Leopardi’s comments in the Zibaldone on ‘L’eccitamento d’idee simultanee’:
La rapidità e la concisione dello stile, piace perchè presenta all’anima una folla d’idee simultanee, [. . .] e fanno ondeggiar l’anima in una tale abbondanza di pensieri, o d’immagini e sensazioni spirituali, ch’ella o non è capace di abbracciarle tutte, e pienamente ciascuna, o non ha tempo di restare in ozio, e priva di sensazioni. (Z2041)
Simultaneity is, in Leopardi’s view, the most desirable of poetic effects, and his use of the word ‘ondeggiar’ here, ‘to sway’ or ‘set the mind adrift’, resonates with the ecstatic ‘drowning’ at the end of ‘L’infinito’. Yet ‘comparison’, as it becomes a primary tool of the modern analytic mind, also acquires the power to destroy such ‘drifting’ illusions:
[. . .] è la sola società, e la conversazione scambievole, che civilizzando e istruendo l’uomo, e assuefacendolo a riflettere sopra se stesso, a comparare, a ragionare, disperde immancabilmente queste illusioni [. . .]. (Z2684)
The progressive construction ‘vo comparando’ recalls similar uses of the gerund in Dante (e.g., ‘vo significando’, Purg. XXIV, 54) and Petrarch (e.g., ‘I’vo pensando’, Rime, CCLXIV, ‘I’vo piangendo’, Rime, CCCLXV), but Leopardi may also be remembering here a line from his own translation of the lament for Bion, ‘e or vo cantando/Un mesto Ausonio carme’, an ironic allusion to a pastoral song whose delicacy and simplicity are unlikely to be valued in the rational modern world of ‘comparison’. The ‘lugubre pastorale’, as Leopardi encountered it in the elegy for Bion, combined mourning with a fluent gracefulness, the jubilant vowels of ‘vo cantando’ unexpectedly producing a sad song (‘mesto carme’) that other translators would simply call a ‘dirge’.  In contrast to the ‘airy beauty’ of antiquity (‘il bello aereo’, Z170), however, the world of the Canzoni is a darker, more earthbound one that consolidates itself around a network of portentous words that threaten upheaval and announce themselves, as will be seen, in a designedly ‘lugubrious’ syntax.
Language and Scepticism
This second register of language, palpably marked by ‘disaster’, gradually overtakes the discourse of civic values that is proclaimed in the first two poems of the sequence, ‘All’Italia’ and ‘Sopra il monumento di Dante’. ‘Bruto minore’ is decisive in this respect, for it is here, in the words of one critic, that ‘the idea of the poet-prophet of Foscolo and Alfieri is being finally expunged from Leopardi’s mind and style of writing’.  And it is not merely a pose or rhetorical posture that is abandoned, but a ‘heroic’ confidence in the effectivity of poetic language. ‘Bruto minore’, in short, will find in its protagonist’s suicide the exemplary expression of a scepticism that will colour all of Leopardi’s subsequent work. Indeed, the poem originated in his discovery through a reading of Theophrastus that a tragic sense of the ‘vanity of illusions’ (Z325) had also existed in the golden age of ancient Greece.  With the death of Brutus Marcus Junius and the dawning of the Christian era, that tradition is extinguished for good. In his prose gloss to the poem, ‘Comparazione delle sentenze di Bruto Minore e di Teofrasto vicini a morte’, published alongside it in the 1824 Canzoni, Leopardi sees that period of Brutus’s life as ‘l’ultima età dell’immaginazione, prevalendo finalmente la scienza e l’esperienza del vero e propagandosi anche nel popolo quanto bastava a produr la vecchiezza del mondo’. 
Brutus’s last ‘blasphemous’ utterance is reported by Cassius Dio as ‘O virtù miserabile, eri una parola nuda, e io ti seguiva come tu fossi una cosa: ma tu sottostavi alla fortuna’, and Leopardi also quotes a pithier version given by another ancient historian, Florus, ‘che la virtù non fosse cosa ma parole’.  This declaration at the threshold of death – that virtue is not a real ‘thing’ but exists in name only (it is a ‘parola nuda’) – announces the ‘ruin’ of ancient Rome and with it the collapse of an entire world of compensatory illusions. In the ‘Comparazione’, Leopardi proposes that ‘il concetto di Bruto fu come un’ispirazione della calamità, la quale alcune volte ha forza di rivelare all’animo nostro quasi un’altra terra’, ‘another world’ that is strangely familiar to us moderns who, like Brutus, have seen many once substantial ‘things’ revealed as mere words. This sceptical vision is heralded in the early Canzoni with the ‘calamitous’ imagery of darkness and tempest that had given Leopardi ‘assidui terrori’ in his own sleepless nights as a child.  In ‘Bruto minore’, these infantile fears prefigure the loss of a primal freedom:
Forse i travagli nostri, e forse il cielo
I casi acerbi e gl’infelici affetti
Giocondo agli ozi suoi spettacol pose?
Non fra sciagure e colpe,
Ma libera ne’ boschi e pura etade
Natura a noi prescrisse,
Reina un tempo e Diva. (ll. 49–55)
The plural nouns ‘sciagure’ and ‘colpe’ are accurately rendered by Galassi’s ‘suffering and guilt’, though the return of the word in the singular later in the poem more clearly projects this suffering as a universal condition:
Oh casi! oh gener vano! abbietta parte
Siam delle cose; e non le tinte glebe,
Non gli ululati spechi
Turbò nostra sciagura,
Nè scolorò le stelle umana cura. (ll. 101–05)
This time ‘sciagura’ is variously translated as ‘distress’ (Bickersteth), ‘torment’ (Galassi), and ‘woes’ (Nichols), though the singular form seems again to imply some founding disaster that the half- rhyme connects with the latinate ‘cura’, thus providing an ominous echo of Horace’s phrase ‘atra Cura’ (Odes III. i. 40). In a context in which the stars are patently unaffected by human suffering, ‘care’ becomes the ‘black Anxiety’ that, says Horace, ‘sits behind the horseman’ (‘post equitem sedet atra Cura’).
With each of the Canzoni, hints of some ‘damage’ (‘danno’), at once historical and metaphysical, produce an increasingly ‘lugubrious’ vision.  As Andrea Campana observes, the suicide of Brutus marks ‘la fine della Repubblica e l’instaurazione dell’Impero. Il gesto di Bruto non è però “politico”, ma “storico”’.  The disaster is singular but re-enacted time and again as the series of catastrophes that defines historical process (it is the Fall of the Roman Republic, the rise of barbarism, the conquest of the New World, the French Revolution and in its aftermath the progressive ‘geometricization’ of ‘tutta la vita’ [Z160]).  As Leopardi puts it emphatically in ‘Sopra il monumento di Dante’, ‘infinita sia vostra sciagura’. It is something to which fate condemns us, an idea reinforced by the etymology of the repeated word ‘danno’ (as in ‘Beato te che il fato/A viver non dannò fra tanto orrore’, ‘Sopra il monumento’, ll.103–4). Like Brutus, Leopardi recalls that ‘Era un tempo ch’io fidava della virtù, e dispregiava la fortuna’;  that has long gone, however, and in the two ‘civic’ canzoni, the damage has already been done to Italy’s sense of national pride (‘All’Italia’, l. 23), its soldiers dying wretchedly in forced service to a foreign power (‘supremo danno’, Leopardi calls it, in ‘Sopra il monumento’, l. 169). In ‘Alla Primavera, o delle favole antiche’, written four years later, this historical perspective is put in tension with the mythic tales of antiquity:
Perchè i celesti danni
Ristori il sole, e perchè l’aure inferme
Zefiro avvivi, onde fugata e sparta
Delle nubi la grave ombra s’avvalla; (ll. 1–4)
The ‘damage’ (‘danni’) done to the sky by winter is being repaired by the Springtime sun, while the rising breeze dispels the ‘sickly air’ of Winter (‘l’aure inferme’) and chases away the lingering shadows. In the margin of his manuscript, Leopardi glosses the second line ‘Ripari il sole. Damna tamen celeres reparant celestia lune. Hor’. [Yet the quickly changing moons recoup their losses in the sky], thus signalling an allusion to Horace’s ‘Diffugere nives’ (Odes IV. vii. 13).  The ‘celestial damage’ done to the sky is initially obscure (and compounded by the poet’s characteristic oxymoron), but it seems to refer to the seasonal disappearance of the constellations. This is more than a bad portent (as in the phrase ‘ill-starred’, for example), and hints at some kind of immemorial loss that seasonal recurrence cannot actually ‘repair’ or make good. In fact, Leopardi’s emphasis here is significantly different from that of Horace’s quoted line for which one free translation is ‘But the months quickly bring back the stars that the sky loses’. 
In Leopardi’s opening lines, the implication seems rather to be that it is the ‘damage’ that will recur regardless of the constant movements of seasonal change, and he thus gives an added edge to Horace’s advice in the Ode to abandon thoughts of immortality (‘Immortalia ne speris’ [You should not hope for immortality]).  Indeed, the emphatic Latinate inversions at the beginning of Leopardi’s poem work to keep winter and its ‘damage’ syntactically before us even as we are teased by hopeful signs of change. A pastoral vision unfolds, but it, too, is firmly placed in the past (‘Già di candide ninfe’, ‘Vissero i fiori e l’erbe,/Vissero i boschi un dì’) and it quickly becomes clear that there is no hope for the return of that ‘bella età, cui la sciagura e l’atra/Face del ver consunse/Innanzi tempo’ (ll. 12–13). Galassi renders ‘sciagura’ here as ‘calamity’, and that seems equal to the enormity of the rejection of illusion for ‘truth’ that marks the advent of modernity for Leopardi. The Latin root of ‘sciagura’ in ‘exaugurare’ proposes this will to truth as a kind of desecration that leaves humanity without consoling ‘auguries’ but only with, again, Horace’s gnawing ‘black Anxiety’, here transposed into the ‘black torch’ (‘l’atra/Face’) of false enlightenment.
The ‘Arcane danze/D’immortal piede’ (recalling the brief dances of the nymphs in Horace’s Ode [ll. 5–6]) now yield to Echo’s doleful complaints and the sounds of persistent human suffering. The sky at the poem’s opening was full of dramatic dark clouds but as we approach the close it is re-evoked in more abstract, ostentatiously ‘poetic’ terms, the ‘curvo/Etra’.  The nightingale begins to ‘sing of the reviving year’ (‘il rinascente anno cantando’), but its song quickly becomes a lament as the air again turns silent and dark, preparing for the thunder and black clouds of the final stanza. This ominous sky speaks of ‘Antichi danni e scellerato scorno,/E d’ira e di pietà pallido il giorno’. The ‘ancient wrongs’ and the ‘atrocious shame’ that attends them allude in part to the terrible tale of Philomela told by Ovid,  but of course they also echo ‘i celesti danni’ of the poem’s first line. The ‘damage’ cannot be undone and while the poem seems to promise some pastoral bliss (a ‘bella età’ and the ‘Novo d’amor desio’) it emphasises instead the tantalising remoteness of these from our own time.
We may hear in the poet’s lines the sound of dancing feet, but we must nevertheless accept that the ‘halls of Olympus’ are now empty.  It is that sense of resounding vacancy – a sound of human suffering painfully present in the repetitive lovelorn voice of ‘lonely Echo’ – that helps us to understand the ‘disaster’ of which Leopardi speaks here. For it alludes not to the ‘antico error’ of Genesis but to ‘la vendetta del cielo, le ingiustizie degli uomini, i danni, le calamità, le malattie, le ingiurie della fortuna’ (Z77), multiple afflictions to which the ‘musical bird’ now seems quite indifferent (‘Ma non cognato al nostro/Il gener tuo’). The nightingale’s song is untouched by our disaster – in one draft, Leopardi had written that ‘non . . . quelle tue varie note/Sciagura esprime’  – and this confirms the tragic separation of humanity from nature that the canzone mourns.  Now cast adrift, humanity’s voice will instead be that of Echo lamenting her lost Narcissus and the ‘error’ so deeply regretted will be at once disembodied and perpetually repeated:
Ella per grotte, Per nudi scogli e desolati alberghi,
Le non ignote ambasce e l’alte e rotte
Nostre querele al curvo
Etra insegnava. (ll. 65–69)
The poem’s play with double negatives such as ‘Le non ignote’ emphasises a kind of periphrastic repetition that sees the generations of history making humanity’s lot ever worse. We suffer not on account of an originary deed but because of the increasing corruption that seems to define our history. As Leopardi puts it in ‘Bruto minore’, ‘In peggio/Precipitano i tempi; e mal s’affida/A putridi nepoti/L’onor d’egregie menti e la suprema/De’ miseri vendetta’ (ll. 112–16). No Biblical or Platonic ‘Fall’ of man, then, because (in Damiani’s words) ‘Per quanto colpevoli possano essere gli uomini, l’errore originario non è delle creature, ma di Dio stesso’. 
‘Alla Primavera, o delle favole antiche’ is usually read as part of a diptych with the poem that immediately follows it, ‘Inno ai Patriarchi, o de’ principii del genere umano’. There the mood is, if anything, even darker, and while ‘Alla Primavera’ ends with a plea to Nature, that ‘la favilla antica/ Rendi allo spirito mio’, the new excursion into the ‘primitive’ world of the Biblical patriarchs is slow to generate that ‘spark’ of light that would signal the return of primaeval youthfulness. The ‘fathers of the race’ had been born into the ‘alma/Luce’ (the ‘alma lux’ of Virgil’s Aeneid ), but the failings of later generations have left humanity subject to the ‘tiranna/Possa de’ morbi e di sciagura’ (ll. 12– 13), a general ‘disaster’ that yokes together ancient and biblical worlds (in an unexpectedly syncretistic elision, the guilt of Adam and Eve is said to have offended Olympus and led to the appearance of Erebus on earth [l. 21]). Leopardi’s use of ‘sciagura’/‘sciagure’ in both singular and plural forms is carefully judged, then: illnesses and afflictions are multiple (‘sciagure’), but there is just one disaster (‘sciagura’), though, paradoxically, as we have already noted, it is ‘infinite’ in its effects.  The point is made again later in Leopardi’s poem:
Agl’inaccessi
Regni del mar vendicatore illude
Profana destra, e la sciagura e il pianto
A novi liti e nove stelle insegna. (ll. 67–70)
Jonathan Galassi translates ‘la sciagura e il pianto’ as ‘crimes and tears’, though the use of the singular seems again to have apocalyptic implications, setting it off from cases where the plural ‘sciagure’ is chosen.
The Syntax of Disaster
Leopardi’s concept of ‘disaster’ emerges, then, from an overdetermined lexical field where words such as ‘sciagura’, ‘calamità’, ‘danno’, ‘ruina’, ‘atra’, and ‘cura’ lead a sort of half-life between the singular and universal (for translators, however, the conventional lyric ‘I’ and its entailments are, as we have seen, temptations often difficult to resist). At the thematic level, the disaster remains equally ambiguous. Is there one or many? Has the disaster happened or is it to come? Is it finally irreducible to an actual historical event, having instead to be imagined not as the content of writing but as some outer limit of non-meaning? Does disaster, then, signify the end of poetry or might it actually be the pre-condition of poetry’s continued existence? Curiously, these are the very questions we might also find ourselves asking of another, much more recent text preoccupied with disaster, Maurice Blanchot’s L’Écriture du désastre, first published in 1980. The two works are widely separated in time, to be sure, but both share an extreme scepticism that finds human attempts at meaning constantly frustrated by the unmoveable externality of what lies at the outer edge of language.
For each, in different ways, to enter language is a kind of death, and a death endlessly repeated and dramatised in the act of expression itself. Or should we say in literature itself, because for Leopardi and Blanchot it is only there, beyond the false consolations of philosophy or religion, that we might finally reckon with the frightening exteriority of those infinite spaces Pascal had so powerfully evoked. It is perhaps not surprising, then, that to read Blanchot’s book in dialogue with Leopardi’s work, is to experience some striking echoes and resonances. I shall focus here on a passage in L’Écriture that has been much commented upon. Blanchot calls it ‘(Une scène primitive?) [(A primal scene?)]’, and his hesitant parentheses and question mark might signal that this ‘primal scene’ is not to be confused with the witnessing of parental coitus that forms the centrepiece of Freud’s case history of the Wolf-Man.  Here is Blanchot’s ‘scene’:
(Une scène primitive?) Vous qui vivez plus tard, proches d’un cœur qui ne bat plus, supposez, supposez-le: l’enfant – a-t-il sept ans, huit ans peut-être? – debout, écartant le rideau et, à travers la vitre, regardant. Ce qu’il voit, le jardin, les arbres d’hiver, le mur d’une maison: tandis qu’il voit, sans doute à la manière d’un enfant, son espace de jeu, il se lasse et lentement regarde en haut vers le ciel ordinaire, avec les nuages, la lumière grise, le jour terne et sans lointain. 
Ce qui se passe ensuite: le ciel, le même ciel, soudain ouvert, noir absolument et vide absolument, révélant (come par la vitre brisée) une telle absence que tout s’y est depuis toujours et à jamais perdu, au point que s’y affirme et s’y dissipe le savoir vertigineux que rien est ce qu’il y a, et d’abord rien au-delà. L’inattendu de cette scène (son trait interminable), c’est le sentiment de bonheur qui aussitôt submerge l’enfant, la joie ravageante dont il ne pourra témoigner que par les larmes, un ruissellement sans fin de larmes. On croit à un chagrin d’enfant, on cherche à le consoler. Il ne dit rien. Il vivra désormais dans le secret. Il ne pleurera plus.  
[(A primal scene?) You who live later, close to a heart that beats no more, suppose, suppose this: the child – is he seven years old, or eight perhaps? – standing by the window, drawing the curtain and, through the pane, looking. What he sees: the garden, the wintry trees, the wall of a house. Though he sees, no doubt in a child’s way, his play space, he grows weary and slowly looks up toward the ordinary sky, with clouds, grey light – pallid daylight without depth. 
What happens then: the sky, the same sky, suddenly open, absolutely black and absolutely empty, revealing (as though the pane had broken) such an absence that all has since always and forevermore been lost therein – so lost that therein is affirmed and dissolved the vertiginous knowledge that nothing is what there is, and first of all nothing beyond. The unexpected aspect of this scene (its interminable future) is the feeling of happiness that straightaway submerges the child, the ravaging joy to which he can bear witness only by tears. He is thought to suffer a childish sorrow; attempts are made to console him. He says nothing. He will live henceforth in the secret. He will weep no more.] 
This remarkable passage may remind us of some of the motifs we have already examined in Leopardi’s work: most notably, there is the ‘scene’ observed by the child from the window, with its Pascalian sky, ‘soudain ouvert, noir absolument et vide absolument’ [‘suddenly open, absolutely black and absolutely empty’], revealing in its absolute indifference ‘que rien est ce qu’il y a’ [‘that nothing is what there is’]. It is perhaps accurate to call Blanchot’s ‘scène primitive’ [‘primal scene’] a ‘cosmological fable’, since the ‘disaster’ which it seems to announce is ‘le désastre comme retrait hors de l’abri sidéral et refus d’une nature sacrée’ [‘the disaster as withdrawal outside the sidereal abode, and as refusal of nature’s sacredness’].  Yet this ‘disaster’ signals more than a secular disenchantment of the world, for at the very opening of the ‘scene’ a death seems to have taken place (we hear of ‘un coeur qui ne bat plus’ [‘a heart that beats no more’]) and, inscrutably, while ‘we’, as readers, are said to ‘live later’, it is also clear that this death is in some puzzling, special sense our own – or, at least, our death as an infant, a word whose Latin origin, ‘infans’, refers to the child’s initial inability to speak (from Latin ‘affari’, to speak to). Leopardi also pondered this etymology: ‘fante [adult man] non è che il partic. fans di for faris [to speak] . . . Oltre ch’egli è l’opposto d’infans cioè non parlante’ (Z4049; emphases in original). He had already encountered the Latin word infandum, ‘unspeakable’, when he translated the second book of the Aeneid; in rendering it with an ostentatious Latinism, Infando, he emphasised that for Aeneas to tell Troy’s tragic story, as he was enjoined to do by Queen Dido in the book’s opening lines, was effectively for him to renounce the silence which had been the privilege of infancy.  Blanchot, for his part, concludes that ‘on ne vit et on ne parle qu’en tuant l’infans en soi . . . cela qui n’a pas encore commencé à parler et jamais ne parlera’ [‘one lives and speaks only by killing the infans in oneself . . . that which has not yet begun to speak and never will speak’].  This ‘killing’, then, is the condition of our access to language, and with it comes the knowledge that death is a part of oneself.  The child, says Blanchot, has died of ‘ce “pouvoir-mourir” qui lui donne joie et ravage’ [‘this “ability to die” which gives him joy and devastation’].  Leopardi’s fantasies of youthful innocence and his conviction that he was unjustly dispossessed of his own express a similar sense of a death continuing to haunt life: ‘Io sono, si perdoni la metafora, un sepolcro ambulante, che porto dentro di me un uomo morto, un cuore già sensibiliss. che più non sente ec’. (Z4149).
Leopardi’s ironic ‘si perdoni la metafora’ strongly suggests a connection between mortality and poetic figuration. Perhaps this is less a death than a dying; a dying, we might say, into language; and with that dying necessarily comes a birth, that is, says Leclaire, ‘the most imperative summons of our bondage – to be born again and again to language and desire, all the while never ceasing to mourn the loss of the fascinating infans’.  The great cycles of birth and death are nothing more than a form of ‘bondage’, then, and remain impervious to the meanings we try to project upon them. Nor is the time of the disaster truly time at all since it must be considered ‘non pas comme un événement du passé, mais comme le passé immémorial [. . .] qui revient en dispersant par le retour le temps présent où il serait vécu comme revenant’ [‘not an event of the past, but as the immemorial past [. . .] which returns, dispersing by its return the present, where, ghostly, it would be experienced as a return’].  What is so terrifying for the child looking through the window at the ‘ordinary’ sky is its lack of ‘depth’ and the ‘absolutely black’ and ‘absolutely empty’ image it presents to him. It is as if the glass through which he looks is suddenly broken open to reveal the full enormity of nothingness. This is a moment in which, as Kevin Hart puts it, ‘absence impinges on consciousness as though it were a mode of presence’.65
Leopardi expresses something similar when he talks of ‘il solido nulla’: ‘Io era spaventato nel trovarmi in mezzo al nulla, un nulla io medesimo. Io mi sentiva come soffocare considerando e sentendo che tutto è nulla, solido nulla’ (Z85). Yet, as Blanchot’s text subtly reminds us, this devastating perception of emptiness, of the brute force of existence that undoes all attempts to assign it meaning, is greeted by a ‘flood of tears’ that also expresses a ‘ravaging joy’.  The child’s parents misunderstand, of course, and he will not speak to them of what is now his ‘secret’, that ‘rien est ce qu’il y a’ [‘nothing is what there is’]. This is indeed a ‘revelation without revelation’,67 for the empty sky, like Leopardi’s ‘solido nulla’ and Silvia’s tearful smiling eyes, announces a ‘contraddizione spaventevole’ in the order of things that thought cannot resolve or overcome (Z4129).68
Such baffling contradiction may certainly inspire ‘terror’, but it is also, unexpectedly, the imaginative site of a lyric poetry that identifies itself with what Leopardi calls in the ‘Comparazione’ Brutus’s ‘ispirazione della calamità’: ‘E in questa parte l’effetto della calamità si rassomiglia al furore de’ poeti lirici, che d’un’occhiata (perocchè si vengono a trovare quasi in grandissima altezza) scuoprono tanto paese quanto non ne sanno scoprire i filosofi nel tratto di molti secoli’.  Recalling the motif of comparison and simultaneity in ‘L’infinito’, this passage suggests that the poetic ‘frenzy’ [‘furore’] may reveal in one glance of the eye a wholly unknown region of thought, ‘another world’ seen as if from a great height and in its externality resistant to figurative appropriation by the poet.70 What is outside remains outside, and it is just this sense of a pure exteriority (palpable in nature’s indifference, not to say malignity) that Leopardi’s concept of disaster shares with Blanchot’s.
No simple event lies behind this evacuation of meaning; the disaster is repeatedly ‘framed’ to suggest that it is at once located in time immemorial and yet endlessly recurs.71 For both Blanchot and Leopardi, Ovid’s tale of Echo and Narcissus is powerfully suggestive of this ambiguous temporality. We have already heard the nymph’s doleful song in ‘Alla Primavera’, and Blanchot will find in its empty repetition the form of a ‘disastrous’ writing that is only ‘l’allitération mimétique, rimante, d’un semblant de parole’ [‘the mimetic, rhyming alliteration of a semblance of language’].  This ‘semblance’ offers no place for self-expression; it is a language that is purely external, whose empty words (Leopardi’s ‘parole nude’) leave the subject exposed and ‘naked’ in the face of overwhelming cosmic disaster. For Blanchot, in this moment language too is suddenly exposed, revealed in all its perplexing ‘neutrality’ as the product of a ‘radical subtraction’ of anything relating to presence. 
In contrast, Leopardi develops a poetics of amplification in his Canzoni, deploying the sublime or elevated style to evoke disastrous events (storms, thunder, raging rivers, collapsing ruins, cosmic catastrophe) and to transform them into constitutive figures of poetic form itself (hence the conjoining of ‘calamity’ and the ‘frenzy’ of poetic creation).  Here, we may appreciate Mengaldo’s insight that Leopardi is primarily a poet not of metaphor but of syntax, for while the Canzoni are acutely attuned to semantic nuance, as in the lexical field that develops around the word ‘sciagura’, they are also increasingly audacious in their manipulation of word-order.  Through syntactical complexity, in fact, Leopardi’s poetics of disaster secures its place in the tradition of the sublime. Pseudo-Longinus, in his immensely influential treatise on the topic, had given the example of Homer’s description of a shipwreck: ‘by forcing into an abnormal union propositions not usually compounded he has tortured his language into conformity with the impending disaster, magnificently figured the disaster by the compression of his language, and almost stamped on the diction the precise form of the danger’.  The idea of language being ‘tortured’ into an ‘abnormal’ syntax gives it a certain exteriority, and Pseudo-Longinus accordingly commends Homer’s ability ‘not to persuade the audience but rather to transport them out of themselves’ [163]). Again, then, we might have reason to be dissatisfied with translations of Leopardi’s ‘sciagura’ as ‘unhappiness’, ‘woe’, and so on because in cleaving to the idiom of a melancholy lyricism they fail to acknowledge that the elevated style seeks the amplification of personal emotion into something loftier and more designedly impersonal.
Disaster and Sublimity
This idea of elevated style is especially clear in Leopardi’s various comments on the poems of Horace who inherits the mantle of Pindar as a major poet of ‘sublimità di concetti e d’invenzioni’ (Z23). In Ode IV. II. 5–8, Horace had famously celebrated his precursor: ‘Like a river rushing down a mountainside, swollen by rains above its normal banks, Pindar boils and surges on with his deep booming voice’. It is just this force and energy, with its ‘daring dithyrambs’ and ‘free unregulated rhythms’ (IV. II. 10–11), that Leopardi praises in Horace’s poems and seeks to emulate in his own Canzoni. Indeed, the stylistic ‘elegance’ of both Horace and Virgil consists especially, says Leopardi, ‘nel pellegrino dei modi e delle voci, o delle loro applicazioni a quel tal uso, luogo, significazione, nel pellegrino delle metafore ec’. (Z1323). Horace’s genius is marked by his capacity for ‘bold phrases’ (‘ardiri’) that defy convention and expectation.  Readers find themselves disoriented – ‘vi trasporta e vi sbalza più volte di salto da una ad altra idea lontanissima e diversissima’ (Z2051) – and these ‘leaps’ give an effect of simultaneity that complicates conventional linear movement (Nietzsche, for example, praised Horace’s way of creating a ‘mosaic of words in which every word, as sound, as locus, as concept, pours forth its power to left and right and over the whole’ ).
Much of Horace’s verse deploys the device of hyperbaton, an inversion or distortion of word order that can, for example, postpone the connection of an adjective to the word it describes or of an agent to the action it performs. The device was popular in Augustan writing but Horace uses it more extensively than most (some forty percent of his adjectives are separated from their nouns) and one commentator surmises that ‘the word order of the Odes must have seemed strange to the uninitiated’.  Generally, hyperbaton allows a particular emphasis or provides a way to meet metrical demands, but the Greek word originally means ‘to overstep’, and its connection with excess and the transgression of ‘natural sequence’ makes it, in Longinus’s view, the ‘truest mark of vehement emotion’.80 The ‘recklessness and audacity of the transpositions’, he observes, produce such ‘strange and unlikely order’ that it can leave the audience ‘terrified of a total collapse of the sentence’.  This is the other aspect of the energy and speed Leopardi associates with the Horatian style for, when allied with the sublime imagery of storms and threatening skies, it, too, may become a destructive force, making the sense of impending disaster the animating form of poetic expression itself.  Now language becomes something truly external, a foreign place in which the natural order of the sentence does indeed seem to ‘collapse’ or implode.
In the Canzoni, syntactical inversions and transpositions are ubiquitous. Take a relatively straightforward example from ‘Ad Angelo Mai’:
E che valor t’infonde,
Italo egregio, il fato? O con l’umano
Valor forse contrasta il fato invano? (ll. 13–15)
In each sentence the verb appears before its subject (‘il fato’), this last word acquiring particular emphasis through its deferral. Almost inevitably, the English translation is obliged to restore conventional word order and in doing so risks flattening Leopardi’s tone and losing the semantic charge so often carried by his rhymes (‘l’umano’/ ‘invano’). Galassi, for example, translates as follows:
Great Italian, is it destiny that has inspired you? Or does fate contend to no avail with human courage?
The gain in lucidity comes at a cost: Angelo Mai is a cultural hero, no doubt, but it is hard to think that Leopardi is really suggesting that ‘fate’ is always defeated in the face of ‘human courage’. And while Leopardi is never afraid to use repetition for emphasis, Galassi has a more conventional preference for variation that can produce empty distinctions, such as that here between ‘destiny’ and ‘fate’. In the original, however, inversion and repetition work to complicate the poem’s thinking and to dramatise the contrast between ancient and modern life that is their constant theme. In ‘Bruto minore’, for example:
Non fra sciagure e colpe,
Ma libera ne’ boschi e pura etade
Natura a noi prescrisse,
Reina un tempo e Diva. (ll. 52–55)
The lines express nostalgia for an earlier age of ‘natural’ freedoms, but syntactical inversion emphasises first our present state of ‘sciagure e colpe’ and then recalls nature’s original status as ‘Reina’ and ‘Diva’ at the end of the sentence, the two words separated by ‘un tempo’ as if to stress how remote such a condition now is. Compare Galassi’s version which, again, reverses the word order to achieve greater lucidity:
Nature, Queen and Goddess once, ordained a life for us that wasn’t suffering and guilt, but free and pure in the forests.
The bitter negativity of the original has drained away, with the new syntactical clarity producing a wistfulness of tone that is remote indeed from the sublimity to which Leopardi’s poem aspires.
The opening stanza of ‘Alla Primavera’ presents an even greater challenge, with the first sentence of fourteen lines piling up descriptive items within an overarching syntactical structure that seems almost to undermine its own logic (classicist D. S. Carne-Ross aptly observes that these lines are ‘almost as hard to construe as one of the knottier odes of Horace’ ):
Perchè i celesti danni
Ristori il sole, e perchè l’aure inferme
Zefiro avvivi, onde fugata e sparta
Delle nubi la grave ombra s’avvalla; Credano il petto inerme
Gli augelli al vento, e la diurna luce Novo d’amor desio, nova speranza Ne’ penetrati boschi e fra le sciolte
Pruine induca alle commosse belve;
Forse alle stanche e nel dolor sepolte
Umane menti riede
La bella età, cui la sciagura e l’atra
Face del ver consunse
Inanzi tempo? (ll. 1–14)
‘Perchè i celesti danni/Ristori il sole’ – most commentators read the conjunction as equivalent to ‘per il fatto che’, while Rigoni also suggests ‘per quanto, benché’ and notes that it may be construed as at once ‘causale e concessivo’.  Galassi translates ‘perchè’ as ‘although’, but even the numerous intervening clauses cannot quite make us forget that the conjunction would normally prompt a countervailing main verb (although Spring returns, the golden age of antiquity and childhood will not) rather than a rhetorical question (‘Forse . . . riede/La bella età . . . ?’). Leopardi’s syntax keeps us constantly on edge, making us wait for that first long sentence to complete itself and teasing us in the meantime with semicolons. ‘Credano il petto inerme/Gli augelli al vento’: again, the idea is simple enough in itself, but it is complicated by the late disclosure of the grammatical subject and the archaic aspect it deliberately assumes – ‘augelli’ rather than ‘uccelli’. ‘Forse alle stanche e nel dolor sepolte/Umane menti riede/La bella età’ – what will turn out to be a question begins obscurely, the reader not initially grasping the referent of ‘stanche’ and ‘sepolte’ and then finding these adjectives separated from each other by ‘nel dolor’.
Leopardi’s syntax, we might conclude, constantly registers our distance from a natural order we apparently once inhabited. That order, it seems, has been destroyed or damaged and its pieces reassembled to form something external to us, something painfully unnatural. That is not to say that Leopardi’s Canzoni lack grandeur, but it is a grandeur generated from a view of the ancient myths not as lived realities but as textual ruins, partially legible now in archaisms (‘Etro’, ‘augelli’) and periphrases (‘Di febo i raggi’) that, in contrast to nature’s ‘rinascente anno’, speak only of ageing (‘vecchiezza’). This is indeed the time of ‘la vecchiezza del mondo’, as Leopardi calls it in the ‘Comparazione’,  and while the arrival of the ‘Primavera odorata’ might arouse even a ‘frozen heart’, the ‘tortured’ syntax of these lines puts any sentimental fantasies to flight:
Ottenebrati e spenti
Di febo i raggi al misero non sono
In sempiterno? ed anco,
Primavera odorata, inspiri e tenti
Questo gelido cor, questo ch’amara
Nel fior degli anni suoi vecchiezza impara? (ll. 14–19)
Youthfulness (‘Nel fior degli anni’) is syntactically framed by ‘amara’ and ‘vecchiezza’, suggesting that it is quickly extinguished by the knowledge of a ‘bitter old age’ to come. The postponement of the verb ‘impara’ until the end of the sentence signals, too, that to learn this lesson takes all the time we have. While Spring still works its magic of natural renewal, humanity can only grow older in a world in which, as for Brutus, things have become mere words. As Leopardi reminds us with his dramatic equation of ‘calamity’ and visionary inspiration, this is the necessary condition of a properly modern poetry, a poetry that, as Blanchot puts it, must ultimately acknowledge that it is itself ‘the realm of disaster’. 
Conclusion
Is that equation of poetry and disaster too easily made? Blanchot’s art, as we have already said, is an art of ‘subtraction’, and the child who looks through the window sees a sky that is ‘vide absolument’ – ‘l’affirmation intense, silencieuse et désastreuse du dehors’ [‘absolutely empty’ – ‘the intense, silent and disastrous affirmation of the outside’].  We exist, as Jacques Derrida might say, in a world of radical expropriation, a world in which nothing is ‘proper’ to us, and in which we stand nakedly alone.  The godless world of ‘Alla Primavera’ is like that, with its ‘nudi scogli e desolati alberghi’ shrouded by ‘l’aer muto e fosco’. But while human presence is banished from this landscape, it survives in the philological detail of the writing. Leopardi’s poetics is not, like Blanchot’s, one of subtraction but of amplification, and the ‘favole antiche’, although now relegated to the past, seem to echo still, transformed perhaps, in ‘la favilla antica’, the ancient ‘spark’ that conjures with a youthfulness and inspiration still to come. Differences aside, though, what above all defines the experience of disaster for both writers is precisely this waiting which is perhaps a waiting for nothing other than waiting itself. A brief note in the Zibaldone perfectly catches the lexical moment in which disaster extinguishes hope: ‘Il primitivo e proprio significato di spes [hope] non fu già lo sperare ma l’aspettare indeterminatamente al bene or al male’ (Z3571). Leopardi wrote this in 1823, the year he temporarily abandoned poetry for prose. With his return to poetry in 1828, the idyllic mode would eclipse the rhetorical world of the Canzoni. The word ‘sciagura’ would henceforth have no place in Leopardi’s poetic lexicon, though the idea of disaster it had named would remain an indelible shaping presence of his work to come.

***

‘Il sospetto di un altro mondo’: appunti per una storia originaria (1936–1945)

Introduzione
Questo saggio è frutto di una prima ricognizione intorno al concetto di origine nel campo della letteratura italiana contemporanea, in un arco cronologico molto ristretto, compreso tra la fine degli anni Trenta e i primi anni Quaranta del secolo scorso (1936–1945 circa).  È superfluo ribadire quanto allora fosse divenuto pressante il bisogno di ridiscutere i pilastri ideologici e politici sui quali poggiava la società contemporanea, all’acme della sua crisi sociale e culturale, in cui, per riprendere una celebre riflessione del Gramsci dei Quaderni del carcere, ‘il vecchio muore e il nuovo non può nascere: in questo interregno si verificano i fenomeni morbosi più svariati’. 
Era allora essenziale riflettere su come si sarebbe potuto fare opposizione, evadendo, con difficoltà, le maglie sempre più strette della censura fascista. Gli autori di questo corpus, ancorché provvisorio e in fase di sviluppo, sono innanzitutto accomunati da una sostanziale avversione nei confronti del regime, magari sopraggiunta tardivamente e dissimulata in modo onesto, ma non meno convinta, la quale prendendo atto dell’efferatezza del presente, spingeva a cercare altrove,
spesso nel passato, custode di una forza oramai perduta, i germi capaci di mettere in discussione il male presente e rigenerare dialetticamente il tessuto frastagliato del mondo.  Questo sguardo retrospettivo appartiene a una tradizione tutta italiana, che connette, come ricorda il filosofo Roberto Esposito, il Rinascimento alla filosofia del Novecento, passando per i nomi centrali di Giambattista Vico e Giacomo Leopardi, entrambi pensatori che declinano il tema dell’origine in combinato disposto con quello dell’infanzia dell’uomo e del mondo. 
Il secondo punto in comune è sempre legato a questo tema: il discorso sull’origine non è, se non da alcuni, esplicitamente evocato, ma da tutti è mascherato sotto le forme di un’infanzia tanto perduta quanto oramai da analizzare, sviscerare, ritrovare. Parlare dell’infanzia, come momento di soglia o paradiso perduto che ci si lascia alle spalle, e nel quale invece si suppone esistesse una pienezza o una forza sorgiva – la poesia le illusioni l’immaginazione – che il tempo ha spazzato via, significa inventare un mito e ideare un modo per parlare dell’inizio, identificare un punto nello spazio e nel tempo da cui ripensare la propria storia individuale e collettiva, la nostra esperienza nel mondo.
Gli autori qui in esame ne sono consapevoli, e sono spronati a tal fine da nuovi saperi, quali l’antropologia e la psicoanalisi, che il filosofo Michel Foucault considerava ‘dispositivi’ del pensiero e delle scienze moderni, il cui intento ultimo consisteva nel ritrovare l’identità propria dell’uomo, ‘nella pienezza o nel nulla che egli è’.5 A questi due saperi si intreccia quanto di più avanzato fosse stato allora elaborato, in questa direzione, in ambito internazionale e che era, seppur in ordine sparso, penetrato in Italia sia dall’area mitteleuropea (da Goethe in avanti) sia da quella francese, in particolare dalle opere di Henri Bergson e Marcel Proust.6
Carlo Emilio Gadda, Cesare Pavese ed Elio Vittorini osservano, in modi diversi, il presente con uno sguardo strabico, proiettando desideri, volontà, propositi, paure su ciò che è assente, il passato, nella fattispecie un passato più o meno indeterminato, identificato con l’infanzia e raffigurato come un’età perduta, di cui pure è possibile attingere qualche sparuto scintillio.  Per essere più chiari, si potrebbe sfruttare una metafora che costituisce ‘l’intuizione primaria della topologia’, secondo la quale, scrive il filosofo Peter Sloterdijk, ‘si abita proiettando un altrove in un qui’; si vive, cioè, il presente con la convinzione che il passato possieda uno statuto particolare che si è perduto, e che nondimeno si ambisce di recuperare. 
È forse Walter Benjamin, il filosofo che, in quegli stessi anni, più si è speso per la riscoperta dell’autentico e dell’originario nel tempo presente.  Sin dalla ‘Premessa gnoseologica’ al Dramma barocco tedesco (1925), Benjamin considerava l’origine (Ur-sprung) non una categoria logica, ma storica, che poteva mostrare nel presente la sua struttura originaria, la sua attualità.  Lo studioso Ralf Konersmann, a commento del pensiero benjaminiano, scriveva:
L’origine [. . .] è la meta.  L’inizio non è dunque passato, come noi esseri che stanno nella storia siamo inclini a credere, non è in nessun modo non più. È piuttosto non ancora. Partenza e ritorno sono così movimenti equivalenti.12
Nelle prossime pagine e in studi futuri cercherò di indagare il tema dell’origine quale categoria storica entro il contesto letterario di primo Novecento; qui lo farò da una prospettiva specifica, quella del ‘fascismo rifiutato o in via di redenzione’ che, attraverso l’infanzia, suggerisce la possibilità di un presente alternativo al regime. Gli autori di questa storia avvertivano l’origine come sfuggente, impalpabile, ineffabile – e proprio per questo sempre più attuale, sempre più vicina, portatrice della promessa di illuminare il presente. In definitiva, essi spendono se stessi e le loro idee con la preoccupazione di un ritorno. Si tratta, ai nostri occhi, di una discorsività ideologica che ha avuto però il pregio di ricercare l’originaria identità dell’uomo nel momento del maggiore disprezzo per la sua libertà. Tale originaria identità è un mito: un mito letterario, sociale e antropologico che cionondimeno svolge il compito di voler ambire all’integrità, di restituire l’uomo all’uomo.
Partenze e ritorni
L’incipit di Conversazione in Sicilia è il punto di avvio di questa storia. Sono anni travagliati per Elio Vittorini (1908–1966). Dopo aver abbracciato il fascismo con la speranza di una palingenesi della decadenza sociale, egli ha ora, dinnanzi ai propri occhi, il dramma della guerra civile spagnola.
